conclusion: The anger many liberal Americans feel towards republicans is justified given their party's actions
premises: as a non american but one interested in politics, i've seen many discussions about american politics that have talked about the level of anger between the two different parties and they typically blame the two equally. a typical complaint from republicans is that they're treated like they're racist, misogynistic, bigoted, ignorant, selfish and or foolish. from their lies over actual policy issues like health their embrace of white identity politics republicans seem far more interested in cultural issues like nfl protests and sexual assault allegations than issues like the economy and america's standing in the world. their support of trump, roy moore and brett kavanaugh suggests they view improved treatment respect for women as something to be actively fought and a danger to men's justified dominance. their concerns over the deficit rapidly vanished once trump was elected suggesting the tea party movement was as much about race as anything. their support of tax cuts suggests they're mostly interested in short term economic and political benefits for the wealthy over any actual improvement to the country as a whole. their support of trump, a man who fits virtually every negative stereotype people have of republicans voters, makes them seem bigoted and ignorant, as well as suggesting they favour the interests of their party over their country.

gt: the ultimate thing i can tell you is to always approach a subject with the conceptualization of perspective. you start off by assuming that the person you're talking to thinks your wrong, and unless your goal is to prove yourself right, the assumption that the person your talking to is either objectively wrong or unwilling to analyze demonstrable reality should be the option of last resort, and that is the point the conversation ends. imo, a conversation should aim to reach an elevated understanding of the truth for both parties even if one or both participants shift slightly then the conversation could be seen as at least productive. first and foremost, what is your criteria for changing your mind?

conclusion: High schools should not have credit requirements
premises: according to the national research council and institute of medicine, 1 'a national survey of more than 2,000 youth in grades 7 through 12 worked a median of 3 hours on an average school day, and spent 2 hours 'hanging out with friends. ' . . . the average adolescent watches nearly 3 hours of television a day. ' page 13 in other words, students are dedicating as much time to mindless tv watching as they are to actual school work. the situation worsens when students start applying to college. according to jeff shiffman, the director of admissions at tulane university 2 , most colleges don't look for 'well rounded' students. they look for students who are passionate about one subject, and are motivated to pursue that passion. it took me 4 years of high school to find my own passions in music, math, sports, and computer programming. now that i'm applying to universities for engineering majors, i feel regretful that i didn't dedicate more time to advance my skills in these specific areas. i'd be much more developed in my own passions had i not been forced to take classes such as chemistry, biology, and history. this change would motivate students to do well in school, increase their likelihood of being accepted into college, and allow them to grow exceedingly well in their own passions. national research council and institute of medicine. 2004. engaging schools: fostering high school students' motivation to learn. washington, dc: the national academies press. doi: 10. 17226 10421. accessed 6 nov. 2018 2 'jeff schiffman undergraduate admission new orleans. '  accessed 6 nov. 2018.

' page 13 in other words, students are dedicating as much time to mindless tv watching as they are to actual school work. the situation worsens when students start applying to college. according to jeff shiffman, the director of admissions at tulane university 2 , most colleges don't look for 'well rounded' students. they look for students who are passionate about one subject, and are motivated to pursue that passion. it took me 4 years of high school to find my own passions in music, math, sports, and computer programming. now that i'm applying to universities for engineering majors, i feel regretful that i didn't dedicate more time to advance my skills in these specific areas. i'd be much more developed in my own passions had i not been forced to take classes such as chemistry, biology, and history. this change would motivate students to do well in school, increase their likelihood of being accepted into college, and allow them to grow exceedingly well in their own passions. national research council and institute of medicine. 2004. engaging schools: fostering high school students' motivation to learn. washington, dc: the national academies press. doi: 10. 17226 10421. accessed 6 nov. 2018 2 'jeff schiffman undergraduate admission new orleans. auto_conc: Students should be required to take more classes than they currently are.
gt: let's use my own undergraduate school, the university of massachusetts lowell, as an example. here are the admissions standards. to gain undergraduate admission to umass lowell, one must graduate high school having taken four english courses, four mathematics courses, three science courses with laboratory work, two social science courses, two courses in the same foreign language and two other electives. that's not harvard. that's just a second tier state school. i can only imagine that more competitive schools have more stringent requirements for high school coursework. if high schools stop requiring their students to take these classes, then those students will have been set up to fail when they start applying to undergraduate schools. you might have been slightly better at engineering if you had spent less time on chemistry, biology, and history, but you wouldn't even be admitted to uml.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're misunderstanding the purpose of the college admissions process. it's not to teach students how to work, it's to teach them how to be successful. a lot of people don't know how to do that, but they do learn how to make money, and how to use the money to make a living. if you're going to get a degree in a field where you don't have to spend a ton of time studying, you need to be able to do a lot more than just study, and you have to be willing to work a lot to get that degree.

auto_conc: I believe that god exists and that he is responsible for all the suffering in the world.
gt: i am in a bit of an interesting position to answer this question, as i am a passionate student of evolutionary biology which includes studies of abiogenesis or 'life from nothing' but also raised religious and still holding some aspects of faith. in science, there is a heavy emphasis on the burden of proof. for a hypothesis to be viable read: testable it must be falsifiable. if something cannot be proven as false on the physical level as in something supernatural it cannot be proven true either. so what does this mean? it means you can believe there is a god but there is no current way to prove it. your view is that it simply makes sense. in essence, you invoke occam's razor: the most likely explanation the correct. the problem with this, is that while a divine ruler is possible or at least not impossible it certainly is not the most likely, in comparison to other ideas. so what do we know? we know the organic components necessary to for life to form namely amino acids were present on archean earth some 3. 5 bya and that these components are themselves formed through inorganic processes. we know certain organisms can self organize and all organisms can replicate sexually or asexually, and that large structures such as galaxies form by rules set forth by the principles of physics to form and unravel. we know evolution can explain forms and behaviors and mechanisms of life of all kinds: from flight in birds and chemical communication in arthropods to immune systems and four chambered hearts. there are explanations for the vast majority of systems both biotic and abiotic on our earth. but then, you also mention intelligence and morality. you also mention the christian god as the god likely orchestrating our reality. let's examine these two. intelligence and morality are both very relative. we consider ourselves the most intelligent animals on earth, but we cannot organize as precisely as an ant colony. we can't echolocate our prey and we can't hunt by smell or hearing. these activities take intelligence, albeit a different kind. but let's isolate to human intelligence. chimpanzees and bonobos are in their stone age. they use the same tools our ancestors homo habilis did: rocks, sticks, grasses. given time, would they reach our 'level'? current studies suggest they could, just as we did. morality is a human construct to be sure, in that we give it a name. but all social animals have rules. wolf packs, lion prides, baboon troops and even flocks of geese follow social constraints to keep the peace in their ideal forms. isn't that what morality is? rules to keep the peace? additionally, if the christian god is the head honcho, why do all human civilizations have a set of moral and ethical rules, even if they were unexposed to the christian god in his entirety? the secular answer is that it makes evolutionary sense to preserve the species. i offer not proof that god is not real, but simply some evidence that it doesn't necessarily 'make the most sense'. that said, it leaves us to wonder who sparked the original organism? or spurred the big bang? i suppose short of god descending to our plane, it remains but an issue of faith. forgot a thing

conclusion: A pill to stop gender dysphoria would be objectively a better choice
premises: this seemed to offend people and i don't get why. and the current treatment is to make them appear to be the opposite gender, through changes in clothing, voice therapy, hormonal treatments that last a lifetime, and or a series of plastic surgeries. and all this comes with a lot of social stigma, and many people write them off as sexual romantic partners. it's very costly, invasive, and to become passing takes years if ever. we have developed psychiatric drugs for all kinds of mental health issues, including depression and anxiety. we tell depressed people to seek treatment, even if at the moment they just want to kill themselves. because they might not want to take such a drastic action if they were getting treated. pretty much a sick brain doesn't always know best. there's no drug to effectively treat gender dysphoria, and i don't even think it's feasible to try to develop such a thing. and i think it would be fair to mandate people to try this drug before giving them a green light to transition.

conclusion: Anti-depressants don't cause people to commit suicide or other violent acts.

conclusion: Tobacco should be banned, and no one really 'enjoys' smoking.

conclusion: The American Civil War wasn't about slavery in the way you think it was.
premises: i'm not a huge history buff, but i've been trying to learn about this war and i'm having a hard time convincing myself out of this hunch. it seems to me that altruism is pretty rare in its purest form. i can't wrap my head around the notion that such a brutal conflict was fought primarily to benefit a group of people that were still treated like shit even in the states that claimed total opposition to slavery. slavery is awful, but why would young men in the north want to risk their lives for black slaves when they weren't even willing to treat free blacks with the same respect at home that they would other white folk? and correct me if i'm wrong, but didn't the north have a policy that escaped slaves were to be returned to their owners if caught? my position is this: the agrarian nature of the south required man power. the north had become more industrial and therefore did not depend on slave labour to thrive. the easiest way to cripple the south's economy would be to deprive them of their means of production while conveniently taking the moral high ground. i can't comment on the south's racism, but my feeling is that their livelihoods were more important to them than arbitrarily oppressing a race of people. could the south have really been so opposed to blacks being free that mothers would willingly sacrifice their sons to uphold slavery? it just seems like too much of a stretch for me to believe that the north was just a bunch a good guys for a brief period in history without having any other motives.

conclusion: The minimum wage should be abolished
premises: it is my view that it does more harm than good to a community by sacrificing the number of jobs available to increase the well being of select individuals. furthermore, i don't think that the government is capable of setting an hourly wage that is 'fair' as fair is subjective and varies wildly by region and by career. if i open a clothing store, and i need to hire a cashier. i should pay said cashier a salary that is representative of the value said cashier brings to me and my store. assume that i can afford to pay the cashier is 30,000 a year about 15 an hour for the value they bring to the store. then that's what i pay the aforementioned cashier. i now have a choice: either i somehow make 10,000 dollars more this year, or i let my cashier go and take over the register myself. as automation technology matures, i may even upgrade to an all digital system. after all, it is impossible for you to do that for each and every small business. and yet, it is my job somehow to now deal with the consequences regardless of how my business is actually doing. in that scenario, the flick of a government pen has legislated away a job. please note: i am in favor of basic income.

gt: to say it simply, in general; the fiasco around this is very disrespectful, if for no other reason than because it is needlessly confrontational. there was never any way this wouldn't turn out as a hotly debated act and there should have been countless other avenues to take a positive approach. if the players spent their time or money actually helping the places they're virtue signaling for, instead of just mildly interrupting a football event, there would have been nothing to be critical of them for. to respond specifically to your last about the military; the anthem is a ceremony to express patriotism and its a pretty clear anti america message if you protest during it. thats more than just making a statement about our social climate, its spitting on everyone who has sacrificed to make the nation a better place and all it represents. something that matters a great deal to our military and other institutions. i would say that the right to and freedom to protest is a very american value. if the protesting had not been directly in response to the anthem, it wouldn't have been an offensive issue. but in doing so, it opens a huge can of worms, and i fully expect that pro athletes can do better than this.

conclusion: Philosophy is a pointless field of study
premises: i checked out an introductory book about it from my school library as a teenager, and quickly gave up on it because it seemed boring and irrelevant to life. then i went to university to study english and creative writing, and had to study derrida and lacan and someone else i've forgotten. i found it so frustratingly impossible to engage with their ideas that i ended up dropping english after my first year because i hated it the day i made my mind up about dropping it was when i found myself sitting in a lecture about 'the thingness of things' . now, in the interests of full disclosure, i do have asperger's so maybe that's why i struggle to wrap my head around it. however, i don't generally have much of a problem with abstract ideas or theory of mind if i did i probably wouldn't have been studying english and creative writing at degree level in the first place . which is fine if you're religious, but there's religious studies and theology for that. if you're an atheist as i am, and believe in the big bang and evolution, then the question of why is irrelevant. there is no hidden meaning there. getting beyond the surface and looking deeper is a job for scientists, unpacking atoms and unravelling genomes. there's an assumption that answers can be gained from within, from thinking and writing and reading the essays of other thinkers. while i agree this is a worthy pursuit in terms of expanding one's field of empathy and learning about how other people view things, i don't see how any kind of new development can come of it. innovation requires looking outwards, observing and engaging one's environment. all that introspection can achieve is essentially the kind of thing you find in r showerthoughts re wordings of concepts you already knew, gimmicky novel approaches to the familiar. but it's obviously an ancient and widely studied area, so i presume there must be something more to it that i'm missing. can you shed any light on it? i hadn't really given much consideration to the applications of philosophy in the ancient world and its contribution to the development of logic, democracy and other fundamental concepts. so, overall the view expressed in the post title is changed but i won't be picking up any philosophy books any time soon.

auto_conc: i think philosophy is a waste of time.
gt: for the first point, i think you're tunneling on one aspect of philosophy. philosophy is an incredibly broad field in the same way mathematics is a broad field. in the same way that it's not fair to judge all of math as 'just playing with numbers' or whatever, you shouldn't tunnel on a certain kind of philosophy and then reject the whole. certain philosophers also tend to stick to certain kinds of philosophy, so you might be forgiven for thinking that all philosophy sounds like semantic word games if the philosophers you're most familiar with focused on that kind of stuff. your second point is more interesting. i'd draw a parallel to science here. you don't discover anything new by studing newton's laws of motion, or the maxwell equations, but that doesn't mean that what you're working on isn't useful. a vital part of any intellectual discovery is understanding the vast wealth of thought that people have already pored into the subject you're working on. we stand on the shoulders of giants, and you're almost certainly not the first person to have thought about a particular topic. it's impossible to actually come up with something new until you've diligently studied the old.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think there is anything more to philosophy than it is to look beyond the surface and looking deeper. there is no hidden meaning there.
known_conc_attacks: philosophy is not a pointless field of study, it is a way of thinking about the world. if you don't like philosophy, then you can't be a philosopher.
auto_conc_attacks: i would argue that philosophy is a waste of time. i don't think it's a waste, but i do think it is a good way to learn about philosophy. i think you're missing the point of philosophy. philosophy is about understanding the world in a way that allows us to understand the world. it's about understanding how things work, and how we can use those things to improve our lives. it doesn't have to be a 'waste' of time, it's just a way of learning about the world and how it works.

conclusion: Looking at your phone while driving on the highway isn't as unsafe as people make it out to be.
premises: so please don't just downvote and tell me to fuck off because you hate my guts. 1. stay in the slow lane. you only have to worry about what's in front of you and to your left. which leads me to 2. don't tailgate. be far away from the person in front of you. stay aware of your surroundings. constantly be looking up and using your peripherals. 4. self explanatory 5. as long as you're driving straight, have plenty of space between you and the car in front of you, and are being constantly aware of your surroundings, your risk for an accident hasnt really increased as long as you are engaged enough to stop using your phone in risk situations that i described above. so please, change my view. please don't make your arguments about 'why do you need to even use your phone in the first place' or 'you are a shitty person putting everybody's lives at risk every time you drive', please discuss the points i mentioned above because making me reconsider those are the only thing that would really change my mind. i want to break this habit, but i'm convinced i don't need to. i'm not saying taking dumb snapchats and videos and not looking up for minutes is a smart idea. all i'm saying is that if you're smart about mitigating your risk, there really isn't that much to worry about

auto_conc: if you're paying attention to the road, you don't need to look at your phone while driving
gt: to put it bluntly i think you are way overestimating your own ability. your rules might make you feel like you are doing it safer, but physics and human physiology are working against you. it's also a compounding risk. i mean there are lots of things people do everyday while driving that are distracting such as changing the radio or drinking a coffee. based on time of attention your version of texting may even be 'safer' but no number of rules can change the fact that you are paying less attention while texting than if you were not texting at all. it is your responsibility to reduce risk while driving for your safety and others. go watch some compilation videos of crashes on youtube and find out for yourself how fast accidents happen and how irresponsible other drivers can be. ask yourself if your eye happens to be on your phone for that second instead of the road whether you could react in time. you can't. you know what really grinds my gears? i'm sure it's happened to you before you are safely following the car ahead of you when suddenly and without warning no brakes or turn signal they swerve at the last second to pass a completely stopped car that you couldn't see before. you are no better than a drunk that thinks they are a better driver. on a second note i notice that your rules are dangerously complacent. being in the 'slow' lane, texting only when others are not near you, texting only when it's 'safe. ' it's never safe, driving is not a passive action. 'complacency kills' is a good motto to repeat in your head. i would hate for you to be the person that dies because you drove the same road to work everyday for 8 years but were looking at your phone the day that road crews decided to block off that lane or a tree fell the night before or a dog dashes across the street. you are texting in the slow lane because you are assuming it is safer but in reality the fact that you think that shows that you are becoming too complacent and that makes it all the more dangerous. i'm being tough on you because my gf looked down at her phone for one second and didn't notice that the curb suddenly jutted out so she clipped it and rolled her car over. driving for 8 years at that point, and only going 35 miles an hour on a straight, empty road that she was very familiar with. luckily she was ok but it was certainly life changing for all the wrong reasons.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know if you've read this yet but i think you're underestimating how much risk you are putting yourself in. if you're driving in the slow lane, you're not going to be able to see the car in front of you, and you're going to have to worry about what's going on in the lane behind you. you're also going to need to be aware of your surroundings, because if you don't, you'll be less likely to get hit by a car.
known_conc_attacks: if you are not aware of your surroundings, you will not be able to see what's in front of you, which is why you should be paying attention to your surroundings.
auto_conc_attacks: i think it depends on the situation. if you're not paying attention to the road, you don't need to look up and using your peripherals.

conclusion: Some psychiatric drugs should be legalised (be allowed to buy over the counter) to receive without a prescription.
premises: i am open to listening to different opinions and why this isn t a good idea. i don t mean very serious drugs but things like anti anxiety, anti depression and anti add. i think that these drugs can be traded illegally anyway which means that there is no safety control, and the government does not get money. not everyone can afford to get a diagnosis. not everyone wants to. i, for one, do not wish to go through the official process as its expensive, time consuming and makes me nervous. now, some people might say that these drugs can be abused. we could just make a system where you need a passport id and when you buy the drugs, and your name is entered in the system, and you can only refill after a month. anxiety and ad h d are fairly common problems and quite easy to help with medication. i don t see why i cannot just go to the pharmacy and get something to help me calm down or focus. now some people may bring up side effects or potential murder risks. this is why we would have the system where you can only get monthly refills. and this is why we would only sell lighter drugs in this way. the ones least likely to cause serious side effects. and if you get a side effect? you should just stop taking the tablets or talk to a doctor at that point, if you wish. you wouldn t have enough pills to kill anyone. i think even if you don t have anxiety but if you suspect you do, you probably do and you take the pills, i think the worst that could happen is they act like a sedative and you get sleepy. you could just stop taking them then. and most people are very stressed and worried these days, so there would be very few people who would take the pills truly without cause. same with ad h d. if people suspect they have it, they probably do. the worst that could happen, is you have a side effect and then stop taking your pills. or if it works, you can now concentrate on school or work. some parents won t take their kids to a doctor. my mum thinks mental illness is fake and dumb. i have pocket money and i could just buy my own medicine. i don t want to be failing school. so, could you please tell me some arguments against this? why would it not be a good idea? thanks. update: thank you for the responses. i do now have some doubts about whether this is a good idea. ideally, we would have safer, lighter drugs to use, but apparently not many exist now that fit the criteria. so its more of a future wish. i have also reevaluated my stance on the ssri s and now understand that withdrawal symptoms can be severe, and i m not including them in my idea anymore. i am going to bed now, and will be back tomorrow in maybe 14 hours. i have to have that much sleep because i have a math test on sunday and obviously i procrastinated and have one day left and there is little hope because i can only go 10 minutes before drifting off good night day

conclusion: Black people who blame everything on racism are the reason race politics are so prevalent today.
premises: this is stupid and is not likely to happen. obviously racist people still exist, but, you are not likely to meet one or even be discriminated against by one in the modern day. this is another point i would like to make, so, ask for elaboration if you want it. thanks.
argument: Black people who blame everything on racism are the reason race politics are so prevalent today. : this is stupid and is not likely to happen. obviously racist people still exist, but, you are not likely to meet one or even be discriminated against by one in the modern day. this is another point i would like to make, so, ask for elaboration if you want it. thanks.
auto_conc: I believe that if you are a white person in America, you should be able to identify people who are of a different race.
gt: i see two major problems with your argument. first, you're using the phrase 'not likely' a lot. let's use a different example. your kid is not likely to get shot by a school shooter. when you compare the number of schools that exist in america over 100,000 to the number of school shootings that have taken place less than 500 in 175 years , we can definitively say that it is 'not likely' that your child will be the victim of a school shooting. the thing is, unsurprisingly, this doesn't make people feel better about school shootings. they still happen often enough for it to be something terrifying and abhorrent to most people, and when it does happen, it has long term and wide reaching affects. the whole nation is rocked by it, and the community that it happens in is shaken for years to come. not to mention that the lives of the survivors and of the victim's families are changed forever. all it takes is for one kid to get shot at school for thousands of kids to be afraid to go to school the next day. it's the same thing with racial issues. all it takes is one instance of blatant, public racism for black people everywhere to be afraid. so even if we agree that being the victim of racism isn't likely, is it likely enough to make whole communities afraid? that leads to the second point. racism is not always blatant. it doesn't always happen in a way that makes it clear that it is racism. most examples of racism are subtle. for example, several studies have shown that people with traditionally non white names have a harder time getting a job interview, even when they have the same qualifications as applicants with traditionally white names: since 1989, whites receive on average 36 more callbacks than african americans, and 24 more callbacks than latinos. we observe no change in the level of hiring discrimination against african americans over the past 25 years, although we find modest evidence of a decline in discrimination against latinos. so when you say, 'you likely did not get rejected from that job because you are black' we can demonstrate that that isn't true. that doesn't mean that betty in hr is a raging racist who dreams of dawning a klan hood one day. it could be that even she doesn't know why john seems more qualified than hakeem. it's just a gut feeling. the same reason why my grandmother always locked the car doors when we were sitting at a stop light and a black man was waiting to cross the street. she never did that with white men. this kind of subtle racism is the most prevalent, and the hardest to prove as well. i can't prove that your dad was stopped at that store because he was black. but how do you know that it wasn't, and what makes you believe that subtle acts of racial bias aren't as pervasive as people who experience them say they are?
masked_conc_attacks: it's not likely that racist people still exist, but it is likely that they are not likely to meet one or even be discriminated against by one in the modern day.

conclusion: I believe that Equality of Opportunity is more important than Equality of Outcome.
premises: the title shows my basic premise when it comes to politics. i think people should have no governmental obstacles to stop them from being able to succeed from their own merit. i think that if you are a hard worker, you deserve to be able to work your way to the top, seek out knowledge, and stand above those who weren t able to succeed the way you did. you should be able to work your way from the bottom and get to be a ceo or the president or any other top level position if you work and learn and push yourself to the top. i don t think for instance, having affirmative action programs are a good idea. the way i understand it, they try to push for diversity by for example, if two people both have the same qualifications, or indeed even if one is higher than the other, the one with lower or equal standards could get accepted instead, solely based on their race or other criteria, even if they were less qualified. another example is if you have 3 people in a room, a, b, and c. a earns a lot of money, and gets taxed at a higher rate than both b and c, despite the fact that a works harder than b and c. just because he has more money, that money is redistributed to b and c so they can also get a higher standard of living, even though they didn t work for it like a did. these kinds of ideas i think are counterproductive, especially the more they increase. in my last example for instance, if everyone was to give all their money to d, who then combined all the money and then gave it back to a b and c equally, then you end up with a problem. if a knows their money will just be given back to the b and c anyway, why try and make so much more money? and b and c, why would they try and earn more money if they know that they can just rely on a to get it for them? so now a, b, and c all have less incentive to work, and therefore they all have less money. welfare programs promote this kind of behavior as well. instead if we took it in the complete opposite direction, and they all kept everything they had, then they would all have an incentive to earn more money. a could get richer, and even employ b and c if they were willing to work for a, and b and c would realize that they couldn t just rely on a to get everything for them. they would have to work in order to survive, and would therefore have to earn things for themselves. they all have an incentive to work, and therefore must better themselves to earn things. this principle can be applied to many things, such as speech, wherein the opportunity would be everyone can speak their mind. if b and c decided that they didn t like something that a said, they could simply not associate with him. they could instead speak how they wanted to, and tell a to buzz off, and associate with what they want. if outcome was put into place, and a was not allowed to say those things that b and c didn t like, then b and c would feel more comfortable, but a wouldn t be allowed to express their opinions, and would therefore lead to a less diverse group of opinions and discussions. also, if a was to open a shop and discriminate against gay people for instance, if they all had equal opportunity, then b could open up a shop, and c might decide that they don t like a s policy that much, or perhaps c is gay as well, and decide to go to b. this would rob a of his business, and he would either be forced to change his policy, or lose money because of the customers that didn t like his policy or were refused because of it. if they all had the same outcome, this couldn t happen, but if a was religious, and didn t want to serve these gay people for instance, then it would violate his freedom of religion. i should also mention that i think this is better from a moral standpoint as well, not just a logical standpoint. in the first example, b and c are taking a s money and giving it to themselves just because a earned more than they did. they are taking away a s right to their money. in the second example, b and c are taking away a s right to speak as he chooses. he said something they didn t like or agree with, and said by law, you cannot say that anymore. i should make a distinction that this is different if a said i am going to kill you. that implies he is about to attack you, and you should be able to criminalize that. i m referring to if a said b should die in a fire. that s not nice, but it doesn t imply action. a shouldn t be criminalized for saying something mean. in the third example, b and c are taking away a s right to choose who a gives their service to. no one has a right to someone s services. in this example, the government is forcing a to do something that he doesn t want to do, violating his religious beliefs as well. that is my stance when it comes to politics. change my view!

auto_conc: i think everyone should have the right to pursue their own dreams, and not be limited by others.
gt: i wrote this quickly so i apologize if it isn't clear is rushed. i legitimately disagree with some of your claims so i looked through the responses and didn't find any that aligned with my own objections though there are a lot of responses so if you have come across this one already, then i apologize . your thought process is great. you are beginning with a certain simplified worldview and then elaborating based on motivation, taxation, notions of what makes a good society, a good economy etc. the fundamental problem is that your initial simplified worldview is fictional or, at the very least, it does not apply in general circumstances and is thereby of only partial use meaning that you ought to supplement your view with other views when the initial conditions do not hold . i will try to illustrate this in two ways. first, you begin with 3 people in a room, a, b, and c, and you ask us to imagine that a works harder than b and c, and that a thereby earns more money. a is taxed higher and yada yada yada. this is indeed a possible circumstance. but it is not the only possible circumstance. suppose, instead, you have 3 people a, b, and c. they are clones, equal in every way. equally hard working, equally smart, equally qualified etc. there is one job opening available in this room. all three apply. all are equally qualified, but one job cannot be given to three people. accordingly, an arbitrary decision process results in person a obtaining the job. person a now makes a bunch of money and person b and c have none. the inequality in outcome, in this circumstance, is not based on hard work, or skill, determination, merit, intelligence whatever else you want to apply. i propose that the situation i have put forth, is just as relevant to the world as the situation you put forth. but your conclusions do not apply to this new situation. i would go even further though i don't expect you to be convinced by this, and making such an argument isn't essential to making my point in this post and say that the meritocracy is fictional. second, inequality in opportunity is readily apparent in the world today. i was born into a middle class family with disposable income. i was raised in an enriched environment with lots of books, emphasis on education, sports, solid reinforcement etc. not everyone has such opportunities. i have friends who had more opportunity than me. they went to private school, international trips, family members in high ranking positions in notable companies who could get them job placements. i have friends who had fewer opportunities than me. raised by single parents who had to work multiple low paying jobs just to afford rent and food, and thereby couldn't direct as much time money to environmental enrichment. this is obvious not to mention political inequalities in marginalized groups, racial inequalities, sexual, other possible inequalities , but a more general point is worth making here. there is a common tendency illustrated in your own case to suppose that intelligence, hard work, resourcefulness, cleverness, cut throatness etc. are for some reason starting properties, rather than outcomes themselves. that is, you are assuming that 'hard worker' is something that people are born with and that this somehow serves as a starting point for an idealized equality of opportunity world. this is certainly not the case. being a 'hard worker' is as much the outcome of a process as is wealth inequality. is there even such thing is equality of opportunity? two general points in closing. 1. inequality of outcome will facilitate social unrest, if that inequality is sufficiently pronounced. social unrest can be extremely dangerous, and limiting social unrest is a benefit for those with and without power. if in your hypothetical room person b and c could get very pissed off and decide to burn the room down and overthrow the system that allows person a to have inequality of outcome, it may be in person a's best interest to give up some of what he has earned, so as to perpetuate the social conditions in the room that allow him such benefits. 2. there is a silly tendency to attribute social power success to something innate inherent in a person. and this long predates genetics and the notion that genetics determine who you are is generally a very silly claim and widely known to be such among biologists experts think of monarchs who had their inherent social power justified through god and, oddly, those who overthrew those monarchs also had their social power justified through the same god. such appeals to innateness may explain inequalities of outcome though other explanations are possible or may make such inequalities seem inevitable ostensible inevitability is a powerful mechanism of social control . but why does some innate inherent quality justify inequality of outcome? i'm not sure so i bring this up to point that out to you and others. why does innate difference justify inequality of outcome? it seems to me that, in some areas at least we generally do not think this to be the case eg. in democracies today at least in the west we generally allow equal political power to each individual at least as an ideal , regardless of whether the person is a genius or an idiot, wealthy or poor, man or woman, white or black, tall or short.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think there's a whole lot of merit in your argument, and i don't really think it's fair to say that you should have no governmental obstacles to stop people from being able to succeed from their own merit. i think you're missing the point of the argument, which is that it's impossible for people to be able to work their way up to the top, regardless of their merit. there are plenty of people who are able to get a job, but that doesn't mean that they can't work for it. it's just that you don't have any incentive to work at all.
known_conc_attacks: i don't understand what you're trying to say, but i'm going to try to change your view here. i'm not going to argue that equality of opportunity is more important than equality of outcome, but that's a different topic. the idea is that you should have no governmental obstacles to stop someone from being able to succeed from their own merit. i don't think that's the case. i think that people should be able to work their way to the top, seek out knowledge, and stand above those who weren't able to do the same.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think this is a good idea, but i think it's a great idea. i think we should have a system in place to allow people to pursue their own dreams, and not be limited by others. for example, let's say you're a teacher, and you want to get a job, but you don't want to pay for it because you're not qualified to be a teacher. that's a pretty good idea. but it doesn't work out that way. it's not a perfect system, but it does work.

conclusion: Thanos' plan makes no sense when you take economics and policy into account.
premises: i have to preface this by saying i realize this isn't a serious topic, and i understand it's not an important problem to debate or is it? additionally, i did not grow up reading marvel comics, and i have had very little context on thanos besides what i saw in the avengers movies. he believes that the snap will prevent economic collapse. he says: what's happened since then is that the children born have known nothing but full bellies and clear skies. it's a paradise. i am failing to see how this would work: 1. the post snap scene shown in the movie does not show a thriving civilization. why wouldn't we see hundreds of worlds being perfectly happy with how things are now? 2. if you cut half the population, i imagine that would initially cause political chaos, all the jobs needing to be transferred, all the people making moves because certain people are gone. suddenly, 2x the resources are available, but half the people are there to use them. would this not lead to a universe wide baby boom? how would people not want to start wars with other planets for those unused resources? am i supposed to buy the idea that everything will be 2x more readily available and things will just go on as normal? 3. i understand that thanos saw this strategy work on gamora's homeworld, but i don't see how it would have worked in that case either, for the reasons above. in that sense, i believe thanos is really falling for a logical fallacy by thinking his past approach will work anywhere. please change my view!

gt: i don't think he was going for economic amp; policies of planet into account, from my point of view his plan was to save the eco system of the planet. eg. earth here human are exploting the resources for their personal use while not thinking of other species that dwell on it, as a result many species are getting extinct. even if he eradicate's half population of every species on earth it will still be helpful for the eco system. as human which are idiotic users of natural resources will have to adjust their lives amp; make balance of economy amp; other social necessities but animals will have time on their hand as they have not interfered with nature so i think snap was not meant for economic amp; policies but for eco system

conclusion: A private business should be able to discriminate.
premises: i feel like we can beat racism homophobia etc. by simply having and expressing better ideas. i'd much rather have the racists out in the open with their beliefs and allow society to choose where to put their business. their is a massive amount of money and time wasted on an issue that would be solved naturally with a free market.

auto_conc: I feel like we can beat racism/homophobia by having and expressing better
gt: are you comfortable living in a society where you're basically guaranteeing that small towns will be segregated based on race? if there's one doctor in the town, and he refuses to treat black people, or white people, or people of any colour. or, the town's only grocery store owner who refuses to sell food to black people, or white people, or people of any colour. is that a society worth living in? moreover, there doesn't exist a single private business on the planet that operates in a vacuum. they are inevitably supported by the taxes of all residents, which pays for the infrastructure that makes their business possible electricity, water, roads, etc . taxpayers don't get the option to say, i want to pay my taxes in a way that only supports infrastructure around black or white private businesses. so, why should the business owners get the option to do that?

conclusion: Free Will does not exist
premises: what i mean is that neither humans nor any animal can really choose anything. the future is as set in stone as the past. i base this on a few things: to the best of my knowledge, there is no divine being. the inability of the conscious mind to micromanage the brain. basically, the fact that you can't just release serotonin dopamine endorphins on command. this means the brain is a slave to its surroundings, because your course of action depends on what chemicals are currently in your brain if you're angry, you're more likely to snap at someone. not to mention to paradox this would cause in the first place.
argument: Free Will does not exist : what i mean is that neither humans nor any animal can really choose anything. the future is as set in stone as the past. i base this on a few things: to the best of my knowledge, there is no divine being. the inability of the conscious mind to micromanage the brain. basically, the fact that you can't just release serotonin dopamine endorphins on command. this means the brain is a slave to its surroundings, because your course of action depends on what chemicals are currently in your brain if you're angry, you're more likely to snap at someone. not to mention to paradox this would cause in the first place.
auto_conc: I don't believe in the free will of humans.
gt: i would argue that we have limited free will, or at least what some would call the illusion of free will. for example, we can make choices, i decided to comment on this particular post. no person coerced me into commenting. i decided how to dress myself this morning. maybe i even changed my mind and wore something different. however, imagine that a supercomputer knew the position and charge of every single particle in the universe, and had the processing power to compute what all of that means. suddenly you can analyze a person's brain and see exactly what's happening on an atomic level. you can see that they are taking a sip of coffee, but they are distracted by a television and are fatigued from staying up late last night. because you have literally all the information on this person in real time, the computer predicts that this person is going to miss their face and spill coffee all over themselves. and they do. such a computer could predict the infinite future of everything, with no irregularities, thus disproving the existence of free will. unfortunately no such device exists yet, and fatalism is rarely given a second thought by most people.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're misunderstanding the idea that the future is as set in stone as the past. there is no divine being.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'free will', but i would like to point out that you're missing a key point. free will is a concept that has been around for hundreds of thousands of years. it's a concept, but it has not been proven to be true yet.
auto_conc_attacks: what do you mean by 'free will'?

conclusion: Asians in USA go through normalized racism.
premises: recently posted the same subject on r unpopularopinion but it looks like that subreddit is not fit for discussions. this simply means that racism towards asian people have been highly desensitized. racists remarks or actions towards asian people may not be considered racist by non asian people. some examples or racism i will cover are. use of racist remarks such as chink, japs, gook, paki, slant eyed and et cetera sometimes gets used in mainstream media without acknowledgement that these words might be offensive and even comparable to the n word. all asians are grouped similarly. now, i've heard that it was hard for most people to differentiate between chinese, japanese, and korean people. and i fully understand that it is hard. i'm not wishing for people to automatically know which country i was from, but to be respectful when asking. i don't mind it when people take interest and ask me directly 'hey, are you from somewhere else? ' that's fine. just don't come up to me or other asian people and start saying things like 'ni hao' or 'konnichiwa' or 'annyounghaseyo'. and please note. the reason why some asian people might be offended when mistaken for another race is that there are some 'badblooded' history between them. i personally love japan. but for my parents and grandparents who personally faced wwii, korean war, and japanese colonial era directly, they might really dislike being mistaken for a japanese person. the notion that things aren't racist because other race see them as 'positive' is just. weird. i am still allowed to be upset if i get mocked for being bad at math despite being asian. 'well asian people are more successful and smart. so they shouldn't complain'. when i hear this excuse, they are almost always referring to chinese, japanese, or korean people. they are completely omitting south eastern asians who for the most part, are not as successful when they are in the states. not to mention that not all asian people come from wealth or success. my single mother had to quit school at 17 to start selling donuts, often working 80 90 hour week just to get by. i'm pretty sure she can complain a bit. she had 5. 0 out 4. 0 gpa through ap courses, loads of extracurricular activities including being the treasurer and later president of student council, perfect attendance, 35 and later 36 on act. basically the whole yard. but for university, she had to settle for our state university due to lack of scholarship offers and out financial situation. personally, i'm a permanent resident of united states, who for some odd reason was marked as an international student. i had to 'compromise' by giving up my 12,000 scholarship in exchange of paying in state tuition rather than out of state tuition. one thing to note is that anyone who graduated from our public high school is considered to be in state. despite attending the same school from preschool till graduation, i was still marked as an international student who must identify themselves and show documents in order to be marked so. 'don't be such a special snowflake'. i personally don't understand the whole 'xzhe, xzher' thing myself and don't consider myself to be a sjw. but i do believe in standing up for what i believe. i also believe that i am not making a 'big deal' over nothing, or blowing things out of proportion. i have personally witness korean international students fall into depression and self harming due to racism. some of which, had decided to go back to korea rather than continuing them study. i don't think this is a 'small deal'. my parents own a shop in a minority asian part of town. for the first decade or so, they have been targeted due to their race fortunately the neighbor are now very much welcoming of us and are mostly very pleasant! asian people are fetishized. you guys probably know what i mean already. the notion that asian females are 'submissive' 'meek' 'eager to please' 'tighter' are all very sick. asian guys are emasculated. i guess if statistic shows that on average, asian guys are smaller in certain areas, i can't really argue with that. but they aren't less of a man because of that alone. i'm going to be 100 honest. i'm a very feminine guy so i can't really give personal examples for this one. but i have seen quite a bit of my korean acquaintances get rejected on the sole grounds of being asian. i'm not stating that asians have it the worst. i'm not stating that asian people aren't racists themselves. i'm stating that there are racism against asian people that people of other race might not consider racist when they really are. please. don't say 'well asian people are the most racist people i know so ' yea, my mom's super racist.

conclusion: being trans is mental illness and teaching children that they might be a different gender, allowing children to permanently alter their biology with hormones, is abuse.

2 identity is psychological, not biological. you can identify as a double amputee trapped in a normal body, should a physician remove your legs? 3 if i want to cut off healthy legs, i m mentally ill. but if i want to cut off my breasts, then i m just a man in a woman s body? 4 i understand that the trans community has high rates of self harm and suicide. 5 if i was told at age 10 that i might be a boy, i very well could picture myself declaring i was boy. especially the awkward prepubescent years when breast buds were forming and you just feel like your body is weird. 6 when my child says he s a dog, i don t buy him dog bowls and put his meals on the floor. but if a boy says he s a girl, i m not supportive if i don t buy stereotypical girl things and tell him he s a girl? we can t give children tattoos even if they want them, but we can block puberty? 8 if gender identity was truly hard wired at birth and people were born into the wrong body wouldn t identical twins, 100 of the time, have the same gender identity? those teen goths saw it as expressing their identity and that other people just didn t get. childhood transgenderism feels like the same fad, but with extremely permanent repercussions. i m truly disturbed that the current policy at least where i work is to encourage this. i cringe hard when i picture myself at 14 and 15, but what if those identity choices had been permanent? change my view?

conclusion: The future of humanity is NOT in outer space
premises: i truly hope you can change my view on this, since i am very well aware that this is both an incredibly boring and depressing view to have. i do not have a background in science, and i am very well aware that people much more accomplished than myself would strongly disagree, but that being said, the more i look at the facts, the less likely it seems that anything productive can be accomplished by colonizing, or even traveling to, other planets. let's look at what we currently know about space travel: the nearest star, other than the sun, is over four light years away from the earth. keep in mind that the planets of this star system most likely won't be able to sustain human life, meaning that all the individuals and equipment required to terraform and repopulate another planet one which we know basically nothing about would have to be transported more than four light years away from earth. additionally, the people who would go on such an expion would be unable to communicate with anyone on earth, since we are unable to send messages so far away using any kind of technology that currently exists, and would be completely unable to return. with this in mind, it seems nearly impossible that we will ever be able to reach, let alone colonize another star system, but what about our own star system? well, first let's consider our reasons for colonizing these planets in the first place. most of these planets are either too hot or too cold to sustain life, with the most likely exception being mars, venus, and a number of moons, including our own. even so, these planets present incredibly hostile environments; they are home to extreme temperatures, little to no oxygen, and most likely no liquid water whatsoever. there are theories as to how we might be able to terraform these planets, making it possible for humans to survive there, although needless to say that won't be an easy process. while there is little doubt earth is becoming less habitable to humans, the reality is we currently have water, oxygen, food, plant life, and temperatures humans can survive in almost everywhere on the planet. if it is possible to terraform an environment which is as hostile as mars or venus, shouldn't it also be possible to re terraform earth? wouldn't this be much easier, and a much more productive use of our resources? so perhaps we don't need to colonize other planets, but they are still home to a number of resources that we can benefit from here on earth, right? maybe we can simply set up mining stations throughout our solar system, and bring minerals back to earth. the problem with this is that inter planar travel costs a lot of resources as it is. transporting mining equipment and mining staff to another planet, and transporting a significant quantity valuable minerals back to earth would be extremely cost inefficient. admittedly we would also be granted access to entire planets worth of raw materials, so some might argue that the trade off is ultimately worth it, but keep in mind that we would also need to burn enormous amounts of fuel, and since we currently depend primarily on fossil fuels, we most likely wouldn't be able to find anything of comparable value anywhere else in the solar system. remember that we are currently facing the risk of running out of fossil fuels entirely, and that they are, as the name suggests, made of organic material. with this in mind, it is almost impossible that we will find anything like it elsewhere in our solar system. like i said at the beginning, this is a massive bummer, and i truly hope i'm wrong. i do not have a background in science, and there is a good chance i don't know what i'm talking about, so if you are able to change my view, i would be extremely happy. that being said, if i'm right, i believe the scientific community would be better off recognizing this hard truth, and dedicating their resources to something more productive than space travel, such as researching ways to make the earth continue to be inhabitable.

conclusion: Sex-selective abortions in Western countries should remain legal
premises: they can cause disastrous demographic shifts, similar to those china and india are seeing in certain regions. this reasoning is not applicable in western countries for several reasons: 1 children of all genders are equally welcome, for the most part. while sexism, homophobia, or transphobia certainly can affect children as they age, parents probably aren't going to select for one sex over the other in significant numbers. 2 parents who are willing to abort a fetus of the wrong gender will probably mistreat that child as he or she ages. if you're committed enough to get a relatively late abortion i. e. at the 18 week range because you want a boy, there's a reasonable chance you won't be a good parent to a daughter you're forced to have. 3 any laws limiting abortion based on gender will disproportionately affect minorities. doctors will assume that the abortion is because of the fetus's sex and deny certain segments of the population care, for fear of breaking the law. moreover, winding back abortion rights is dangerous in today's political climate. cmv!

everyday it seems i can find new studies that have more and more downsides to marijuana smoke in the short and long term and i just don't understand why people seem to think that there are no downsides here. medicinally it still is considered to have no medical benefits and i don't really see how it possibly could as current understanding of thc which is the strongest known cannabinoid in marijuana seems to cause more harm then good. i can understand that cbd is being shown to be successful in treating things like chronic pain and anxiety however thc vastly outnumbers cbd in weed and smoking to get these effects seems counterproductive. i feel as if medical marijuana companies are trying to piggyback off the false notion that it's a harmless drug and push it onto people asap similarly to how tobacco companies operated back in the day. at the end of the day these companies are profitable off addiction and they have ulterior motives when it comes to testing this stuff. they say things like it's not as bad as alcohol or tobacco cigarette but to me this seems like a logical fallacy as one could really justify any reckless behavior this way. one of the main reasons i've been so torn up on this lately is that a lot of my friends including my girlfriend started smoking and have definitely changed. it bothers me. it bothers me that they started presumingly under age and were not fully aware of the consequences and now a lot seem to have dependencies on the drug. they claim it's fine but in my eyes it's the same as smoking as cigarette, at least in the physical sense, and if people smoke tobacco to unwind most people would agree that it's very unhealthy to form habits around that. at the end of the day, smoking every once in a while won't kill you in the same way occasionally smoking a cig won't kill you, however i believe that having a dependency on anything is not healthy and weed is no exception.

conclusion: If you arent okay hunting/slaughtering animals yourself, you shouldnt eat meat
premises: so many friends of mine hate when i discuss the way their meat is slaughtered and packaged all up for the store not while they are eating though. i m not a jerk. but i haven t had meat in 5 years because of this very reason. i hate watching videos of animals be slaughtered, let alone actually doing it. if you don t, you re just reaping the rewards while being completely disconnected from what is actually on your plate. i find it more justified for a farmer to eat an animal they raised or a hunter to eat an animal they actually hunted simply because there s more respect for the animal they killed. they saw it alive and made the conscious decision to kill for their meal. no one who goes shopping for their pork ribs or chicken breasts at their local grocery has that connection to the living animal. it s just meat not a once living being. now i ll acknowledge that it s more efficient for factory farms to exist. i m not expecting anyone to go slaughter a chicken during their lunch break.

conclusion: It is hypocritical to both (1) support the right of companies to deplatform groups/individuals and (2) to oppose the right of companies to withhold service from a group/individual.
premises: seriously, please change my mind, i've been thinking about this for too long i will explain in greater detail through examples. alex jones has been in the news the past few months as service after service drop him like the dead opossum your dumbass uncle picked up before he realized the lil fella wasn't so dead after all they suddenly realized what they'd been carrying, squealed like little girls, let go with all but two fingers, hurled it as far away from them as they could, warned it not to come back, and vowed to do a better job of prodding with a stick whatever they're about to pick up to see if it is what it seems like . insert whichever supposedly harmless person or group you'd like in his place. i posit that deplatforming jones or others requires no reason to be given. any reason given is also of little to no importance. it is a different landscape where the sites have all the power insert 'youhavenopowerhere. gif' . you should resign yourself to accepting pretty much any excuse they come up with, even if it wasn't a policy they had up to that point. breakdown of expected counter arguments: any legal argument. i am interested in your case law or what have you, but this is a logical argument and laws do not necessarily have inherent logic. case law will not necessarily be enough to change my mind. this includes hate crime arguments and the lot. on hate crimes as a moral argument; i see that this view has an arguable slippery slope fallacy in comparing possible hate crimes to people that are just living their lives. alex jones is a pretty bad dude, so an intentionally extreme example might be 'you can kick hitler from the discord, why can't i deny this objectively sweet and adorable little girl a life saving surgery? ' here, i think the slippery slope lies in the service, not the denied person group. if it is necessary to life, then there is no comparison. i'm not saying you should support christian doctors refusing gay patients, i'm saying you should respect the right of the bigoted owner of a mini golf place to tell suspected gay people to keep walking. situations are incomparable: a website which hosts and maintains data that you upload and something like a restaurant certainly have differences. the key similarities that i think make them comparable are that the people to be excluded are the resource that the entities are after. this argument is a bit like 'company owners have autonomy to choose whether they make money off of someone allow them food a profile , if they lose money off of someone allow them to come in keep their profile but shadowbanned with no ads , or if they refuse to lose money off of someone kick them out ban them '

conclusion: People who wish to transition genders need to wait until they are at least 21
premises: however i feel like at younger ages you're still very much finding out who you are as a person and it's possible that you may regret this decision. i once read an article in the atlantic about a girl who felt uncomfortable and at a young age and eventually began to transition luckily her parents kept putting off a physical surgery and overtime the girl realized she really was a girl and not a boy in a girls body. she found gender dysphoria as a coping mechanism because she felt odd and needed something to identify with. i have also read of a person who transitioned at a young age i can't for the life of me remember the name of this person but they were a mtf by using puberty halting drugs to look more feminine but when they got older and wanted the physical surgery they were unable because their penis was too small due to never having gone through surgery. now that person is stuck with no option because they chose to rush the process. for a decision that will stay with you for the rest of your life it may be hard to wait but it's easier to stop it before it happens than it is to go back. however i feel as though it will be worse for their mental health if they have a surgery and regret it afterwards with now it no longer being a temporary problem but a permanent one.
argument: People who wish to transition genders need to wait until they are at least 21 : however i feel like at younger ages you're still very much finding out who you are as a person and it's possible that you may regret this decision. i once read an article in the atlantic about a girl who felt uncomfortable and at a young age and eventually began to transition luckily her parents kept putting off a physical surgery and overtime the girl realized she really was a girl and not a boy in a girls body. she found gender dysphoria as a coping mechanism because she felt odd and needed something to identify with. i have also read of a person who transitioned at a young age i can't for the life of me remember the name of this person but they were a mtf by using puberty halting drugs to look more feminine but when they got older and wanted the physical surgery they were unable because their penis was too small due to never having gone through surgery. now that person is stuck with no option because they chose to rush the process. for a decision that will stay with you for the rest of your life it may be hard to wait but it's easier to stop it before it happens than it is to go back. however i feel as though it will be worse for their mental health if they have a surgery and regret it afterwards with now it no longer being a temporary problem but a permanent one.
auto_conc: i don't think people should wait until they are older to transition
gt: according to a recent study by the american academy of pediatrics, around 51 of ftm children and teens attempt suicide, as do 42 of nonbinary teens and 30 of mtf teens. the age range was 11 19 years old for this study. this was based on surveys, so it obviously doesn't include the information of those who completed suicide. different studies with different methodologies have also found that rates of depression and anxiety are reduced by at least 50 in groups who are allowed access to medical treatment compared to those without access, and some studies have as much as a 90 reduction between groups. amp; x200b;additionally, studies have shown that the rate of people regretting gender confirming surgeries essentially the most permanent irreversible part of medical transition are under 4 , with some smaller studies saying that they had no participants who experienced regret. surgery is rarely the first part of transition too puberty blockers and hormones nearly always come first. puberty blockers are 100 reversible and only some of the effects of cross hormone treatment remain after treatment is discontinued. amp; x200b;i would think that with such a high risk associated with not treating transgender adolescents and such a comparatively low risk associated with regretting transition, it's irresponsible not to allow appropriate steps to be taken to allow younger people access to the treatment that they need.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's possible that you'll regret it after the surgery, but it's a very real possibility that you will regret it afterwards.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's possible that they'll regret it after they've gone through it. i think they should wait until they're at least 21. it's not like they're going to regret it when they're 21.
auto_conc_attacks: i think it's a good idea to wait until you are older to transition. if you don't want to wait, then don't do it.

conclusion: "Reverse racism is just racism" is a racist trojan virus
premises: we see it repeated verbatim and in minor variations in response to the same triggers over and over and over. for those who think 'meme' means 'funny cat picture,' meme theory actually holds that ideas work very much like viruses, using our brains as hosts in which to replicate and spread. we can trace that spread back epidemiologically and observe mutations that have helped a meme propagate. we can also talk about common features or strategies of different memes that contribute to their spread and survival. the essence of the rr r meme is that to not apply the concept of racism equally to any and all races on either end of an act of prejudice is a double standard, i. e. hypocritical. invoking hypocrisy or double standards is almost always itself hypocritical literally, 'under reasoned' or 'under examined' . it's easy to frame almost any position as a double standard, and accusations of hypocrisy are a strong emotional hook for young people in particular. these accusations rarely say much of anything about the supposedly hypocritical position, though. they just cast doubt on those holding the position: in practice, an ad hominem attack. rr held that any policy action to counteract racism constituted 'racism against white people. ' this meme was calculated to perpetuate racism by sidetracking discussions of racism, watering down the concept, and stalling anti racist action. it can safely be characterized as racist. the r is a wrapper for the rr meme to make it more palatable to people who might reject the harder 'we should never do anything about racism' position, but rr is still in there. both rely on the 'double standard' hook to get your attention, but rather than addressing policy, rr r invokes the idea of individuals acting with racial prejudice toward whites. in addition to being more acceptable, this approach introduces the idea of a relatable however unlikely threatening scenario, engaging an even stronger emotional hook: your fight or flight instinct. while also making rr more acceptable by degrees to those who have accepted rr r. to change my view: demonstrate that rr r has some utility in reducing, opposing, or increasing our understanding of racism, rather than supporting and propagating racism even if inadvertently while muddying the waters. constructing phrases where you can substitute 'white' for 'black' will not achieve this end. repeating some pure and idealized, a contextual and a historical definition of racism is also not productive. you can quietly believe in your heart that racism is some platonic ideal because it ends in ' ism,' but the reality remains that the only relevant application the only reason the word came into use and continues to exist is to refer to the favored position of white people and the disfavored position of everyone else in post colonial societies.

conclusion: The US government giving financial aid to students and to universities at the rate/manner it does is ultimately counterproductive.
premises: what we're doing now is essentially letting them do whatever they want and then bailing them out, when i believe that they should be given a specific, tight budget that must be followed in order to receive subsidies.
argument: The US government giving financial aid to students and to universities at the rate/manner it does is ultimately counterproductive. : what we're doing now is essentially letting them do whatever they want and then bailing them out, when i believe that they should be given a specific, tight budget that must be followed in order to receive subsidies.
auto_conc: I believe that we should tax the rich and give the money to the poor.
gt: it increases the price, but not be nearly as much as you apparently think it is and not really a cyclical problem as you've suggested either. basic economic principles means that the government paying x for everyone's college would raise the price of college somewhere between 0 and x depending on the elasticity of supply and demand how consumers and providers choose to respond to price changes . the fact that the government doesn't offer financial aid to everyone is just going to make the price rise that much closer to the 0 end of things. but consumers as a whole will never be worse off if the government offers to pay for some college expenses. suppose widgets sell for 25 and the government comes along and offers everyone a free 10 if they buy a widget, so now it only costs people 15. suppose each person has an internal value for how much they are willing to buy a widget for. people who were willing to pay 25 were already buying widgets. people who aren't willing to pay even 15 will continue to not buy widgets. and anyone paynig between 15 25 will now buy widgets and claim the government money. the widget maker can respond to this in a number of ways. they could start producing more widgets to serve the people who are willing to pay 15 25. or they could raise their prices to up to 35 and get the whole 10 for themselves but get none of the benefit of additional sales. the only case in which they'd probably do the second one is if there is a strictly limited supply and making more just isn't really an option. why can't they raise the price above 35? well they would sell even less than they were originally and that isn't how sellers respond to things. as they make more money per sale they make more, not less. here is a more visual explanation of how the supply and demand curves respond to a subsidy like this one. unless the supply curve is vertical, meaning they just don't respond to changes in price by offering just as many spots no matter the price they can get and no new colleges opening up offering classes either when the price increases , then the consumer will also benefit from the subsidy. the overall price for consumers will be cheaper. but with a selective subsidy you can have some consumers hurt a little . the base price won't increase by as much as if everyone got the subsidy, but for anyone not getting the subsidy, they could end up paying a little more then before the subsidy.
masked_conc_attacks: the problem with this is that it doesn't work out. if you want to get rid of subsidies, you need to give them the money to do so. if they don't want to do it, you can't give them that money. it's not like they can't do whatever they want.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point of the system. it's not about the government giving financial aid to students and to universities at the rate of manner it does, it's about the university providing financial aid for students and universities.
auto_conc_attacks: you're right that we should tax the rich and give the money to the poor, but you're wrong that the rich should be given the money. the poor should be able to do whatever they want and then bailing them out.
