conclusion: the story of Job teaches no valuable lessons, other than God is a jerk.
premises: by this i mean that the book doesn't contain any notable insights nor does it resolve any interesting theological questions, albeit i personally love it as a piece of absurdist fiction. worse than that, it seems to be undermining the very religion of whose holy text it belongs to. the book revolves a lot about theodicy; the problem of evil in the world. how can bad things happen to good people, and vice versa? the closest thing the book gives to an answer, is that we puny mortals can't grasp it. the israelites are taught time and again, that the reason they're getting slaughtered by fillistines or robbed and exiled is because they have turned away from god and sinned. they are led to believe, convinced by prophets send by god, that their actions have consequences corresponding to their sins. obviously when job suddenly gets hit by outrageous misfortune, his friends believe him to have committed some secret sin to cause it. we know however, that no such cause exists, and that god just wanted to prove a point to a buddy. god even scolds the friends for assuming that jobs misfortunes were caused by sin, like they have been repeatedly taught by him. all through the bible people are explicitly being punished or provided for according to their sins. by punishing job he is undermining the coherency of his followers, by denying them the belief that has kept them together through suffering and exile; that their suffering isn't pointless, and that it's all just and right. even if job gets richer in the end, how about his original sons and daughters who died horrible deaths for no reason? in the book satan raises the question of the possibility of selfless righteousness. some people are righteous whilst reaping no benefit whatsoever. the problem of unpunished evil goes completely unanswered. also, whether job even remains faithful is, in my opinion, up to debate. is it faith to maintain that god is injust and unfair? he repents at the end, but i would say satan won the bet here. furthermore, job is obviously right in saying that he is punished through no fault of his own, and therefore unfairly. he never explains how his action was fair, apparently because 'god works in mysterious ways' tm and no human could ever understand. except we can, it's right there, black on white, in the beginning: god punished job to prove a point to satan, and if people can't grasp the reasons for their suffering, they are probably either nonexisting or preposterous as they are in the case of job . basically the take away seems to be that sometimes, god is just a bully. phew, sorry about the rant, really needed to get this off my chest. anyways, i know that there are much more knowledgeable people than me in this sub, so i hope you can show me where i've completely missed the point which is probably the case and tell me why i'm wrong!
argument: the story of Job teaches no valuable lessons, other than God is a jerk. : by this i mean that the book doesn't contain any notable insights nor does it resolve any interesting theological questions, albeit i personally love it as a piece of absurdist fiction. worse than that, it seems to be undermining the very religion of whose holy text it belongs to. the book revolves a lot about theodicy; the problem of evil in the world. how can bad things happen to good people, and vice versa? the closest thing the book gives to an answer, is that we puny mortals can't grasp it. the israelites are taught time and again, that the reason they're getting slaughtered by fillistines or robbed and exiled is because they have turned away from god and sinned. they are led to believe, convinced by prophets send by god, that their actions have consequences corresponding to their sins. obviously when job suddenly gets hit by outrageous misfortune, his friends believe him to have committed some secret sin to cause it. we know however, that no such cause exists, and that god just wanted to prove a point to a buddy. god even scolds the friends for assuming that jobs misfortunes were caused by sin, like they have been repeatedly taught by him. all through the bible people are explicitly being punished or provided for according to their sins. by punishing job he is undermining the coherency of his followers, by denying them the belief that has kept them together through suffering and exile; that their suffering isn't pointless, and that it's all just and right. even if job gets richer in the end, how about his original sons and daughters who died horrible deaths for no reason? in the book satan raises the question of the possibility of selfless righteousness. some people are righteous whilst reaping no benefit whatsoever. the problem of unpunished evil goes completely unanswered. also, whether job even remains faithful is, in my opinion, up to debate. is it faith to maintain that god is injust and unfair? he repents at the end, but i would say satan won the bet here. furthermore, job is obviously right in saying that he is punished through no fault of his own, and therefore unfairly. he never explains how his action was fair, apparently because 'god works in mysterious ways' tm and no human could ever understand. except we can, it's right there, black on white, in the beginning: god punished job to prove a point to satan, and if people can't grasp the reasons for their suffering, they are probably either nonexisting or preposterous as they are in the case of job . basically the take away seems to be that sometimes, god is just a bully. phew, sorry about the rant, really needed to get this off my chest. anyways, i know that there are much more knowledgeable people than me in this sub, so i hope you can show me where i've completely missed the point which is probably the case and tell me why i'm wrong!
auto_conc: the story of job is a disempowering piece of literature
gt: the story of job illustrates the idea that it's just as important or even more so to stick to your morals in hard times as it is in good times. it also demonstrates kanye's age old axiom, 'to whom much is given, much is tested. '
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point of the book. it's a story of a man who is punished for his sins, but is not punished because of his sin. this is not the same as saying that god doesn't punish people because of their sin, but because of the fact that they are punished for their sin.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the whole point of the book. the book is a book about theodicy. it's not about god punishing job, it's about the idea that god is a jerk. it doesn't teach you how to be a jerk, it teaches you how not to be the jerk that you are. it tells you that god doesn't punish you for your sins, but that you should be punished for your actions. this is not true of any religion, but it is true of all religions.
auto_conc_attacks: i think the book is a disempowering piece of literature. i think it's important to realize that it's not just about the book, it's about the world.

conclusion: I believe that it is both a waste of resources and unjustifiably selfish to have children in these times. I would go so far as to say its immoral.
premises: i got into an argument with someone over my opinion today, and they weren t able to articulate a convincing counter argument so i m wondering if one of you might be able to. my thinking is thus: we are living in an era of upheaval and political unrest all around the globe. we are just beginning to feel the effects of global warming and climate change, and in the years to come the effects will become even more dramatic. the planet is overpopulated. and it s been estimated that there are 153 million orphans around the world who need homes. if you simply must have a child, adopt one of the many who need a family. with all that said, what incentive is there for having a biological child? some people want to have a child that shares their dna, that looks like them, that will continue their lineage. and i m sorry, but in my book that s just plain old fashioned selfishness. why do you think you re so special? it s that kind of limited, self centered thinking that has gotten us to a crisis point as a planet. once all the orphans in the world have been adopted, and we ve turned back the clock on global warming and overpopulation, then maybe it ll be acceptable to procreate again. there was a point in human history where we needed to procreate so that the species would survive. now the opposite seems to be true we need to not procreate if we want to survive. i realize this is a very emotional subject for a lot of people. but really, why would you do that when you could adopt a child in need? for the sake of our planet and our species. can someone can come up with a different argument, that can withstand the scrutiny of logic?

auto_conc: it s selfish to have a child when you could adopt.
gt: second overpopulation thing i've seen on here today the planet is not overpopulated. we haven't even begun to hit the limits of how many people we can sustain with the space and arable land available we haven't even hit the limits of how many humans we can sustain with our current agricultural output, starvation only exists because of economic reasons ukraine makes enough bread to feed the world, and america enough corn to do so several times over . the idea that we're overpopulated comes from outdated victorian ideas, the overcrowding of cities, and the destruction of habitats. cities are overcrowded because there are economic incentives to move to cities and it is difficult for urban planners to keep up with the influx. habitats are destroyed for farmland, yes, but those farms produce food that goes to the meat industry and things like syrups and those farms only exist because the countries involved want to build up an agricultural industry, just going by the numbers they're unnecessary . food that tastes good is inefficient to make, basically. it is more expensive to adopt an orphan than conceive a child, and is difficult to do my oboe teacher adopted a child, apparently the paperwork was insane . adopting of orphans is moral, but that's a different assertion than procreating right now is immoral.

gt: fetuses don't achieve viability outside of the womb even after they are born. humans specifically baby humans are really weak on their own. they need at least one adult to care for them. so should we be able to neglect fetuses after they are born too? most people don't think so. most people consider it wrong to leave a baby in a trash can. the argument against this, that i can imagine, is that someone else can take care of the child after it is born after roughly 6 months of pregnancy. however, why is there a compelling interest to taking care of the child? most people don't want to adopt. why don't we just leave the orphans on the street to fend for themselves? overall, you always have a choice for everything. if i decide to cheat on my wife, that is my choice. if i decide to speed, it's my choice. if i decide to kill someone, that's my choice. the main argument is, is the fetus human alive, is killing something that is human alive wrong? personally i'm fine with killing things. i eat meat, i'm fine with kill shelters, with animal testing etc. however, i value human life. there is a religious reason i have for valuing human life. i believe that humans are made in god's image and that other animals are given to us, with our dominion over them. we shouldn't kill animals recklessly because we have dominion, but it is amoral whether or not an animal dies. however, i think it is moral whether or not a human is killed or not. if you are not religious, then according to the atheistic logic that makes sense to me, you get to define what is right and wrong. so you decide if human lives are moral or not, whether animal lives are moral or not, whether plant lives are moral or not. if you aren't deciding for yourself, then you are deciding from a relativist cultural standpoint i'm assuming you aren't, but i'll cover it just in case . if this is the case, then it is legally acceptable in america and it is something that is hidden. don't ask, don't tell. you only risk cultural shame by mentioning it which is why i'm assuming you aren't talking about relativism .

conclusion: In no academic institution, including grade school, should there ever be such a thing as mandatory attendance. If a person can pass without ever having to show up to class, they should be allowed to do so.
premises: now, for starters, i'm not a big fan of our educational systems, but since i cannot offer a better practical alternative for the time being, let's speak in context of the current systems that are commonplace across most countries today. let's keep it simple, and we'll address any complexities as they arise in the comments. with regard our current standardized educational systems, the majority of schools and universities require that a student be present for a certain percentage of lectures in order to pass the course. imo, this is pure fucking bullshit; regardless of whether a student is in middle school, high school, under grad or post grad. plenty of the courses that i've been required to maintain an attendance rate of 85 of over the years have been a complete waste of time, and i could have been utilizing my time better doing countless other things. i just don't understand what the point is in having students attend the courses when they don't feel like doing so. interested in hearing different views on the matter.

auto_conc: Attendance should not be a requirement to pass a course.
gt: well first it's important to know why some states created laws to begin with. in washington it is mandatory to attend school because of a bill called the becca bill. becca was a girl who was taken and killed. despite being gone for weeks, her school never informed anyone that she stopped showing up. the state decided that parents shouldn't be solely responsible for making sure kids are safe, so they created the bill. i work at a school and we must report when kids stop coming or regularly don't attend. usually, yes it's lack of motivation for various reasons, but sometimes it's family or community factors they can't control and letting the courts know about their absences can start the ball rolling in getting the student help. sometimes kids don't come because of abuse, neglect, drug addiction their own or parents . if you took away the legality to attend school, you'd no longer have this safety net.

conclusion: Climate change should be the the focus in upcoming elections.
premises: as nations and individuals we really need to act quickly in order to limit the damage. i know saying 'should' can be the wrong word to use but i believe it would would show the candidate to be corrupt or ignorant if they don't address the issue. there are many issues that face us as a society, but climate change is the one most likely to threaten our core way of life if nothing is done. it is on the same level as the threat of global nuclear war, which rightfully received this kind of attention during the cold war when it was especially likely.

gt: william nordhaus just earned the nobel prize in economics for his work on climate change. if you want to get deep into his work here is a link and some notes: the international target for climate change with a limit of 2 c appears to be infeasible with reasonably accessible technologies a target of 2 c is technically feasible but would require extreme virtually universal global policy measures moreover, notwithstanding what may be called the rhetoric of nations, there has been little progress in taking strong policy measures. for example, of the six largest countries or regions, only the eu has implemented national climate policies, and the policies of the eu today are very modest link 2 the study estimates that the scc is 31 per ton of co2 we show a calculation for constraining temperature to a 2 c limit in two cases: one with a hard cap of 2 c, and the second where that cap is for an average of 100 y rather than a single period. the sccs for the two limit cases are 184 and 107 per ton of co2 amp; x200b;nordhaus' research indicates that holding a 2 c target which is even higher than the new ipcc recommendation of 1. 5 or 2 would cost 184 per ton where the scc is only 31. this does not say that the cost is 0, but that it is overall more expensive to attempt to hold these stated numbers.

conclusion: X-Men is a bad and potentially dangerous metaphor for the LGBT struggle
premises: see, anyone can have lgbt experiences, and what is doing the harm is the categorization of people into neat boxes that you can use to oppress them. boxes that, at the end of the day, don't reflect the reality and the diversity of people's experiences. i think it's better to focus on the fact that the lines people draw in order to be able to oppress marginalized people are inherently blurry, and that you can't effectively separate people into those who you want to oppress and those who are immune. in the case of lgbt people, how strong should your attraction to the same sex be or to what extent should your gender identity not align with the one you were assigned at birth, in order to be excluded from the lgbt community? it's better to be inclusive than to try and accept the boxes that society puts us in. but being a mutant is different. you either are or aren't a mutant. there are no half ass powers. mutants and non mutants are different enough for a legitimate case to be made for separatism. this idea of separatism, that we're so different from non queer people that they're not allowed in our spaces, is something that i see gaining popularity these days, and i honestly feel like it could be dangerous, and it could exclude people who need our help most, young and questioning people who don't immediately adopt a queer identity as a lot of us do.
argument: X-Men is a bad and potentially dangerous metaphor for the LGBT struggle : see, anyone can have lgbt experiences, and what is doing the harm is the categorization of people into neat boxes that you can use to oppress them. boxes that, at the end of the day, don't reflect the reality and the diversity of people's experiences. i think it's better to focus on the fact that the lines people draw in order to be able to oppress marginalized people are inherently blurry, and that you can't effectively separate people into those who you want to oppress and those who are immune. in the case of lgbt people, how strong should your attraction to the same sex be or to what extent should your gender identity not align with the one you were assigned at birth, in order to be excluded from the lgbt community? it's better to be inclusive than to try and accept the boxes that society puts us in. but being a mutant is different. you either are or aren't a mutant. there are no half ass powers. mutants and non mutants are different enough for a legitimate case to be made for separatism. this idea of separatism, that we're so different from non queer people that they're not allowed in our spaces, is something that i see gaining popularity these days, and i honestly feel like it could be dangerous, and it could exclude people who need our help most, young and questioning people who don't immediately adopt a queer identity as a lot of us do.
auto_conc: people in the LGBT community need to accept that everyone is different, and stop trying to categorize people into neat boxes.
gt: as a fan of x men i agree with you that it's a dangerous parallel to draw. i feel like the whole point of x men was to show that powers is not what defines us as people, and it's our actions that define us as individuals. as should real life, i don't care what your orientation is as long as you're a nice guy i'll treat you nicely. however the struggle between the x men and magnito as shown in the movies is how the lgbt community want to be seen so that's how they're going to see it. it's a good metaphor becuse in the movies it shows a group of people that are mistreated becuse they are different and becuse people don't understand them. although thats not how i see things it's how the community sees them. they see it as a 'they don't understand us because they aren't us' which is a dangerous idea to have becuse of how it turns out in the movies and the comics but it is a valid one for what they beleive in. so i'm not saying they're right, but it does seem like a perfect parallel to how they feel. and all we really want is to understand each other so we can figure out where to proceed, but if they don't draw that line like magneto then they're afraid the community will be destroyed.
masked_conc_attacks: i think it's important to recognize that the lgbt community is a group of people who are different from the rest of society. it's a group, not a group. it is a collection of people that are different than the rest. there are people who have different experiences, but are different because of their race, gender, sexuality, etc. and that's okay. i don't think it is fair to categorize people into neat boxes that don't reflect the reality and the diversity of people's experiences. you can't categorize them into a bunch of neat boxes. you have to make sure that they are all the same, and that they all fit into the same category.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a good metaphor for the lgbt struggle, but i do think it is a bad metaphor for a trans struggle.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to categorize people into neat boxes. i think we should be able to separate people into groups of people who we want to oppress.

gt: i am an independent progressive. i've watched the democratic party bash progressives for years while paying lip service to social issues and being center to center right on foreign policy, wall street regulations, and especially on issues regarding all the money swirling around congress. the hot topic right now is how radical mainstream democrats are and how scary and new that is. mainstream democrats have been moving to the right for decades to appeal to moderates and to pad their pocketbooks, and only recently have started to shift back left when they finally started to realize the were losing more of their base than was being gained in new moderate voters. this isn't new, it's a return to a compromise second approach rather than compromise first, and is more aligned with the largest portions of their base. my point is, i'm still an independent progressive. i could have called myself a member of the democratic party the whole time and been more right than wrong on sheer percentage. hell, i'm probably 70 80 aligned at this point in the shift, at least with the rhetoric, and that's pretty damn high. but i'm not choosing a team, i'm not leaving myself open to be burned by another tactical shift, and most importantly i'm not raising money for the dnc to hoard it away or pay it out to candidates the people don't want. no, i will vote based on the policies that the men and women running align themselves with, and when that means i'm voting republican very rare, best example i have is the mayor of my town after years of a corrupt democrat or independent or third party unless it's the general election for president, i'm not interested in lighting that particular vote on fire so be it. you should figure out what's important to you and define yourself by that. your party isn't interested in you beyond your money and your vote. but you'll find individual candidates here and there who will be interested in your values and ideas, and they will fight for them. don't miss out on that because you're playing for the team. because i realize my comment can be seen as off topic. i disagree with you because you are the one who has labeled yourself, and the onus is on you to change that. people are justified in their assessment of you as a republican, because at minimum you are a benign accomplice to all the ideas republicans espouse. even if that isn't 100 accurate, nobody sees you fighting the monster from within, debating republicans on conservatism, fighting republicans when they are harmful to your sensibilities. they see you as accepting those things and they are justified in that because most of them have no way to see otherwise.

conclusion: Incels are suffering from mental health issues, but are being held to a double standard compared to other people who suffer from the same mental health issues.
premises: the mainstream opinion of what incels are is that they're violent misogynists. either violent in their actions, or that they entertain violent fantasies in their minds. and the reaction to that is 'they chose to feel this way about things, they don't deserve our help. ' they're selfish assholes. like the alek minassian tragedy. amp; x200b; but i can remember other similar tragedies, from as far back as columbine to as recently as aghdam's youtube assault, where people didn't react this way. instead of reacting with 'what a selfish asshole' the reaction was 'this person is clearly disturbed, not in their right mind, they snapped, they went wrong in the head, they're suffering from a deep personal anguish. if only someone could've helped them before this happened. amp; x200b; we don't condone the atrocities they commit, of course not. but when people like danny ledonne or aaron stark speak on the matter, the people suddenly wanna talk about how love is the answer and how you should reach out to the people who you think might need it. and that's how people reacted to most cases like this. and i don't yet see how these cases differ from cases like minassian or rodger. take cho's atrocities at virginia tech. he was also hateful. he also wrote manifestos fueled by his hate. he also entertained abhorrent, violent fantasies inflicted upon people who didn't deserve but somehow he saw fit to blame anyway. but the reaction wasn't 'cho was a selfish asshole. ' the reaction back then was 'cho wasn't in his right mind, someone should've helped him. ' or ricardo lopez, 'the bj rk stalker. ' incel before 'incel' was really a buzzword. like an incel, he was lonely. like an incel, he felt 'entitled' to a woman. like an incel, he saw fit to punish that woman for being with someone else, even though that woman didn't know he existed. and like an incel, he was very depressed and unhappy with life in general. and like many incels, he eventually ended up killing himself. and what happened? he wasn't seen as some piece of shit like minassian was. bj rk even mourned his passing. because she and many others understood that what he was doing was not acceptable, but his mind was too far gone for him to just stop doing it. amp; x200b; and it wasn't just cho or lopez or aghdam or the columbine kids. there's stack, there's huberty, there's a whole long list of them, who commit extreme unjustified acts, but somehow we're able to see the tortured existence inside. not being able to date bj rk is no reason to actively try and mutilate her. just like not having had sex is no reason to call for the enslavement of all women. but for lopez we understand that while his reasons are unjustified, something's wrong in his head that turns his loneliness into a reason to kill. so why can't we see that in minassian, or rodger, or the many other incels out there? and in aghdam's case, only just slightly before. how did our attitude towards mental health change so drastically between aghdam and minassian?

conclusion: CEO salaries should be tied to the wage of their lowest paid worker
premises: this provides a powerful incentive to a ceo to increase the 'value' of their company as it'll improve their stock. the downside of this is that it creates a massive wealth gap and enforces poor wage for low skill workers, with ceos making, in some cases, over 1000x minimum wage.
argument: CEO salaries should be tied to the wage of their lowest paid worker : this provides a powerful incentive to a ceo to increase the 'value' of their company as it'll improve their stock. the downside of this is that it creates a massive wealth gap and enforces poor wage for low skill workers, with ceos making, in some cases, over 1000x minimum wage.
auto_conc: Companies could use a UBI as a justification to offer lower wages.
gt: first of all, such a thing will immediately result in companies contracting out all the low paying duties. the ceo of a tech company is not going to be held back because the company employs one minimum wage parking lot attendant. hr will be contracted out too. only the employees driving the core revenue of the corporation would remain. now after all the support jobs are contracted out, let's look at two companies. one is the company that was contracted for the low end services of the first company. it's a big company contracting these services to lots of others. say it has 50,000 employees. you have a ceo managing a 50,000 person company and his salary is based on minimum wage. now let's look to that engineering company that contracted out its support jobs. all that's left is a few hundred engineers and managers, and the lowest paid person there makes 60,000 a year. this ceo of a small company is allowed to make over twice the salary of the ceo of the huge company. does that make sense? , finish this off. so now you're a talented ceo type and are looking for a job. you look at these two companies, and of course you're going to go for the engineering company since you can make more money. this will be happening across the nation, so in the end the most talented ceos will be running the high paid companies, and the companies employing most of the minimum wage workers will be run by the less talented ceos. do you think that is a good situation?
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that ceos make less than minimum wage, but i think it is fair to assume that they make more than minimum wages. i don't see how this is fair.
known_conc_attacks: i don't know what you're talking about, but i think it's worth considering. i don't think ceo salaries should be tied to the wages of their lowest paid worker. if they make 1000x minimum wage, then they should be able to increase the value of their company as it'll improve their stock value.
auto_conc_attacks: what if a ceo makes less than 1000x minimum wage?

auto_conc: I want to quit work and never return for the rest of my life
gt: consider finding work that is more fulfilling. it's absolutely true that many jobs are awful, and your plan actually sounds pretty good. there's absolutely nothing wrong with saving up and having an early retirement plan. however, once you have those ducks in a row, you may enjoy another kind of work. working, when you don't need to work, negates a number of downsides. you don't have to put up with crap, you can pick the work that seems most interesting, and if a job goes south, you can bail. if you want, you can start your own business, and explore something you enjoy with fairly few limits. it's a bit like having a hobby, but people take businesses seriously in a way that they don't take hobbyists. running a business can be basically a hobby if you want it to be, though. tl:dr: having to work sucks, but choosing to work can be amazing.

conclusion: If there is a universal gender wage gap, it is much smaller than reported.
premises: the commonly cited statistic is '77 on the man's dollar'. i don't think this is a fair evaluation, or evidence for widespread wage discrimination. there are tons of factors it doesn't account for. education, position, hours worked per week, willingness to demand a raise promotion, and willingness to relocate, to name a few. much of the above factors are choice. for example, out of the five best paying college majors, four are dominated by men. out of the five worst paying, four are dominated by women. is this discrimination? is there someone forcing women to choose poorly paying majors? no. a study by the american association for university women a clearly feminist organization found the wage gap to be not 23, but 6. 6 percent. it is entirely possible this is sexism. but it could be any number of other, unexplained reasons. despite what tumblr wants you to believe, there are differences between men and women. this doesn't mean that there aren't wage gaps in certain fields or that certain employers don't practice wage discrimination.
argument: If there is a universal gender wage gap, it is much smaller than reported. : the commonly cited statistic is '77 on the man's dollar'. i don't think this is a fair evaluation, or evidence for widespread wage discrimination. there are tons of factors it doesn't account for. education, position, hours worked per week, willingness to demand a raise promotion, and willingness to relocate, to name a few. much of the above factors are choice. for example, out of the five best paying college majors, four are dominated by men. out of the five worst paying, four are dominated by women. is this discrimination? is there someone forcing women to choose poorly paying majors? no. a study by the american association for university women a clearly feminist organization found the wage gap to be not 23, but 6. 6 percent. it is entirely possible this is sexism. but it could be any number of other, unexplained reasons. despite what tumblr wants you to believe, there are differences between men and women. this doesn't mean that there aren't wage gaps in certain fields or that certain employers don't practice wage discrimination.
auto_conc: I don't think the wage gap is real.
gt: it is factual that women make . 77 of what men make in america. sometimes, people suggest that if this can be 'explained' by things other than discrimination at the point of hiring, it doesn't 'count. ' for example, some of the pay gap can be attributed to child rearing practices. but in a market based society, a person's value and more concretely, their agency and power is fairly directly tied to the dollar amount at the bottom of their w 2. for this reason, the wage gap is a problem. it suggests that the lives that women lead are less valuable to society, or perhaps that they are not capable of much work that is more valuable. people who are interested in closing the wage gap envision a world where men and women share equally in the burdens and rewards of life where women have the economic and social power that men have traditionally held, and men have the domestic and family rewards that have traditionally been given to women.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think this is a fair evaluation, or evidence for widespread wage discrimination.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's important to note that this isn't a study of the gender wage gap, it's a study about the wage gap between men and women. a study by the american association for university women a clearly feminist organization found the gap to be not 23, but 6. 6 percent.
auto_conc_attacks: the wage gap is not real. it is a result of a lack of choice. there is a difference between men and women, and it is not because of choice, it is because of lack of opportunity.

conclusion: Souls don't exist
premises: one thing that i see everyone take for granted is the idea of 'souls'. the idea that everyone has a soul, and that it's distinct from our corporeal forms. usually people use it in reference to the afterlife or reincarnation but that's a religious debate and i just want to talk about who we are here on earth. there's no supernatural part of us that makes us unique. we all have consciousness , which is an interesting topic, but the answers to that question lie in philosophy and psychology and neuroscience, not spirituality. we don't understand everything about the brain but we know enough about it to detect and measure emotions, memories, and personality traits. if those things are determined by grey matter rather than a soul, then what exactly does a soul do? how is it a useful concept whatsoever? the interesting thing i find about this topic is that it's one in which everyone of all backgrounds and political stripes agrees and just assumes must be the case. conservative christians and spiritual chicks on tumblr both agree that we must have souls, despite there being literally no evidence to suggest that. i think it's time that we discarded that antiquated idea.
argument: Souls don't exist : one thing that i see everyone take for granted is the idea of 'souls'. the idea that everyone has a soul, and that it's distinct from our corporeal forms. usually people use it in reference to the afterlife or reincarnation but that's a religious debate and i just want to talk about who we are here on earth. there's no supernatural part of us that makes us unique. we all have consciousness , which is an interesting topic, but the answers to that question lie in philosophy and psychology and neuroscience, not spirituality. we don't understand everything about the brain but we know enough about it to detect and measure emotions, memories, and personality traits. if those things are determined by grey matter rather than a soul, then what exactly does a soul do? how is it a useful concept whatsoever? the interesting thing i find about this topic is that it's one in which everyone of all backgrounds and political stripes agrees and just assumes must be the case. conservative christians and spiritual chicks on tumblr both agree that we must have souls, despite there being literally no evidence to suggest that. i think it's time that we discarded that antiquated idea.
auto_conc: The concept of a "soul" is outdated and irrelevant.
gt: why do you think 'everyone' believes in souls? atheism, one of the fastest growing belief systems in the planet, typically doesn't provide for the existence of anything beyond the material. 'spiritual chicks on tumblr' and 'conservative christians' both share belief systems with a degree of mysticism and external non material parts of existence, in this particular area wouldn't a better mark of comparison be atheists or other areligious people? what do you think distinguishes 'souls' from 'consciousness'? what makes them distinct concepts to the extent that you don't consider them as the kernels of self awareness, critical thinking, and moral reasoning present in most human brains to be the same thing with different names?
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know what you mean by'soul', but i think it's important to remember that the idea of'souls' doesn't exist in the same way that the concept of 'consciousness' exists in the real world. it's not that we don't have a soul, it's that we have a concept of our own consciousness that we can use to understand our own thoughts and feelings. i don't think you can say that there is no supernatural part of us that makes us unique.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure if you're familiar with the concept of souls, but i think it's important to remember that there are a lot of people who believe that we have souls, and that we don't. i'm not going to try to change your view on this, because i don't think that's what you're trying to do here. you seem to think that there is a supernatural part of us that makes us unique, but that doesn't mean that it doesn't exist. i think you're missing the point of the idea of'souls' as a concept. there are plenty of people that believe that they have a soul, but they don't believe that there's a supernatural aspect to it.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're talking about, but i think it's important to understand what you mean by'soul.'i think you're confusing'souls' with 'i don't have a soul.'that's not the same thing as 'i have a brain. '

conclusion: People who say all politicians are the same/corrupt don't understand how corruption works, and are part of the problem.
premises: corruption, as any phenomenon occurring in a system governed by institutions, is a result of the incentives individuals within the organization are subject to. this enables a rabbit chase for 'the right' person, that will never really yield any results. even if we find an angel, it will ultimately be corrupted if the incentives are not right. instead of wasting energy on finding the right leader to whom a cult of personality is owed we should focus on designing systems where even devils are forced to act right. if having a functioning government was all about finding the right person, we would be doomed, as we can hardly tell what the real motivations and ideas of a given candidate are.
argument: People who say all politicians are the same/corrupt don't understand how corruption works, and are part of the problem. : corruption, as any phenomenon occurring in a system governed by institutions, is a result of the incentives individuals within the organization are subject to. this enables a rabbit chase for 'the right' person, that will never really yield any results. even if we find an angel, it will ultimately be corrupted if the incentives are not right. instead of wasting energy on finding the right leader to whom a cult of personality is owed we should focus on designing systems where even devils are forced to act right. if having a functioning government was all about finding the right person, we would be doomed, as we can hardly tell what the real motivations and ideas of a given candidate are.
auto_conc: The search for the right leader is a never-ending process.
gt: even if you had a system that would prevent corruption, who would prevent the elected people from corrupting that system? it s a bit of a chicken and egg scenario. people may be corrupt going in, or just get corrupted once there. power or access to power will inevitably draw corruption to it. systems are never better than the participants in those systems and they require people to enforce the system. people are corruptible. chicken and egg.
masked_conc_attacks: the problem with this is that it doesn't make sense to have a functioning government. if you want to have an effective government, you have to have the right people. the problem is that you don't want the government to be corrupt. you want it to be a government where people are free to do whatever they want with what they want. that doesn't mean that it should be corrupt, it just means that the government is corrupt.
known_conc_attacks: the problem with corruption is that it's not a result of the incentives individuals within the organization are subject to. it's a consequence of the fact that the incentives are not right.
auto_conc_attacks: the search for the right leader is a never-ending process. it's a never ending process.

conclusion: It is plausible that most jobs in North America and Europe are mostly bullshit most of the time, (inspired in part by David Graeber's thesis in Bullshit Jobs).
premises: he's just the messenger. as graeber points out, 'when someone describes his job as pointless or worthless, he is necessarily operating within some sort of tacit theory of value: an idea of what would be a worthwhile occupation, and therefore what is not. the assumption in modern culture is that markets assess some kind of quasi objective value through pricing. if your labor isn't that valuable, for example, you will be paid less. hundreds of people reported to graeber that they get paid very well to do what appears to be wholly without value to society many of whom work in finance, for example . we can also point to countless activities that are widely accepted as valuable that are unremunerated, like helping neighbors plant flowers, household chores, etc. also, despite being absolutely critical roles for the functioning of society, many careers like education and waste management do not pay very much, and if left to the market alone may not even get done further suggesting there is something off about the market driven theory of value. so on the one hand, we have markets saying the value of a job is worth x gt; 0, while on the other hand we have the people working the jobs themselves saying they're not worth anything at all to anyone. that said, markets are just as susceptible to human error as human beings themselves. think about con artists swindling people out of money. do we say the con artist produced a value to the person swindled just because they convinced them to give them their money? what if some guru or company convinced millions of people to flush some massive portion of their earnings down the toilet every year? because those choices are fundamentally individual choices, they would clearly constitute market choices. but would it be any sign that the real value of those people's decisions? people can and do waste their money. the thing is, many of our primary motivators in life make it difficult to see this kind of waste even when it's right under our noses. in addition, politicians are highly motivated to endorse the expansion of jobs irrespective of whether they produce value. their motivations stem in one part from the lack of saturation of theories about what makes a good life, and in another part because, again, currently the only way to stave off starvation for the people they represent is to get them jobs at all costs bernie sanders' guaranteed jobs plan ring any bells? and just in case you think companies who thrive and flourish in the competitive marketplace are exempt from this problem, consider the fact that our entire economy goes through cycles of boom and bust, with massive hirings and layoffs that indicate that even this system, several times over the course of an average human lifetime, is subject to the same managerial and administrative bloat that government institutions are often rightly charged with. efficiencies take time to develop, perhaps even requiring countless iterations of boom and bust, and bullshit will thrive wherever these efficiencies fail to manifest. now this all might seem like a digression from my claim, but i think it's essential to have in mind for its analysis. there's nothing particularly fancy about the argument. garbage collectors, teachers, nurses, physicians, architects, construction workers: if they ceased to exist, we would be in real trouble. physicians, for example, may spend gt;50 of their day sitting through bureaucratic meetings, and or ticking boxes on endless forms that could be automated away by technology. major researchers report being forced to spend more time on grant proposals than actually performing research or teaching students. so change my view. feel free to use your own experiences. but don't forget i am just making a plausibility claim, and given my extremely flexible definition of bullshit, if you even agree with the simple claim that there's a lot of bullshit in human decision making behavior in the harry frankfurt sense of bullshit , then you might already be a priori on my side. have a good labor day.

conclusion: Teachers Shouldnt Assign Homework.
premises: we students go to school 8 hours a day 5 days a week. then we have to spend more hours during our time off doing more school work when we should have been given time during class to do it. with the amount of homework i receive it s difficult to balance sports, school, homework, and spending time with friends and family and when im not doing hw im stressed out about when im going to find time to complete it. we spend 45 hours a week at school and dont get paid just to go home and have more time spent on hw when we could be doing something useful and fun. teachers should use time spent in class more useful rather than giving us tons of hw so cmv.
argument: Teachers Shouldnt Assign Homework. : we students go to school 8 hours a day 5 days a week. then we have to spend more hours during our time off doing more school work when we should have been given time during class to do it. with the amount of homework i receive it s difficult to balance sports, school, homework, and spending time with friends and family and when im not doing hw im stressed out about when im going to find time to complete it. we spend 45 hours a week at school and dont get paid just to go home and have more time spent on hw when we could be doing something useful and fun. teachers should use time spent in class more useful rather than giving us tons of hw so cmv.
auto_conc: I believe that school is a waste of students' time
gt: i'm a teacher and have been for 7 years. i've taught abroad, in a rich private school and at a large urban public high school. when i taught abroad my students came into my class and worked hard for the hour i saw them. we got through a ton of stuff. the jokes and off topic banter was minimal during class and this lead to much more work which is math in my class . i had 11th graders taking the ap calculus test and getting 4s and 5s. when i taught at a rich private school it was similar. i thought middle school and the kids were much younger and less serious, but they came to work. if they were out of line i'd contact the folks and get them in line. we got through algebra 1 quickly and effectively. in both instances i assigned minimal homework. 5 10mins 3 days a week. at my public high school there are seniors in algebra 1 alongside incredibly bright freshman. the fresh show up on time and do work but the class is often derailed by those seniors who stroll in late, take forever to get started, sarcastically respond to me and barely do shit. i wish i could get through everything in the class period allotted but the simple fact that we structure class like this and don't offer a tract for less academically skilled kids to veer off and achieve in a different i am left managing kids. this takes time. a lot of time. i'm good with classroom management and i actively engage my lowest performing kids so they can muster a good grade instead of a 12 or something equally poor. but it is time consuming and difficult to explain a concept to a reluctant 12 grader over the course of an hour when that same freshman learned it in 5 minutes. this means there's a lot of review, many different ways to express the same topic, hands on examples, activities to keep them off of their phones and on the work. i give homework for two reasons: 1. to get those kids that need help to do work independently so i can see what they need to work on. analysis. 2. to push those other kids that should work independently and move ahead.
masked_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i don't think that teachers should give students more time off to do homework. they should give them more time to do other things.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point of education. it's one of the most important things in life. you have to be able to do what you want to do with your time, and you're not going to get a whole lot of time off. you're going to have to deal with the fact that you don't have time to do something useful and fun, and that's going to cost you a lot of money. if you can't do that, then it's not worth it.
auto_conc_attacks: i think it's important to realize that there are a lot of people who don't like school. it's not a waste of time, it's just a way of life.

conclusion: All men are potential rapists
premises: the fact is that the only thing that keeps people from doing 'bad' things like stealing, killing, raping, etc. is the fear of the law. more specifically, the fear of being punished. if you could get away with anything what would you do? you're lying to yourself if you think you would still act like the upstanding citizen you are. absolute power corrupts absolutely. if you had the power to do anything and get away with no punishment, you would do unspeakable things. the law is only thing that keeps men from raping. certain species of animals have been known to rape. it is not out of the question to say that rape is human nature. history has proven this. what happens when soldiers can get away with anything? you get the rape of naking. the rape of berlin. go back even further in ancient times when rape would occur during the sacking and looting towns villages. furthermore, why was martial rape legal for so long? why do we still live in a rape culture? if humans had a innate sense of good evil, none of this should be. clearly morality is not objective, but is based on what society wants. society has chosen that rape is wrong, and has ingrained that in us ever since we're young. but really, it is in man's nature to rape. this logic does not just apply to men. it's just that in lawless states it doesn't happen this way. has there ever been a female on male version of nanking? also the reason i focus on rape is because people generally admit they would steal money if they could get away with it. rape is a more touchy subject though.

conclusion: Aerial wiring is superior to underground wiring
premises: that means, it can't be made on already established settlements, almost nobody is willing to get their garden ruined to get the wires installed. ugw only works for new settlements. ugw is inappropriate for earthquake zones. that's why japan still uses power posts. ugw may be a problem for regions with underground rodents basically everywhere if you include rats . rodents like to gnaw stuff and squirrels cause a lot of blackouts in the us. not recommended for countries with corrupt politics.

gt: anyone can know 'what' something is, but it's important to understand 'why' so you can make informed decisions about it in the proper context. the 'why' is the context and backstory. we know that darth vader is the right hand man of the emperor. luke knows this. this is the 'what'. but luke allows himself to be captured and taken before the emperor because he knows the 'why', i. e. , the context. he knows that darth vader was once anikin skywalker, his father, and that he was the student of obi wan kanobi. from this he surmises that he was good once, and there may still be some good in him, meaning he can turn from the dark side to the light. basically, luke knew darth vader's history , and was able to make decisions knowing the proper context. this is why knowing your history is important. darth vader is a fictional example, but the principle holds.

conclusion: The current state of too many debates about race is sad and irrelevant
premises: and by 'not caring' i don't mean that we shouldn't care about racism issues or racist actions politics speech; i mean living your life and making decision without caring about the race of people around you or your race. there are so many debates currently about 'can white people say nigga', 'is it okay for a white little girl to dress as moana', i even saw on this subreddit 'it is morally okay for a white person to have dreadlocks'. it's such a waste of time to teach what people can or cannot do based on their race, i'm pretty sure we would look ridiculous when debatting this in the eyes of a racism free society. a little girl wants to dress as moana for halloween, come on leave the poor girl alone, who cares. socially speaking, you would even be morally wrong to be 'colorblind' for a lot of people today. i mean, if in your personal life you were physically unable to aknowledge race imagine a rare disease where you can't recognize any race you only see humans , chances are that you could still be accused of racism. to cmv, it would need to convince me that focusing so much about what can do this or that race isn't just ridiculous and has benefits or isn't ridiculous.
argument: The current state of too many debates about race is sad and irrelevant : and by 'not caring' i don't mean that we shouldn't care about racism issues or racist actions politics speech; i mean living your life and making decision without caring about the race of people around you or your race. there are so many debates currently about 'can white people say nigga', 'is it okay for a white little girl to dress as moana', i even saw on this subreddit 'it is morally okay for a white person to have dreadlocks'. it's such a waste of time to teach what people can or cannot do based on their race, i'm pretty sure we would look ridiculous when debatting this in the eyes of a racism free society. a little girl wants to dress as moana for halloween, come on leave the poor girl alone, who cares. socially speaking, you would even be morally wrong to be 'colorblind' for a lot of people today. i mean, if in your personal life you were physically unable to aknowledge race imagine a rare disease where you can't recognize any race you only see humans , chances are that you could still be accused of racism. to cmv, it would need to convince me that focusing so much about what can do this or that race isn't just ridiculous and has benefits or isn't ridiculous.
auto_conc: I don't think we should care so much about race.
gt: saying that you 'don't see color' minimizes and dismisses the fact that race significantly impacts a person's life. it is also inaccurate because everyone sees race and reacts subconsciously to it whether they believe they do or not. for example, the implicit association test has consistently shown that the majority of people including people of color subconsciously associate white people with positive characteristics and black people with negative ones. this has real life implications in social institutions ranging from the fact that black people tend to receive harsher sentences for the same crime as a white person, to the fact that students of color in schools are disciplined with exclusionary discipline suspension, expulsion at a higher rate than white students. being 'colorblind' is simply not an option until we achieve an equitable society.

auto_conc_attacks: let me ask you this: do you care about race? if so, why would you care? if you care, then why should you care so much about racism?

conclusion: I don't see how morality can be objective
premises: it's abstract. unless you believe rational thoughts can appear without any humans present, it's subjective. the reason things like trees are objective is because if you were to kill every human, the tree would still be there. but you can't say the same for something that exists in head. so yeah, that's my argument. i'd prefer no theological attempts at changing my view god exists and his morals are objective because that'd completely shift the focus of the discussion, and i'm an apatheist.
argument: I don't see how morality can be objective : it's abstract. unless you believe rational thoughts can appear without any humans present, it's subjective. the reason things like trees are objective is because if you were to kill every human, the tree would still be there. but you can't say the same for something that exists in head. so yeah, that's my argument. i'd prefer no theological attempts at changing my view god exists and his morals are objective because that'd completely shift the focus of the discussion, and i'm an apatheist.
auto_conc: I don't believe in an all-knowing and all-seeing.
gt: i generally believe that morality is subjective for the most part, but i think it is possible to construct a non theological framework for objective morality. tell me if you disagree with my definition of morality, but i'm going to use one of the first ones i found with a quick search: a system of ideas of right and wrong conductthe first step is to decide on some goals, some purpose for having morality. this step is a bit subjective, but i think theoretically you could come up with a few baseline points that a large amount of people could agree with for example, we want a system of morality that minimizes suffering, while maximizing enjoyment and quality of life. all of those terms might have to be defined a bit better, but lets imagine we sit down with a bunch of people and decide on some metrics that we can agree on to determine quality of life, suffering, etc. at this point, i think i can believe that there is some objectively optimal morality that we could choose to adopt, which if we all followed would fit the criteria layed out in the previous step. without a god to deliver that morality to us, we might not ever discover it, and even less likely that everyone would choose to follow it, but it probably exists, independent of whether we know about it or not.
masked_conc_attacks: what do you mean by objective?
known_conc_attacks: you can't say the same for something that exists in head. it doesn't matter if it exists in your head or not. if you were to kill every human, the tree would still be there.
auto_conc_attacks: you can't say the same for something that exists in head. you can't claim that something exists in your head.

conclusion: James Cameron's Avatar is Underrated
premises: but by now the circlejerk about 'pocahontas in space' or 'fern gully in space' or 'dances with wolves in space' have come so far that i feel that this movie has gone around to being pretty dang underrated. let's knock that first big criticism right off the bat: yes. the plot is derivative. but to be honest, there are a lot of derivative movies out there, so i don't think that's as huge a knock against the movie as other people do. and honestly, the plot structure makes a lot of sense: you have a big crazy world you've developed, what's the best way to get the audience to appreciate it? take an audience proxy character and put them through a protracted fish out of water narrative. now on to the movie's good points firstly, it's one of the only movies, and especially one of the only not completely animated movies, to get a really really good result out of 3d. i've seen the movie 4 times since it came out in 2009: twice in theaters, and twice seeing the extended cut at home protip: the extended cut really does improve the plot quite a bit . and if it came back into theaters in 3d, i would watch the hell out of it in that format, and i'm not normally one to shell out extra for movies in 3d secondly, the movie is technically and visually very well executed outside of 3d: the creatures are all interesting and cool; the ecosystem is dramatic and visually stimulating, mixing tropical rainforest, influences from undersea structures, and karst style rock formations; the near future style human technology is all interesting and gives a good sense of purpose and feels used and lived in. the opening interstellar spaceship did the really cool semi plausible long distance spaceship design that the martian did, but years before that film. and to be honest, the cast is pretty excellent, especially in the roles they're given. stephen lang is awesome as a villainous version of r. lee ermey rip gunny . michelle rodriguez continues to do michelle rodriguez things, which imho is never bad, though it's always a little bit campy. sigourney weaver is good. sam worthington and zoe saldana are both pretty decent as well. so yeah, i think the 'derivative plot' circlejerk has gotten so strong that people ignore the good things about a movie that did a few things wrong and a lot of things right. i don't think it's a 10 10 movie, but it's a solid and entertaining film that stands up to rewatching.

gt: it's not underrated if anything it's overrated. for being the highest grossing film of all time i doubt there's been anyone thats seen the movie more than a couple of times. good movies are ones you can watch whenever and are gone back to repeatedly. avatar isn't really the movie for that. i'm on mobile so i can't find this article, but there was one that polled people on how much of avatar they remember and it was a large amount of people not remembering a large portion of the movie. personally i think it's gorgeous, but the content of the movie its pretty forgettable.

auto_conc_attacks: i don't think the movie is derivative, but i do think it's a good movie.

conclusion: Contemporary Feminism is sexist
premises: ok so first of i think of everyone as equal and i don't think any race or gender is better then the rest. it's sexist for both men and woman actually. so they get stuff handed to them. a small example of this is a female adaptation for every movie. if hollywood was truely feminist they would make their own movie with a female lead that is both empowering to woman and actually a good movie. now on the male end of this. so a man can't make a valid point without being called priveleged white scum or what have you. yes i know all men aren't white but you see my point. i truely think it's coming from a good place. however they need to become more self aware and realize they are who they hate. so yeah that's it. change my view
argument: Contemporary Feminism is sexist : ok so first of i think of everyone as equal and i don't think any race or gender is better then the rest. it's sexist for both men and woman actually. so they get stuff handed to them. a small example of this is a female adaptation for every movie. if hollywood was truely feminist they would make their own movie with a female lead that is both empowering to woman and actually a good movie. now on the male end of this. so a man can't make a valid point without being called priveleged white scum or what have you. yes i know all men aren't white but you see my point. i truely think it's coming from a good place. however they need to become more self aware and realize they are who they hate. so yeah that's it. change my view
auto_conc: i think men are always the "bad guys" in society.
gt: the best way that i ve been able to describe modern feminism is with the analogy of a race. normally, everyone begins at the same starting block, and when the gun goes off, everyone goes on a runnin. however, due to inequality, there are very few races in the world that have everyone on equal footing, if they could even be let in to start the race in the first place. in short, some racers don t even get to start at the start. in this specific case, we ll focus on women. the first wave of feminism brought western women up toward the starting line a whole bunch! the right to vote, divorce, etc, moved women s rights forward and gave them more of a fighting chance at equity. however, they still were not starting as far forward as men. next game advancements in attitudes toward female sexuality and reproductive freedom, equality in the workplace, each step bringing women a bit closer to the starting line. however, we are still not there. now, let s tackle modern examples that you ve given, like female representation in the media. this is, to some including me , a comparatively small step forward when it comes to getting to the starting line. however, it is still a step forward. think about it from the prospective of women in this race we see ourselves pushing closer and closer to the starting line, more and more toward equity. some people may see this, however, as their chance at the proverbial first place being threatened. technically, yeah. the more people there are in the game, the more likely someone else will win out. however, this is where i like to make things a bit bigger picture. yes, human nature is self preservation. we want the best for ourselves, and this is not always a bad instinct. however, it s entirely possible to want the best for yourself and want the best for others as well. that is why feminism has also fought to ensure that male rape victims are treated fairly in society and in law, that fathers have an equal chance in custody cases if they choose to pursue it, that men do not suffer from the same generalisations and stereotypes that harm women. i will not deny that every movement has its fringes that must be challenged when they make harmful statements, generalisations, and accusations. feminism is no different. however, it still holds the equity of sexes at its heart, and that means getting everyone to the same starting line. cassini.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a good idea to make a movie with a female lead. i think it would be better to make it with a male lead than a female one.
known_conc_attacks: what do you mean by 'white scum'? i think it's sexist for men and women to get stuff handed to them. i don't think any race or gender is better then the rest.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's sexist for men to be the 'bad guys' in society.

conclusion: I don't believe that 'non-binary' or 'genderfluid' people is a real thing, and that the people who claim these things are mostly doing so because it's trendy.
premises: i want to preface this by saying that i'm not anti gay, or anti trans, or anything like that so that's not what i mean when i say this.
argument: I don't believe that 'non-binary' or 'genderfluid' people is a real thing, and that the people who claim these things are mostly doing so because it's trendy. : i want to preface this by saying that i'm not anti gay, or anti trans, or anything like that so that's not what i mean when i say this.
auto_conc: I'm starting to think I'm anti-gay.
gt: i'm bisexual, fully down the middle. there are different 'roles' that women are expected to play in relation to their sexuality. straight women are expected to be coy and reject male advances to prove their 'worth', which is trash, and leaves me feeling ashamed about my body, sexual desire, and sense of self. gay women are expected me to resent all things straight, which leaves me feeling ashamed about my body, sexuality, and sense of self. obviously these are generalizations, but they run deep and have had real effects on my life. the reasons that i'm mentioning this is because people always make assumptions based on gender, and being bisexual made me hyperaware of this. i tried to kill myself at 14 because the thought of becoming a woman not physically but socially was unthinkable. so, yea for me there's something deeper than 'i can use this to look cool'. side note: people are surprised i choose to be nongender because i'm i've got a 'classic' female body ie 5'8'', white, big tits, small waist, blond hair, blue eyes. i think the reason me as nongender confuses folk is because they, like you, connect nongender to 'desperate' gay lesbians who are confused about their identity, or people wanting to be 'trendy'. just because can easily and perfectly fit into the idea of what 'femininity' should be doesn't make it any less toxic.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. i don't think it's fair to say that you're anti gay, or anti trans, or anything like that. i think that it's unfair to say you aren't anti trans.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'conclusion', but i think you're missing the point. there are a lot of people who claim to be 'nonbinary' or 'genderfluid' people, and i think that's a good thing. however, i think it's important to note that not all of the people claiming to be nonbinary or genderfluid are doing so because it's trendy. for example, i'm not anti gay, or anti trans, or anything like that. i'm anti transgender, but i'm also anti cisgender.
auto_conc_attacks: what do you mean by 'anti gay' or 'anti trans'?

conclusion: People who had abusive non-supportive parents do not have the same chance at success as people born into good circumstances.
premises: hello all! this is my first cmv post, and i'd like to start by saying i would really like it if my view ends up being changed! to be clear, i define success as personal self actualization and fulfillment, not necessarily as wealth. however, being abale to attain a living wage and pay into a savings account seems like a reasonable part of this definition. they will not be able to learn as much from the curriculum and from the social aspects of school. they likely have no good role models growing up model support, self love, kindness, and emotionally intelligent behaviors. as an adult, they will have to teach themselves these things, if they can. while their peers might feel confidence and trust in themselves as adults, children who grew up without support come into adulthood without these positive attributes. they are more likely to make mistakes like engaging in destructive behavior that will set them back even further. without having someone support them in creating positive experiences when they were are young, it is up to luck to create positive experiences that build self esteem and self trust. the thinking they grew up with and lack of properly fostered self esteem will cause them to feel limited in what they are capable of. they will be very likely to close themselves off to oppurtunities thinking they can't do it. the pattern of failure started in childhood is mostly beyond their control.

conclusion: Star Wars the Last Jedi is bad except for in visuals.
premises: warning: this post will contain spoilers for tlj. if you hadn t watched it and don t want it be spoiled, then click off this post now. you have been warned now, i am of the camp, who, gasp, wasn t a big fan of tlj. now unlike most people i can see some good in it, and i think that those few good points are what makes up the positive camp. so this why tlj is not good. 1. that has to do with the character rey. rey is a mary sue sue . she is great at everything she tries. she s an amazing pilot, mechanic, gunslinger, jedi, force user, who can stand toe to toe and even beat much more experienced jedi and sith lords. now, in fa, i was able to ignore it more due to the fact that i thought that it would be revealed in lj, that she was connected to someone or something important. in tlj, it s decided that her backstory, that thing teased about by jj abrams and his mystery box, is unimportant. she s just the child of some drunk hobos. she s a no one. this infuriates me. there is no reason this character should be this powerful without any training. it took luke months before he became a tenth as powerful as her. ben spent all of his life training with a jedi legend, easily defeated by a girl who didn t think the force was real just a few days ago. it also doesn t help that rey expresses less that the lovechild of bella swan and jimmy stewart. i mean, does she even smile in this movie. at all. 2. another hole in wall do even have to state this. superman leia are so many plot holes in this movie. so. instead of talking about them in long ranting detail, i will just create a list. 1. how did the order get everyone together. 2. where did they get the resources to fund them. 3. why didn t holdor tell them about the plan. she risked a mutiny because she didn t tell them about it. 4. how did the hacker know that they were using escape pods. 5. how do spaceships run out of fuel. this is the first time we ve heard about this risk. 6. why didn t the fuel up earlier. 7. how do bombs fall in 0 gravity. 8. why did ben kill his master. wasn t the point of killing his dad to prove his loyalty to him. 9. why would luke create a map to him if he wanted to be left alone. 10. if lightspeed could destroy a ship like that, why didn t one x wing flying into the death star in iv and cut it in half. 11. when did luke get the jedi texts. 12. how did luke die? 13. how can leia fly through space! ? ! 3. clutter my third big problem with the movie was that it felt cluttered. new important characters have been introduced into the movie that we have never heard of and for the most part didn t care about. rose: token asian who adds nothing to the plot. she only exists to be the token. holdor: she could ve should ve been replaced by admiral akbar and the movie would have been better for it. dj: hacker who could have been interesting had he been given more time on screen. only character you will actually even passingly care about. now. many might argue that i am being heavily judgmental. here is my proof that these characters suck. quote one line they said. any line. this movie is also very cluttered, despite being near 2 hours and thirty minutes. this is mostly due to the casino plot point. it was mostly a drag and a bore. they spend multiple minutes talking about how capitalism is evil. in my opinion, instead of the c plot, we could should have seen a rise of factionalism rise in the resistance. with no cleat leader, many pretenders, and faction groups rise. some thinking they should flee and regroup later. and others saying that they should stay the course. that would have been much more interesting than the bland casino scene. 4. deus ex machina and a lavk of this is my 4th and last problem with it. that and they fail to answer the real questions we have. why can leia fly? she just can. she s just chosen. how does rey learn the force so quickly? cuz movie. how do they know the rebels are escaping in the pods. cuz movie. questions we wanted answered. who s snoke? who cares. who re rey s parents? i dunno, junkies? how did fin join the stormtroopers? who cares! how does luke use to force to project himself? who cares. who were the knights of rin? who cares. in summary the biggest problem is that the movie fails to give us satisfying answers to the biggest questions and fails to create compelling stories or characters. so, cmv that tlj is bad.
