gt: i will disagree somewhat. pretty much all those issues can be papered over, or have reasonably sounding answers. the problem with the movie to me is more straightforward: it fails in its execution. i can believe rey is an amazingly powerful and competent individual but the movie failed to convince me that this makes sense. i can believe holdo might have had reasons to conceal information but the movie failed to convince me of this. i can believe leia could have jedi powers but the movie failed to set this up. i can believe luke could have had a moment of doubt instanity fear and considered killing ben for a second but the movie failed to give a proper reason. that, to me is what it all comes down to. the various problems are not necessarily inherently nonsensical or horrible. they could have worked if well done. the problem is that the movie failed at making them work. to give an example: the idea is that the movie has a theme of failure. but it never actually goes through with it. poe gets a lot of people killed and nothing happens really. nobody bashes his face in for killing their friends. nobody resists his mutiny because he's a maverick that already screwed up before. nobody demands him to be shot out of an airlock. he feels zero guilt at getting lots of people killed. holdo seems to feel zero guilt at how her handling of the situation resulted in a lot of deaths. the movie doesn't actually go through with what the actual results of those failures would be. if you're going to write a whole movie around failure, you have to actually do it, not chicken out instantly.
masked_conc_attacks: i think rey is the most important character in tlj. she is a great pilot, mechanic, gunslinger, jedi, and even beat much more experienced jedi and sith lords. she can stand toe to toe, but she can't beat a lot of jedi. she's the only one who can even beat a jedi without training.
known_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i don't think it's really a good movie. i think that rey is a great pilot, mechanic, gunslinger, and force user. i do think that her backstory is unimportant in the movie, but in the end, she's the only one who really knows anything about the force. she's not a force user, but she does know that the force is real, and she knows that it's going to be a real thing. she doesn't know anything about it, she just knows that she has to learn how to use it. she does not know what the force actually is, but that doesn't mean that she knows it's real.
auto_conc_attacks: i think that you're missing the point of the movie. it's a good movie, but it's not a good film because it's kind of boring.

conclusion: It should be illegal to be a billionaire
premises: when i say that, i mean that billionaires should be required to give enough money to charity or something similar so that they're no longer billionaires. in fact, i think that this should apply to anyone with 10 million usd, but i'm just going to focus on billionaires feel free to tell me why i'm wrong to extend this to people with 10 million usd though . the reason for this is pretty obvious: they have too much money to make meaningful use out of and yet there are people who make too little money for an adequate life. almost three years. to run out of money buying something every day that most people can't buy in their lifetime. according to this oxfam article in 2017 the eight richest people have as much money as the poorer half of the world. that's a huge imbalance! imagine how many lives they would save or improve if they gave away their wealth!

auto_conc: I think that all billionaires should be forced to give away a significant portion of their wealth.
gt: the rich keep money to themselves but it only affects themselves. if you take out the richest and redistribute all their money, all you'll do is create an economical imbalance that results in money being valued less. 10 will be worth the same as what 5 is worth now. and once you get to that point, what's the whole purpose anymore?
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think you should be required to give enough money to charity or something similar so that they're no longer billionaires.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it should be illegal to be a billionaire.
auto_conc_attacks: the problem with this idea is that it is so vague that it doesn't seem to be a good idea at all. for example, i think that if you have 10 million usd you should be forced to give it to charity or something similar so that they're no longer billionaires.

conclusion: gun control will do nothing to protect people.
premises: the 2nd amendment was put in place so that the people would be able to defend themselves when the government can t. around 75 of shootings are committed using illegally aquired guns. just about every single mass shooting has occurred in a gun free zone. mass shootings happen for the same reason police brutality incidents happen, because they target people they know can t fight back. you could say that other countries have strict gun laws and they work, but the u. s isn t like other countries. look at cites like chicago and los angeles which have super strict gun laws, yet super high crime rates.
argument: gun control will do nothing to protect people. : the 2nd amendment was put in place so that the people would be able to defend themselves when the government can t. around 75 of shootings are committed using illegally aquired guns. just about every single mass shooting has occurred in a gun free zone. mass shootings happen for the same reason police brutality incidents happen, because they target people they know can t fight back. you could say that other countries have strict gun laws and they work, but the u. s isn t like other countries. look at cites like chicago and los angeles which have super strict gun laws, yet super high crime rates.
auto_conc: I believe that the 2nd amendment is useless and should be repealed.

conclusion: Fact cannot possibly exist.

conclusion: Cultural Appropriation is largely misidentified, and should be addressed on a case-by-case basis
premises: some background: i'm a cis, white, liberal woman. this particular opinion i hold is one that tends to clash with the general belief systems of many of the communities and political sects that i consider myself a part of, and that's why i'm coming here to hopefully gain insight into aspects of this phenomenon that i, as a white person, may not realize or understand. i feel like an example scenario may be the best way to explain what i mean, so here we go: jenny is a 16 year old white girl. she lives and goes to school in an area that has a fairly equal population of black people and white people. she has seen black girls online and in school that wear box braids, and she thinks they're beautiful. she regularly compliments all kinds of women on all kinds of hairstyles that she thinks are pretty, and gets inspiration from them all the time. eventually, she decides to go get box braids for herself. she posts a picture on social media and some guy named richard comments 'so hawt! ! ' or something. a look back through richard's post history shows that a week ago he made a post disparaging natural hair hairstyles, calling them 'ghetto', 'trashy', 'ugly', what have you. as annoying sounding a term as it is, i truly do believe that 'cultural appreciation' is a genuine thing although i hate saying it because i feel like it has the same connotation as 'all lives matter' or some shit . anyway, my point here is that jenny loved a certain hairstyle, and acted out of nothing but admiration and respect. had she been the one to previously condemn such a hairstyle when worn by a black woman but gone on to decide that it was 'okay' if she did it, then she certainly would be guilty of ca. in this instance, the only person at fault is richard, who also didn't commit ca, but was absolutely a massively problematic bigot. regardless of whether jenny's hairstyle was what incited richard's hypocrisy, she is not the one responsible for his skewed stances or more accurately, the larger societal views that he represents in this situation . basically: there's no doubt that in many instances, society vilifies an aspect of a certain culture simply for the association with said culture, but then glorifies it when it presents itself among 'white culture'. this is absolutely problematic, but attacking well meaning individuals is the wrong way to deal with it.

conclusion: Jesus never existed
premises: just a few reasons no one alive during jesus' time writes about him. everything we allegedly know comes after the fact. writers like philo of alexandria and other early 1st century writers are utterly silent. no one mentions jesus positively or negatively. the early church gives some pretty big clues about it. in his first apology, justin martyr all but comes out and admits that jesus' story wasn't so original. martyr's explanation for this? devils knew jesus would show up and made religions that were similar to him but got it all wrong . it's the lamest of lame excuses. the matter wasn't remotely settled even in ancient times. athenagoras of athens in the second century pens a 30 paragraph essay explaining christianity called 'a plea for the christians' in which he explains that the son of god didn't come into reality, but it just an idea; a purely spiritual being. doesn't make much sense to me. most modern christian scholarship on the subject never even remotely addresses the idea that christianity could just be the 1st century's version of scientology; a made up scam. first century judea was certainly the right place for such a scam religion to take off. they treat jesus as an historical figure and refuse to consider that he might and likely is a work of historical fiction. and the historical method of looking at information doesn't give us a way to tell history from historical fiction: not with the bias that modern day christians carry with them.

conclusion: Avoiding partisan hackery does not mean compromising your positions, nor does it mean being some sort of centrist who wants to meet in the middle. It simply means that you shouldnt allow your position on one subject, dictate your position on another non-related issue.
premises: your position on abortion policy should not be a good predictor for your position on climate policy. if i can guess your position on abortion, gun control, healthcare, education, affirmative action, capital punishment, drug laws, minimum wage, and corporate taxes, simply by you telling me your views on climate change policy, then odds are you re just a victim of tribalism and group think, and you haven t actually come to many of these conclusions through objective research. it is because i d be all the way left on some issues, all the way right on some issues, in the middle on some, mixed on others, and uncertain some as well. it s possible that going all the way in one direction for every issue just so happens to be correct, but i d say it s rather unlikely. i don t want to give away any of my positions, since they aren t relevant to my point.
argument: Avoiding partisan hackery does not mean compromising your positions, nor does it mean being some sort of centrist who wants to meet in the middle. It simply means that you shouldnt allow your position on one subject, dictate your position on another non-related issue. : your position on abortion policy should not be a good predictor for your position on climate policy. if i can guess your position on abortion, gun control, healthcare, education, affirmative action, capital punishment, drug laws, minimum wage, and corporate taxes, simply by you telling me your views on climate change policy, then odds are you re just a victim of tribalism and group think, and you haven t actually come to many of these conclusions through objective research. it is because i d be all the way left on some issues, all the way right on some issues, in the middle on some, mixed on others, and uncertain some as well. it s possible that going all the way in one direction for every issue just so happens to be correct, but i d say it s rather unlikely. i don t want to give away any of my positions, since they aren t relevant to my point.
auto_conc: i think if you s pro-choice or anti-capitalism, you s probably wrong about a lot of policy.
gt: participating in party politics isn't necessarily about engaging in tribalism or group think, and it certainly doesn't mean agreeing with the party line on every single issue. there is far from consensus on many issues in either major us political party, even among elected officials. just look at the voting records of us representatives or senators, almost none of them vote along the 'party line' 100 of the time. parties aren't about dogma, they're organized coalitions of groups with often vastly different views that are willing to compromise with each other on certain issues to see change they want on other issues. the main reason most people choose to engage in party politics on one side or the other by which i mean registering with one party, voting in primaries, donating to candidates,favoring candidates of a specific party, etc. is because it's by far the most effective way to actually see meaningful change on issues they care about. voting in primaries or engaging in party activism can dramatically change the platform of that party on certain issues. donating to candidates or volunteering will help elect a candidate that aligns with you on issues you care most about. i'm not trying to say there aren't issues with political parties in this country, or that there isn't often a valid reason to not want to support either party. i'm just saying that, as a citizen, refusing to engage in the party system is robbing yourself to influence issues you care about. it is often easiest to enact change within a system than outside of it.

conclusion: The UN Security Council should not have permanent members with veto powers
premises: it consists of 15 seats, 5 of which are held permanently by the us, uk, france, russia, and china. the other ten seats are held by various states for two year terms. the permanent member status gives five countries outsized influence on global politics basically for as long as the un exists. they are always guaranteed an influence on the council no matter what. this seems unjust to me. perhaps a hypothetical will help explain my view. let s say france decides that they want revenge on germany for the two world wars so they invade though belgium of course . so i guess there are two major aspects for you to cmv. 1. 2.

auto_conc: I think the UN security council is undemocratic.
gt: while it s definitely debatable i personally believe, and the founding fathers did too, that the biggest problem with a democracy is tyranny of the majority. most of the bill of rights and the republic set up by the us constitution was to get around that tyranny of the majority. without veto powers in the u. n. that tyranny of the majority could play out on a global scale. let s say the majority of countries are christian and decide that now the world religion is christianity and practicing anything else is illegal, the big 5 with their veto power act as an effective way to keep this from happening. by including russia and china in the permanent 5 it puts a check on western powers and better represents the world.

premises: sugary, fatty food is so much cheaper then healthier meals. think about it, look at any grocery store. fresh, lean meats and fresh vegetables especially organic are ungodly expensive. meanwhile, you can get sweets, prepackaged food and processed food for only a couple bucks. think about it, being a very poor person or maybe someone who recieves snap benefits, with very little money to spend on food has to ration their money and make it last a month. seriously, have you ever noticed that in general it's usually poorer people who are overweight and more wealthy people are thinner another good example is mcdonald's and other fast food places. it's a quick solution for people who have very little time to cook, but you can buy a burger for literally 1 dollar. the grilled chicken sandwich costs around 5, and a salad costs about 6 or 7. it may not seem like much, but it adds up. a lot. now there is some personal choice involved, but still, there's really no healthy options for people who can't afford to buy fresh healthy food on a regular basis. this is all my opinion, because i went through something similar when i was between jobs. but i am willing to listen to opposing opinions

gt: there are a few things i want to mention. 1. you can still be obese eating nothing but healthy food, excess is excess. 2. healthy food isn't necessarily that expensive, or even more expensive than unhealthy food. most fruits and vegetables are incredibly cheap. 3. eating unhealthy food in moderation will not lead to obesity source: lost 34 lbs. on a mostly fast food diet kept lt;2,000 kcal day with exercise . 4. 'healthy' options at a lot of restaurants, namely salads and similar, are not at all healthy and often worse than the regular menu options, like burgers, at least in terms of raw calorie content. obesity, for the vast majority of people, is and always has been from consuming far more calories than you burn. you can do this with healthy food, you can do this with unhealthy food, healthy food can be cheap or pricey, unhealthy food can be cheap or pricey. all it takes to avoid obesity is self control, regulating calorie intake to be less than or equal to what you burn. i don't even think convenience is that great of an excuse. i can order two jr. chickens for 4 cad, and that's 740 kcal. perfectly adequate as a meal in terms of calories at least , and very convenient. i don't have to get the quarter pounder w cheese with upsize fries and coke for 1,390 kcal.

conclusion: Divorce is not a Tragedy; a tragedy is staying in an unhappy marriage.
premises: and i am not going to address marriages that contain abuse, drug use, or financial irresponsibility. i'm just referring to marriages that have become roommate situations at best, daily fights at worst. 1 you will not grow. it should be a place of mutual respect and support. but if you are in a marriage with a disconnected, unsupportive, nagging, etc. , spouse, any growth you make will be survival skills. 2 you will likely become depressed. people often assume that someone is lonely if they are alone, but i'd argue that sometimes the feeling of being alone when you are with someone is much worse. that feeling of knowing things shouldn't be this way, that you've tried and tried and you are still stuck and have no means of making the marriage work and just pass each day as co managers of shared life logistics is depressing as h ll. the inability to fix a marriage will make this worse, and while there are thousands upon thousands of counselors and books and classes and talks about fixing your marriage, in truth they rarely work. 3 you will have a negative impact on your kids there's so much to tackle here, so i'll just cover the most salient points. kids will learn what marriage looks like from you. some say that they don't fight in front of the kids, so it's not hurting them. well, kids pick up on the negative emotions in the room. you don't have to raise your voice or slam a door to know mommy and daddy can't stand one another. and if you grow up in a family where the parental foundation is really a shaky facade, the kids will be raised feeling insecure about their family and their relationships. 4 one of you is likely to cheat on the other it's happened so much around me in the past few years it's sad, and that is one or even both spouses cheating. whether it gets discovered or not, it's happening a lot. if you cheat, you made that decision with free will. 5 very few people have what it takes to fix a marriage if you and your spouse have spent years being unable to communicate and resolve your issues, if you have reached the point where you nitpick each other in front of your friends, etc. , i think the marriage is dead and can't be saved. this last item is probably the biggest one that someone may be able to change my view on. what seems to happen, though, is that one or maybe even both parties in the marriage is unwilling and or incapable of doing what is necessary to fix a bad marriage.

conclusion: The next James Bond must be non-white
premises: not for the sake of representation, but because the series has nowhere else to go. rations continued well past the war, the big changes in society were inward universal healthcare, declining heavy industry, pop cultural awakening, migration from former colonies changing the social makeup . the uk s power to project colonial strength by hard power pretty much ended with the suez crisis. a form of soft power to say: we re still here. the uk is not like this today. the empire as it stood has completely ended. the younger generation has no clue what this colonial outlook is like. the capital is one of the most ethnically diverse places in europe. brexit happened. the fantasy of the sophisticated colonial gentleman is a symbol with nothing to signify. while daniel craig salvaged the character from the cheesy nonsense of the later brosnan years, he s also showing his age, and his bond specialises in being a broken, shattered, deconstructed version of the sean connery ideal. after casino royale, not much about the character has been added beyond the eternal metatextual isn t it time you retired? that s why the new bond should add a totally different perspective. it shouldn t be like kingsmen a crass send up of the old bond style but something that acknowledges the shift to different, more fractured ideological conflicts and the post colonial age. the new bond shouldn t be a colonial tourist, but someone who can navigate apocalyptic ideologies nationalists, fascists, jihadists and complex identity politics with ease and understanding. the new bond shouldn t be casually waltzing into a cold war type super villain lair that has cold war fantasy weapons like space lasers, but uncovering networks of ideologically linked cells that work on makeshift means and exploit political conflicts. he shouldn t have all technology handed to him by q, but understand how the internet works as a field of conflict and be somewhat digitally savvy. most of all, he shouldn t be a fantasy figure from the late colonial age. he should be a product of that era s consequences. there s no better way to embody that than with an ethnic minority bond. it shows a globalised, not formally colonising uk. it imbues the character with an intrinsic understanding of navigating different worlds and cultures. it forces the filmmakers to not lazily retreat to retreads of past films. it makes bond going to exotic locations meaningful and difficult, because it can no longer be taken for granted that a colonial gentleman can just swan around the rest of the world like he owns the place. it raises the stakes of the character and the films to match the stakes that exist in our world today.

conclusion: It's absolutely ridiculous that the military (US) gets a budget of 500+ billion dollars while institutions like NASA and the education system barely get a quarter, if that, of the military's budget.
premises: i find it unbelievable. also, tell me if i'm wrong, but to me there is no possible way they use all of that money. i remember seeing a youtube video where they talk about how the military buys new bullets every year because they want to, while the exess bullets from last year are used for training. in addition, why on earth do they need that much money when we aren't even in any major wars? if we were in a world war or something, i'm all for a large military budget. but we aren't, so why do they need that much money?

auto_conc: I believe the US government spends too much money on the military.
gt: the us military is a global force that works to protect not only the us, but us allies. the us military's role is not just to defend against military threats like russia or china, but also to defend trade routes ex. somali pirates , aid in troubled countries ex. exert soft power , train allied militaries i. e. nato , develop new technologies ex. the internet was invented by the us military , etc. the us military does a lot beyond just simply invading third world nations. moreover, the entire global economic system is dependent on western military power. if we were to start slashing our military budget, a country like china could come in and grow their global footprint, thus giving them more soft power diplomatically, as well as hard power militarily. it would threaten capitalism to shrink our military footprint.

auto_conc_attacks: the us military is one of the largest military organizations in the world. it's the only one that has the capacity to fight in a war.

conclusion: It's stupid to join a High IQ Society like Mensa
premises: high iq societies are clubs that typically only allow members with a certain iq percentile. people who join these clubs typically do so to indicate that they're intelligent and to socialize with peers who are as intelligent. the reason i think it's stupid is mainly because i believe these people put way too much value into their iq. and iq score is typically a very narrow indicator of intelligence, excluding things like emotional intelligence, creativity and social skills. not to mention it's outdated, since the iq of the general population has been steadily growing, but the average is still set to 100. meaning that and iq of 140 is less impressive than it used to be. which brings me to my main point in that his members overestimate the value of iq, a lot of them probably take much pride over it because they lack other significant achievements in their lives.
argument: It's stupid to join a High IQ Society like Mensa : high iq societies are clubs that typically only allow members with a certain iq percentile. people who join these clubs typically do so to indicate that they're intelligent and to socialize with peers who are as intelligent. the reason i think it's stupid is mainly because i believe these people put way too much value into their iq. and iq score is typically a very narrow indicator of intelligence, excluding things like emotional intelligence, creativity and social skills. not to mention it's outdated, since the iq of the general population has been steadily growing, but the average is still set to 100. meaning that and iq of 140 is less impressive than it used to be. which brings me to my main point in that his members overestimate the value of iq, a lot of them probably take much pride over it because they lack other significant achievements in their lives.
auto_conc: I believe that iq is a stupid measure of intelligence.
gt: i think that if you join any kind of society for the express purpose of being able to brag about your eligibility, you probably have some insecurity to work through but this is hardly unique to members of mensa. another example that comes to mind is paying to be listed in who's who directories and the like. on the other hand, there are people who join societies like this because they enjoy the activities and social programs therein. many older people in particular, who may be lonely, might look for any kind of group or society they are eligible to join. i've never heard a bragging word leave my elderly neighbor's mouth, but she goes to mensa meetings every week because she likes to simultaneously have human interaction and keep her mind sharp by doing brain games with other people who enjoy them. anytime she mentions mensa, it's usually because she want to share a cool puzzle she got there. in brief: if your motive for joining mensa is to brag, then you have issues with insecurity. but that is not the only reason people join mensa. so i think that to say the organization itself is stupid because a certain subset of its members join only for status is not a tenable argument. societal attitudes toward praising intelligence or other heritable traits is a separate issue entirely, of which certain individuals' mensa membership is at most a byproduct.
masked_conc_attacks: iq is not a measure of intelligence. iq is a way to measure intelligence. if you are intelligent, you are likely to have a high iq. but if you aren't intelligent, then you are probably not going to be able to do the things you want to do.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's stupid to join a high iq society. i don't know if you're talking about a society with a low iq, but i think you're referring to a society that only allows members with a certain iq percentile. iq is not an indicator of intelligence, it's a measure of social skills. it is a measurement of how well you interact with others.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's stupid to think that iq is a stupid measure of intelligence.

conclusion: (Theoretical) physics is no longer beneficial and should be defunded
premises: in past eras, advanced physics helped humanity develop by explaining the world around us. it helped us understand orbits, advance our knowledge of how atoms function, leading to developments in many fields, and enable our technology to take advantage of more mechanics of the universe than before. however, recently the amount of useful results to come out of the physics field seems to have dwindled. now, most of what is produced seems to deal with highly conceptual research, such as string theory and quantum gravity. other avenues of research, such as particle physics research, produce information with little to no practical uses for humanity. the large hadron collider alone cost 4. 75 billion, and annually requiring approximately 1 billion to continue operation. although the collider was instrumental in proving the existence of the higgs boson, the particle has no uses. other experiments involve not investigating anything new at all, merely proving and re proving what we already know about relativity and its related research. instead of continuing to pour money into a field which has extremely limited benefits, i believe funding should be taken out of the physics field and used to solve real problems in the world. the money used to build the lhc could have been used for things like feeding the poor, fixing the education system, or advancing medicine. if the lhc's annual budget was taken away, there would be an extra 1 billion dollars every year dedicated to solving tangible real world problems.

conclusion: The left is more fascist than the right in America.
premises: contrary to what reddit would have you believe fascism doesn't 'racist' or 'far right'. fascism just means gt; a governmental system led by a dictator having complete power,forcibly suppressing opposition and criticism, regimenting all industry, commerce, etc so there's three main components of fascism. 1. government has complete power 2. they forcibly suppress opposition 3. they regiment industry and commerce so let's start with 1. trump's administration is deregulating at an incredible rate and deregulation is one of the core republican policies. positions of the republican party deregulation significantly decreases both the size and power of a government. now number 2. forcibly suppressing opposition doesn't necessarily have to be done through murder. censorship is also extremely effective at this. this is made evident from the widespread censorship of conservative view points from all major social networks. you could make the argument that the left only calls for censorship of speech that incites violence. the right has fewer circumstances in which they believe their opposition must be censored. you could also argue that these are private companies completely within their rights to not give a platform to anybody for whatever reason. but that situation is very comparable to when street owners tried to censor demonstrations from people they didn't agree with politically. this was dangerous because the street owners had an oligarchy on the means of free speech. they could censor any idea they disagreed with. this is a perfect comparison for social networks today, with one judge going as far as to say gt; in coming to this holding, the court emphasized that streets and parks are the quintessential forum for the exercise of first amendment rights and while in the past there may have been difficulty in identifying the most important places in a special sense for the exchange of views, today the answer is clear. it is cyberspace the vast democratic forums of the internet in generally, and social media in particular . the major social networks have an oligarchy on the means of free speech. it is censorship when they ban opposing views from their platform. and finally 3. this one is pretty cut and dry. it's pretty much half of their platform but that doesn't mean the democrats are worse. both parties are so so far from actual fascism that it's pointless to call either even remotely fascist. anyone who does so doesn't understand the definition of fascism. which is understandable considering how the democrats on this site have overused the word to the point that nobody seems to.

auto_conc: It's pointless to call the current state of America fascism.
gt: as others have written here, your definition of fascism is not consistent with any of the vast historical or political science scholarship on fascism. indeed, it seems you quoted nearly the entire definition from dictionary. com except for the part about key parts about nationalism and racism. you simply cannot have a meaningful discussion of fascism without talking about nationalism and a racialized view of the nation. this is well summarized by kevin passmore in a short introduction to fascism: fascism is a set of ideologies and practices that seeks to place the nation, defined in exclusive biological, cultural, and or historical terms, above all other sources of loyalty , and to create a mobilized national community. fascist nationalism is reactionary in that it entails implacable hostility to socialism and feminism, for they are seen as prioritizing class or gender rather than nation. this is why fascism is a movement of the extreme right. fascism is also a movement of the radical right because the defeat of socialism and feminism and the creation of the mobilized nation are held to depend upon the advent to power of a new elite acting in the name of the people, headed by a charismatic leader, and embodied in a mass, militarized party. fascists are pushed towards conservatism by common hatred of socialism and feminism , but are prepared to override conservative interests family, property, religion, the universities, the civil service where the interests of the nation are considered to require it. fascist radicalism also derives from a desire to assuage discontent by accepting specific demands of the labour and women's movements, so long as these demands accord with the national priority. fascists seek to ensure the harmonization of workers' and women's interests with those of the nation by mobilizing them within special sections of the party and or within a corporate system. access to these organizations and to the benefits they confer upon members depends on the individual's national, political, and or racial characteristics. you seem to be talking about authoritarianism, not fascism. that's a fine conversation to have, as long as we're clear we're not talking about fascism. your points, one by one:1. the left wants a more democratic economy, whereby the people are able to control the economy through democratically legitimate institutions. american left style regulation is not total power, because power is always subservient to the electorate. 2. aside from censorship of hate speech and speech that violates different networks terms of service, there is no censorship of the right wing. there is absolutely no evidence that mainstream right wing voices are silenced in america. in fact, they have their own loud speakers, like breitbart or fox news. none of this compares to the way that trump has delegitimized the media. in fact, his war on truth bears many resemblances to the fascist technique called 'the big lie. ' 3. i'm not really sure what work 'regiment' is doing in your definition, but this is the part that seems to least relevant to fascism. economic interventionism, the left most certainly is. but that does not make them any more or any less fascist than the right. amp; x200b;
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're misinterpreting the definition of fascism. fascism is a government that has complete power, but it's also a government with complete power.
known_conc_attacks: the left is more fascist than the right in a lot of ways. i think you're underestimating the extent to which the left is a fascist. it's not that the left isn't fascist, it's that the right isn't a fascist at all.
auto_conc_attacks: i think you're misunderstanding the definition of fascism. the term is used to describe a government that has complete power. it's a government which has complete control over the economy. the government does not control the economy, it controls the media, and it is the government that regulates the media. it is also the government which controls the internet. it does not regulate the media or the internet, it regulates the communication of information. this is a government with complete power, and the media is controlled by the government. the media has a monopoly on information, and that monopoly is the only way to regulate information. it doesn't have to be regulated by government, it has to be controlled by private companies, and if you want to censor information, you can do so through private companies. if you don't want to do that, you're going to have to do it through private corporations, which means you have to deal with private corporations.

conclusion: Attaining biological immortality would not be good for the human species and, ultimately, is a selfish idea.
premises: firstly, this post is inspired and essentially a response to the following two videos by youtuber cgp grey: typically, i love content from this channel, but i find myself vehemently disagreeing with the simplicity of his view about the function of death as a part of life. the following are reasons why i believe death needs to happen. the idea that suddenly everyone will be immune to death, and that the last person will die forever is preposterous. this would cause widespread issues including backlash from those whos religion does not agree with immortality, for example panic, and most likely a desperate struggle for people to gain access to this 'death cure'. the presence of a death cure itself would cause a great deal of chaos, and even if the chaos ends one day, there will be other issues that arise 2: having a world where old ideas, practices, beliefs, and ideologies remain with the people who hold them sounds awful. the way things are now, new people are being born every day bringing new points of view, movements, and ideas forward. with new generations comes innovation and change. think of some of the points of view or ideologies held by people as early as 20 years ago. now think about 50 years ago. 100 years? the world we live in has drastically changed with our new ideas. for this reason the cycling of human life is necessary. those who are old overwhelmingly tend to become stuck in their ways, believing that their longevity makes their points of view valid. curing a death will either put a halt to this change, or slow it dramatically due to the need to control our population. 3: having a cure for death would require us to impose extreme controls on our population. currently, our population is growing at an alarming rate, while the condition of our planet deteriorates. if we find a death cure, and continue to grow in the same way, we will very quickly outgrow our means for sustaining ourselves. the solution to this problem would be imposing extreme controls on who can breed and when. these things would need to be monitored, and rules would need to be enforced. i don't think i need to describe the dystopian future that this would create. the idea of even being able to successfully control the breeding of 7 billion people is extremely difficult. rather than keeping one organism alive for a potential eternity, it is far easier to have that organism breed, multiply, and have their offspring do the same. this allows for the spreading favorable traits, creating new and better version of each organism. 5: with an eternity to live, inevitably you will get bored. sooner or later in an infinite time span you will no longer be able to find joy in what mortal life might have to offer. when you've seen an done everything over an infinite amount of time, you'll eventually decide it's time to check out anyway. this isn't inherently bad, a desire to live is necessary for life to carry on. cmv currently my comments aren't coming through properly are being tacked on to the wrong posts. i will reply to comments as soon as i can.

conclusion: Not everyone should be allowed to have children
premises: the three main bases of assessment would be: 1 financial economic, 2 psychologically, 3 criminal history. 1. economically financially: the person or couple must be able to demonstrate that they will be able to provide for the child's basic needs housing, food, reasonable estimate of healthcare etc. , and education at least through high school . this would be based on a holistic assessment of the person's and or couple's current income both active and passive , earning potential, availability of fairly liquid capital; the total earning potential should be able to cover the benchmarked costs for the above mentioned necessities without incurring excess debt i haven't calculated exactly what that'd be, but it'd be leveraging themselves up to a certain percentage of their current income 2. psychologically: the person or couple must be able to demonstrate that they pass a psychological evaluation that deems them fit to be parenting. i haven't completed figured out what the guidelines would be yet, but it would basically have to demonstrate that the person or couple doesn't have any severe mental disorders nor a recurring history of disorders . 3. criminal history: the person or couple cannot have a lengthy or recurring history of criminal activities this would be based on a has a lengthy history of criminal offenses; not civil offenses their past would need to be evaluated and indexed based on severity; e. g. first degree murder would pretty much rule out your chances, while involuntary manslaughter would be need to be further examined . ultimately, i think successfully implementing these measures would: increase gdp per capita, increase household income per capita, increase household expenditure per capita, decrease income inequality, increase literacy rates, reduce violent crime, decrease household debt, reduce underemployment and unemployment note: unemployment is different from underemployment . these quantitative changes would also qualitatively lead to a 'better society' with a higher quality of living. this is still a developing view, but it's a rough idea that i've been thinking about recently. i did a lazy job of fully fleshing out my thoughts because there're just way too many changes and causal links to list, but feel free to pick something and question it. you won't be able to cmv if you talk about how this isn't feasible in terms of implementation.

conclusion: Infinity War was not that good.
premises: spoilers, obviously. also standard first time posting and on mobile disclaimers. at the time of writing, the movie has an 84 certified fresh rating on rotten tomatoes and the poll on r movies has a mean rating of 8. 81 i'd link it, but again, mobile . and despite wanting to love it, i came out of the movie largely disappointed. here are my complaints. 1. thanos is not a great villain. his rhetoric rings empty: the whole 'ultimate solution' schtick is never once challenged directly and never has an alternative solution proposed. sure he 'loves' his 'family,' but that's told to us, not shown, really. 2. the fights look good, but were ultimately nonsensical. strange's only use of the time stone ends up being pointless as he doesn't follow through unless that's part of the setup for how the avengers 'win' later in the follow up, which still rubs me the wrong way 3. in a 2 1 2 hour movie no one, with the very minor exception of vision, got any character development. i understand this is a consequence of the ambition of the project, but that's no excuse. and here's where i'm going to put a secondary super spoiler warning 4. literally erasing 50 of the cast was incredibly lazy. i understand this was an attempt to pare back the frankly unmanageable number of characters but it came off as an obvious plot device. having no rhyme or reason to who got dusted may have made plot sense but it's no coincidence that the characters lost were a. not the super main main characters ie tony and steve or anyone with whom they have unresolved plots ie black widow and b. were actors who likely had to be paid disproportionately to their screen time ie sam jackson, idris elba . the only outliers here to me seem to be starlord and strange. i have more minor complaints but this post is long and pretentious enough. cmv! i am admittedly a movie only person. that being said, i prefer to evaluate the experience in only that context.

gt: one of the big reasons data mining is legal isn't that these companies take your private information. is that they are incredibly efficient at taking your public information. what you do with the government is a matter of public record. so, if you get married, get arrested, file a court case, register a vehicle, all of that is public in most states some exceptions apply for certain states . you buy from a business, the results of that transaction are as much the business's as they are yours. you sign up for a rewards program that's free? it's not. you pay with your information. privacy is a right. but the companies you speak of don't violate it any more than someone who goes through the trash you put on the curb is stealing from you.

conclusion: I would vote for a Democrat if they changed their position on guns, or at least educated themselves on the topic.
premises: i want to start out by saying i'm not opposed to voting for a democrat. i wrote in bernie sanders name in 2016 because he aligned with a lot of my views, however, one thing especially at a national level i cannot stand is democrats views and general ignorance on guns. part of my issue stands in the fact that i really appreciate the constitution, i especially appreciate the second amendment. i believe that of all the rights we have as human beings the pre eminent one is the right to self defense. a bunch of colonists taking on the greatest military superpower of the time, it's a miracle america won. i also am a gun owner myself as well as my family. i live in a rural area where police presence is limited and when i'm sitting outside my rural house it scares me that help could be so far away. moreover, my father taught me to respect firearms to treat them as they were always loaded, to know my target and what's beyond, to never point a firearm at anything i'm not willing to shoot, to lock up my guns, and to keep my finger off the trigger and the trigger guard. i grew up in a not so gun centric house but i learned about them. as an adult, in modern politics, i see politicians mainly democrats trying to restrict the second amendment. which is all well and good except when i hear gun control advocates say 'bullet' rather than 'cartridge' or 'clip rather than 'magazine' so much of the gun control debate and policy is measured on the mechanics of firearms. i don't believe that democrats need to be an expert in firearms in order to have a say in the gun control debate, but i want my politicians who want to regulate my second amendment rights to understand the distinction between a semi automatic and an automatic weapon. i want them to understand that an automatic weapon fires as long as you hold the trigger down or until you run out of ammunition and a semi automatic weapons fire one round per trigger pull. i want them to understand that automatic weapons are extremely regulated and require a special federal license to acquire. i want them to understand that the ar in ar 15 doesn't stand for assault rifle and referring to it as that is disingenuous and appeal to emotional appeal. i want them to understand that 'silencers' suppressors don't make guns super quiet like in the movies. gunfire is very audible with a suppressor and saying otherwise is again disingenuous. the gun show loophole is another thing that bothers me, mostly because if you purchase a firearm from someone with a ffl regardless of location you must have a background check. now that we ve come to the midterm elections i ve been listening to the democratic candidates talk about gun control in the wake of parkland and las vegas.

gt: here's the official position of the dnc, as stated in the 2016 democratic platform preventing gun violence with 33,000 americans dying every year, democrats believe that we must finally take sensible action to address gun violence. while responsible gun ownership is part of the fabric of many communities, too many families in america have suffered from gun violence. we can respect the rights of responsible gun owners while keeping our communities safe. to build on the success of the lifesaving brady handgun violence prevention act, we will expand and strengthen background checks and close dangerous loopholes in our current laws; repeal the protection of lawful commerce in arms act plcaa to revoke the dangerous legal immunity protections gun makers and sellers now enjoy; and keep weapons of war such as assault weapons and large capacity ammunition magazines lcam's off our streets. we will fight back against attempts to make it harder for the bureau of alcohol, tobacco, firearms, and explosives to revoke federal licenses from law breaking gun dealers, and ensure guns do not fall into the hands of terrorists, intimate partner abusers, other violent criminals, and those with severe mental health issues. there is insufficient research on effective gun prevention policies, which is why the u. s. centers for disease control and prevention must have the resources it needs to study gun violence as a public health issue. what part of this troubles you enough to vote for someone from a different party? note that in these modern times, the 4th amendment is much more important than the 2nd amendment in securing our freedom from tyranny. however, i appreciate that some people are in situations where they need guns to ensure their personal security.

conclusion: Most recreational drugs should be legalised.
premises: the subject of drug usage can sometimes be a somewhat taboo subject. some people are very conservative about this and others are not. why? well when any society attempts to control the consumption of any substance by banning it, we get black markets. that is essentially all strict drug laws do, they create a black market. that black market fuels organised crime and demonises certain persons from society. my second reason, is that if you legalise certain drugs people are consuming anyway you remove the taboo of them seeking help if they become addicted. as it currently stands there is help for those who want to quit smoking tobacco or quit consuming alcohol. these drugs are arguably far worse than most other substances available on the black market. my last reason is i fully believe that a lot of people can take other substances responsibly, in the same way one consumes alcohol. not every user is an addict. i think we need to stop demonising people for wanting to let off some steam by taking a substance that allows them to make their lives that bit more bearable. i welcome any counter arguments here, in which may change my view.
argument: Most recreational drugs should be legalised. : the subject of drug usage can sometimes be a somewhat taboo subject. some people are very conservative about this and others are not. why? well when any society attempts to control the consumption of any substance by banning it, we get black markets. that is essentially all strict drug laws do, they create a black market. that black market fuels organised crime and demonises certain persons from society. my second reason, is that if you legalise certain drugs people are consuming anyway you remove the taboo of them seeking help if they become addicted. as it currently stands there is help for those who want to quit smoking tobacco or quit consuming alcohol. these drugs are arguably far worse than most other substances available on the black market. my last reason is i fully believe that a lot of people can take other substances responsibly, in the same way one consumes alcohol. not every user is an addict. i think we need to stop demonising people for wanting to let off some steam by taking a substance that allows them to make their lives that bit more bearable. i welcome any counter arguments here, in which may change my view.
auto_conc: I believe all drugs should be legalised.
gt: i would say yes, ideally most recreational substances would be legal, however, each place has different histories with recreational substances, different laws, different societal beliefs, that would significantly impact the way they would be received. in a significantly religious state, there may be more of a backlash, people may interpret the state supporting the legalisation as a move against the grain or the tenets of the major religion. a state with a significant drug problem, may abuse the legalisation of such substances and temporarily regress into a self indulgent binge, while states with less prominent social problems may be relatively unchanged by the move, with those that partake in recreational consumption of drugs no longer threatened hindered by the laws that previously restricted use and possession. really subjective, no one knows what will happen. while some countries have had notable success in the legalisation of some or all substances, in conjunction with controls against the production, acquisition and resale or substances, this is not necessarily the result other countries would experience. whatever countries decide to do is a risk. countries that permit more freedom in regards to all aspects of illicit substances are taking a significant risk. whether a given country is willing to take on such a risk is subject to so many variables that are beyond the bounds of discussion of this post.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think you need to stop demonising people for wanting to let off some steam by taking a substance that allows them to make their lives that bit more bearable.
known_conc_attacks: the problem with your view is that it's not a good idea to ban recreational drugs because they're harmful to the health of the person taking them. it's a bad idea to allow people to get addicted to drugs because you want to prevent them from getting addicted to them. the problem isn't with the legalisation of drugs, it's with the prohibition of drugs. you can't outlaw drugs if you don't want to. the issue is that if you legalize recreational drugs, you're going to end up with a lot of people who want to use them, and you're also going to create a black market.
auto_conc_attacks: what do you mean by 'legalisation'?

conclusion: Of all the men (rightfully) accused in the wake #MeToo, Louis C.K. deserves a second chance.
premises: let me say at the outset that what louis c. k. did was wrong and morally reprehensible for a variety of reasons. this post is in no way a defense of what he did; it is, however, trying to put it into perspective of other forms of abuse. i understand this opinion is a unpopular one, but am truly looking for people to cmv in this post, and explain to me their viewpoints. i want an honest discussion about a very sensitive issue. i also want to say that i am a man, but my family has been affected by sexual abuse. at the end of the day, while i believe louis c. k. should be punished in the court of public opinion, i do not believe that punishment should include a lifetime ban from entertainment the same way i feel it should for people like kevin spacey, bill cosby, and harvey weinstein, for the following reasons: 1 degree of the accusations: i believe that 'bad things' have degrees. unwanted exposure and lewd questions are horrible and deserve consequences; but physically violating someone through physical contact is far worse. i don't believe it is fair to equate louis exposing himself to someone physically violating another person's own body, as was the case with cosby, spacey, and weinstein. i think that the physical violation of another person's body is one of the most vile acts human beings can do to another person, but that is not what louis c. k. did. of the 3 instances reported in the nyt article, none of them involved physical contact. there is one anecdote about louis possibly shoving a women into a bathroom , but as of now we don t know if this actually happened nor the circumstances involved. no woman has come forward to directly accuse louis of this. 2 a reasonable explanation: in his response to the ny times article, i am sympathetic to c. k. 's claims that he did not fully understand how much power he wielded over these individuals because of his celebrity. to his cr, in every one of these instances, c. k. did ask before committing these acts. these instances seemed to happen at the time when his career was first starting to really flourish. i take him for his word when he said he didn t understand how, in his newly found celebrity, asking wasn t really asking. that is in no way an excuse for what c. k. did because his behavior was still wildly inappropriate, but i am still somewhat sympathetic to his explanation, which leads into my third point 3 lack of predatory nature: louis c. k. made bad judgments, but his behavior does not seem predatory to me the same way cosby's, spacey's, and weinstein s were. he never threatened to ruin a woman's career for not allowing him to expose himself in front of them, and based on the information we currently have, it seems as if this behavior stopped at some point. now, it is alleged that c. k. s agent david becky may have made vague threats on louis' behalf to the women who accused him, but i don't think that is enough to put that blame on louis. it is possible becky was acting without c. k. s knowledge. furthermore, when the ny times article was published, i found louis c. k. 's response to be a no bs acknowledgement of both the accusations and the hurt he caused. i think we have to give c. k. crfor that. 5 a learning moment: undoubtedly, the importance of metoo is that it finally gives victims of sexual assault a voice. but perhaps also we should hear from truly contrite men who have behaved inappropriately in the past to understand their reasoning and learn from their thoughts and regrets. i don t believe we should give predatory monsters like cosby, spacey, and weinstein a voice to explain their actions. it may be too soon for c. k. to make a comeback , but i think some day he should be allowed to.

conclusion: If I am an oppressor, it is in my interest to remain one.
premises: i am a straight white male. for many, this means that i am not only in a position of privilege in relation to several other groups, but also that i hurt the interests of those groups by unconsciously exhibiting certain views and behaviors. for the sake of the argument, lets grant all of that. let's also assume that everyone is equal, regardless of sex, genetic background etc. and the only source of outcome variation is historical injustice and various structures and ideologies that support oppression. even if all of the above is true, there is no reason for me to actively seek to empower groups that i don't belong to. power is relative, so every bit of power that women, immigrants, minorities etc. gain, i lose. in fact, all of these groups have a proven record of actively trying to take my power away. not only that, but some of them openly declare so just enter the term 'white men' into google news. women's rights are a good example of this. 99. 93 of humans are born biologically male or female. that makes me concerned, because again, i want to be in a position of power, no matter what. perhaps men have oppressed women, that doesn't concern me. what concerns me is that we're not oppressing them now. even if we, just for the sake of the argument, assume that women are superior to men in some significant way, it would only make oppressing them all the more necessary. based on this reasoning, i support all political action that hurts the groups that i don't belong to. this has led me to having political positions that would be seen as extremely disagreeable by the absolute majority of westerners at least that's what i'm assuming . and i should probably emphasize here that this is not an ideological choice. more power is better than less no matter what. even if i was benevolent, i would still rather be benevolent from a position of power. now here you might say 'hey, this power stuff is weird, who thinks like that? ' and perhaps you're right. however, i have only about 80 years to live and i intend to extract maximum utility out of those 80 years. every millimeter matters. that's not to say that i go out there and engage in some kind of violent activism i still gain much more by just working towards my goals on my own. still, that doesn't stop me from feeling a little bit of joy every time i hear a complaint about women's reproductive rights or how the police in the us apparently hate black people.

auto_conc: i'm a straight white male, and i don't feel bad about that.
gt: it sounds to me like that kind of view is sociopathic. if you have no human empathy then you have abnormal emotional responses to things, which may lead you to improperly define your interest. im sure many powerful people felt like their interests were secure until the people they were opressing got ahold of them. concepts of self interest that see it as separate from social interests are too narrow to capture the big picture.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'power is relative'. i'm sure you're talking about the fact that you don't have any power at all, but that doesn't mean that you have no power. power is relative. it's like saying that if you are in a position of power, you should be able to do whatever you want with your life. if you aren't, then you can't do what you want.
known_conc_attacks: if you are an oppressor, it is in your interest to remain one.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm not sure if this is a good thing or not, but i think it's important to note that you're not the only one who feels bad about it. i don't think you're the only person who feel bad about the fact that you feel like you're being oppressed. if you're a straight white male, and you feel bad for being oppressed, then i think you have a valid reason to feel bad. it's not that you are not oppressed, it's just that you don't feel good about it because you feel it's wrong to feel that way. i'm not saying that you shouldn't feel bad, but it's that you should feel bad because you're in a position of power. for example, i'm a black man, and i feel bad that i'm being oppressed because i feel like i've been oppressed.

conclusion: The rich should pay more for a traffic infraction than the poor
premises: i recently stumbled across the idea of progressive traffic fines, which work in a way similar to progressive taxes. i came to agree with the notion, though i've found few arguments to the contrary. c a progressive traffic fine based on the income of the violator would punish violators more equally, and thus be more just. i am willing to entertain other ideas about this, and change my view where merited!
argument: The rich should pay more for a traffic infraction than the poor : i recently stumbled across the idea of progressive traffic fines, which work in a way similar to progressive taxes. i came to agree with the notion, though i've found few arguments to the contrary. c a progressive traffic fine based on the income of the violator would punish violators more equally, and thus be more just. i am willing to entertain other ideas about this, and change my view where merited!
auto_conc: I believe that fines for speeding should be based on the income of the driver.
gt: right, what makes them think they're entitled to their own money? they should give it to me! because reasons
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think this is a good idea, but it seems to me that there are a lot of problems with this system. first of all, it's not like we're going to be able to enforce a progressive traffic fine based on the income of the violator. it's more likely that the driver will end up paying more than the other driver. second, if the driver doesn't pay the fine, then it's hard to enforce it. third, you're not going to enforce the system based on income. you're just going to have to pay a lot more for it. if you don't pay enough, you'll have a lot less of a problem with it. you can't enforce it based on your income, but you can enforce it if you want to. i'm not saying that this is the best solution, but i think it would be a good one. i don't see how it's fair to punish someone based on their income.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to punish the rich for a traffic infraction, but it's not fair to penalize the poor for a crime.
auto_conc_attacks: if you don't want to pay a fine based on the income of the driver, then you shouldn't pay one.

conclusion: Addiction is a choice not a disease
premises: at least initially. there is a time in everyone s life where they may be offered the opportunity to engage in excess drinking, smoking, etc. you choose to either take or not take the pill. you choose to either inject the needle or not inject that needle. you choose to drink that alcohol.
argument: Addiction is a choice not a disease : at least initially. there is a time in everyone s life where they may be offered the opportunity to engage in excess drinking, smoking, etc. you choose to either take or not take the pill. you choose to either inject the needle or not inject that needle. you choose to drink that alcohol.
auto_conc: Taking drugs is not always a victimless crime, as drug users can harm others.
gt: do you consider diseases to be only those things with tangible representations in the real world? meaning something which can be isolated and examined on some level, like a bacteria or a virus or a patch of cancerous skin cells or a particular brain formation even the absence of something like a depressed person missing their correct balance of neurotransmitters? because a great deal of mental disorders psychopathologies would not meet that criteria. there are many debilitating conditions which have no physical representation in reality. it would be nice if you could take someone with ocd, put them in an mri, and say, 'you see this bump right here? that's your ocd. ' unfortunately most conditions like this don't work that way. also . . . if someone is regularly taking a substance drugs for a long time, then goes off that substance, the nerve dendrites which normally recieve the neurotransmitters produced by taking the drug can actually start to grow seeking more of the drug. imagine the dendrites are like garage doors that drugs use to park their cars. if you deprive those garage doors of cars, they will start making more garage doors in the hopes of enticing more cars to park in them. it's a literal ramping up of the craving for more drugs that someone who has not been taking a lot of drugs wont feel. and when the next time there's a big flood of cars, well look at all these nice new garages to house them all.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'the time in everyone s life where they may be offered the opportunity to engage in excess drinking, smoking, etc.'i'm going to focus on the fact that there is a time in every person's life where alcohol and tobacco are the only choices they can make. if you're going to choose to take a pill, you are going to have to make a choice about whether or not you want to take the pill or not.
known_conc_attacks: you are right that addiction is a choice not a disease. however, there is a difference between a choice and a choice. a choice is the choice of whether or not to take a pill or not. if you choose to take the pill, then you are choosing not to use the pill.
auto_conc_attacks: there's a difference between a crime and a victimless crime. if you're a victim of a crime, you're not committing a crime. you're committing the crime because you believe it's a crime to harm others.

conclusion: If male privilege exists, then so does female privilege
premises: off the top of my head, here are a few examples. girls tend to outperform boys in school. males are much more likely to be victims of violence. male parental rights are significantly less. many sharehouse rental accommodation is female only. there are female only scholarships and grants.
argument: If male privilege exists, then so does female privilege : off the top of my head, here are a few examples. girls tend to outperform boys in school. males are much more likely to be victims of violence. male parental rights are significantly less. many sharehouse rental accommodation is female only. there are female only scholarships and grants.
auto_conc: Men and women are biologically different and thus they play different roles in society.
gt: i m curious about your definition of female privilege. are you saying that there is at least one instance in modern western society where women have an unfair advantage over men? if that s the case, i think it d be hard for anyone to disagree with you. or, are you saying that the privileges that women have are the same amount of privileges that men have, and therefore are disproportionally not talked about? i m not trying to change your view, i m just wondering where your goalpost is, whether it s that females have any privileges men don t have, or that females have the same amount of privileges unique to their gender that men do. lastly, in the majority of the world, females are still very much disadvantaged much more than male counterparts. if you agree with that statement, then i think it d be worth it to refine your op to being confined to western societies. my family is from china, for example, and i think it d be very hard to claim privilege of being female as something that needed to be talked about.
masked_conc_attacks: if you look at the statistics you'll find that men are more likely to be victims of violence than women are.
known_conc_attacks: if male privilege exists, then so does female privilege.
auto_conc_attacks: you seem to be assuming that all men and women are biologically different, and thus they play different roles in society. however, there are plenty of studies that show that women are more likely to be victims of violence than men. these studies show that men are less likely to commit violence than women.

conclusion: In the next couple of years Amazon will buy Valve, buy Steam from Valve, or make their own software to become the primary PC game distributor.
premises: amazon is rich as fuck and it won't be long until they're the largest retailer in the world. they're currently 3rd behind walmart and cvs. their purchase of whole foods shows they're interested in expanding into new markets. they're also not ignorant to the world of gaming, having purchased twitch in 2014. you can find lots of complaints online about operations administration at twitch but they have undoubtedly expanded its audience in the last 4 years, and i think the amazon higher ups view it as a financial success. it certainly seems like a more reliable way to make money. making games is financially risky. but it could also be super rewarding: see pubg and fortnite . nobody really knows, but googling shows that valve is maybe worth about 5bil. that's not an unreasonable purchase price for amazon, having previously spent 1bil for twitch, and 14bil for whole foods. you can also find a few reports online from various ex employees that describe valve as kind of stagnant. they say it's lost the innovation and motivation it used to have. some even point to gabe newell specifically and say he's no longer motivated, and spends most of his days just playing dota. this implies that he could be receptive to buyout offers.

gt: and in 2500 we will see a conan sent by amazon cyberlife
masked_conc_attacks: i think valve is a financial success. it's not a financial failure. it is not a business failure. there are plenty of companies that make money, but they are not going to do it for profit. they are going to invest in new products, and they will invest in the quality of the products they sell. they will spend money on marketing, marketing, and customer service. valve is not the only company that makes money. they have a lot of customers who want to buy from them. they want to be a part of their community. they don't want to lose their customers, they want their customers to be part of the community. that's why they are so successful. they aren't going to be able to make money off of their customers. they're going to have to spend money to keep people happy. they'll have to invest money to make sure that their customers get what they want, and if they can't do that, they will be forced to spend

auto_conc_attacks: i think you're underestimating the impact that amazon is going to have on the gaming industry.

conclusion: Instead of teaching youth to "not judge" we should be teaching them *how* to judge with kindness, mercy, logic, and fairness.
premises: let me start by explaining what i mean when i say judge in this context. i am a father of a 5 year old girl and as anyone who's spent a lot of time with babies and young children, i want to help guide her through life and give her the tools to interpret the world around her. when we see a child behaving very poorly in public there are times when i choose to speak with her about what's happening. at the onset of this moment, when we are going to voice our thoughts about the behavior of others, whether it's my daughter and i, you by yourself in your head, or anyone in really any circumstance, we are entering a judgmental space by it's literal definition. any way to frame, or speak about some else's actions requires judgments to be made. our society has made the word 'judgmental' have strong negative connotations, and i believe people are uncomfortable with using others as teaching opportunities for fear of being 'judgmental' here's an example of what i'm talking about. daughter and i see a child screaming in the market, jumping up and down creating a massive scene, hitting their parent ect i'll ask my daughter 'why do you think they're being so terrible' i insert the view i'm teaching, that the behavior is terrible, so judgment is made but begin a dialogue. normally she'll say 'they're mad' or something like that, and we'll talk about things that make us mad, what might have this other child mad, i'll say something like 'i get mad, you get mad, everyone get's mad sometimes, it's ok to be mad but that's not how we act when we're mad right? ' i believe we should be creating a template for judgment to exist, where it's where the person's identity isn't attacked, but their behavior and actions content of their character are understood and discussed. the person who could change my view would do so by showing me how this style of parenting causes more harm than good and i shouldn't have a conversation with my daughter making judgments about the misbehaving child. after reading lots of really amazing responses i have learned a few things. firstly that framing things this way with some of the specific language could be bad for my daughter because when she steps out of line, she inserts herself as the 'terrible' child, or that she is doing 'terrible things', which may be true by whatever definition we have for terrible, it can damage self esteem and doesn't promote healthy learning. 2ndly there is a problem with syntax and semantics with the term judgment, and while none of those arguments swayed me, they are still very much relevant. lastly, it's friday afternoon, and i'm going home. be well.

auto_conc: it's ok to be judgmental when raising a child
gt: while teaching kids, i get lots of utterances like 'this song is shit', and that's very tiring after a while. on the other hand, i respect everyone's freedom of speech and thinking. so i try teaching them to distinguish between blatant judgements and justified opinions. the latter ones 'i find this song shitty because' using the lines of argumentation that you described are acceptable for all. the former only for professionals in a given area.

conclusion: Voting isn't actually productive or necessary
premises: however, i just can't shake the feeling that it doesn't really do anything. my singular vote doesn't mean anything. the electoral college and what my state is held by matters. like, i'm in texas so my vote for beto isn't gonna matter because my district is so gerrymandered that my liberal section of the state is partioned out with smaller, conservative west texas. i have voted democrat in every past election and it doesn't matter because the state is held by republicans. i'm not here to debate republican vs democrat by the way. cmv.

auto_conc: i don't think my vote matters in this election.
gt: everyone seems to feel this way when it comes to election day but we so easily lose track of the link to the the actions behaviors of these officials throughout the rest of the term. lets assume you are super cynical about politics and you feel that all politicians are cheats and liars. they are still elected officials and and the end of the day have to pay lip service to the voters and make it look like they care about their constituents. that need to put on the air of caring for the people will influence the way that they are writing legislation and making deals which actually benefits people. maybe it is a 80 greed 20 social benefit kind of deal but imagine if those same people did not have to care about voters then it would be 100 greed all the time in which case you lose that 20 benefit. knowing that people are at least generally watching does have an effect. so even with a cynical view of the government it is super important to maintain voting as a healthy institution. the less that people care about politics the less that politicians will care about people and the most direct avenue for expressing care about politics is voting. if you are less cynical about politics then the rate of return for the value of voting only goes up.
