conclusion: The mainstream (US) Left and Right are both equally divisive.
premises: i would first note that i'm specifically talking about the mainstream dialogue, not the radicals on either end of the perspective. also, i am apolitical partially due to my career and do not favor either party or vote. i've noticed as several recent pieces of literature state the right wing is the source of political division as if it is axiomatic. i'm not talking about low hanging fruit types huffpo, salon, etc but legitimate academic works including straight talk on trade by dani rodrik president of political economy harvard and a world in disarray by richard haass president of the council on foreign relations . that said, historically, it's very clear that the right has been the perpetrator of division on race and every other aspect. but lately, it sure seems that the liberal wing is resorting to identity politics on the level of the early 20th century. there is division between urban and rural that smells like the pre holodomor period in ukraine, white supremacy living in the ether like alleged schemes of jewry in the northern european plain, and an attack on religious attitudes that resembles the ideas that led up to the early 1900's christian armenian genocide in turkey. i'm not positing that we're on the brink of a catastrophe. it can't be quantified necessarily, but it's definitely there: paul ryan has identified as such. change my view. i would also add that from my experience on reddit only been here for about a month , the left wing is brutal to the point of downvoting moderate ideas that exist in law today, or the current state of the economy, such as employment figures. as someone who pays attention to political polling, i'm aware that this isn't the state of the country at large.

premises: so there's some nuance to my beliefs here. if someone is caught outside without clothing then there shouldn't be any sort of repercussions or fines that affect them for being naked outdoors. in public transportation, like on buses or trains, we shouldn't have public nudity because of the issue of transference of germs between people because of contact on the seats. this change would be primarily for two purposes: first 1 to get rid of the laws and fines that are placed on people for being naked. given certain circumstances these sorts of laws can be detrimental towards people, and punishes them for simply being in their most natural state. and 2 to allow people the freedom to express their bodies publicly how they wish to without fear of punishment by the law. simple rules like 'no shirts, no shoes, no service' would still be applicable towards those facilities that choose to enact them. for those who don't know, in spain nudity is legal minus a few regions like in barcelona. this doesn't mean that public nudity is acceptable everywhere, there's a lot of places where nudity is gonna be looked down on, such as in the middle of a town. but it's still legalized and the country itself has a lot of options for interested people like nudists. last thing to cover is probably going to be religious and moral beliefs that are going to possibly be affected by this. to which my best argument that i can come up with is the rule of freedom of expression. in the united states at least, this is part of one of the biggest rights we have: freedom of speech. i don't think we should be limiting our expression by enacting certain laws with how we present our bodies, even if that presentation means no clothing at all. so there's my case, let's see yours. i'd love for you guys to tear into it! let's discuss this topic.

conclusion: Term "white privilege" is misleading and ultimately harmful to fighting racism
premises: i'm from a very 'white' country and besides stuff that i read online i have very little inside view on racial tensions in the usa. this is just something i've been thinking about and i'm wondering whether someone shares my views or has a solid argument against it. i don't think the term itself is correct and it changes the focus of the discussion. i really don't think that there's any doubt, that it's true. white people don't need to be afraid of contact with the police force, receive better treatment from justice system, etc. he's treated better than he should be. i think it's an important distinction that impacts discussion about systemic racism and racism in general. i think it's much more difficult to have a constructive conversation, when you tell someone who is simply treated the way everyone should be that he's privileged. i'm not surprised it doesn't sound good to some people and they react with hostility. it also switches focus from underprivileged groups. we shouldn't discuss what to do with white privilege, but how to get other races to the same level.

gt: i think most people in motorized wheelchairs are doing their best to be courteous and polite though. as you say, spaces can be tight and moving around difficult. if someone steps on my foot in a line i do not assume they are intentionally not concerning themselves, i assume it was an accident. now if they step on my foot pushing past me to get to the front of the line they are a jerk, and if a person in a wheelchair rolls over your foot to roll to the front of the line they are a jerk too. but i think it is just that a large motorized wheelchair it is easier to make a mistake in most cases though.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know about you, but i have a friend who is in a wheelchair. he was in an accident, and he had to use a wheelchair to get out of the way of a car. he had a broken leg, and had to walk to the hospital, where he was treated for it. it took him a few hours to get back to his car, and when he got back, he was on his way to the emergency room.
known_conc_attacks: you are right that people in wheelchairs should follow the same rules as the people walking in a wheelchair.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't know if you've heard of this, but i'd like to point out that people in wheelchairs are more likely to be knocked over and seriously injured by people in motorized transportation. that being said, i'm not sure where you're coming from, but there are plenty of places where people with wheelchairs can get knocked over.

conclusion: (1) Atheism and objective morality contradict each other. (2) There is no objective morality, all morality is subjective
premises: it was my assumption that this was a common belief among atheists; however, i ve come across a number who argue in favor of objective morality including matt dillahunty on the atheist experience show. a true follower of christ believes that killing someone is a sin, yet a large segment of the pro death penalty population is conservative christians. in this case, christians are caveating their stance against murder with their pro death penalty views.
argument: (1) Atheism and objective morality contradict each other. (2) There is no objective morality, all morality is subjective : it was my assumption that this was a common belief among atheists; however, i ve come across a number who argue in favor of objective morality including matt dillahunty on the atheist experience show. a true follower of christ believes that killing someone is a sin, yet a large segment of the pro death penalty population is conservative christians. in this case, christians are caveating their stance against murder with their pro death penalty views.
auto_conc: I believe that Christians are hypocrites for not supporting the death penalty.
gt: i don't see how theism would be treated differently here. just because a god sells his subjective opinion on morality doesn't make it so because such a god may be omnipotent or otherwise very powerful; that's just 'might makes right'. objectie morality is just silly in my opinion with or without theism. objective morality like objective reality is just an unprovable and silly idea; i'd say that it's one of those things that's worse than wrong and 'not even wrong' because the claim is beyond vague. what does it even mean for morality to be 'objective'? the claim is utterly vague and unfalsifiable and something one might call a 'god' existing or not doesn't change anything about that.

auto_conc_attacks: i don't believe that christians are hypocrites for not supporting the death penalty.

conclusion: There are significant, genetic differences in IQ between races.
premises: i know you guys get this a lot, but i really don't want to think this way. i want to be able to whole heartedly believe in racial equality. the most convincing evidence for the 'herarian' i've seen is admixture studies. biracial individuals tend to have higher scores than monoracial africans but lower iq scores than white folks. the adoption studies are also very convincing. just thinking logically, why would we expect that evolution stopped at the neck? i know people love to bring up mali, nubia, great zimbabwe, or the swahili city states; honestly, i don't know how anyone could seriously believe that these civilizations were as advanced as those in europe, asia, or even mesoamerica. why didn't major empires or nation states develop in equatorial or southern africa? overall, i haven't seen convincing evidence supporting a purely environmental explanation of racial differences in iq. thanks.
argument: There are significant, genetic differences in IQ between races. : i know you guys get this a lot, but i really don't want to think this way. i want to be able to whole heartedly believe in racial equality. the most convincing evidence for the 'herarian' i've seen is admixture studies. biracial individuals tend to have higher scores than monoracial africans but lower iq scores than white folks. the adoption studies are also very convincing. just thinking logically, why would we expect that evolution stopped at the neck? i know people love to bring up mali, nubia, great zimbabwe, or the swahili city states; honestly, i don't know how anyone could seriously believe that these civilizations were as advanced as those in europe, asia, or even mesoamerica. why didn't major empires or nation states develop in equatorial or southern africa? overall, i haven't seen convincing evidence supporting a purely environmental explanation of racial differences in iq. thanks.
auto_conc: I believe that racial differences in iq are the result of evolution.
gt: first i ll address the points you ve made. iq tests have lots of intraracial diversity. serbia is an almost entirely white country. their average iq is 89, much closer to the american black average of 85 than the american white average of 102. why would we see this if it s racially based? in addition to this, the american black iq of 85 is much higher than the african black iqs, which delve low into the 70s, yet american blacks on average have a european admixture of about 20 , not nearly enough to bring up the iq 15 points. second, the civilization argument is unconvincing. why didn t asians dominate if iq is directly related to civilization? whites did way more with lower iqs. calculus, space travel, atomic bombs, colonizing the world, creating industry. how did this happen if asians have higher iqs? and let s look at the middle east. iraq created mesopotamia with an iq of 87, why can t blacks do the same with 85? saudi arabia has the same iq as uganda 84 . india created thriving civilizations with an iq of 82. shouldn t ugandans be able to make the same civilizations as india? what s your response to the following counter points? 1. the flynn effect. intelligence actually increases over time despite genes remaining the same, implying that environment plays a much larger role than previously thought. 2. gender iq gap once existed, no longer does. let s debate anything said above or anything i didn t include mentioned in your op.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know if you've seen any convincing evidence that evolution stopped at the neck, but i don't think that's a bad thing.
known_conc_attacks: i don't see how you can believe that evolution stopped at the neck. there are significant, genetic differences in iq between races.
auto_conc_attacks: what do you mean by evolution?

conclusion: Defining sexuality as "attraction to sex" is an unhelpful way for people to label themselves: it should instead be "attraction to gender".
premises: small background: argued this point in another post, but the discussion was pretty cancerous and got nowhere, so i won't bother linking it; but feel free to look it up in my post history if interested the big comments, basically . i am very interested in legitimate counter arguments, so i posted this here. words have definitions, and are used to describe the world in useful ways. definitions cannot be proven wrong because they are axiomatic: they change overtime when a new definition for word x is better , not when the old definition is 'wrong'. this is not a good argument, as i see it. it's the rhetorical equivalent of 'it's wrong because it's not right', when the debate isn't about right or wrong, but more vs less useful, and definitions are never estabilished fact they change along time, locale, context, even between dictionaries . also: reminder that gender is, in pragmatic terms, gender identity expression, independent from sex. and for those unaware, 'trans woman' means male to female transgender, vice versa for trans men. just to avoid potential confusion. onto the real point: why is my definition more useful? as you can probably deduce from the title, the proposed 'change' has a lot to do with trans people. let's take a cis male attracted to cis and trans women. under the old definition, he is bisexual. however, why should he ever label himself as such? since he doesn't like men, cis or trans, he is not interested in showing availability to them: by labeling himself as bisexual, he is opening himself to that dating market, which he does not want to do. trans women generally view themselves as women, so they wouldn't show more interest towards a man who showed availability to other men; that is irrelevant to her. let's take another example: a cis male attracted to only cis women, 'straight' on the old definition: the change makes absolutely no difference. a potential counterargument is that he doesn't want to be open to dating trans women, but he can reject them, just as he would any other woman he doesn't like. an obvious counter argument to this counter argument, is that under the old definition, i could similarly say he is opening himself to trans men like buck angel someone a straight man is most likely not attracted to, so the argument is self defeating. deltas to whoever makes me rethink anything about this
argument: Defining sexuality as "attraction to sex" is an unhelpful way for people to label themselves: it should instead be "attraction to gender". : small background: argued this point in another post, but the discussion was pretty cancerous and got nowhere, so i won't bother linking it; but feel free to look it up in my post history if interested the big comments, basically . i am very interested in legitimate counter arguments, so i posted this here. words have definitions, and are used to describe the world in useful ways. definitions cannot be proven wrong because they are axiomatic: they change overtime when a new definition for word x is better , not when the old definition is 'wrong'. this is not a good argument, as i see it. it's the rhetorical equivalent of 'it's wrong because it's not right', when the debate isn't about right or wrong, but more vs less useful, and definitions are never estabilished fact they change along time, locale, context, even between dictionaries . also: reminder that gender is, in pragmatic terms, gender identity expression, independent from sex. and for those unaware, 'trans woman' means male to female transgender, vice versa for trans men. just to avoid potential confusion. onto the real point: why is my definition more useful? as you can probably deduce from the title, the proposed 'change' has a lot to do with trans people. let's take a cis male attracted to cis and trans women. under the old definition, he is bisexual. however, why should he ever label himself as such? since he doesn't like men, cis or trans, he is not interested in showing availability to them: by labeling himself as bisexual, he is opening himself to that dating market, which he does not want to do. trans women generally view themselves as women, so they wouldn't show more interest towards a man who showed availability to other men; that is irrelevant to her. let's take another example: a cis male attracted to only cis women, 'straight' on the old definition: the change makes absolutely no difference. a potential counterargument is that he doesn't want to be open to dating trans women, but he can reject them, just as he would any other woman he doesn't like. an obvious counter argument to this counter argument, is that under the old definition, i could similarly say he is opening himself to trans men like buck angel someone a straight man is most likely not attracted to, so the argument is self defeating. deltas to whoever makes me rethink anything about this
auto_conc: the old definition of 'bisexual' is better than the new
gt: men and women have sexual characteristics that differentiate each other. biologically they scratch itches that the vast majority of people, who are straight, respond to. trans people who pass are tricking the brain of the 'straight' man who likes trans women but not dudes by having a majority of features that resemble a woman's. we're attracted to sexual characteristics and i think you're making the mistake of reducing it to genitals when it's more than that.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think you can argue that your definition of 'biological' is wrong because it is axiomatic. i think the problem with your definition is that it is incorrect because you are using it in a way that doesn't make sense. if you are trying to change your definition, then you need to change the way you use it in order to make it more useful.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think this is the case. i think it's important to distinguish between a person's sexuality and their gender identity. for example, a person who identifies as a woman might identify as a man, but that doesn't mean that he's attracted to women. the same could be said for someone who is attracted to a woman, but it's not the same thing for a man who doesn't like women.
auto_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i don't think it is a good argument for changing the definition of bisexual. i think it would be better to change the definition to include bisexuality. i'm not saying that the new definition is better than the old definition, but it's a good counter argument.

conclusion: There should be no choice when it comes to organ donation after your death
premises: the organs you re buried with serve no functional purpose to you, but potentially have the power to save countless lives. even in the times where secularism appears to be on the incline, i accept that there still needs to be exceptions for people of faith. in that past people have stated to me that we can will a house, will money or other assets so why no choice with organs? for me it s because you worked your whole life to build up a decent pension, house, cars, cash etc and these things can be direct benefit to your loved ones when you pass on. organs are different. i know it the modern day that any sign of losing your right to choose anything is seen as a negative, i have a hard time finding any reasons for the government not to legislate this.
argument: There should be no choice when it comes to organ donation after your death : the organs you re buried with serve no functional purpose to you, but potentially have the power to save countless lives. even in the times where secularism appears to be on the incline, i accept that there still needs to be exceptions for people of faith. in that past people have stated to me that we can will a house, will money or other assets so why no choice with organs? for me it s because you worked your whole life to build up a decent pension, house, cars, cash etc and these things can be direct benefit to your loved ones when you pass on. organs are different. i know it the modern day that any sign of losing your right to choose anything is seen as a negative, i have a hard time finding any reasons for the government not to legislate this.
auto_conc: i believe that organ donation should be mandatory.
gt: would you be willing to slightly modify the view, to better account for those with anti donation views? i believe that organ donation should be the default, but it would an opt out program. opting out of donation would also remove you from the list of those able to accept a donation.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think the government should be allowed to do this.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'no choice', but i think you're missing the point. if you're talking about the death of a loved one, i don't see why you'd want to have a choice. it's not that you don't want to donate your organs, it's that you want to save someone's life. i'm not saying that there should be no choice, but you seem to be arguing that there shouldn't be.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think the government should be required to do this, because i don't believe they should. i think they should be able to do whatever they want with their bodies, even if they don't want to.

conclusion: There will be no war with Russia
premises: they are blustering, buffoonish, dishonest, folks who are still salty about the fall of their great empire. even their nuclear bombs aren't a advandtage as we have more of them, and in much better quality. poland on its own could probbably handle the russian mlitary, i mean, the ukraine has not been defeated yet which really puts into perspective the weakness of the russian military. europe on its own outmatches russia like a rhinoceros outmatches a goat. even if russia could somehow invade, they would have no chance of occupying for very long. you need an insane number of soldiers to hold down an area with a population of 500 million people, even if most of the population does not participate in a likely insurrgency. russia required 150 soldiers for every 1000 people in chechenya which has a population of 1. 3 million people. they can barely hold onto chechenya much less the small piece of the ukraine they stole, how can they hold on to europe? russia sees europe as customers for their oil barons, not as a target that must be enslaved or exterminated. russia is an economic bully using military threats to scare the people they are trying to sell to.

gt: you points seem to rely on military power as the only factor. the usa lost a war with vietnamese farmers and are struggling to contain dudes in pick ups with ak's right now, despite our nuclear power and vast array of aircraft carriers. war is not limited to full on, nuclear bomb vs nuclear bomb style warfare. it's often proxy wars. take the russian invasion of crimea a few years ago. if russia were to start invading another country, something closer to europe, there would hopefully be a response. this could escalate into the uk being involved, or any other european ally. the us would be inclined to help it's allies over russia. it's entirely possible.

conclusion: I would have a happier, more fulfilled life if I didn't have to work.
premises: this belief dives into many parts of my life so i'll go through each. to me, working makes us slaves. people are forced to get jobs just to survive. everyday feels like a fight for my life. i feel as though if people were told that they could have food, water, a house, car and education for free, then we would have no worries to just do what we wanted to do with our lives. personally, if i could just spend my days carving wood, writing a book, or anything leisurely by myself, i would do it. don't confuse that sentence with 'i want to make a business out of those things i love' because i don't. if someone told me i could carve wood as my job, i'd be upset because then it loses the leisure. that once leisurely activity then becomes a means of my survival, the root of my fight or flight response, my anxiety and i don't want that. it's become clear that many are focusing on the 'needing some work for fulfillment' and the 'liesure leading to depression' answers. so i feel the need to expand my post to include that i'm more referring to working to survive. generally, i'm a busy body but working to survive is awful. maybe the cmv is actually 'the need for money survival prevents me from living a fulfilling life'. some have confused my desire to live a life without a need for survival as a desire to have anyone else help me survive and in that you'd be wrong. a stress free life for every person without a need for them to survive. ideally currently unrealistic , people just would survive. i don't know how i'm sure we're hundreds of years away from this solution and it would take more than just me to figure it out but it's beside the point. some believe that i think that things are just going to appear but throughout, i've only referenced resources necessary for survival. just a world where your basic needs are met. that doesn't mean tv, or movies, or anything that you don't absolutely need. those other things are wants not needs. so if you wanted something, of course you'd work for it. but if you needed something, that's different.

conclusion: its good to correct peoples grammar.
premises: i ve been seeing it more and more lately. people using fewer instead of less or people using are to refer to groups instead of is . i m not an english major. i haven t even taken more english classes than the average person. so please don t mistake this as an english major trying to strut their stuff and feel superior. i understand that it s just the internet and people have argued that proper use only really matters if you are writing a paper or an email to a boss or a colleague. but over a long enough period of time, improper usage of basic skills leads to the proper usage becoming forgotten. right? now if i m just being overly picky about these i m more than happy to hear why. just be nice about it.
argument: its good to correct peoples grammar. : i ve been seeing it more and more lately. people using fewer instead of less or people using are to refer to groups instead of is . i m not an english major. i haven t even taken more english classes than the average person. so please don t mistake this as an english major trying to strut their stuff and feel superior. i understand that it s just the internet and people have argued that proper use only really matters if you are writing a paper or an email to a boss or a colleague. but over a long enough period of time, improper usage of basic skills leads to the proper usage becoming forgotten. right? now if i m just being overly picky about these i m more than happy to hear why. just be nice about it.
auto_conc: i think people who use "in a day and age" as a way to refer to something are just lazy.
gt: i think it depends on context. for the record, i was an english major and i am an english teacher so, literally, part of my job includes correcting grammar . however, i think in addition to tone how you do it, when you do it matters a lot. sometimes it's better to focus on what people mean and correcting their grammar makes them feel less heard. so if the person is saying or writing something serious, address the content, not the style. make them feel heard. even in the classroom, it's important to separate revising content based workshops from ing grammar and spelling because people naturally get lost in pedantic issues rather than truly improving their expression. at the end of the day, meaning should be highly prioritized over style which should be prioritized over grammar. i'm fine with grammar bots, and i'll answer grammatical questions. people love to ask english teachers grammar questions. honestly, i love talking the finer points of grammar sometimes, as well as linguistics in general. but i see a lot of derailment from truly communication happening when someone chooses to nitpick grammar instead of looking at meaning. grammar rules exist to facilitate meaning in the end.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're underestimating the importance of proper use of language. if you're going to use a word that you're not familiar with, then you need to be familiar with the word. in other words, if you don't know how to use it properly, you're probably going to have a hard time understanding what it means to be an english major.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's very important to have a proper grammar. if you're writing a paper or an email to a boss or a colleague, you're not going to be able to use the correct grammar.

conclusion: The USA is too litigious and strict with law, and it negatively impacts a lot of us.
premises: from invention creation on patents to multi million dollar lawsuits against medical companies, it seems to me that those who want to change our nation, often for the better, have to worry an unreasonable amount about the legal implications of their desires. from wanting to cure people the best you can, or in a way more similar to eastern medicine, to wanting to improve technology it seems there is often a law that restricts or regulates a person's ability to really get as far as they otherwise could. secondly i believe the desire to go to court over so many things creates an amount of hostility and fear in others. it limits many of our amendments, because you can sue someone over nearly anything we become afraid to say and do things we have every right to do. yet, the better lawyer often wins, not the actual person in the right, or in the wrong. i'm not saying we should dump lawyers as a profession, or litigation as a means of correcting a wrong. i am saying that billboard signs suggesting you take something to court is over the top, and measures should be taken to make this society more responsible and interactive. certainly some good arguments for having our court system and litigation as a means of compensation, protection, etc still searching for the point that would make america seem balanced in this aspect, though. u oneshomeisonescastle has brought up a very good point that there is no real way to go about changing how things are, i offer nothing in the way of 'fixing' the issue i bring up, and because of my general lack of experience on the topic, any fixes i'd suggest would likely break the system more i. e. people would have less access to legal services when it would be much better if they need them i don't entirely concede my original point, but somewhat digress there's nothing better i can offer.

conclusion: Marrying younger is a great option. (Not child brides but 19-early twenties, at least finish high school first!)
premises: my wife f25 and i m27 got married young. i was 21 and she was 19. i didn t have any engrained habits that needed to be reconciled with another person. i don t have a certain way that i load the dishwasher, budget my money, fold towels, soap preference, side of the bed i sleep on, etc. small things aren t an issue because we both came up with them together. 2. we developed as adults together so we formed to complement each other. i often joke that we are a one hermaphroditic blog with one mind because we have similar stances on issues. we don t have irreconcilable differences because we didn t have any engrained stances. no rvsd debates in on our house! i also always had someone to call me out on my youthful bullshit still do! 3. being married doesn t mean that i can t developer as healthy a individual. we have separate hobbies interests, viewpoints and tastes. there are plenty of things we can do separately. 4. also, i don t have the fomo fear of missing out about sowing my wild oats because i have an automatic sex buddy! 5. it s a better financial situation for broke young kids. now i m finishing up engineering degree and i have a sugar mama ; we also got tax breaks from an early age. there are more write offs for both being students at some point and there s a tax break for being married. there are many more minute points but the main ones are 1, 2 and 5. i think couples who get married young have a greater potential to do great.

auto_conc: i think getting married young is a good thing.
gt: aged 20 to 30 is arguably one of the most transformative times in ones life. yes, people can and do get and stay married during this time, but the risk factor is high because of this reason. the ideals and goals one has at 20 is almost always a very far stretch from where the ones arrives at 30 with, and because of that, binding your life with another person is not exactly the wisest thing to do. im not saying it can't work, i'm just saying it typically doesn't work and this is the main reason. marriage stands a better chance once both parties have moved through this period of growth. for some, they can grow together and find they want the same things out of life, but the reality is that most do not. i speak as someone who started dating my husband at 20, married at 26 and were still happily married at 35. so i know what's possible, but for every couple like us, there's 5 others who had the opposite experience.

conclusion: The US needs a Constitutional Convention
premises: hopefully this isn't too common a topic on cmv; the last post to put it this way was 2 years ago and more recent ones were more narrowly defined and are nearly a year old themselves . it had a great run it's the oldest constitution in continuous use, but most modern constitutions are written to be updated more frequently and actually are. ours is only really updated by supreme court decisions, with only 2 amendments being ratified in the last 50 years one of which was first proposed in 1789! til . the founders could not have imagined the world we live in today or its challenges, and the document is written as such. flawed solutions like the electoral college were created to solve problems of the 18th century that are irrelevant in the 21st. the founding fathers saw tyrannical government as the biggest threats to the rights of individuals, and wrote the constitution to protect those rights. that was logical in their day, but that is not the threat that those of us in modern democracies face. tyrannical companies taking from an article that's currently on the front page are the primary threat to individual rights and freedoms, and our government and constitution is not equipped to deal with that threat. i'm sure i'll get into more specific critiques in the comments, but that buildup of history and precedent makes justice incredibly difficult to come by in many instances and needs revision. if you haven't, i'd urge you to read the text. it takes like 20 minutes for the main text; probably 40 60 with amendments and is available everywhere. one of the main arguments that will likely be raised that will not change my view is the political will difficulty argument. i know it would be hard or impossible to make happen, especially given current politics.

conclusion: Racial information should be removed from college and job applications.
premises: i think it's absurd that it's done and it's not equal opportunity. people say by doing this that you're benefiting white people but i'm not sure how that's true. the argument can be made on financial assistance with how much money they're are assisted with based on race, however that should be determined after the applicant is accepted.
argument: Racial information should be removed from college and job applications. : i think it's absurd that it's done and it's not equal opportunity. people say by doing this that you're benefiting white people but i'm not sure how that's true. the argument can be made on financial assistance with how much money they're are assisted with based on race, however that should be determined after the applicant is accepted.
auto_conc: I think affirmative action is wrong and should be abolished.
gt: i have 2 point. 1 is that it's used as a statistical tool. where they want to know how many of a specific race or gender is applied or attending so that info can be used for various things. one thing that info is used for is to make sure that an equal opportunity is presented for all. like a collage that leans toward accepting students of a particular race. this information would make it harder for schools to selectively pick from highschool's using the methodology that you can dertermine within reasonablity a persons race economic level from the school they went to that have a higher chance of giving them a student of a race economic level that they want. 2 it is used for pr. one of the main things that collages love to talk about is how diverse they are. to avoid the 'then they are picking them for there race' argument that could stem from that line of thinking it would be best to put it in terms of value to the other students. a student who can bring in firsthand knowledge of another culture and share that knowledge with other students would be more beneficial to the school to have them enrolled there. colleges are a business first so it makes sense for them to do what helps them the most.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's absurd that it's done and it's not equal opportunity. i think it is absurd that they are doing it because they're benefiting white people.
known_conc_attacks: it's not about race, it's about how the applicant is going to be treated. it's a matter of how they are treated. a lot of white people are treated differently than black people.
auto_conc_attacks: what do you mean by 'equal opportunity'? i think affirmative action is wrong and should be abolished. i think it's absurd that it's done and it's not equal opportunity.

conclusion: A joint account with a percentage-of-income (with a few other considerations) is the best way to split money
premises: i know this can have a lot of exceptions. please don't make your arguments about pointing out 2 or 3 exceptions that are technically true. i'll list a few to save the trouble: a person with reckless spending or addiction gambling issues should not have this split. significant inheritances should not necessarily have this split the extremely rich or extremely poor should not necessarily have this split massive debts massive differences in work time lots of other exceptions but for most people, i think this split is the best method. money has an economic value. if you compare the salary of a strategic consulting manager and a veterinarian assistant, you're going to get 200k versus 40k or something crazy. but in a relationship, i don't think economic value should necessarily be considered, unless the difference in income is so vast that one person's income is literally chump change i. e. 500k vs 30k . in a relationship, especially that of a marriage, the 'most important value' is time and effort of the individual. person1 makes 80k after taxes; person2 makes 40k. person1 would input 40k into their joint account, while person2 inputs 20k. as a result, in real money, person1 is providing more. person2 is also providing 50 . caveat. please read this caveat. let's say for example i make 100k and my partner makes 20k. i put in 50k and keep 50k while she puts in 10k and keeps 10k. unfortunately, that means that i get to live it up and have a pretty damn good life whereas she has to keep both savings and expenses under 800 per month. so why this view? 1. 2. provides freedom to both people and rewards high earners in exchange for providing more this allows both parties to win. 3. this makes their life much more difficult and makes them less capable of affording more. 4. gifts are more meaningful in a fully shared money situation, gifts are important but also become difficult to justify. makes for a difficult situation. 5. use your own money. no problem! want to buy a ps4? no need to ask me, go for it! want to go out and treat 10 people out to drinks? go for it! not my money, not my problem. again this is basically the freedom argument. caveats i know there are exceptions to this rule. i'll try to list out as many as i can. and yes some of this repeats from the beginning of the post but i thought mentioning it twice makes it more likely for everyone to see it. here's a real life example. i make 80k and my girlfriend makes 30k post taxes. but neither of us works harder than the other. she makes 30k because she chose a career that's important for the world, but pays very very little. if we do a 75 75 split, then i end up keeping 20k per year. she gets 7. 5k. maximum retirement contribution is 5. 5k. so now i have 14. 5k left and she only has 2k. 2k for a whole year is nothing. she can barely afford anything for herself. i keep 20k, she gets 15k. now it's more even, now it's fairer. cmv

no need to ask me, go for it! want to go out and treat 10 people out to drinks? go for it! not my money, not my problem. again this is basically the freedom argument. caveats i know there are exceptions to this rule. i'll try to list out as many as i can. and yes some of this repeats from the beginning of the post but i thought mentioning it twice makes it more likely for everyone to see it. here's a real life example. i make 80k and my girlfriend makes 30k post taxes. but neither of us works harder than the other. she makes 30k because she chose a career that's important for the world, but pays very very little. if we do a 75 75 split, then i end up keeping 20k per year. she gets 7. 5k. maximum retirement contribution is 5. 5k. so now i have 14. 5k left and she only has 2k. 2k for a whole year is nothing. she can barely afford anything for herself. i keep 20k, she gets 15k. now it's more even, now it's fairer. cmv
auto_conc: i think the most sensible split of money in a relationship or any relationship is: "you get what you deserve, she gets what she can afford."
gt: while i haven't personally dealt with large scale financing with a long term partner, i have been on many multi day dates or trips with friends that involved some amount of covering who paid for what, or people paying up front for rooms and getting paid back by the group later, or whatever. what i noticed was that there were two very distinct philosophies regarding payment. some people wanted extremely equitable payments, keeping track of most all expenses and the relative amount owed by most everybody. they would be very upset if they felt transactions were 'unfair', or if people failed to remember even minor exchanges who went on a donut run in the morning, or w e . another group of people, while obviously not willing to cover everything for people, would basically just take things as they went and expect all the little expenses to even out over time. if they noticed a trend e. g. they're paying for every donut run , they'd bring it up and ask somebody else to cover, but not try to figure out how much anybody 'owed'. to this group of people, not only did they not need to have everything turn out 100 equitably all the time, it was actually deeply unpleasant to deal with the sort of exact tallying and scorekeeping and reminders that were part of keeping things equitable. to use an analogy, it's the difference between the people who keep track of whose turn it is to buy a round at the bar, versus the people who figure that rounds at the bar will even out in the long term. relationships are no doubt the same way. some people might really want things to be equitable and to figure out exactly how much is appropriate to spend and who pays for what from the get go. if that's what works for you, more power to you. but plenty of people don't want that, and in fact find that sort of tallying to be a tremendous and unnecessary burden when a combination of trust not caring about exact quantities spent works out well enough.
masked_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i don't think it's the best way to divide money. in a relationship, if you split your income, you have to pay for the benefits of the relationship. i think that's a good thing, but it's a bad thing to split your money. for example, if i make 100k a year, i have to give 100k to my wife, and she has to give 10k to me. that's not a good way to split my money.
known_conc_attacks: if you make 100k and have 100k, you're going to get 100k. if you make 200k and you have 10k, then you're probably going to be able to buy a ps4.
auto_conc_attacks: i think that it's important to distinguish between a person who gets 100k and someone who gets 50k. you don't get 100k, you get 50k, and you get 20k. that's pretty much the same as a person getting 100k.

conclusion: Alpha dog theory is not a myth
premises: watch this video to get a basic understanding of this discussion amp; x200b; here is my brief response: 1. there's a reason for dominant and recessive traits in our dna. genetic traits develop as we evolve to survive in our specific ecosystem. superior traits in male adults physical strength, endurance, intelligence, skin tone, etc attract females they can't help but be attracted, they're coded this way because they have a higher chance of survival in that specific part of the earth. he chooses the equally genetically desirable female. 2. regarding aggressive behavior, adam misrepresents the traits of the dominant male. the meek rule the earth. listen to the world's most powerful people speak. the last thing they are is aggressive because it displays a weakness in their ability to control their own emotions. being kind also actually takes more balls than being an asshole, simply because we are socially conditioned to think 'asshole she will let me fuck her', and if you go against the grain to be a man of honor, you will encounter resistance, but reap huge rewards as your character is revealed. change my view!
argument: Alpha dog theory is not a myth : watch this video to get a basic understanding of this discussion amp; x200b; here is my brief response: 1. there's a reason for dominant and recessive traits in our dna. genetic traits develop as we evolve to survive in our specific ecosystem. superior traits in male adults physical strength, endurance, intelligence, skin tone, etc attract females they can't help but be attracted, they're coded this way because they have a higher chance of survival in that specific part of the earth. he chooses the equally genetically desirable female. 2. regarding aggressive behavior, adam misrepresents the traits of the dominant male. the meek rule the earth. listen to the world's most powerful people speak. the last thing they are is aggressive because it displays a weakness in their ability to control their own emotions. being kind also actually takes more balls than being an asshole, simply because we are socially conditioned to think 'asshole she will let me fuck her', and if you go against the grain to be a man of honor, you will encounter resistance, but reap huge rewards as your character is revealed. change my view!
auto_conc: I believe that males are born aggressive, and females are born friendly.
gt: your premises correct me if i m misrepresenting you :1 some traits in men are more preferable2 these preferable traits are genetic3 women s desire for these traits is also geneticto take each point in turn:1 no contest, if your talking in generalities2 some preferable traits are also environmental being born into a wealthy family and learned knowing how to cook 3 if we only wanted things for genetic reasons, women would idealize the same sorts of men over every time period. similarly, what kind of women men prefer changes in the 1700s, it was full figured women, in the 1970s it was narrow waisted women. if sexual desire is hardwired, it wouldn t be malleable. that it changes overtime suggests it s at least partially a software thing, as opposed to a hardware thing. evolutionary psychology is interesting, but it sometimes borders pseudoscience when it makes causal claims. usually, evolutionary psychology presents a theory that explains human behavior however, unless a theory is tested, it is just a hypothesis, a hunch. moreover, as this hypothesis does not explain all the facts, such as why our conception of the ideal man changes over time and culture, it s not even that good a hypothesis.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a big deal, but i don't see why it shouldn't be. i'm not sure what you mean by 'the meek rule the earth', but i think you're missing the point. i think it is important to recognize that there is a difference between being kind and being an asshole. it's important to realize that there are a lot of people out there who are not being kind, and that being kind is not necessarily a bad thing. if someone is going to be kind to you, then you're going to have to be nice to them. i mean, it's not like you're saying that they are being nice to you. you're just saying that you're being kind to them, but that's not the case.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think there's any evidence that this is true, but i do think it's a myth. there's a lot of evidence for this, and it's hard to argue against, but it's true that alpha dog theory is a myth because it's based on the assumption that alpha dogs are more likely to be aggressive than other dogs. it's also true that it's not a myth, it's just that the evidence is so strong that it doesn't make sense.
auto_conc_attacks: i think it's important to note that your view is based on a misunderstanding of biology. it's not that males are born aggressive, it's that they're born friendly, and they have a higher chance of survival in that specific part of the earth.

conclusion: I would have a happier, more fulfilled life if I didn't have to work.
premises: this belief dives into many parts of my life so i'll go through each. to me, working makes us slaves. people are forced to get jobs just to survive. everyday feels like a fight for my life. i feel as though if people were told that they could have food, water, a house, car and education for free, then we would have no worries to just do what we wanted to do with our lives. personally, if i could just spend my days carving wood, writing a book, or anything leisurely by myself, i would do it. don't confuse that sentence with 'i want to make a business out of those things i love' because i don't. if someone told me i could carve wood as my job, i'd be upset because then it loses the leisure. that once leisurely activity then becomes a means of my survival, the root of my fight or flight response, my anxiety and i don't want that. it's become clear that many are focusing on the 'needing some work for fulfillment' and the 'liesure leading to depression' answers. so i feel the need to expand my post to include that i'm more referring to working to survive. generally, i'm a busy body but working to survive is awful. maybe the cmv is actually 'the need for money survival prevents me from living a fulfilling life'. some have confused my desire to live a life without a need for survival as a desire to have anyone else help me survive and in that you'd be wrong. a stress free life for every person without a need for them to survive. ideally currently unrealistic , people just would survive. i don't know how i'm sure we're hundreds of years away from this solution and it would take more than just me to figure it out but it's beside the point. some believe that i think that things are just going to appear but throughout, i've only referenced resources necessary for survival. just a world where your basic needs are met. that doesn't mean tv, or movies, or anything that you don't absolutely need. those other things are wants not needs. so if you wanted something, of course you'd work for it. but if you needed something, that's different.

gt: depends on how you mean. if you mean live in the current society but without working and everyone else does, with you being unaffected, or society doesn t truly exist and everyone is free to do whatever. either way, you can look at it from this pov. the human brain naturally gives incentive to progress, weather its building shelters, eating food or getting money, the brain rewards good actions that help the body. but the world has changed since we truly had to hunt food. so many replaced that with there jobs. and money being the prey. the brain rewards you for progression at work, like a raise. because the brain loves to work on big projects that take a ton of time. without the jobs, you wouldn t get the reward. this is where a lot of rich people get depression. they have reached the peak and can t go any farther up. obviously find a job your interested in and can stick with so your brain can make you happy.

conclusion: It's unethical to accuse someone of sexual assault after 4 decades
premises: a great example of this rush to judgement is chris hardwick, who was actually removed from his show at amc based on allegations from his ex girlfriend chloe dykstra. so now we have a woman coming forward nearly 40 years later to accuse a supreme court nominee of groping her while in high school. aside from the fact that the timing makes her political motivations interesting and aside from the fact that her story does seem credible and aside from the fact that she apparently isn't willing to testify about it which is perhaps the worst part amp; x200b; there is a reason most criminal charges have a statute of limitations. for someone in brett kavanaugh's position, how could he reasonably be expected to defend the allegations in a meaningful way, in a way where he can clear his name with certainty? where were you on this day 36 years ago? who were you with? do you have an alibi? there can be no physical evidence collected or pictures taken, or detailed police reports of the events. the accuracy of of the statements of potential witnesses of an incident evidence shows eyewitness testimony isn't as accurate as we thought, and it gets worse over time. christine ford doesn't even know for sure when the assault took place, but she thinks it was 1982. amp; x200b;

auto_conc: the standard of proof in sexual assault cases is too low
gt: it seems that a large number of children were sexually assaulted by priests over an extended period of time in their lives. some children were even given a special crucifix so that other priests could recognize them and molest them too. given the special nature of a trusted father figure, the purposefully instilled belief that you somehow caused the sin in the first place, the fact that people really do lose their memories of such traumatic events and only remember them much later in life, the need to stop someone from ever doing such a thing again no matter their age, and potentially stop others from molesting by showing them they can be charged at any time of their life, i'd say there's a fairly ethical reason to allow people to come forward 40 years later.

conclusion: Poe Dameron was not simply just wrong for questioning Admiral Holdo and taking action, nor was he the "true villain" of TLJ.
premises: i think i maybe should've made this 'cmv: holdo should have done something to inspire all members of the resistance to trust in her and not come up with a plan of their own especially considering poe's history . ' poe obviously made some serious mistakes previously, but i believe that in regards to the chase and their plans, he and holdo were both right and wrong in some respects. i recently had a discussion with someone where they told me that they thought that he should have just trusted her and done as he was told, that all in the military should always follow their orders without question though i'm not trying to open another rabbit hole with that , and that the scene was meant to illustrate how men need to just shut up and listen to women. she may have had a plan and it may have worked and by that one could argue that she was right; i see this as a parallel to the jedi at large. i believe this ties in with luke's saying the jedi need to end and all of that to illustrate how even if one group may be in some way right, if they can't effectively communicate why they're right or something else to get people to trust in it enough to actually implement it, it's not going to succeed or produce the desired change or outcome regardless. like how much anakin was preached to about the evils of the dark side but was never communicated the realities of it well enough to successfully instill in him what it would take to get him to have not gone down that path. holdo failed as a leader by failing to instill the faith in her needed for her plan to work successfully. it's 100 fair for her to not have wanted to divulge specific details in an effort to safeguard the plan, but given what she thought of poe as a person i think it's completely fair to say that she definitely should have at least simply told him that she did have a plan and that she wasn't just going to let them all die without even trying to do anything, which is what she led them to believe was happening. she didn't even have a look of confidence when saying what she said to the crew, again that could have been intentional in an effort to keep the plan secret, but she should have said something more to, at least, poe. what good is a leader who knows exactly how to fix all our problems if they aren't actually a leader and can't get people to actually do the things to make those changes happen? poe was faced with a situation where he was basically told that they were just going to fly til they ran out of fuel and the enemies caught up and killed them, without even trying to do anything about it. he was given, so far as i perceived, no reason to support this order other than the fact that she was of superior rank. he made the call in his mind that since they were just going to let them all die that he would at least come up with a plan to try and do something about it, a plan which a black guy and an asian woman both also supported and helped to come up with but no one seems to talk about the black guy or asian woman who also didn't follow holdo and supported taking action on their own . this whole thing seems to be getting reduced to being about sex, or more specifically, the evils of white males and the patriarchy, and the fact that a black guy and asian woman also opposed holdo doesn't fit in with that notion very well. the other person also said how if he just would have followed his superior's order how the plan would have worked perfectly. one could, perhaps fairly, say that this wouldn't even be a factor or a point for me to make if he had followed orders, but i can also, i believe fairly, say that if finn and rose had followed orders and gotten the right person at the casino instead of deciding that they could make due with the option that presented itself as opposed to the one they were ordered to find that then poe's plan would have worked. really, both plans could have actually simultaneously worked. if finn and rose had gotten the right person and managed to covertly board the enemy ship and disable their shields, anyone not necessary for the fight could have escaped in the landing pods and just a few could have stayed back to try and destroy the enemy ship; in which case they would again already be facing death and if the battle started going south then they could have still simply flew lightspeed through it as holdo did on her own. i may be wrong but i think it's also fair to speculate that it would have taken fewer people in the ship for the battle than the number that died in the pods in the failed escape attempt. the last jedi, to me, was about how much more complicated these things are than any of us generally like to contend with. about the problems with the mindset of 'i'm right so you just need to shut up and do what i say because i'm right. ' they may damn well be right but that is certainly not an effective way to act because it will not inspire people to come to follow you. we must demand more of our leaders and we must be more sympathetic to and have more empathy for those we view as being in opposition to us, if not out of care for them out of care for actually advancing your own correctness instead of just ranting about how smart you are and how dumb everyone else is and how the world would be so much better if we just listened to you continuously because no matter how much you rant it doesn't cause the change you wish to see. yoda told luke that the best thing he may have to offer as a teaching are his mistakes, and from that he tells leia that no one is ever really gone. they can't give up on kylo, ben is still there. luke can't try to kill his nephew because of a dream he had and we can't declare people to be evil and delete them from our lives because they voted for trump. if we actually are so much smarter and want the world to be better then we need to be better and we need to do more and we need to care and work not just within the frame of how we feel things should be people should just follow orders and consider and work also based on how things actually are at the present moment consider your feeling that this person is wreckless and in your mind simply sexist and realize that they will probably not follow you if you don't do something more to get them to, regardless of whether that's something you should have to do or not . that is not, however, to say that we shouldn't also work to move things in the direction of how they should be. tldr some are acting like it's just an issue of sexism and i think that's an almost comically absurd i say almost because it's too troubling to really be funny for me, i thought the movie made such a beautiful statement that seeing it so severely oversimplified and misperceived damn near makes me sick oversimplification at best and to a degree just plain wrong.

produce the desired change or outcome regardless. like how much anakin was preached to about the evils of the dark side but was never communicated the realities of it well enough to successfully instill in him what it would take to get him to have not gone down that path. holdo failed as a leader by failing to instill the faith in her needed for her plan to work successfully. it's 100 fair for her to not have wanted to divulge specific details in an effort to safeguard the plan, but given what she thought of poe as a person i think it's completely fair to say that she definitely should have at least simply told him that she did have a plan and that she wasn't just going to let them all die without even trying to do anything, which is what she led them to believe was happening. she didn't even have a look of confidence when saying what she said to the crew, again that could have been intentional in an effort to keep the plan secret, but she should have said something more to, at least, poe. what good is a leader who knows exactly how to fix all our problems if they aren't actually a leader and can't get people to actually do the things to make those changes happen? poe was faced with a situation where he was basically told that they were just going to fly til they ran out of fuel and the enemies caught up and killed them, without even trying to do anything about it. he was given, so far as i perceived, no reason to support this order other than the fact that she was of superior rank. he made the call in his mind that since they were just going to let them all die that he would at least come up with a plan to try and do something about it, a plan which a black guy and an asian woman both also supported and helped to come up with but no one seems to talk about the black guy or asian woman who also didn't follow holdo and supported taking action on their own . this whole thing seems to be getting reduced to being about sex, or more specifically, the evils of white males and the patriarchy, and the fact that a black guy and asian woman also opposed holdo doesn't fit in with that notion very well. the other person also said how if he just would have followed his superior's order how the plan would have worked perfectly. one could, perhaps fairly, say that this wouldn't even be a factor or a point for me to make if he had followed orders, but i can also, i believe fairly, say that if finn and rose had followed orders and gotten the right person at the casino instead of deciding that they could make due with the option that presented itself as opposed to the one they were ordered to find that then poe's plan would have worked. really, both plans could have actually simultaneously worked. if finn and rose had gotten the right person and managed to covertly board the enemy ship and disable their shields, anyone not necessary for the fight could have escaped in the landing pods and just a few could have stayed back to try and destroy the enemy ship; in which case they would again already be facing death and if the battle started going south then they could have still simply flew lightspeed through it as holdo did on her own. i may be wrong but i think it's also fair to speculate that it would have taken fewer people in the ship for the battle than the number that died in the pods in the failed escape attempt. the last jedi, to me, was about how much more complicated these things are than any of us generally like to contend with. about the problems with the mindset of 'i'm right so you just need to shut up and do what i say because i'm right. ' they may damn well be right but that is certainly not an effective way to act because it will not inspire people to come to follow you. we must demand more of our leaders and we must be more sympathetic to and have more empathy for those we view as being in opposition to us, if not out of care for them out of care for actually advancing your own correctness instead of just ranting about how smart you are and how dumb everyone else is and how the world would be so much better if we just listened to you continuously because no matter how much you rant it doesn't cause the change you wish to see. yoda told luke that the best thing he may have to offer as a teaching are his mistakes, and from that he tells leia that no one is ever really gone. they can't give up on kylo, ben is still there. luke can't try to kill his nephew because of a dream he had and we can't declare people to be evil and delete them from our lives because they voted for trump. if we actually are so much smarter and want the world to be better then we need to be better and we need to do more and we need to care and work not just within the frame of how we feel things should be people should just follow orders and consider and work also based on how things actually are at the present moment consider your feeling that this person is wreckless and in your mind simply sexist and realize that they will probably not follow you if you don't do something more to get them to, regardless of whether that's something you should have to do or not . that is not, however, to say that we shouldn't also work to move things in the direction of how they should be. tldr some are acting like it's just an issue of sexism and i think that's an almost comically absurd i say almost because it's too troubling to really be funny for me, i thought the movie made such a beautiful statement that seeing it so severely oversimplified and misperceived damn near makes me sick oversimplification at best and to a degree just plain wrong.
auto_conc: poe and finn were both right in some respects
gt: i think your view can boil down to yes and no . as an enlisted service member, i can tell you that poe was 100 wrong. and if he had pulled that stunt in the armed forces, he would have been tossed in jail and court martialed. there are two levels in the battlefield; tactical and strategic. poe, as a fighter pilot directly albeit the best in the resistance is at the tactical level. his technical knowledge is incredibly strong, he can think on his feet, and he can be relied on to win any battle. admiral holdo is at the strategic level. she s not focused on the battles, though winning them is important; she s focused on the war. a consequence of that is what leads to a lot of lower ranking officers and enlisted personnel not thinking very highly of anyone with stars on their shoulders; generals and admirals are often not seen as being very in touch with their junior personnel. holdo has the entire resistance to think about, not just the ego of the hot shot fly boy who just cost them their entire bomber fleet. but this is where the resistance itself comes into play. the resistance is not a military. they have ranks, but not uniforms, and a very loose chain of command which can beat be described as tldr; leia s in charge. i would honestly classify them as more of a guerrilla unit than an army. without those reinforced chains of command, you open yourself up to a situation where a junior officer leading others into a mutiny could happen. you could argue that this is a good thing, but at the end of the day you have a situation where poe jeopardized the escape plan holdo put together because he didn t trust his leadership.
masked_conc_attacks: i agree with you that the jedi need to end, but i don't think it's fair to say that holdo should have done something to inspire all members of the resistance to trust in her and not come up with a plan of their own especially considering poe's history.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think this is a good way to look at it. poe was a great leader, but she didn't have a plan. she was also a good leader. she had a plan, and she knew exactly what it would take to get her to do it. she knew that the jedi were going to kill her, and that she was going to do whatever she could to get them to stop doing it. it's not that poe didn't know what she was doing, it's that she knew what she had to do to get people to believe in her. she also knew that she wasn't going to let them die without knowing what they were doing. i'm not saying that she should have done that, but that she shouldn't have done it.
auto_conc_attacks: i think poe was right in some respects but not in all respects. poe and finn were both wrong because they were both right and wrong.

conclusion: Marijuana and psilocybin should not be schedule 1 drugs.
premises: the us controlled substances act of 1970 classified schedule 1 drugs as: the drug or other substance has a high potential for abuse. the drug or other substance has no currently accepted medical use in treatment in the united states. millions of people use them casually and lead normal, successful, productive lives. there is not a high potential for abuse. neither drug is lethal in any dose, and reports of death or serious injury directly related to either are extremely low. they are both very safe. the number of people who have had their lives ruined because of the legal penalties associated with this classification is enormous.

masked_conc_attacks: i think it's important to note that there are a lot of people who use schedule 1 drugs, and that they are not dangerous. there are plenty of people that use them casually and lead normal, successful, productive lives. the problem is that most people don't know what they're doing, or how they're going to react. that's why it's so important to distinguish between 'dangerous' and 'harmful' drugs.

auto_conc_attacks: it is true that there is a high potential for abuse, but it is also true that the drug itself has no currently accepted medical use in treatment in the united states.

conclusion: Casual dating (and casual sex) is inherently dehumanizing
premises: for instance, if you date someone just to make your ex jealous, you're clearly using and dehumanizing your partner. that example's pretty clearly wrong, but there are lots more that seem pretty innocent at first: if you're just dating around to find out what you like, aren't you just treating the other person as a means to an end? if you're dating someone casually because you just went through a tough breakup and feel like you deserve something light and fun, aren't you using that person as a substitute for a feeling? if you pick someone you wouldn't ordinarily date because you're sick of being single, are they just an emotional crutch? if you date someone in school you know will be moving away in a couple of years, are they anything more than a placeholder for a person? if you feel sorry for your nice single friend and go out with them to boost their self esteem, are you treating them as you would want to be treated? it seems to me that in each of these cases, you'd be guilty of using your partner. i can't think of any. a good rule of thumb might be: if your partner asks, 'why did you decide to go out with me? ' and you're reluctant to tell them the real reason, you're probably using them and you should probably break up with them. response 1: 'as long as it's between consenting adults, there's nothing wrong with it and we shouldn't judge them too harshly. ' consent is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for an action to be ethical. that is, for a relationship to be ethical, it must at a minimum be consensual, but it takes more than that. it must also be genuinely good in the long term for all parties involved. for instance, it wouldn't be ethical for two completely incompatible people to date each other just because they're both terrified of being alone, even if they both consent to it. they could even hurt others if they have children. response 2: 'as long as you're upfront about your motives, you're in the clear. ' few people are willing to be so upfront, precisely because they're aware of how much it makes them sound like a sociopath. 'i had a bad breakup and i'm just looking for a rebound. you cool with that? ' few people say that sort of thing upfront. and if you are upfront, sure, it may lessen your burden of guilt, but that doesn't mean you should be doing it in the first place. if you sell someone placebo drugs, and you tell them upfront, 'hey these drugs probably won't do a damn thing. i'm just trying to make a cheap buck. ' and they buy them anyway, sure, that's better than lying to them about it. but isn't it even better not to sell placebo drugs at all? similarly, if someone's just a rebound for you, it's better if you tell them that upfront rather than make them think they're special, but isn't it better still not to use someone that way in the first place? besides, our motives are often obscure even to ourselves. we may not realize someone was a rebound until the relationship is over. if you're not really, truly excited about someone after a few dates, then what are you still doing with them? response 3: sex is no big deal. it's just our messed up society that puts such an unhealthy emphasis on it. our society probably does have an unhealthy attitude toward sex. but sex is a big deal, and it's not just another activity like skiing. otherwise, we can't explain why forced sex is a special kind of crime. here's what i mean. rape is a serious crime, one that can potentially cause serious psychological damage. likewise, it's a serious crime for an adult to have sex with a child. part of the reason is that they can't meaningfully consent to sex. but why is meaningful consent necessary in this case? young children can't meaningfully consent to getting their hair cut or being taken skiing, either, but that's no crime. rape and sex with children are evil because it's a particularly heinous type of violation, perhaps a violation of something that should be sacred. it's not just an activity that our society places too much emphasis on. sex is intimate in a way that can cause lasting psychological damage if forced upon someone. presumably this is because sex is so deeply rooted in our biology that we can't help but have certain psychological reactions to it. sex does something to you, and you can't necessarily help it no matter how enlightened you are. or even if you can completely separate sex from all the messy emotions, you can't know if your casual partner is capable of doing the same, because you don't know them well. if sex is special, perhaps even sacred, we're playing with fire if we act as if it's no big deal. we risk hurting ourselves and others psychologically, even if it's all perfectly consensual. addendum: there's some part of me that still feels like i'm being ridiculous and unrealistic about my approach to dating, but my conscience won't be clear unless i can see why. or if i'm not being ridiculous, then at least i'll feel more confident about refusing to date anyone for any reason who doesn't meet my possibly unrealistic standards. i can't seem to settle this on my own, so i would appreciate some outside perspective and wisdom.
