auto_conc: Many "innocent" human actions are in fact deeply immoral.
gt: i take issue with your title's phrasing:casual dating and casual sex is inherently dehumanizing i don't expect this road to lead anywhere to a delta but humans in their natural habitats as can be seen with tribal cultures around the world treat sex very differently. that's not to say that dating doesn't exist but sex is seen very differently, as is the culture surrounding it. i would say it can't be inherently dehumanizing if our natural views toward sex and natural inclinations lean elsewhere.
masked_conc_attacks: i think it depends on the context of the relationship. if you're dating someone just to make your ex jealous, you're clearly using and dehumanizing your partner. however, if you are dating someone because you're sick of being single, you are clearly using them as a means to an end.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. casual dating is inherently dehumanizing. it's not like you're using someone to make your ex jealous, it's that you're treating them as a substitute for a feeling.
auto_conc_attacks: what is the difference between 'innocent' human actions and 'in fact deeply immoral'? if you're dating someone just to make your ex jealous, you're clearly using and dehumanizing your partner. if you are dating someone because you're sick of being single, are you using that person as a substitute for a feeling?

conclusion: Card games like Magic The Gathering are not gambling
premises: you generally know what you are going to get for your money using mtg as the example, you're going to get 15 cards, with a rare, 3 uncommons, and the rest commons. sometimes you get a foil card, sometimes a mythic rare, but it's always the same number of cards. these cards ostensibly all have the same value they can all be used to play the game they are for, and it's up to you, the player, to determine which cards warrant a place in your deck. the game's producer makes no claim about which cards are more valuable deciding which cards work better in your deck is a core part of the gameplay, and the producer would not want to break that by telling you which ones are better. any secondary market for the cards should not be taken into account. how is it the company's responsibility that other people might be willing to pay you money for what you got in your card pack? if you are opening a box of lucky charms, and i say i am willing to pay you a quarter for every unicorn marshmallow you give me, does that mean general mills is now engaging in gambling? even if dozens of websites spring up for the purpose of buying and selling lucky charms marshmallows, general mills is still no more responsible for the market value of any given marshmallow than it is now. sight unseen auctions are legal, and i see no reason to prevent them from being so. i think this same logic extends to digital card games like hearthstone, and even to loot boxes themselves, but i'll leave that for another post.
argument: Card games like Magic The Gathering are not gambling : you generally know what you are going to get for your money using mtg as the example, you're going to get 15 cards, with a rare, 3 uncommons, and the rest commons. sometimes you get a foil card, sometimes a mythic rare, but it's always the same number of cards. these cards ostensibly all have the same value they can all be used to play the game they are for, and it's up to you, the player, to determine which cards warrant a place in your deck. the game's producer makes no claim about which cards are more valuable deciding which cards work better in your deck is a core part of the gameplay, and the producer would not want to break that by telling you which ones are better. any secondary market for the cards should not be taken into account. how is it the company's responsibility that other people might be willing to pay you money for what you got in your card pack? if you are opening a box of lucky charms, and i say i am willing to pay you a quarter for every unicorn marshmallow you give me, does that mean general mills is now engaging in gambling? even if dozens of websites spring up for the purpose of buying and selling lucky charms marshmallows, general mills is still no more responsible for the market value of any given marshmallow than it is now. sight unseen auctions are legal, and i see no reason to prevent them from being so. i think this same logic extends to digital card games like hearthstone, and even to loot boxes themselves, but i'll leave that for another post.
auto_conc: general mills is no more responsible for the market value of any given card than it is now.
gt: gambling can be defined as either 'play games of chance for money; bet. ' or 'take risky action in the hope of a desired result. ' . cracking packs of magic cards fits both of these criteria. by your logic, scratch cards would also not be gambling. you are buying a product without fully knowing what it contains, likely not to make your money back, but with the possibility for a large pay off. packs of magic cards are obviously a lot lower risk as you always get something and a lot lower reward unless you are cracking alpha beta , but it is still present.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're talking about here, but i'd like to point out that general mills do not have a monopoly on the sale of certain cards. they are not directly responsible for the value of the cards they are selling.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's gambling, but i do think that it's fair to say that it is gambling. it's not gambling.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think general mills is responsible for the market value of any given card than it is now.

conclusion: Suicide should not be prevented if the person has the capacity to make decisions. The right to die should be a basic human right.
premises: i understand that this is a very unpopular opinion, but here me out. if they want help, then they should be able to receive it. it's kind of like natural selection. you can argue that people who are physically ill with things like cancer get treatment, but my point is most people who have physical terminal illnesses do not 'choose' to die. this goes to anyone whether they are in great pain because of a physical illness, or they are suffering emotionally from a mental illness. honestly, i don't like the fact i have this opinion, but i still believe in it. that's why i've come here. change my mind.

conclusion: The Jedi are full of shit and leaning toward the "Dark" Side is the way to go.
premises: just look at their respective codes. the jedi code: there is no emotion, there is peace. there is no ignorance, there is knowledge. there is no passion, there is serenity. there is no chaos, there is harmony. there is no death, there is the force. the sith code: peace is a lie, there is only passion. through passion, i gain strength. through strength, i gain power. through power, i gain victory. through victory, my chains are broken. the force shall free me. now, while certain parts of the jedi code, specifically lines 2 and 5, are good, the rest of it seems to be pushing a worldview based on restraint, discipline, and order. now this in and of itself is fine, but it accomplishes this by restricting the influence of passion. passion amp; emotion is the chief governing factor in humans. maybe it's different for certain alien species, i don't know. the sith, on the other hand, encourage passion. they use it, control it, and gain strength and inspiration from it. this is their strength, but also their weakness. emotion can grant power, but it can also blind you. passion should never be without restraint, but the abandonment of it by the jedi is both unrealistic and harmful to it's members. i just wrote a 1500 character wall of text on the philosophy of space ninjas. i am a massive fucking nerd.

gt: they are both extremists. the movies and story are focused on the most hardcore of extremists.

conclusion: People who say all politicians are the same/corrupt don't understand how corruption works, and are part of the problem.
premises: corruption, as any phenomenon occurring in a system governed by institutions, is a result of the incentives individuals within the organization are subject to. this enables a rabbit chase for 'the right' person, that will never really yield any results. even if we find an angel, it will ultimately be corrupted if the incentives are not right. instead of wasting energy on finding the right leader to whom a cult of personality is owed we should focus on designing systems where even devils are forced to act right. if having a functioning government was all about finding the right person, we would be doomed, as we can hardly tell what the real motivations and ideas of a given candidate are.

gt: i believe that your analogy is misplaced here due to not fully understanding the complexities of rules based morality. in rules based morality, the act itself is what is being judged, not the consequence. so, if an act ion is immoral, then the consequence doesn't matter. amp; x200b;for an example, i will describe two identical scenarios with different actions;1. a bankrobber holds a customer hostage. the police frees the customer by shooting the robber. action free customer, consequence robber gets shot. 2. a bankrobber holds a customer hostage. the police shoot the robber. the customer gets free afterwards. action shooting the robber, consequence customer gets free. these two scenearios seem identical, but in 1. , the action is not morally wrong, though the consequence may be undesired. in 2. , the action may be morally wrong depending on whether you think bank robbery deserves a death sentence . amp; x200b;the key difference between the two is why stuff happens. situation 1 cops would be equally satisfied with any other method that freed the customer and didn't force them to shoot the robber, while situation 2 cops would shoot the robber regardless of whether he had a hostage in the first place.

conclusion: Too many people go to college in the US.
premises: tl;dr: i believe that the obsession with telling everyone to 'get an education' is misguided and has been incredibly harmful to our society. close to 70 amp; 37; of graduating high school students are now attending college of some sort directly after graduation. this has had a number of unfortunate results: 1. when 70 amp; 37; of the population excluding high school dropouts wants to go on to higher education, it means that there will be a mathematical guarantee that a significant amount of individuals with below average academic skills, intelligence and education will be attending. the result is that schools either must admit students that they know can't handle the workload or reduce the academic rigor in order to accommodate less capable students. 2. employers can no longer use a bachelors degree as a meaningful discriminator because they are way too common. when having a bachelors degree in a field not directly related to your job i. e. non stem was less common, an employer could infer that whoever had it was at least of an above average intelligence and academic ability, even if they didn't go to an elite educational institution. essentially saying, 'even though an english degree isn't really directly related to this job, this person still must be reasonably capable to have gotten a degree at all. ' now that degrees are handed out left and right, this is not longer useful. it is also very damaging to capable people who didn't get a degree and has forced people to take on more debt to attend graduate school or accept lower salaries in order to be competitive. 3. someone with 40th percentile intelligence is not going to be able to complete a degree in organic chemistry or mechanical engineering, so the result is they study largely useless degrees, wasting their time and money learning stuff they will never use on any job. while i certainly believe that having academics in a society has value, there is a limit of how many history and psychology degrees can be given out and still have marginal value to society. spending 4 years of your life and going deep into debt had better improve your employment prospects, and i really don't believe it does for most people of average to below average ability. go into a retail store or restaurant in a major city and odds are that multiple non management employees will have degrees. 20 years ago, this would have been unheard of. 4. it kill innovation and entrepreneurship. because so many young people come out of school with a ton of debt and no real skills even if you have a more useful degree , it kills entrepreneurship. someone of middling intelligence who has a ba in psychology isn't going to be able to start any business that they couldn't have out of high school. they certainly won't be as capable of starting a business as someone who spent those 4 years in trade school and or an apprenticeship learning how to do a real world skill. even if they have the ability, being saddled with debt means that they are less willing to take the risks required to be an entrepreneur. this is all well and good, but for something that costs as much as it does, it just doesn't make sense for the majority of people.

auto_conc: I don't think the military is all that bad.
gt: there is a little bit of history here. after the vietnam war, many servicemembers came home to a response that ranged from embarrassment to disgust. even those who 'supported' vietnam vets often focused on very negative aspects and by extension characterized all vietnam vets as broken. i'm old enough to have had a lot of older friends who were vietnam vets, and served in the military directly after. the resentment was widespread. so some of the reversal has been, like all reversals, overdone. instead of just appreciating the sacrifice, many people decided to go all the way to revering the military and veterans. however, doing this often causes a similar harm because they still treat the veteran as separate and possibly broken. add to this the fact that many politicians have learned to use veterans as props. the current administration is the worst, but everyone does it some. once again, props are often separated, given almost magical status, then mistrusted, resented, and ignored in the end. i guess this probably won't change your view. but it's something that society hasn't gotten right yet, and i think it is important.
masked_conc_attacks: what do you mean by respect for the military?
known_conc_attacks: the military is the most important part of our society, and it's the only thing that matters to us. as a military member, i know that i have a lot of respect for the military, but i don't think it's a good thing for the us to have such a large contingent of soldiers. i think it is important to remember that the military is one of the most powerful forces in the world, and i think that it's important to be aware of the importance of the military in our lives.
auto_conc_attacks: the military is not all that bad. i don't think the military is all that good, but i do think it is a good thing.

conclusion: The diving/flopping that occurs in soccer is detrimental to the game and FIFA should do something about it.
premises: i and many other of my casual soccer fans have watched a significant portion of the world cup this year. the way i see it, the world cup is a potential stage to attract millions of people as fans of the sport, and i m sure it does a relatively good job at it. on top of that i ve seen a number of near breakaway opportunities where, at the sniff of contact, the offensive player goes down instead of attempting to play through contact as well as other similar situations . if players should be punished for embellishing acting fines would likely be the best means of doing so. now i understand some teams pay their players more than others so a universal fine number might not work. i m thinking maybe a small percentage of their compensation from their teams? cmv!
argument: The diving/flopping that occurs in soccer is detrimental to the game and FIFA should do something about it. : i and many other of my casual soccer fans have watched a significant portion of the world cup this year. the way i see it, the world cup is a potential stage to attract millions of people as fans of the sport, and i m sure it does a relatively good job at it. on top of that i ve seen a number of near breakaway opportunities where, at the sniff of contact, the offensive player goes down instead of attempting to play through contact as well as other similar situations . if players should be punished for embellishing acting fines would likely be the best means of doing so. now i understand some teams pay their players more than others so a universal fine number might not work. i m thinking maybe a small percentage of their compensation from their teams? cmv!
auto_conc: i think soccer players should be punished for embellishing goals.
gt: one of the big issues with soccer is that there is such a high premium on scoring opportunities. it isn't uncommon for a game to only have 1 or 2 goals, and those goals coming on only a handful more scoring opportunities. with the premium on goals 1 goal can easily be deciding, particularly if the leading team adopts an all out defense strategy , the incentive to try and draw penalties either free kicks or penalty shots which can be scoring opportunities without any additional effort by the kicking team is massive. the best way for soccer to deal with this would be to reduce the benefit of flopping. that might mean taking steps to increase scoring so that 1 goal won't necessarily be deciding. that might mean reducing the benefit of free kicks e. g. you can dribble out with possession, but not organize a set piece . that might mean moving back the penalty kick so it isn't nearly as valuable in it's own right.
masked_conc_attacks: the problem with this idea is that it doesn't make sense to punish players for the actions of the players. if you don't want to punish the players for their actions, then you can't punish them for it.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a good idea to punish players for diving or flopping, but i think it should be done.
auto_conc_attacks: the problem with this is that it's not a good idea to punish players for embellishing goals, it's a bad idea to incentivize them to embellish goals.

conclusion: Willpower is a Dangerous Delusion
premises: but it's not. and like the kid waiting for a santa claus that never comes, we get hurt by believing in the illusion of willpower. but evidence shows this is not actually true. if it were, everybody would fulfill their new year resolution, we would all be much healthier, fitter and happier. the ugly truth is that we constantly do things that are harmful for us. i see the mind as being ruled by a savage monkey, the unconscious, which actually decides our behaviour. to decide, it uses a model of the world which is obsolete, it still thinks we are in the stone age. we eat candy because fruit was rare and highly advantageous for survival, we spend so much time on instagram because we need to belong, social validation as in the stone age exile was death etc. it cannot change behaviours that the unconscious monkey thinks are advantageous to survival. by accepting it's an illusion, we can move past it and develop real solutions.

gt: so can you explain how one would stop smoking, if willpower is an illusion? i watched your video, and i actually agree with you that you need to change the model to change the behavior. but if it not willpower that causes the model to change, what is it?
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure if you've read this yet, but i'd like to point out that it's not that hard to change your behaviour, it's that you have to accept that you are doing things that are harmful for you. for example, if you were to stop eating candy, you would have to start eating chocolate. if you stopped eating chocolate, you wouldn't have to eat candy. so if you stop eating chocolate because you need to belong, then you would still eat candy because you would spend time on instagram because you needed to belong. you can't change your behavior because you don't want to belong to social validation, because social validation is necessary for survival.
known_conc_attacks: the problem with your view is that it is not a 'deeper truth.'it's a way of thinking about the world. it's not a way to think about what is and isn't good for you. it is a way for you to feel good about yourself, and to be able to focus on what you want to do. it isn't an illusion, it's an experience. it can be used to help you feel better about yourself. you can be a good person, but you can't be a bad person. you have to be good at what you do. you don't need to be bad at anything. you just need to do what you think is right for you, and that's what you're doing. if you are good at something, then you're good at it. but if you're bad at it, you're not good at anything else.
auto_conc_attacks: i think you're underestimating the power of willpower. it's not that we don't have willpower, it's that we have a lot of willpower that we can't control. for example, if we were to say, 'i need to eat candy because fruit was rare and highly advantageous for survival, we would spend so much time on instagram because we need to belong, social validation as in the stone age exile was death etc.'that's not what willpower is. we have willpower because we know that it's important to do things that are harmful for us. but if we accept that willpower is an illusion, then we can move past it and develop real solutions.

gt: ethanol has industrial and scientific uses too. to stop people from using that ethanol to drink, you must put adulterants in it to make it undrinkable. the government murdered 10,000 people through this method during prohibition. a repeat now would be maybe 30,000. and then of course you have the issue that alcohol is the result of a natural process. enforcement would be an insane impossibility. you only need a cooler to make beer and wine. if you think it was hard to catch the moonshiners of old, just wait until people are 3d printing stills. people will still drink. only now you've pushed it underground. i buy a bottle of whiskey now, i know it is safe to drink. i know the exact percentage of alcohol because regulation requires it. once it's underground all of that is lost. i won't know what's in the whiskey, and i won't know what percentage it is. people will also start to drink more as they did during prohibition, because when you score some booze you're going to drink it all up. alcohol consumption only went down overall because the casual drinkers stopped drinking, and those aren't the people who are going to have the health and social problems related to alcohol.

conclusion: College coding classes should be more focused on mobile & web app development.
premises: so i just graduated with my computer science degree back in april and after reflecting on what i learned in my coding classes, it seems like we are working with antiquated technology. as an example, i wouldn't consider my algorithms or theory of computation courses as 'coding classes,' because while some code was done, it was largely more theoretical stuff. my java and python classes however were just all about learning those languages. we dipped into php and sql in my databases class but that's about it. the first time i ever did a web app was when i learned . net myself working on my senior project. every other code class besides sysadmin if that counts never really touched on any networking topics. so what we learned through school for the most part was how to make an offline desktop app. you code something in java, you run a . jar file, and you're good to go, no coverage of rest api usage or anything. in reality, this isn't too relevant anymore. people don't use desktop apps in large quantities anymore, bar video games. the average person probably uses: chrome firefox, discord, steam, itunes spotify, and maybe 3 other programs of their choice a couple adobe products, maybe a few ides, etc. . mobile apps have largely replaced the usefulness of desktop apps. if you want a budget tracker for example, you'll likely just do it on your phone so you can punch in numbers whenever you need to. if there's a desktop app that isn't too fitting for mobile, typically it works better as a web app so people don't have to download specific software. of course i listed some desktop apps above that are still relevant and still useful, but they are much lower in popularity compared to mobile or web apps since they are typically less portable on a pc or require downloads and setup. and especially with every app being connected to the internet nowadays it seems downright outdated that we don't even so much as cover simpler web connectivity things like rest apis in these coding classes. i couldn't tell you how to integrate an api into a java application, and i used it for several years throughout highschool and college. cmv.

gt: i work with lots of people who write code but never studied computer science. none of them ever really 'got' core computer science and software engineering best practices. i never formally learned web or mobile dev. it takes me about a day of effort to get useful in a web framework the one a year i think i'm going to actually finish one of my side project ideas. mobile isn't special. it's not different and it's not hard for someone who knows the fundamentals. note: embedded and low resource environments not included.

conclusion: Alcoholics Anonymous is heavily flawed from a scientific perspective and hasn't tried to improve it's system since it's inception
premises: i have a friend who has been attending aa meetings recently because he was ordered to do so in some fashion after getting a dui for the record i don't know if that means he was given a true option or made to attend or 'choose' jailtime and the whole thing has got me thinking about whether or not aa works and if sobriety is even the intended outcome of the program. below i've listed the famous 12 steps and below that are my relatively disorganized thoughts on the program having looked into it for the first time in any in depth manner. this means that i m still in the early stages of my views and can be very much subject to change. 1. we admitted we were powerless over alcohol that our lives had become unmanageable. 2. came to believe that a power greater than ourselves could restore us to sanity. 3. made a decision to turn our will and our lives over to the care of god as we understoodhim. 4. made a searching and fearless moral inventory of ourselves. 5. admitted to god, to ourselves, and to another human being the exact nature of our wrongs. 6. were entirely ready to have god remove all these defects of character. 7. humbly asked him to remove our shortcomings. 8. made a list of all persons we had harmed and became willing to make amends to them all. 9. made direct amends to such people wherever possible, except when to do so would injure them or others. 10. continued to take a personal inventory and when we were wrong promptly admitted it. 11. sought through prayer and mation to improve our conscious contact with god as we understood him, praying only for knowledge of his will for us and the power to carry that out. 12. my current view is that because of the lack of change of the steps over the years since the 30 s suggests a lack of improvement that would be unacceptable in any other field of treatment for diseases. here are some of my thoughts on the matter. first up, as many have pointed out, there's a whole lot of god involved throughout the 12 steps 6 direct references and 7 if you count 2 , i'm not sure how this is supposed to appeal to athiests such as my friend. if a person does not believe in god they will be put off from the program from the start making it much harder to reach their goal of sobriety. if alcoholism is a disease then why does aa treat it simply as a matter of will power? i wouldn't try to treat cancer with prayer alone, and for the record there are various medical treatments for alcoholism. there is also a stigma of personal failure when people relapse which doesn't make sense for a couple of reasons. first, if it's a disease then people are sick which means that blaming them for not being able to control their health adds a layer of shame which can only do harm to the person's primary goal of getting sober. in turn this will increase the time to get sober because it will add time to get over that shame before starting again. shame does nothing to help get a person back on track as far as i can tell. second, you would never assign blame to a person with cancer who has gone into remission and then had the cancer come back, why would we do the same for literally any other illness? we conclusion: Laissez Faire is the ideal Governmental/Societal Structure
premises: as morality cannot be imposed, and the smart, or selfish, or rich will always have advantage any system, however vetted, will produce unintended consequences. the more complex the regulation or system, the harder it is to evaluate the success. welfare, government oversight, banking and industry regulation, healthcare and similar policies inevitably fail to produce better results than the self correcting selfish incentives of competition. for example: the recent fiduciary rule attempted to standardize compensation for advisory services on asset management. this was meant to be a more strict policy compared to a disclosure based, potentially conflicted, model in which suitability was the standard. the problem which was attempted to be addressed was: broker has fund a and b which are both suitable, but picks a for revenue purposes. the solution was, fund a and b must pay the same. simply put . the reality was that the industry broadly increased fees holistically, to maintain revenue levels but collect it another way. average fees went up. in the chaos of the administration change, the standard was ultimately struck down. it seems to me, that ultimately, people learn from experience, and in the learning process even systemically, many problems self correct from individual incentive. a social darwinism of behavior, as evolution has shown us the impact of selective competitive advantage with iteration, why can that not apply also to society? us spending on welfare is comparatively high compared to international spending on a proportional decrease in standardized poverty levels can t vote on my phone directly, but a 2012 study was referenced on wikipedia s welfare page . my view could change with appropriate statistical evidence. it seems most of the research on these concepts are highly partisan, and the results are hard to take at face value. to be honest my current view is how i was educated. i would appreciate a differing, well supported viewpoint.

us spending on welfare is comparatively high compared to international spending on a proportional decrease in standardized poverty levels can t vote on my phone directly, but a 2012 study was referenced on wikipedia s welfare page . my view could change with appropriate statistical evidence. it seems most of the research on these concepts are highly partisan, and the results are hard to take at face value. to be honest my current view is how i was educated. i would appreciate a differing, well supported viewpoint.

conclusion: There is nothing wrong with the encouraging/ reinforcment of masculinity.
premises: i often see people criticizing phrases such as 'man up! ,' 'be a man! ,' etc, and claiming these are bad for young people men and women to hear. historically and biologically, men have been and are more combative than women so if a woman needs to be combative to accomplish something, i see no problem is saying 'be a man. ' this also applies to other traits such as independence. as an aside, some may argue that ideas of masculinity and femininity are purely socially construed and that people only act certain ways because of societal influence. i wholeheartedly disagree masculine and feminine traits largely have to do with the presence of sex hormones acting on the nervous system. so the idea that phrases like 'be a man' need to go away because it's keeping together a negative social construct are unfounded. if anything is unclear, i will be happy to elaborate on any ideas in the comments.

auto_conc: I believe there is nothing wrong with being a man.
gt: would you agree that generally human beings can do things that are irrational and potentially harmful? masculinity and i would argue femininity as well are both sets of human behaviours that can be good or bad. and in some circumstances are definitely bad, you don't want people acting independently in a surgical operation, you want people working together in a very strict fashion. this is a conclusion that came about from comparing surgeries where people worked independently with ones where people used set checklists and protocols to coordinate, and finding that the latter had lower levels of mistakes made. i guess my main point is that masculinity is a good tool for when you need to be competitive or combative, but those situations are occasional for most people, and outside of them masculinity needs to be controlled. it's something that needs to work for you, not the other way around.

' quickly looking around the internet it seems like many arguments against this are pulling some logically fallacious reasoning saying something along the lines of, 'it's ridiculous to say illegal aliens aren't in the jurisdiction of the u. s. , obviously we can arrest them and charge them with crimes, so they are in our jurisdictio t. for example, the atlantic article s. in this view, schuck and smith misread the historical material ' it then also links an article in which it uses the argument about jurisdiction i talked about abo s. i would really appreciate some better argued materi l. the aforementioned atlantic article also links 'the citizenship clause: a legislative history' ? twitter impression true amp;httpsredir 1 amp;article 1607 amp;context aulr , which i am trying to go through; it's just a bit long amp; x20

auto_conc: i think birthright citizenship should be abolished.
gt: the cornell law 'article' linked is actually the full text of the supreme court's opinion. it's a fascinating read, rich in historical context and i thank you for sharing it as it shines a light on the question that news stories fail to adequately capture. here's the money paragraph from the opinion:the real object of the fourteenth amendment of the constitution, in qualifying the words, 'all persons born in the united states' by the addition 'and subject to the jurisdiction thereof,' would appear to have been to exclude, by the fewest and fittest words besides children of members of the indian tribes, standing in a peculiar relation to the national government, unknown to the common law , the two classes of cases children born of alien enemies in hostile occupation and children of diplomatic representatives of a foreign state both of which, as has already been shown, by the law of england and by our own law from the time of the first settlement of the english colonies in america, had been recognized exceptions to the fundamental rule of citizenship by birth within the country. so there it is, the supreme court, explaining after painstaking review of the law and history of the matter their conclusion that the phrase 'subject to the jurisdiction thereof' refers to three exceptions:1. members of certain indians tribes2. children of alien enemies in hostile occupation; and3. children of diplomatic representatives of a foreign state. that's it. the holding of the case is really that straightforward. if you are born in the u. s. and fall outside of these three exceptions, you are a citizen.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure if this is a good or bad idea, but i think it's important to note that a lot of the arguments against birthright citizenship seem to be based on the idea that there is no such thing as a 'jurisdiction' in the united states. it's not like there is a law that says that there are no laws in the u. s. that you can't arrest someone and charge them with crimes. that's not the case. there are laws in place that say that a person can't be arrested and charged with crimes, but that does not mean that they're not in the jurisdiction of the government.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point of the citizenship clause. it's not about the law itself, it's about the laws of the land. it is about the rights of the people. i think the argument you're making is based on the idea that the law should be applied to people born in the united states, not to aliens born in other countries. i don't think that's the case, but i think it's important to remember that the constitution was written in the first place, not in the form of a law. the purpose of the constitution is to protect the citizens of other countries, and to protect them from foreign invasions. it doesn't apply to illegal aliens, but it does apply to those born in america. that's not to say that illegal aliens aren't in the jurisdiction of the u. s. or that they are. the constitution says that the government should not be able to arrest people for crimes, but that it should be allowed to arrest
auto_conc_attacks: what do you mean by 'natural born'?

gt: culture is not the only aspect to heritage, genes are very much involved. for example, i'm predominantly scottish but i have everything from native american to german to dutch to english in my makeup. it is perfectly accurate for me to say that i'm scottish even though i and four generations of my scottish ancestry was born in the us. it's not only accurate but medically important: certain racial genetics can offer clues to herary disorders such as tay sachs and sickle cell anemia. if i tell you i'm scottish, i'm being factual and honest, even if i was born in the us. genetically, that is what makes up most of my heritage and its incredibly relevant. if i told you i was culturally scottish, however, that'd be a big fat lie. i'm culturally american, even if i do know what my family tartans look like and want to try haggis.

conclusion: Rap is lower quality music and is overrated.
premises: before i get into this, let me be clear what i'm not trying to say : all rap is bad. rap takes no talent. people shouldn't listen to rap at all. people who listen to rap are less intellegent. all the problems i list are exclusive to rap and not other genres of music. ok, now let's get into this : 1. rap uses less people to create, which does not always indicate, but usually indicates less effort overall . obviously, the more people working on something, the more hours that can be put into something. that doesn't mean one person can't create something good, but the likelihood of an individual creating something good is statically less than that of a group. 2. most rap songs use rhymes, which can alter what the creator wants the song to mean . the creator of a song might want to portray a message, express an emotion s , or cause the listener to critically think in some way. since many rap songs rely heavily on rhyming their lyrics, they have to alter the words of the songs in order to rhyme. while this can be entertaining, the meaning of the song is often lost, misunderstood or not taken seriously. 3. rap relies too heavily on vocals and not a variety of instruments . that's not to say that rap never uses anything else, but vocals are always at the forefront; everything but the vocals is just background noise, vocals are emphasized. this means that rap as a genre lacks variety within artists and between artists. it becomes more difficult to distinguish between rap songs, and they start to blend together. this begins to ruin the perception of what's good and what's bad. on top of that, if the vocals are bad, the whole song is bad vs. if one instrument were bad, the entire song is not necessarily ruined. 4. rap is easier to learn than other genres that use other instruments, and most anyone can do it if try tried. there's no hand eye coordination with vocals as with a guitar or piano. on top of that, traditional vocals require the singer to use certain pitches consistently and at loud capacities and to a beat. this makes it easier to learn than other interments or vocals. meaning, people without natural talent can start rapping, and lesser quality songs can be made in abundance. of course, a rapper can spend an equal or greater amount of time practicing as any other musician. but remember, people can also get really good at sitting down and standing up, that doesn't equate to quality. i try to be objective, but i obviously wouldn't be making this argument if i didn't have a bias. i do enjoy some rap, i'm not completely adverse to it. other genres have similar problems, i would say the same of a lot of pop or country music. let me know what you guys think, am i way off base? thanks for reading, i look forward to your responses.

conclusion: The right wing in the US shouldn't whine about identity politics since they also engage in identity politics; identity politics for white people.
premises: let's just disregard the fact that 'average voter' generally means the white voter, in this case. it starts with these communities that collectively complain about their problems. my issue with this is that this seems to be a very ahistorical view. blacks were enslaved based on their identity. women weren't allowed to own their land based on their identity. it's incredibly troublesome to me that people ignore this. because it certainly wasn't for no reason. and it isn't like the fight is over on any of these fronts. blacks are still facing issues with police brutality. women are dealing with sexual harassment in the workplace and not finding adequate help when they want to come forward. ice are literally asking mexican people for their papers. why should they not band together and advocate for each other? i don't see why that's bad. so now let's focus on the right. do you think that's just a coincidence? of course not. democrats have a more diverse voter base because they picked up the slack that republicans weren't willing to pick up. that isn't the fault of democrats. it's the fault of republicans those demonized those identities to begin with. it's their creation. first off, the implication here is that, somehow, the lgbtq community, black people, hispanic people. muslims, etc. can't be working class. that's incredibly problematic. secondly, they say this because they feel that advocating for these groups is off putting to white voters. i'm open to all discussion. if i need to be more clear in a certain area, please let me know. this is my first time doing this, but i'm curious to see your opinions on this.

rubin and jordan peterson are conservatives isn't really true, that is also an identity politics view that assumes anyone who opposes some parts of the far left must inherently be alt right. considering a sizable number of bernie sanders and 2 term obama voters voted for trump, simplifying the argument to them being alt right is pretty ignorant. ben shapiro is conservative but neither of the 3 play identity politics except perhaps attacks on the far left who are by definition a group with and ideology they disagree with so not really identity politics all 3 agree there are many agreeable moderate liberals who have differing views but are reasonable. lastly just because both sides are potentially hypocritical doesn't mean they aren't both aiming at the right goal. the vast majority of people on both sides of the political spectrum agree that we should have equal opportunity and rights for all individuals, historically opressed minorities don't want to be judged by the group identity rather judged in the content of their character to paraphrase dr martin luther king jr , and men, whites, conservatives, straight people don't want to be blindly lumped into a group of people who are just viewed as opressed who need to pay for actions they didn't take. but the problem is we are viewing the loud voices of the extremes as representative of the whole. all conservatives are nationalist bigots of the underrepresented and all left wingers are misinformed bigots of the status quo, but these where the views of the fringes but by playing identity politics we have had to pick a side and defend it and our political views have move further and further to the edges over the last 15 years and our mediating reasonable center has shrunk to the point where no one will believe you're a centrist. if you argue a right winger you'll a communist if you argue a left winger your a fascist. so yes everyone is playing this game and they have fucked it up for everyone but extremes will take over.

death by stoning. killed by shooting? criminal should be shot. thieves should lose all their property, rapists should be raped. this may be an extreme form of justice, but i believe it is one of the only just system. you see completely sick, sadistic cruel people, that only get punished by being behind bars? it's ridiculous imo. intuitively, surely you would believe a man like that deserves more than simply life in prison. and in reality, all he did was serve one month and hang himself. death by hanging is nothing compared to what he did, he doesn't deserve death by the rope. i believe everything he did, should be done to him. of course he can't get impregnated, but there should be a procedure; where punishments should be somewhat adjusted and equivalent. for example, he would be trapped and chained also for 11 years, and continuously raped and starved. of course, you may think this is equally sick and doesn't do any good at all. but i am willing to sacrifice our humanity if it means punishing a monster that committed acts of no humanity at all. maybe if monsters like him knew that their acts would have equal weight in punishment to them, they would be in fear rather than laugh at how simple their punishments will be anyway. 2. i think this may be more fair. families are the ones who would be most affected by crimes, most hurt. the action they decide cannot be worse than what the criminal did, only equivalent or lower. for example, a thief cannot be decided to be raped by a family. a rapist cannot be forced to be burnt to death by the family, only raped. however, im not saying families can choose lower punishments e. g a murderer being punched in the face as this would be a complex thing to decide. however if they cannot decide, i believe the 1st option should be chosen.

gt: justice is a complicated concept, and not one so simple as revenge. this is perfect revenge. this is imperfect justice. as a premise, punishment has five recognized purposes according to a book on criminal law deterrence , incapacitati on , rehabilitation , retribution , and restitution . deterrence is obvious, and jail leads to incapacitation so they won't do it again. restitution returns things to the way they were. if i stole ten dollars from you, i would owe it back. retribution means i pay you some extra as a punishment for stealing it in the first place. rehabilitation is the sticky one. society gains a lot from rehabilitated prisoners. i know of at least one murderer that went on to be a successful member of society. if we killed him back, we would have lost his talents and the world would have been the poorer for it. if they can be rehabilitated, it would be just for society not to lose them. the 'person' they were is dead, and we have a new one now.

conclusion: Sometimes attacking someone's "character rather than their ideas" is unavoidable
premises: i read this nyt article about facebook's conservative workers feeling like they can't express their opinions. we do this so consistently that employees are afraid to say anything when they disagree with what s around them politically. ' even though i'm very liberal, i'm not unsympathetic. to take an extreme example, if someone is a holocaust denier and wanted me to discuss this with them, i personally feel like there's nothing to talk about. if they pressed me on it, i would have to say they're either woefully delusional or anti semitic, or both. the facebook employee's complaint also strikes me as tone policing, asking folks who have had to endure countless arguments with bigots to use language like 'that's a bigoted idea' instead of 'you're a bigot. ' i do believe there's a difference between a good faith and bad faith argument debate. but even if you're arguing a racist or sexist idea in good faith, i think it's unreasonable to ask the people you're talking to not to think that you're racist or sexist. it reminds me of people who bemoan how heated political debate get for a lot of people, politics aren't 'just politics,' they have real world consequences. and the topics we're talking about these days are really personal. many of us have trans friends whose lives are in serious jeopardy because of policies. many of us have immigrant parents. fifty percent of us are women who are affected by anti choice laws. i frequently lurk on r asktrumpsupporters to try to get a sense of what people who support trump think about these topics. i've seen some posts that i disagree with but i can sense empathy and the fact that they genuinely believe their way is the best solution for everyone involved. but i've also seen many more posts that are rooted in racist ideas, particularly around immigration. i can't help but feel like these ideas stem from these posters being racists themselves rather than having some inexplicably complex worldview.

conclusion: If abortions were not an option, then everyone would agree that fetuses are human lives.
premises: they have human dna distinct from their parents. they have organs which, while they are still developing, are self contained and distinct from their mothers organs. they respond to external stimuli independently of their mothers. the most prevalent arguments for the idea that fetuses are merely a part of the mother s body seem to be these, so i ll address them here: 1. the fetus is entirely dependent on the mother. it certainly is. however, newborn babies are also entirely dependent on the mother. not just financially, but in a very literal sense. they, like fetuses, get food directly from the mother s body. is it ok to kill babies because they re inconvenient to the mother? 2. why? because human beings don t stop developing until their early 20 s. we don t spring out of the womb as fully grown adults. i don t even have to argue that this argument is illogical on principle. i only have to point out that the line demanded by this logic is far later than birth. so is it ok to kill teenagers? 3. the mother has a right to control her own body. she surely does. yes, women have the right to control their own bodies. they can chop off their own legs if they really want to. what they do not have the right to do is kill children. it merely assumes the answer to the question and moves on. so what arguments am i missing? change my mind.
argument: If abortions were not an option, then everyone would agree that fetuses are human lives. : they have human dna distinct from their parents. they have organs which, while they are still developing, are self contained and distinct from their mothers organs. they respond to external stimuli independently of their mothers. the most prevalent arguments for the idea that fetuses are merely a part of the mother s body seem to be these, so i ll address them here: 1. the fetus is entirely dependent on the mother. it certainly is. however, newborn babies are also entirely dependent on the mother. not just financially, but in a very literal sense. they, like fetuses, get food directly from the mother s body. is it ok to kill babies because they re inconvenient to the mother? 2. why? because human beings don t stop developing until their early 20 s. we don t spring out of the womb as fully grown adults. i don t even have to argue that this argument is illogical on principle. i only have to point out that the line demanded by this logic is far later than birth. so is it ok to kill teenagers? 3. the mother has a right to control her own body. she surely does. yes, women have the right to control their own bodies. they can chop off their own legs if they really want to. what they do not have the right to do is kill children. it merely assumes the answer to the question and moves on. so what arguments am i missing? change my mind.
auto_conc: i believe that abortion is wrong because newborn babies are human beings.
gt: you are making the assumption that 'human life' is a binary concept. biologically, this is false. human life comes into existence gradually and it also ceases to exist gradually. if somebody's brain is destroyed but their body is kept alive in an icu, that person is still dead for all practical purposes. switching off the icu machines does not constitute murder. but what if only 90 of the brain is destroyed, and the person is capable of some basic reflexes but otherwise a vegetable? are they dead or alive? the answer is that they are more alive, because human life is a continuum. but still barely alive. the legal system treats life as binary, not because this reflects reality, but because practically , it would be impossible to run a legal system where life was expressed in terms of percentages. it would also have some nasty side effects. living in a society where you constantly have to prove the degree of your aliveness in order to gain protections would be a terrifying experience for most people. in short, binary life is a legal fiction, but a useful legal fiction. but once we have acknowledged this we also have to acknowledge that we have to draw a line in the sand somewhere, and that where exactly we draw that line is arbitrary. however, we can use biology to give us a meaningful ballpark . drawing the line at conception is silly from a biological perspective, because we know that a person's 'essence' resides in the brain, and the brain doesn't develop until later.
masked_conc_attacks: what is the point of killing a baby? is it ok to kill a fetus because it is more inconvenient to the mother?
known_conc_attacks: if abortions were not an option, then everyone would agree that fetuses are human lives. however, i don't think that is the case. the fetus is a part of the mother's body. it is part of her body. that is what makes it a human life.

conclusion: Tipping should be optional and restaurants should just be subject to the same minimum wage laws as every other industry
premises: seriously, wait staff get paid literally pennies, after taxes and everything. i've had friends who only make 2. 13 an hour. now, i get that you can make a decent amount of money with tips, but it honestly is just so random and unpredictable. think about it. some days the customers you get may be generous and give you a healthy tip, but another day, you could get nothing but cheapskates, regardless of how well you do your job, some people still tip crap. i don't think someone's income should be based on factors they literally have no control over. plus, it puts a lot of pressure and stress on wait staff to be as friendly and helpful as possible. and everyone knows, when you're stressed out, you make mistakes. plus, tipping itself, there's so much debate on what the correct amount is. i've hear 15 percent, 18 percent, and, unless you are relatively skilled with math to figure it out or have a calculator you'll never figure it out. it doesn't need to be a project. i mean, i just don't get why it's the customer's responsibility to make sure the staff can have an income. i mean, every business follows that motto. when you pay for something else, like books, you're just buying a book. there's no obligation to pay the employees a small amount too for what the company should be paying them to do. i mean, japan does this well. in fact, in japan it's considered disrespectful and rude to tip. i think it's actually considered bribery. i just don't see who tipping benefits? can anyone change my view though? i personally just can't see who the system benefits.

auto_conc: i don't think wait staff should be tipped.
gt: having to pay wait staff would sink any restaurant. the 2. 13 is probably just enough to cover taxes. i ve gotten many 80 hour checks that come out to 0 after taxes. it is sad that your livelihood relies on the generosity of others, but if you have 10 people waiting tables plus cooks bus boys hosts bartenders and whoever else is required to run your business there d be no way to stay afloat. a slow night or month would be a negative. you would pay more in wages than you make in sales. just to put it out there tip in cash even if you pay with a card. crcard tips are taxed as well.
masked_conc_attacks: it's not that people don't tip, it's that people aren't able to make a living off tips.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're talking about here, but i think it's important to note that you're making a lot of money off of tips. it's not like you're going to be able to make a decent amount of money if you don't tip. if you're not going to tip, then you have to tip.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think tipping should be based on factors they literally have no control over.

conclusion: Sneezing is voluntary
premises: people who sneeze either lack the willpower or desire to resist. all sneezes are preventable. i don't know why people choose to sneeze, but i really wish they wouldn't, it's quite rude. i personally have only ever sneezed a handful of times, altogether an unpleasant experience, i would not recommend it. there's almost always something you can do to prevent it, either by looking away from the bright light which is irritating you, or blowing your nose, etc. it's violent and it's hazardous in situations where you need to maintain control of your faculties like in a car or while crossing the street. this has been a psa. cmv.
argument: Sneezing is voluntary : people who sneeze either lack the willpower or desire to resist. all sneezes are preventable. i don't know why people choose to sneeze, but i really wish they wouldn't, it's quite rude. i personally have only ever sneezed a handful of times, altogether an unpleasant experience, i would not recommend it. there's almost always something you can do to prevent it, either by looking away from the bright light which is irritating you, or blowing your nose, etc. it's violent and it's hazardous in situations where you need to maintain control of your faculties like in a car or while crossing the street. this has been a psa. cmv.
auto_conc: I think people who sneeze are rude.
gt: i sneeze in my sleep and wake myself up. how do you suggest i stop myself from sneezing while asleep?

auto_conc_attacks: i'm not sure where you are coming from, but i don't think it's rude to sneeze.

conclusion: Race is a biological reality and IQ is partly genetic.

believe in the superiority of any race over another, nor do i believe every white is smarter than every black or that every asian is smarter than every white. what i ll be discussing is averages. averages that explain a lot of inequality there are plenty of stupid asians smart blacks or average whites. everyone has the potential and is an individual. socioeconomic and cultural factors are the other very important half of this argument. i ll cite a few different sources and give a brief description jared taylor in the video he cites several different sources showing global iq tests, brain asians have an average iq of 105 110, whites 100 105, arabs 90 100, latinos 80 95, american blacks 80 90 and finally african blacks with a score of 75 on average. the bell curve cavalli sforza cluster tree. png here you can see a genetic map done with tests showing the different mapping s of the genetics of the different human subspecies. more studies have been done like this showing the distant genetics of different races. crime statistics it has been shown that low iq highly increases the likelihood that someone will commit crime. especially violent crime. blacks and latinos are over represented in violent crime despite being small percentages of the population. likewise, whites and especially asians are not as represented or averagely so. iq and success income are highly just visually, not to mention the studies i talked about earlier. how can evolution create the abundance of life that we see with varying sizes shapes and intelligence levels but somehow evolution doesn t apply to humans. i understand this is politically incorrect to talk about, and i m not here to start a politically motivated flame war. cmv.

conclusion: Sex before marriage is to be avoided. Marriage is good (especially if you want to raise children). Legal marriage is pragmatic.
premises: i was raised a christian and still follow much of the guiding wisdom of western evangelicalism. i m also aware of recent studies which indicate that the number of sexual partners across a lifetime and cohabitation before marriage both correlate to higher rates of divorce. i realize marriage isn t for everyone but it does have long term affects on health and happiness measures. with growing recognition of long term cohabitation, i m not sure legal marriage has many benefits but my intuition is that it reduces paperwork travel visas, medical next of kin, taxes . i m unmarried but consider it a possibility within the next few years. better to think it through now than cmv after the fact!
argument: Sex before marriage is to be avoided. Marriage is good (especially if you want to raise children). Legal marriage is pragmatic. : i was raised a christian and still follow much of the guiding wisdom of western evangelicalism. i m also aware of recent studies which indicate that the number of sexual partners across a lifetime and cohabitation before marriage both correlate to higher rates of divorce. i realize marriage isn t for everyone but it does have long term affects on health and happiness measures. with growing recognition of long term cohabitation, i m not sure legal marriage has many benefits but my intuition is that it reduces paperwork travel visas, medical next of kin, taxes . i m unmarried but consider it a possibility within the next few years. better to think it through now than cmv after the fact!
auto_conc: i think i should get married before i have kids
gt: what do you mean when say 'marriage'? is it the formal commitment you make in front of others or does it refer to the long term, monogamous relationship you create with a partner? if it's the former, then this discussion seems somewhat arbitrary because you're glorifying a single moment. if it's the latter, then you have to think of the relationship in its entirety. that long term relationship doesn't begin at the ceremony unless it's an arranged marriage where the individuals haven't met yet . it begins when you started dating. when you start to think about the relationship in its entirety, it seems silly to assign an arbitrary date to engage in sex or cohabitation. to me, it seems like you're adding a lot of undue stress to plan a big celebration the wedding ceremony where you're announcing to you're closest friends family that you are going to take both of these steps at the same time. imagine the vows, 'hey everyone, just wanted to let you know that up until now we were both virgins who have never lived with a romantic partner, but starting tonight we're going to have sex and live together! ' instead, both partners should engage in these activities when they both feel that they are ready for them. they should get married when they're both confident that this is the partner they want to spend the rest of their lives with. to me, a wedding is simply an opportunity to celebrate that love commitment you've created with friends and family. ultimately, marriage is a long term relationship that needs to be worked on and managed forever. it's not like you get married and start with a new relationship or you get married and all the relationship work vanishes. instead, you get married and a week later things should go back to being how they were before the stress of the wedding.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know what you're talking about, but i think you're right that marriage is a bad thing. it's not just about the number of sexual partners, it's about the quality of life of the person involved. i don't think it's a good thing, but it's definitely a good idea. if you don't want to have sex with someone, you're going to have to deal with a lot of paperwork and taxes.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'legal marriage', but i think it's important to remember that marriage is not for everyone. if you want to raise children, you have to be married.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think you should get married before you have kids. i think it's a good idea to wait until you have children before you get married.

conclusion: It should be made illegal for parents to buy their children video games with "mature" age ratings
premises: video games are rated by the country's age ratings board whether it's esrb in the us, pegi in europe or another regional system , based on the content they contain, such as violence, sexual content, bad language or drug use. many violent video games are almost photo realistic and contain graphic depictions of blood and gore, as well as often having the option to brutally kill innocent civilians gta v is an example of this . at young ages children cannot clearly distinguish fantasy from reality in the same way as an adult. i'm sure the thought of a 6 year old sitting in front of a screen shooting people through the head in a video game should make most people very uncomfortable. this would be difficult to enforce, but in my country it's also illegal for an adult to purchase alcohol for somebody under the age of 18, and whilst this doesn't eliminate the problem of underage drinking, it adds a certain weight to the action and reinforces the idea that it's punishable if discovered by the authorities.
argument: It should be made illegal for parents to buy their children video games with "mature" age ratings : video games are rated by the country's age ratings board whether it's esrb in the us, pegi in europe or another regional system , based on the content they contain, such as violence, sexual content, bad language or drug use. many violent video games are almost photo realistic and contain graphic depictions of blood and gore, as well as often having the option to brutally kill innocent civilians gta v is an example of this . at young ages children cannot clearly distinguish fantasy from reality in the same way as an adult. i'm sure the thought of a 6 year old sitting in front of a screen shooting people through the head in a video game should make most people very uncomfortable. this would be difficult to enforce, but in my country it's also illegal for an adult to purchase alcohol for somebody under the age of 18, and whilst this doesn't eliminate the problem of underage drinking, it adds a certain weight to the action and reinforces the idea that it's punishable if discovered by the authorities.
auto_conc: I believe violent video games should be illegal for people under 18.
gt: do you know why it is illegal for shopkeepers to give the games to children? it has nothing to do with any effect on the children, it was about the children doing things behind their parents back and the parents getting really angry about not being involved in that decision. if it's the parents buying the games then they are involved. if there was an epidemic of people converting 10 year olds away from their parents religion for example, you would quickly see a similar reaction against those people.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'adult', but i'm going to try to use the word 'adult'. i don't think that's a good idea, but i think it's a bad idea. i'm not a big fan of video games, and i think there are a lot of things that could be considered 'adult' in a video game, such as the fact that it's made for adults. i think the problem with this is that there is a difference between adults and children. for example, if you're a parent, and you're not allowed to buy alcohol, you can't buy alcohol for your kid. if you want to buy drugs, you're going to have to buy them. and if you don't, you'll have to pay for them.
