auto_conc_attacks: if you're going to make violent video games illegal, then you should make them illegal for people under 18. if you want to make it illegal for children to buy alcohol, then it should be illegal for adults to purchase alcohol.

conclusion: All stable currency throughout history has been backed up by force, at a minimum. Therefore, fiat currency is the best and most efficient kind of currency that could possibly exist.
premises: throughout history, we have gone into debt with each other. not all debts, however, are created equal. as we began to store large quantities of commodities that we found useful, we would record debts of the quantities that we owed using valuable metals that would not tarnish and were hard to reproduce, and found valuable. gold and silver, in this process, began to become a more and more widely accepted medium of exchange. eventually, because gold was such a heavy thing, and after the invention of the printing press, printing began to become such a cheap thing that now the creation of banks and the creation and circulation of banknotes became very popular. banknotes were, ultimately, backed up by force, because they were an agreement by the bank to give the holder of the banknote their gold back upon the return of the banknote. fast forward hundreds of years. and we are at the end of the bretton woods system. then, the u. s. took its dollar off the gold standard. and this is entirely because of taxes and the force behind them. currency acts as a medium of debt that someone owes to you. in the past, it was a debt of gold. and gold was only valuable to most people because the government and the rich interests who had a stake in it, would denominate tax debts in gold. this same logic applies to fiat currency today. any resource standard demands that you store quantities of that resource indefinitely, where it can not be utilized in the production of goods and services valuable to peoples desires. no matter what, if you are storing a fungible resource that has no uses for basic utility for most people, and only produces utility in advanced production, either as a conductor in electronics, or as jewelry, most people do not have use for gold.
argument: All stable currency throughout history has been backed up by force, at a minimum. Therefore, fiat currency is the best and most efficient kind of currency that could possibly exist. : throughout history, we have gone into debt with each other. not all debts, however, are created equal. as we began to store large quantities of commodities that we found useful, we would record debts of the quantities that we owed using valuable metals that would not tarnish and were hard to reproduce, and found valuable. gold and silver, in this process, began to become a more and more widely accepted medium of exchange. eventually, because gold was such a heavy thing, and after the invention of the printing press, printing began to become such a cheap thing that now the creation of banks and the creation and circulation of banknotes became very popular. banknotes were, ultimately, backed up by force, because they were an agreement by the bank to give the holder of the banknote their gold back upon the return of the banknote. fast forward hundreds of years. and we are at the end of the bretton woods system. then, the u. s. took its dollar off the gold standard. and this is entirely because of taxes and the force behind them. currency acts as a medium of debt that someone owes to you. in the past, it was a debt of gold. and gold was only valuable to most people because the government and the rich interests who had a stake in it, would denominate tax debts in gold. this same logic applies to fiat currency today. any resource standard demands that you store quantities of that resource indefinitely, where it can not be utilized in the production of goods and services valuable to peoples desires. no matter what, if you are storing a fungible resource that has no uses for basic utility for most people, and only produces utility in advanced production, either as a conductor in electronics, or as jewelry, most people do not have use for gold.
auto_conc: I believe that we are past the point of no return in terms of monetary policy.
gt: i'm not quite sure what your view is. is it a fiat currencies are preferable to gold backed currencies? b fiat currencies are preferable to gold backed currencies because of a specific set of reasons?
masked_conc_attacks: the gold standard was created in the 1700s. it was the only currency that used to be used in the production of goods and services. the gold standard is a currency that was created by the government and the rich interests who had a stake in it.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think you can really argue that fiat currency has been backed up by force, at a minimum.
auto_conc_attacks: if you're talking about the gold standard, you're going to have to look at the effects of monetary policy on the economy. in the past, gold was the only currency that could be used as a means of exchange, and the only way to exchange it was to use it as a form of currency. this is not the case today, but it's the case now. if you were talking about fiat currency, you would have to think about the effects that it would have on the economies of other countries. for example, the european economy was heavily reliant on gold, which was used as an alternative currency to the u. s. dollar. this was the reason why europe was so successful in the first place.

conclusion: The plight of black Americans is not just due to external factors (e.g. systemic racism), but is also due to internal factors within the community, and those factors deserve more attention.
premises: the legacy of slavery, high incarceration rates, police brutality, and the war on drugs, just to name a few. i don't discount this theory, at least not totally. these challenges are imposed on them by others. it's something done 'to' them. you can rally and protest against external challenges all you like so long as you do so in a rational, non hysterical, scare mongering way , but at the end of the day it'll always be easier to change yourself than to change how others might be acting poorly toward you. it's estimated that over 70 of black children today are born into single parent households, such households being strong predictors of future poverty, behavioral issues, likelihood to end up in jail, etc. in short, it's not good. it's not good for the parent and it's not good for the kid, and yet nearly 3 out of every 4 black kids are born into these circumstances. right out of the womb there are a whole host of statistics indicating that these children will have a much rougher go of things in life, and those stats, unlike others which are also valid have nothing to do with racism but rather the mother's decision to have a child out of wedlock. increased sex education might help this issue, but personally i think it's rather insulting to peoples intelligence to suggest that anyone over the age of, say, 16, doesn't know that sticking 'this' in 'there' and moving 'this' around a bit might result in a child, that children are expensive, and that it's best to have two parents not just for financial reasons but to help raise the kid properly. dropping out of school not having a job the brookings institute published a fairly well researched article titled 'three simple rules poor teens should follow to join the middle class. ' key word there being 'simple. ' these rules are: 1. graduate high school doesn't have to be a good high school 2. get and hold a job doesn't have to be a good job 3. don't have kids until 21 or later and we might add 'don't have kids out of wedlock, given what we just examined, and brookings touches on this subject, too these things are all quite manageable. the state will pay for your high school education, all you have to do is show up. unemployment is quite low at under 4 . and if you're poor, not having kids seems like a pretty obviously good life decision. a single kid takes roughly a quarter of a million dollars to raise from 0 18 in the us. i used to be poor as shit and fairly uneducated, but even back then i knew that my life prospects wouldn't be helped out much by entering into a 18 year, 250,000 lease for an aston martin vanquish s volante and then a couple years later entering another lease agreement for an equally expensive ferrari 488. if i did that, i'd expect you to think i was rather stupid, not ply me with sympathy for my financial problems. and yet that's basically what people who have kids when they're too poor to reasonably support just themselves are doing. anyways, brookings found that for lower class people who just followed these three simple rules, 75 joined the middle class, 23 at least improved their class financial prospects, and only 2 made no class financial progress at all. so if poor black youth or poor youth of any demographic just graduate high school, get and hold a job, and don't have kids until after they're 21 and or married, there's a 98 chance they'll either rise out of poverty or at least improve their status. and again, these are things that are your own personal decisions, not the result of outside influences acting against you. you can't blame the war on drugs or police brutality for your lack of upward mobility when there's three simple things that you can do for and by yourself to gain that upward mobility. veneration of gang poverty culture and the victim complex the first part of this two parter is the hardest for me to quantify with statistics, and perhaps my weakest argument, but it's something i've noticed on a widespread anecdotal scale and felt was worth mentioning. what i've noticed is that poorer people often seem to take a kind of pride in their impoverished status. and look, i get it. i've been poor and homeless and have done some very bad things in the interest of making money that i'd detail here if so many of them weren't federal crimes. but that lifestyle only really has a few possible outcomes: you either get out of it and go straight, you end up dead, you end up in jail, or, and this is what everyone is shooting for, you become that 0. 001 of criminals that makes it big and lives in a mansion with lots of beautiful women, pet tigers on the lawn, tons of cash, and diamond studded everything. and it's that last outcome that i see being often aspired to when young, poor kids get involved in criminal behavior. but that's as foolish as banking on your garage band becoming as big as the next metallica except when your garage band goes bunk you just go your separate ways with some musical skills under your belt; you don't end up dead or incarcerated. the second part is a bigger deal, i think: the victim complex. some of your plight is the fault of your oppressors, true, but if you behave like all of it is their fault then why bother trying to improve your prospects? black publications as well as black leaders like jesse lee peterson, thomas sowell, larry elder, and the youtuber some black guy, among others, have all pointed out that this 'woe unto me' victim complex isn't doing the black community any favors if the goal is to improve the status of the black community in america. black criminality i know, i know, controversial phrasing. most crime is intraracial. and i know the predictable comeback will be: 'but u chadonsunday, they're poor and destitute and oppressed crime is their only option! ' as we discussed earlier, brookings provided a few simple steps as 'options' for gaining upward mobility that are far more sustainable and far, far less likely to result in the person attempting them ending up behind bars of sex feet under. and speaking as an ex criminal who engaged in countless crimes that could've landed me behind bars or six feet under, trust me, there's always a choice. it's a choice between trying to earn a honest living probably making shit pay at a shit job and trying to make a quick and easy though risky buck through criminal behavior. as someone who chose the latter time and time again, i get the appeal, i really do. but even back then i didn't delude myself into thinking crime was my 'only' option, nor was i under any illusions as to what would happen if i got caught. don't commit crimes. don't sell illegal drugs. yes, every once in a blue moon a white police officer will unjustly shoot an unarmed black man i mean cops of all races unjustly shoot civilians of all races at comparable levels, but we only care when the officer is white and the victim is black , but if you really think 'black lives matter' you're far better off combating urban 'black on black' homicides than you are police brutality, since a black civilian is multitudes more likely to die at the hands of another black civilian than he is at the hands of a cop. cheers. y'all know what to do.
argument: The plight of black Americans is not just due to external factors (e.g. systemic racism), but is also due to internal factors within the community, and those factors deserve more attention. : the legacy of slavery, high incarceration rates, police brutality, and the war on drugs, just to name a few. i don't discount this theory, at least not totally. these challenges are imposed on them by others. it's something done 'to' them. you can rally and protest against external challenges all you like so long as you do so in a rational, non hysterical, scare mongering way , but at the end of the day it'll always be easier to change yourself than to change how others might be acting poorly toward you. it's estimated that over 70 of black children today are born into single parent households, such households being strong predictors of future poverty, behavioral issues, likelihood to end up in jail, etc. in short, it's not good. it's not good for the parent and it's not good for the kid, and yet nearly 3 out of every 4 black kids are born into these circumstances. right out of the womb there are a whole host of statistics indicating that these children will have a much rougher go of things in life, and those stats, unlike others which are also valid have nothing to do with racism but rather the mother's decision to have a child out of wedlock. increased sex education might help this issue, but personally i think it's rather insulting to peoples intelligence to suggest that anyone over the age of, say, 16, doesn't know that sticking 'this' in 'there' and moving 'this' around a bit might result in a child, that children are expensive, and that it's best to have two parents not just for financial reasons but to help raise the kid properly. dropping out of school not having a job the brookings institute published a fairly well researched article titled 'three simple rules poor teens should follow to join the middle class. ' key word there being 'simple. ' these rules are: 1. graduate high school doesn't have to be a good high school 2. get and hold a job doesn't have to be a good job 3. don't have kids until 21 or later and we might add 'don't have kids out of wedlock, given what we just examined, and brookings touches on this subject, too these things are all quite manageable. the state will pay for your high school education, all you have to do is show up. unemployment is quite low at under 4 . and if you're poor, not having kids seems like a pretty obviously good life decision. a single kid takes roughly a quarter of a million dollars to raise from 0 18 in the us. i used to be poor as shit and fairly uneducated, but even back then i knew that my life prospects wouldn't be helped out much by entering into a 18 year, 250,000 lease for an aston martin vanquish s volante and then a couple years later entering another lease agreement for an equally expensive ferrari 488. if i did that, i'd expect you to think i was rather stupid, not ply me with sympathy for my financial problems. and yet that's basically what people who have kids when they're too poor to reasonably support just themselves are doing. anyways, brookings found that for lower class people who just followed these three simple rules, 75 joined the middle class, 23 at least improved their class financial prospects, and only 2 made no class financial progress at all. so if poor black youth or poor youth of any demographic just graduate high school, get and hold a job, and don't have kids until after they're 21 and or married, there's a 98 chance they'll either rise out of poverty or at least improve their status. and again, these are things that are your own personal decisions, not the result of outside influences acting against you. you can't blame the war on drugs or police brutality for your lack of upward mobility when there's three simple things that you can do for and by yourself to gain that upward mobility. veneration of gang poverty culture and the victim complex the first part of this two parter is the hardest for me to quantify with statistics, and perhaps my weakest argument, but it's something i've noticed on a widespread anecdotal scale and felt was worth mentioning. what i've noticed is that poorer people often seem to take a kind of pride in their impoverished status. and look, i get it. i've been poor and homeless and have done some very bad things in the interest of making money that i'd detail here if so many of them weren't federal crimes. but that lifestyle only really has a few possible outcomes: you either get out of it and go straight, you end up dead, you end up in jail, or, and this is what everyone is shooting for, you become that 0. 001 of criminals that makes it big and lives in a mansion with lots of beautiful women, pet tigers on the lawn, tons of cash, and diamond studded everything. and it's that last outcome that i see being often aspired to when young, poor kids get involved in criminal behavior. but that's as foolish as banking on your garage band becoming as big as the next metallica except when your garage band goes bunk you just go your separate ways with some musical skills under your belt; you don't end up dead or incarcerated. the second part is a bigger deal, i think: the victim complex. some of your plight is the fault of your oppressors, true, but if you behave like all of it is their fault then why bother trying to improve your prospects? black publications as well as black leaders like jesse lee peterson, thomas sowell, larry elder, and the youtuber some black guy, among others, have all pointed out that this 'woe unto me' victim complex isn't doing the black community any favors if the goal is to improve the status of the black community in america. black criminality i know, i know, controversial phrasing. most crime is intraracial. and i know the predictable comeback will be: 'but u chadonsunday, they're poor and destitute and oppressed crime is their only option! ' as we discussed earlier, brookings provided a few simple steps as 'options' for gaining upward mobility that are far more sustainable and far, far less likely to result in the person attempting them ending up behind bars of sex feet under. and speaking as an ex criminal who engaged in countless crimes that could've landed me behind bars or six feet under, trust me, there's always a choice. it's a choice between trying to earn a honest living probably making shit pay at a shit job and trying to make a quick and easy though risky buck through criminal behavior. as someone who chose the latter time and time again, i get the appeal, i really do. but even back then i didn't delude myself into thinking crime was my 'only' option, nor was i under any illusions as to what would happen if i got caught. don't commit crimes. don't sell illegal drugs. yes, every once in a blue moon a white police officer will unjustly shoot an unarmed black man i mean cops of all races unjustly shoot civilians of all races at comparable levels, but we only care when the officer is white and the victim is black , but if you really think 'black lives matter' you're far better off combating urban 'black on black' homicides than you are police brutality, since a black civilian is multitudes more likely to die at the hands of another black civilian than he is at the hands of a cop. cheers. y'all know what to do.

auto_conc: i believe the uk should have a fully socialised healthcare system.
gt: the biggest issue with completely free healthcare is one that cannot be ignored, but is constantly overlooked. emergency services. allowing for free, unscreened access to healthcare creates an unmitigated disaster. i am constantly reading articles of horror stories in the uk, where people wait hours for ambulances, sit in the er for hours upon hours, and still have corners cut in their treatment. this is due to the fact that people don t pay for their healthcare, and therefore have nothing stopping them from frivolous use of emergency services. and they use them frivolously. and this is already an issue in the us. i m a paramedic, so take it from me. i d say that 60 70 of the patients i see in the er or on he ambulance, have government paid insurance. and i d estimate that 85 of patients that utilize emergency services, do not have an emergent medical problem. and i can absolutely, without a shadow of a doubt, say that 100 of our frequent, frivolous users of emergency services are on government paid insurance. ask anybody that works in this field. you need to realize the significance of those numbers. government funded, unscreened insurance is the primary cause for any and all of the overcrowding of emergency services that is experienced in the us. take that problem and quadruple it, and you can see the kind of horror show that emergency services in the uk face. this problem must be addressed before we make a disaster of socialism implementation like the uk has in so many ways. now, i want you to study up on the country that has the best ranked healthcare system according to the euro health consumer index. netherlands. take a look at why their healthcare system is the best, and why it continues to only keep getting better. maybe that will help to illustrate to you the difference between implementation of a social system, and smart implementation of a social system. social systems are not inherently better, and social system is not afforded the luxury of trial and error, as other systems are. if your social system has even one flaw, it can, and usually will, become a disaster before it can ever be controlled.

'

conclusion: there is a relative lack of respect and deference for the social sciences.
premises: we have a worldwide network of universities with countless sociology, anthropology, political science and critical theory departments, yet it seems like every ordinary person off the street feels equally qualified to speculate or offer opinions about human nature, culture, politics, etc. you just don't see the natural sciences treated the same way. if someone has an interesting thought pop into their head about biology or physics, they don't just assume that thought in its current state is equivalent to research. the curiosity that gets sparked about natural science always seems to lead to a google search, at least. it certainly doesn't seem like it to me. it seems that the most people are willing to do is shop around for statistical studies that support a position they have already determined all on their own to be correct. i totally understand why this is the case. when it comes to social science, everyone seems to believe that we all have access to the same data; we are all human, and we all have experienced belonging to a society. we also have a natural tendency to try to universalize our particular perspective. i think there is a very strong temptation to do this for the sake of our own ego nobody wants to be the villain, everybody wants to be the hero. i just think that it is interesting how rarely people realize that there are legions of professionals out there who do nothing but read, write and think about the topics that they have chewed over during the margins of their day. but what's even worse is how this ignorance carries itself into our social discourse. right now there is a serious accusation of partiality and bias against politically conservative students and faculty in university social science departments. the reason for this is really quite simple: objectivity requires detachment from the subject being studied, and this detachment leads to criticism of normative beliefs and institutions that are currently in power. given that the conservative position is all about maintaining the status quo against external threats, or even returning to an ideological vision of the past when these institutions were supposedly even stronger, conservatives are obviously going to feel particularly attacked by the process of critique. conversely, liberals leftists are going to embrace the results of objective critique and become political advocates for reform. any idea, be it politically conservative or liberal, can have its place if it actually holds up to disciplinary rigor. one example is the youtube personality 'sargon of akkad' aka carl benjamin a guy who invokes classical liberalism to attack feminists and other identity groups, even though he has never critically studied political philosophy beyond what provides him with convenient arguments to rile up his viewers. another even more insidious example is jordan peterson a psychologist ! who levels accusations at the academic left without ever engaging in their scholarship, and who writes books gives lectures about political philosophy without having properly studied the topic as an academic. in both of these figures what we see is a blatant abandonment of the objectivity of academic discipline in favor of dumbed down messages that are specifically designed to fuel people's existing sense of indignation. you would never see the same thing happen in the natural sciences, or at least not to the point where such figures would be taken seriously. i think the closest things i can think of might be anti vaxxers or flat earthers, but it seems pretty widely acknowledged that these people's views cannot be trusted scientifically. they haven't done the disciplined work to arrive at their conclusions, and so we generally treat them as absurd. this is a completely separate standard that never gets applied on the behalf of people who spend just as much time engaged in a scientific discipline. change my view.

gt: firstly 'social science' isn't a science as it does not employ the scientific method. it's simply called a 'science' for the same reason that academia calls programming 'computer science' rather than computer programming. this is coming from someone with a computer science degree academics like calling everything 'science' as science things get more funding. moreover social science originates from academia which means that it should be greeted with skepticism. you must understand that academia for all it's wisdom is also the source of some of the greatest evils of the past century. it is academia and the 'sciences' that brought into this world the ideas of social darwinism, eugenics, marxism, scientific racism, and intersectionality.

gt: polyglot here. i've spent a good bit of time learning russian. i love russian, though i've never been to russia. after a number of hours if i had to guess 800 1000 hours of study i can hold low level conversations with russian people if they are being nice to me and listening and trying their best to be patient. i've also spent few years studying another language that didn't really interest me in school, and i ended up living in that country for a few years. i still can't speak it very well. i've taken a number of tests that measure aptitude for learning languages. i scored extremely well 99th percentile . the moral of what i'm getting at is even if a person really wants to learn a second language, it's hard. really hard , even if they want to learn. and not everyone is gifted in language, either. not everyone has a patient teacher, or someone who cares to help them learn every word or nuance every idea. try not to hold it against people who don't speak english.

conclusion: Gender is NOT a social construct.
premises: yes, i brought it up. something that is heavily debated. people who have my opinions are usually bashed and get a lot of negative comments. i am willing to hear other people s opinions. i am very open to the opinion that goes against mine. here i go. when you are born, you have notable factors that identify you with one gender. a common argument that s brought up is intersex people. there are still factors that make intersex people male or female. now let s touch on the subject of transgenders. transgender people have a mental illness. they have gender dysphoria. i ve talked to people who were transgender and non binary. they didn t bring up anything associated with gender dysphoria. instead the transgender male said that he feels like a male because he doesn t identify with things associated with female. males and females are not obligated to do anything. for example, i am a female and i do not like to wear dresses. dresses is something that is stereotyped to females. just because i do not like dresses, doesn t mean i have to change my gender. there are males who wear dresses and makeup and still identify as a male. when i asked the non binary person why she felt non binary, she said it s because she doesn t identify with anything male or female. like i said before, males and females can do things that are associated with the other gender and still identify with their gender at birth. yes, i said she because i believe that there are only two genders. i hope my opinion is still valid. humans agree and disagree all the time. i hope we can find common ground. thanks for your time.

auto_conc: i believe that there are only two genders.!
gt: i've got friend freddy and friend roger. they are both men, biologically speaking. however, you'd understand very quickly were i to say 'freddy is way more manly then roger'. it's not even particularly controversial, and people don't mean it judgmentally roger is awesome, but that doesn't really matter. it's comprehensible, everyday language. i would certainly that the qualities we denote as 'manly' in this context are a social construct e. g. the connection to 'more manly' and those qualities that freddy has that roger does not. what i've employed in the use of the phrase 'more manly' is gender , and shown it to be a spectrum. mostly what people object to is then going a step further and giving some noun to the location on the spectrum occupied by 'more manly'. so what in there isn't a social construct?

premises: i am using the definitions from mental health involves effective functioning in daily activities resulting in productive activities work, school, caregiving healthy relationships ability to adapt to change and cope with adversity mental illness refers collectively to all diagnosable mental disorders health conditions involving significant changes in thinking, emotion and or behavior distress and or problems functioning in social, work or family activities the suicide rate among transgender people is abnormally high. many transgender people say that their brain is different from that of the gender they were born in. i hope i have not sounded bigoted and transphobic. i really respect them and this is why i want to change my view that they have an illness

auto_conc: i think that transgender people have a mental illness.
gt: 1. gender dysphoria is not the same as transgenderism. the former is a mental illness that often occurs alongside transgenderism, defined by significant distress directly caused by being transgendered, but not all transgendered people are gender dysphoric until they undergo reassignment surgery. 2. if you're arguing that gender dysphoria is a mental illness why? the latest diagnostic manual dsm 5 from one of the foremost authorities on mental health american psychiatric association defines it as such. who are you arguing against? 3. transgenderism without gender dysphoria is no more a mental illness than homosexuality which i imagine you weren't trying to argue being a mental illness . both are abnormal groups with increased suicide rates largely because they are stigmatized and marginalized groups. abnormality has never been a sufficient criterion only distress which is not caused by the transgenderism in non dysphoric cases and impairments in functioning are relevant criteria if you see the aforementioned dsm 5, essentially all mental disorders include this is a criterion for diagnosis; hence why checking if the door is locked 3 times is probably not an ocd, but when you check it 15 times and lose jobs due to constantly being late that's an ocd . or to quote the apa: 'gender nonconformity is not in itself a mental disorder. the critical element of gender dysphoria is the presence of clinically significant distress associated with the condition' if you google that quote you'll get the source, it's a pdf that i can't figure out how to link here .
masked_conc_attacks: i think it's important to remember that mental illness is not a mental illness. it's an illness that is caused by an imbalance in the brain. it doesn't need to be cured, it just needs to be treated.

conclusion: Transgender rights is a low priority issue and the left should divert its political capital elsewhere for now
premises: first off i think there are issues that dwarf it in importance. you're not going to be able to get your transition meds if you can't afford healthcare. is your gender identity really going to matter much when climate change hits in full swing? you're not going to be able to be your true gender if you're in working poverty. will getting more trans people into politics matter much if they're up against vast amounts of corporate , running in gerrymandered districts, with their votes counted on diebold voting machines without a paper trail? i know it's possible to focus on more than one issue at a time. it only concerns a very small of the population. mtf and ftm are a tiny , and other gender concepts even smaller still. it's so rare that people won't see themselves in transgender people, or will find it very easy not to and to 'other' them instead. 2. it can be seen to contradict prior progressive ways of thinking, like 'gender doesn't matter' and 'don't judge a book by its cover'. people who have strained themselves to accept that girls can do all the things boys can, will now have to strain themselves all over again, and won't take kindly to ending up in the 'bigot' category. 3. it relies on relatively recent and advanced concepts in the humanities and medical science that are beyond the understanding of a majority of the population. one key scientific claim behind the movement is that men and women have different brains and transgender brains correspond with their identified gender; this is the subject of scientific debate this is in a society where things like evolution and climate change still get debated. 4. it isn't a 'live and let live' issue like gay rights as it asks the rest of the population to change their behaviour, and tells them that not only the things they say, but the way they think is wrong. they may be minor things like 'state your name and pronouns' at events, or needing to tiptoe around things that could once be assumed to be gender specific like pregnancy and mensturation, or referring to a person you met as 'they' in very strained sentences. the issue arises when people have to 'educate themselves' and 'get with the program'. people who feel frustrated by 'political correctness' are a very rich vein for politicians to tap into. it pays to be the politician telling you that your subconscious is right; that the masculine looking person in a dress is what you think they are and not what you've been told they are. 5. there are aspects of it that are quite frankly offensive to the average persons sensibilities. concepts like 'uncanny valley' are real things, and pictures and videos of normal parts of transgender life are nsfl. this can change over time, but it's a very slow process consider how long it took for something as benign as gay kissing to make it to mainstream tv and cinema . this would be fine, except 6. it combines those things with children. many people are far more conservative when it comes to children than they are with society is general. you may be ok with adults doing what they want to themselves but draw the line at children, because that's something parents are enabling, and to top it all off many of the things are irreversible. on top of that, the rapid rise of people's awareness of this issue will make people think 'fad'. once you get to this nexus, it can turn a disagreement into a crusade. there are many more issues; all that's to say that it's an uphill battle and will need to be a marathon. meanwhile progressives really can't afford to lose again, and issues like voter suppression and climate change are immediate and existential threats. i usually tend to disagree with 'small target' strategies, but this particular issue seems to be political poison. in return for taking a major stand on it, it doesn't seem like it's going to win over any new voters or convert many voters into volunteers activists i'd be very happy to have my view changed on the latter point please share your stories . if it all goes well, a tiny of the population are better off, but it's going to be hard to make it go well. the goal is for people with a wide variety of views to vote entirely along the lines of who'll keep boys out of the girls locker room or women's boxing; the divide is there with an overall majority opposing the idea of gender identity, but it's not clear whether it actually changes votes. however if you see a trap in front of you, you better have a plan when you walk straight into it. for now it seems like the best strategy is to steer clear.

the divide is there with an overall majority opposing the idea of gender identity, but it's not clear whether it actually changes votes. however if you see a trap in front of you, you better have a plan when you walk straight into it. for now it seems like the best strategy is to steer clear.
auto_conc: the transgender movement is a sprint, not a marathon.
gt: really interesting perspective, and i a trans woman find myself agreeing with a lot of you said. in particular, trans issues were clearly brought into the forefront by republicans, as obvious bait to get the base riled up. trans people have always used the bathroom, it was never a big deal before. now, our existence is suddenly being considered a threat by large swaths of the population, which feels pretty terrible. however, i will say while i agree the current progressive strategy is a clear loss, i think it's possible for us to approach this issue in a way that actually makes sense. right now, our strategy is something akin to 'people should be able to choose whatever identity they feel best fits them', and in particular being invasive in people's lives in the way that you mention. things like adding 'they' to the lexicon, adding a dozen new genders to everything, or having people state their name and pronouns during events. i think this is quite a bit too radical, and while i support it long term, i think people are very worried about it. i think a more moderate strategy is advisable in the interim; we should let people get comfortable with more gender conforming trans people that fit into cis society without requiring many changes, before we unleash the ey em genderfluid pansexual anarchocommunist demigirls i make fun of you 'cause i love you! . a few examples of strategies i'd like to see in the movement: redefine gender as something along the lines of 'if your birth certificate and sex hormones agree on one of 'male' or 'female', that is your gender. if not, you may self identify as either gender, and use the faculties of either gender, but may not participate in women's sports. ' this is, as the trump administration would say, 'grounded in science', while also being trans inclusive, and making at least some sense. it cedes some ground to the conservatives, while not really negatively affecting very many people's lives. i think it's a bad final definition for a variety of reasons, but i think it makes a decent starting point that is resistant to the conservative bogeyman of the weird creepy man that starts wearing a dress one day so he can use the women's room. i think that conservatives are imagining trans women as 'men in dresses' and trans men as 'women with buzzcuts'. so maybe we should make the image of trans people less 'weird androgynous in between folks' and more 'people who are basically the same as everyone else but changed their gender'. this is an example of something i'd like to see more of. we really have to stop minimizing people's concerns with the really thorny parts of the trans movement, like women's prisons, or women's sports. i think there are reasonable objections that we should take into account and think about , not just assume everyone raising them is a transphobic asshole. i am sure there are really good potential compromises on this stuff, but if we create a moratorium on anything that even kind of looks like transphobia from a distance, we're really hamstringing ourselves and there's no way we'll be able to find an effective solution that people are okay with.
masked_conc_attacks: how do you define 'transgender' when you're talking about people who don't identify as their gender? i'm not sure what you mean by 'transgendered', but i don't think it's a 'live and let live' issue like gay rights.
known_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i don't think you're trying to change the view of the left. there is a lot of political capital in politics right now, and it's not going to be used to change people's minds. it's going to take a long time to get people to change their minds, and that's the only way to do it. i think it's a good idea to focus on the issues you're talking about, rather than the ones that really matter. you seem to be focusing on the things that don't matter to you, not the issues that matter to the rest of the population.
auto_conc_attacks: 1. the transgender movement is a sprint, not a marathon. 2. it's not a sprint. 3. it isn't a marathon, it's just a short sprint.

conclusion: The message of the MeToo movement should be something like Give all women the benefit of the doubt, dont dismiss them, and investigate their claims rather than Believe all women
premises: i have a feeling that no corroborating or falsifying evidence is going to present itself with regard to the ford kavanaugh situation. if that is the case, i think kavanaugh will likely be voted in. this would cause an outrage because so many people reasonably do not like the idea of appointing people accused of attempted rape to the supreme court. i feel that upholding our tradition of due process is more important than any one unsubstantiated sexual assault allegation no matter how credible the woman seems. i believe she is supremely credible with regard to the claim that something happened to her. however, so far that credibility hasn t been able to be transformed into any sort of verifiability. we shouldn t believe every allegation simply in virtue of its existence. if it is positively shown to be true, action should be taken. if it is positively chosen to be false, the allegation should be dismissed. and if it can t be positively shown to be either, which may very well be the case here, i don t view it as a failure of morality to move forward as if the allegation was shown to be false. there is nothing sexist about the burden of proof being on the accuser. it is possible to show deep sympathy for an accuser and give her the time of day while simultaneously reaching the conclusion that unfortunately her claims couldn t be substantiated so no action will be taken. it is better to let guilty people go free than to punish the innocent. because i believe this, believe all women doesn t seem measured or nuanced enough for me. accusers deserve to be taken seriously and the accused deserve due process! not as catchy i know. i feel like this is a pretty rational, measured take, but it s one i don t really see represented in media.

conclusion: The Pareto Distribution paints a troubling picture for western society.
premises: while displaystyle alpha alpha is variable, empirical observation has found the 80 20 distribution to fit a wide range of cases, including natural phenomena and human activities. this is obviously pretty complicated so i'm sure there are factors i'm not considering, but this seems to paint a very discouraging picture for those in society who want to rise from a low or middle class position in society to a high class position. in particular this seems to apply to people in creative hobbies, like music. i was reminded of this because there are a lot of hip hop songs where the message is that they started from nothing and rose to the top. on the surface there doesn't seem to be anything wrong with this kind of message, but if the pareto distribution is to be believed, there is an 80 chance that they will fail to be financially successful in music, and while this can obviously be influenced by effort and dedication, i think the odds are really stacked against an aspiring artist, and i think many of them are deeply inspired by the message of 'just keep trying and you'll make it'. but for most of them, this will not be true, and i think failure can really psychologically impact them when they realize this. but this is only one example. the dating world has been shown to reflect this as well. okcupid posted an infamous blog post confirming the 80 20 rule and there was a study using tinder that confirmed the same rule as well now i'm not one of those mgtow guys. but i think men and women alike are unrealistic in their expectations, which causes problems. women think they're entitled to the top 20 of men and vice versa. but realistically, most of us are in the bottom 80 . it seems this might be a 'dirty secret' type of situation where our western values conflict with what this information tells us. the idea that anyone can achieve greatness if they try hard enough seems to be pretty naive. or am i totally missing the point of this? maybe things aren't so bad. cmv.

auto_conc: the 80% rule is pretty discouraging for people trying to rise in society.
gt: the pareto principle is merely an observation of the historical or the current relationship between two numbers. it does not make predictions about the future. it is descriptive , not prescriptive. the two numbers don't have to be 80 20, and they don't even have to add up to 100, which are common misconceptions of the pareto principle. it's possible, for example, that in some years, 80 of all wealth will be held by 30 of all people, or 90 held by 5 , who knows. they are all valid pareto distributions, each with a different graph. so no, there's no reason why the mere ability to express things in pareto distributions should be troubling.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's that hard to achieve greatness if you try hard enough. i think there are a lot of people out there who are trying hard enough to make it. there are plenty of people who are working hard enough, but are not able to do it. i don't know about you, but i think you're underestimating the amount of hard work that goes into making it to the top of the world. it's not that you can't succeed, it's just that you have to be willing to work hard.

auto_conc_attacks: i think the 80 20 rule is pretty discouraging for people trying to rise in society.

since my grandmother and father had 0 access to education, they are no different than disadvantage backgrounds in western civilisations. even though my mother has done well, she and i, are still victims of the patriarchy and hierarchy formed in the middle east. i believe i do not need any compensation of equality of opportunity because of my technically 'disadvantaged' background. this is not a slippery slope. in australia, it is a well documented fact that if you are a part of a demographic that has been discriminated against in the past, you will be given compensation even if you personally have not been discriminated against and even if have had equal opportunity as others. this can be seen in governments trying to achieve quotas and even funding private businesses to fill quotas to close gaps. change my mind!

gt: it's not about creating an equality of outcome as much as it is about balancing outcomes with opportunities. inequality is natural. given our natural differences, we will do different things. certain skills personalities will accumulate more resources and power. this is natural. history tells us that this trend will continue until the rich are too rich and the poor are too poor. then you will see bloodshed and revolt. so, since nature tends towards inequality and we claim to support an equality of opportunity something must be done. the child raised by drug addicted miscreants does not have equal opportunities compared to the child raised by wealthy lawyers. these cycles re inforce themselves locking large classes into poverty and elevating others into a quasi aristocracy. we should not try to equalize outcomes. we all know that outcomes are largely driven by personal choices. at the same time, we need to recognize that 'largely' is not 'entirely. ' rather than allow a large, disaffected, and miserable underclass to grow and perpetuate itself, we see that is in everyone's best interests to offer support and attempt to equalize outcomes with the ultimate goal being equalizing opportunity.

auto_conc_attacks: what about people from disadvantaged backgrounds? if you're a jewish person, you should be compensated for that. if you are a black person, then you should not be compensated by the government.

conclusion: Bush was worse than Trump
premises: note: we're talking bush jr. here. please leave the footnote below the following line, but remember to delete this sentence by replacing it with the body of your post.

auto_conc: I think we should change the law in the UK to make it easier to travel
gt: so i'm a big fan of bush. i like him a lot and would have made basically every decision that he did had i been in his place. so you can take this with a grain of salt, or just write me off as being a monster. what would bill clinton have done had he gotten 4 terms? the first months of the bush presidency were taken up with the popping of the tech bubble. in retrospect it wasn't that big of a deal and certainly got over shadowed by other events, but at the time it was a big deal and demanded a huge amount of time dealing with the economic and social impacts. which means i don't think any reasonable president acting without advanced knowledge could have avoided 9 11. would you agree with me on that? now if you accept that 9 11 has happened, i am also going to propose to you that the invasion of afghanistan was also unavoidable. even if you had perfect knowledge of what would happen there, any president would have be compelled to invade afghanistan. lets then talk about iraq. post 9 11 the usa quickly realized that the status quo in the middle east was not acceptable to it. people chanting 'death to america' in the streets was going to eventually lead to attacks. philosophically it became clear that america couldn't simply wall itself off from the rest of the world but instead needed to get involved more directly. so we had a list of hot spots. russia, iran, iraq, north korea, saudi arabia, and 'palestine' that were the major issues. bush put a lot of diplomatic effort into russia and thought he had developed a good working relationship with putin. he read putin wrong. but someone had to. someone had to give putin the chance to play the good guy and let him make the active choice to instead play the bad guy. bush took the hit on that. but look at hrc at state and the reset button. they tried again, and failed again, so it isn't as though bush's actions here were unreasonable. if anything bush was ahead of the curve figuring out who putin was. north korea bush engaged in some pretty successful diplomacy and definately got the pot down to a simmer there. it was obama who allowed the heat to be reapplied. on the saudi arabia front the kingdom basically got on a path towards reform and has been making little steps along it ever since and while its still a shit show and a lot of crgoes to obama for continuing the good work and building on it , its better than iran or iraq so that's some kind of win right? so bush was left with iraq and iran. historic enemies of each other, both enemies of america, and both actively funding terrorists and interesting in wmd's. iraq however was giving good cause for war. they were violating the terms of the first gulf war's end by frustrating the work of weapon's inspectors this was a deliberate policy of saddam so that other players in the region would think he had wmd's available to him . they were firing on us warplanes patroling the no fly zone on a regular basis this is independently a near weekly act of war against the united states . they were funding terrorism in israel and around the world openly paying the families of dead terrorists for successful attacks . and so they were invaded. the decision was put to congress, and virtually every democratic senator and congressman voted in favor of it. would clinton have done otherwise had he been in office? i doubt it. it was, to a certain extent, a war of choice. however post 9 11 saddam's course of conduct was no longer acceptable to america. clinton might have tried deeper negotiations or pushed for more sanctions, but that would have sent a weaker message to iran. furthermore there was good reason to think, at the time, iraq was going to be a relative cake walk. or at least much less of a mess than it turned into. so i don't know if you can really say that clinton wouldn't have done exactly what bush did there. the one thought i will leave you with. the sanctions applied on iraq didn't personally hurt saddam. he had his lifestyle and if ten thousand children a month had to starve to death so that he could throw a lavish party using the food that would have saved them he threw the party. hundreds of thousands of people were dying in iraq yearly due to the sanctions we imposed. imagine we were 15 years later and the sanctions were still in place. who's the mass murderer now?

known_conc_attacks: how is bush worse than bush?

conclusion: Children ought never to be put on psychiatric medication.
premises: my main argument is this: children, physiologically speaking, have not reached maturity. duh. no one disagrees with this. their brains, bodies, emotions and basically everything about them is not mature. a child can display both acceptable and unacceptable behavior at any given time. when the behavior is deemed unacceptable and persistently so, this is when psychiatrists are called upon. this is bad news for the child. since children have not reached puberty, no less their formative years, their enduring personality along with their body, brain and character have only just begun to develop into what in the future can become a stable, integrated self. studies have shown the potential of stultification of children, stunting their growth after prolonged usage of adhd related drugs. interfering chemically with a brain not yet matured must then be seen as having the potential for tremendous, far reaching negative consequences. the idea i am challenging is believing a child and their bad or aberrant behavior necessarily equates to a brain based biological chemical imbalance and or disease process needing the treatment of a psychiatrist who will administer powerful brain and mind altering psychotropic chemicals to a still developing brain. that psychiatric medications certainly alter brain chemistry in anyone taking them is indisputable.

auto_conc: I believe that psychiatrists should not be allowed to diagnose children with mental illness.
gt: i think this decision should be left to doctors who study thousands of patients for years to determine what works and what doesn t. it should be left to their skilled opinions, not a layman s debate. doctor s wouldn t prescribe medicines that hurt unless the benefits outweighed the consequences.
masked_conc_attacks: i think there is a huge difference between a child and a person. a child is not mature, they are not mature. a person is mature because they have not yet reached the point where they can be a stable, integrated self. for example, a child could not be mature because he or she has not reached that point yet. this is not the case for a child, it is the case with a child. it's not a child's fault that they have a bad or aberrant behavior at any given time, it's their fault that a child has a bad behavior at a given time.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're trying to say, but i'm curious what you mean by 'children are not yet mature'. i don't think you're going to change your view, and i'm not even going to try to change my view.
auto_conc_attacks: i would like to challenge your premise that children should not be allowed to diagnose children with mental illness. i think that you are missing the point. a child's brain is not mature. it's just not mature enough to be diagnosed.

conclusion: To have children is to bet over his life
premises: as many would agree world is already a tough place. those who are not able to fit easily suffer more than the others. when we bring a child to this world we take care of them carefully in order to help them grow healthily. setting aside the fact that we might not be able to take care of them well, there are also many factors that are out of our control that may cause our children to suffer a lifetime. those factors may include many negative psychological tendencies or other mental disorders.
argument: To have children is to bet over his life : as many would agree world is already a tough place. those who are not able to fit easily suffer more than the others. when we bring a child to this world we take care of them carefully in order to help them grow healthily. setting aside the fact that we might not be able to take care of them well, there are also many factors that are out of our control that may cause our children to suffer a lifetime. those factors may include many negative psychological tendencies or other mental disorders.
auto_conc: It is better to save a life than to risk a life that could have been otherwise.
gt: gambling is a necessary element of life. going outside without a raincoat is a gamble it might rain . going to the store is a gamble they might not have what you want, someone might cough on you and get you sick . i cannot even think of any action a human can take which isn't a gamble in some manner or fashion. therefore, the fact its a gamble isn't what is morally relevant its the relative risks rewards and the probabilities of those outcomes that matter.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know about you, but i'm not sure how you feel about the fact that you're not able to fit easily, and that you have to take care of your children carefully, because you might not be able to care for them well, and i don't think that's going to be a good thing for you.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's important to remember that having children is not a bet. it's a way to ensure that your child has a good life. if you don't want to have children, you're not going to be able to provide for them. if your child is going to have a bad life, then you're going to need to take care of them. that's not to say that you shouldn't have kids, but that's just not the way it's supposed to be.
auto_conc_attacks: if you are willing to risk your life for the sake of your child, then you are justified in doing so. if you are unwilling to risk a life that could have been otherwise, then it is better to risk the life of the child.

conclusion: Not all cultures are worth saving as a whole. Multiculturalism is not inherently a virtue.
premises: to be clear, i am saying that there are cultures out there that are either unnecessary, or should have parts or the whole of them removed. i know there are benefits in many cases but a benefit does not make something virtuous.
argument: Not all cultures are worth saving as a whole. Multiculturalism is not inherently a virtue. : to be clear, i am saying that there are cultures out there that are either unnecessary, or should have parts or the whole of them removed. i know there are benefits in many cases but a benefit does not make something virtuous.
auto_conc: I don't believe any culture is inherently better than another.
gt: the ethicist kwame anthony appiah identifies the two most basic general principles of what he calls a 'cosmopolitan' morality, though he really means any modern morality worth taking seriously: 1 all people matter, and 2 it's ok to be different. these are the principles that cause us to value multiculturalism. if you don't agree with 1 or 2 above, it's going to be very hard to change your view here. this doesn't mean we can't as a society pass judgement on ideas that violate these two principles. and it doesn't mean we can't as individuals show preference for some people or some lifestyles. but it does mean that we should value a society that, on the largest scale, allows all people to live the kinds of lives they want. for practical reasons not to mention for the sake of kindness and humility , we should withhold judgement about other ways of life unless absolutely compelled not to.
masked_conc_attacks: there are many cultures out there that are either unnecessary, or should have parts or the whole of them removed.

auto_conc_attacks: i don't believe any culture is inherently better than another. i believe that there are cultures out there that are either unnecessary, or should have parts or whole of them removed. i do believe that some cultures are inherently better.

conclusion: Organ donations should be mandatory, not opt-out or opt-in
premises: tl:dr after death you no longer exist and thus can't own your body or organs anymore. i believe that a person stops existing after death. what you wanted while you were alive should not matter at all when the body can be used to potentially save lives. i also don't believe family or friends should have any say. their views hold more value as they are alive, but ultimately it's not their organs, and the organs can do a whole lot more good by helping someone else. i have lost close family in the past, and i definitely understand the will to keep your loved ones 'intact' in a way. but at the same time the options are either a: perfectly fine organs go to waste cremated or buried during a shortage or b: those same organs can potentially save lives and make many, many people happy. when these are the options it seems clear that feelings should be ignored and the family can bury whatever isn't useful.
argument: Organ donations should be mandatory, not opt-out or opt-in : tl:dr after death you no longer exist and thus can't own your body or organs anymore. i believe that a person stops existing after death. what you wanted while you were alive should not matter at all when the body can be used to potentially save lives. i also don't believe family or friends should have any say. their views hold more value as they are alive, but ultimately it's not their organs, and the organs can do a whole lot more good by helping someone else. i have lost close family in the past, and i definitely understand the will to keep your loved ones 'intact' in a way. but at the same time the options are either a: perfectly fine organs go to waste cremated or buried during a shortage or b: those same organs can potentially save lives and make many, many people happy. when these are the options it seems clear that feelings should be ignored and the family can bury whatever isn't useful.
auto_conc: I don't believe people should be able to keep their body after death.
gt: i want my body to by cryogenically frozen, so that at a later point if technology allows, i can be brought back. isn't that reason enough to opt out?
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that people should have the right to own their bodies, but i do think that it's unfair to force people to do what they want with their bodies. it's not fair to force someone to do something they don't want to do with their body.
known_conc_attacks: if you don't want to donate your organs, you can opt out.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think that you should be able to keep your body after death.

conclusion: Not everyone should be allowed to have children
premises: the three main bases of assessment would be: 1 financial economic, 2 psychologically, 3 criminal history. 1. economically financially: the person or couple must be able to demonstrate that they will be able to provide for the child's basic needs housing, food, reasonable estimate of healthcare etc. , and education at least through high school . this would be based on a holistic assessment of the person's and or couple's current income both active and passive , earning potential, availability of fairly liquid capital; the total earning potential should be able to cover the benchmarked costs for the above mentioned necessities without incurring excess debt i haven't calculated exactly what that'd be, but it'd be leveraging themselves up to a certain percentage of their current income 2. psychologically: the person or couple must be able to demonstrate that they pass a psychological evaluation that deems them fit to be parenting. i haven't completed figured out what the guidelines would be yet, but it would basically have to demonstrate that the person or couple doesn't have any severe mental disorders nor a recurring history of disorders . 3. criminal history: the person or couple cannot have a lengthy or recurring history of criminal activities this would be based on a has a lengthy history of criminal offenses; not civil offenses their past would need to be evaluated and indexed based on severity; e. g. first degree murder would pretty much rule out your chances, while involuntary manslaughter would be need to be further examined . ultimately, i think successfully implementing these measures would: increase gdp per capita, increase household income per capita, increase household expenditure per capita, decrease income inequality, increase literacy rates, reduce violent crime, decrease household debt, reduce underemployment and unemployment note: unemployment is different from underemployment . these quantitative changes would also qualitatively lead to a 'better society' with a higher quality of living. this is still a developing view, but it's a rough idea that i've been thinking about recently. i did a lazy job of fully fleshing out my thoughts because there're just way too many changes and causal links to list, but feel free to pick something and question it. you won't be able to cmv if you talk about how this isn't feasible in terms of implementation.

' economic. are there no good parents who are poor? what if i choose to live off the grid? what if i choose to live off the land in the woods? what if i have family members who support me? what if i have a healthy sum of cash and gold coins and bitcoins under my mattress that i don't want friends family government knowing about? should i have to fill out complex paperwork that's probably even more complicated than irs tax forms in order to disclose every detail of my financial situation? an assessment of person's economic situation is completely subjective. economic continued. a person's financial situation is often temporary. lottery winners and nfl millionaires often claim bankruptcy a few years after their winfall. poor college kids get jobs as doctors and lawyers when they graduate. why can't i have a baby today if i am confident i'll be in a good situation tomorrow? psychological. who determines whether or not i am psychologically fit? a government appointed psychologist? 50 years ago being gay was seen as a serious mental disorder. i don't trust the government to judge my mental state a fair way. psychological continued. many governments are controlling and do not allow dissent. imagine we tried your approval system for reproduction worldwide. in places like the soviet union or cuba or venezuela or north korea, you might be deemed as mentally unfit to have children if you disagree with the government's agenda. in places like saudi arabia, yemen, and afghanistan you might be seen as psychologically unfit to have children if you did not fully support islam. and just because your government is good today doesn't mean it won't turn bad in the future. in recent history, we've seen cuba transition from a free country to an oppressive dictatorship and germany and countless others. what if the government of usa, canada, australia, or uk go bad in 50 or 75 or 100 years and these government approval for reproduction laws are on the books? criminal history. a felon who has served his or her punishment is a free citizen. by not allowing them to have children, you are implying that they are guilty of being 'bad' in the future before committing another crime. if they are not allowed to have children, they are being punished for life. yes, punishment for life life in prison is an option now for the worst criminals but those people are essentially already unable to reproduce. to me, maximizing freedom is important. leave me alone to do as i please, and i'll let everyone else do as they please. as long as you're not stealing from me or physically harming me you, and everyone else, should be able to do whatever you want. have kids. don't have kids. adopt. your life, your choice. i generally trust people to make better decisions for themselves over government politicians and bureaucrats making making moral decisions for them.

conclusion: I think the Internet could eventually replace universities
premises: universities as institutions serve a variety of purposes, but first and foremost they provide a social structure that produces and passes along knowledge in a manner that is verified and trustworthy. universities create standards for knowledge and education by establishing disciplines with standardized methodologies and accepted practices, but they also encourage and award innovation as long as new ideas and methods can be properly explicated. disciplines change, and academic professionals are rewarded for changing their disciplines, as long as their ideas can actually hold up to the level of rational scrutiny that is promoted within these institutions. similarly, the standards of the discipline are exercised to evaluate students, and this evaluation is what gives the university degree its value in the labor market. my question is basically this: can the internet develop to the point where it can establish this sort of standardized disciplinary knowledge independent of the institutional structure of the university? can disciplinary knowledge also become social knowledge that is freely accessed, produced and disseminated by literally anyone that might choose to participate? for this to be possible, i think we would need to see a couple big changes take place. first and foremost, we would need a sort of second wave enlightenment which would throw out the current paradigm of alternative facts and insulated echo chambers of information. society as a whole would need to accept a common sense of objectivity and rationality, such that it is able to uphold its own standards of legitimacy. bad faith research and education would need to be quickly marginalized; but we would also need to be willing to accept innovation and new ideas, as long as they meet the standards of our collective scrutiny. secondly, we would need to see some sort of system of compensation that would fund research and education as goods in themselves . as it currently stands, this is the biggest issue in higher education and research. during his presidency, reagan criticized the disciplinary knowledge produced by university researchers, claiming that they were merely satisfying personal curiosity about obscure or useless issues, and using this criticism to justify a massive defunding of higher education. the legacy of this defunding has been the increase in student tuition and debt, an increased presence of private businesses on university campuses, a new focus on collegiate athletics and recreation to attract students, the co opting of research by private interests, etc. research and education have been re cast as means to capitalist ends; research to provide technological innovations to industry, education to equip laborers with knowledge and or general capabilities needed for workplace success. for the internet to become the new medium for research and education, we would need to somehow return to a social paradigm where knowledge itself is a valid end to pursue, and education is inherently enriching , and these goods are willingly funded by society without some expectation of an economic return. can we reach this point in our future? i would speculate that we can for a couple reasons. there will come a tipping point where the continuous expansion of higher education devalues the degree such that it is no longer economically feasible to pursue. secondly, while much of what we see happening on the internet is not encouraging, there are still some bright spots, and there is still the fact that the internet is very young. we have future generations that will grow up not even knowing a time before the internet existed; we can hope that these new immersed generations will make better use of the internet as a medium for research and education. we can hope that these younger generations will react against the uncertainty and relativism of our current generations, and bring about this second wave enlightenment that would need to take place. change my view.

but we would also need to be willing to accept innovation and new ideas, as long as they meet the standards of our collective scrutiny. secondly, we would need to see some sort of system of compensation that would fund research and education as goods in themselves . as it currently stands, this is the biggest issue in higher education and research. during his presidency, reagan criticized the disciplinary knowledge produced by university researchers, claiming that they were merely satisfying personal curiosity about obscure or useless issues, and using this criticism to justify a massive defunding of higher education. the legacy of this defunding has been the increase in student tuition and debt, an increased presence of private businesses on university campuses, a new focus on collegiate athletics and recreation to attract students, the co opting of research by private interests, etc. research and education have been re cast as means to capitalist ends; research to provide technological innovations to industry, education to equip laborers with knowledge and or general capabilities needed for workplace success. for the internet to become the new medium for research and education, we would need to somehow return to a social paradigm where knowledge itself is a valid end to pursue, and education is inherently enriching , and these goods are willingly funded by society without some expectation of an economic return. can we reach this point in our future? i would speculate that we can for a couple reasons. there will come a tipping point where the continuous expansion of higher education devalues the degree such that it is no longer economically feasible to pursue. secondly, while much of what we see happening on the internet is not encouraging, there are still some bright spots, and there is still the fact that the internet is very young. we have future generations that will grow up not even knowing a time before the internet existed; gt: who's going to accrdegrees? who's going to test them? who's going to define thr curriculum? who's going to do the paperwork? who's going to house labs, offices and libraries? you've just said 'what if universities were replaced by the internet', but you haven't actually said what that would look like. it's very hard to argue against something with so little substance other than to point out the lack of any planning, detail or thought into this that you've presented.

conclusion: It's not "anti-science" to include transgender people with their gender of identification.
premises: critics of transgenderism ? say that biology shows there's only two genders, male and female, based on sex chromosomes which are implicit from one's anatomy and hormonal balance if one's chromosomes are not known . after all, biology classes do say that men have xy and women have xx. i know that it's undeniably clear that we are a sexually dimorphic species. this is something that can be empirically tested. but if you were to say something like 'people who have xy chromosomes and this kind of anatomy are men, and people with xx chromosomes are not and cannot be' is that a statement that can be empirically tested? the statement 'people who have xy chromosomes and this kind of anatomy are men, and people with xx chromosomes are not and cannot be' is merely a statement defining the boundaries of a category. these categorical criteria serve a purpose in many scientific, medical, anthropological, etc. contexts, but they need not be ironclad in all contexts. different contexts sometimes call for categorical words to have different criteria! here are four examples of categorical words that have biology based definitions but don't always adhere to those definitions in all contexts: genetically, i'm lt;5 jewish. this may be relevant in some medical contexts, bringing up what kind of conditions i or my progeny may be predisposed to. but in, say, a demographic survey, i wouldn't call myself jewish. it's just not relevant in my life, neither ethnically nor religiously. i'm pretty sure we all understand that to be a 'father,' such as for the sake of celebrating father's day or contact info for the kid's school, need not involve the actual physical sire of the child. for many purposes, it's the male figure who's raised the kid as a typical biological father would. but if you were to go on the maury show to be told, 'you are not the father! ' , you'd know he doesn't mean 'you are not the one who's been raising this boy alongside the mother his whole life! ' rabbits and hares were declassified as rodents in 1912 because their teeth suggested that categorizing these animals in a different order would reflect phylogenetics better. but in pet stores and pet owner communities, they might as well be rodents because they're lumped in right alongside them. to put it pithily, 'knowledge is knowing that a tomato is a fruit. wisdom is knowing that it doesn't belong in a fruit salad. ' to put it more maturely, yes, tomatoes are considered 'fruits' by botanical criteria, but in culinary contexts, they're not. in short, the big trans question isn't so much whether the biological definitions of male and female are valid so much as it is whether these biological definitions should serve as the categorical boundaries between men and women in all non biological contexts.
