' , you'd know he doesn't mean 'you are not the one who's been raising this boy alongside the mother his whole life! ' rabbits and hares were declassified as rodents in 1912 because their teeth suggested that categorizing these animals in a different order would reflect phylogenetics better. but in pet stores and pet owner communities, they might as well be rodents because they're lumped in right alongside them. to put it pithily, 'knowledge is knowing that a tomato is a fruit. wisdom is knowing that it doesn't belong in a fruit salad. ' to put it more maturely, yes, tomatoes are considered 'fruits' by botanical criteria, but in culinary contexts, they're not. in short, the big trans question isn't so much whether the biological definitions of male and female are valid so much as it is whether these biological definitions should serve as the categorical boundaries between men and women in all non biological contexts.

gt: it s best to analyze them in both forms of gender

conclusion: "Fat Shaming" shouldn't be treated as actual discrimination
premises: so in recent years, there has been a greater concern from the general american public about how we treat those who are overweight or obese. many such as those in the fat acceptance movement and other such groups have began to argue that things like pointing out someone's weight, making fun of someone's weight, and certain portrayals of overweight people in media are all something called 'fat shaming. ' criticisms of one's weight are not serious forms of discrimination especially if said criticisms are not mean spirited in nature because unlike things such as race, gender, etc, you can change your weight. they are suggesting their unhealthy lifestyle is not the problem but, rather, the problem is lack of accommodations and society's view of your lifestyle. this view undermines the serious health risks of obesity, something which has currently reached epidemic proportion in the united states. perhaps i have the wrong idea about what these people are saying. i'd love to hear the other side of this argument.
argument: "Fat Shaming" shouldn't be treated as actual discrimination : so in recent years, there has been a greater concern from the general american public about how we treat those who are overweight or obese. many such as those in the fat acceptance movement and other such groups have began to argue that things like pointing out someone's weight, making fun of someone's weight, and certain portrayals of overweight people in media are all something called 'fat shaming. ' criticisms of one's weight are not serious forms of discrimination especially if said criticisms are not mean spirited in nature because unlike things such as race, gender, etc, you can change your weight. they are suggesting their unhealthy lifestyle is not the problem but, rather, the problem is lack of accommodations and society's view of your lifestyle. this view undermines the serious health risks of obesity, something which has currently reached epidemic proportion in the united states. perhaps i have the wrong idea about what these people are saying. i'd love to hear the other side of this argument.
auto_conc: I believe "fat shaming" is not a serious form of discrimination.
gt: obesity is a comorbidity with a lot of mental illnesses and physical disabilities. if you care about not being ablist, it's best not to give people a hard time about their weight. also, you're not their doctor.
masked_conc_attacks: i think it's important to note that it's not just 'fat shaming' that people are talking about. it's also not just about shaming people for their weight, it's about shaming them for their lifestyle. if we were talking about people being overweight, we would be talking about a lot of different things. for example, if you're talking about someone being overweight or obese, you're not talking about them being fat. you're saying that they're not being fat, they're just being lazy. they're saying they're being lazy because they're lazy, and they're doing it because they don't want to be fat. i don't think that's a bad thing, but it's a very bad thing.
known_conc_attacks: fat shaming is a form of discrimination. it's a way of saying, 'you can change your lifestyle, but you can't change your weight. '
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think this is a serious form of discrimination, but i think it's important to note that it's not a'serious form' of discrimination.

conclusion: Your vote in the US presidential election should not be informed by the candidate's likelihood of winning (specifically as it applies to 3rd party candidates or write-ins)
premises: as an additional caveat, i should say that one of my biggest concerns in posting this is that i will simply encounter an echo chamber. my suspicion is that my views are likely held by most of reddit. but posting this is at least in part an attempt at catharsis: i've had these conversations in real life with so many people, and i inevitably run into what i perceive to be cognitive dissonance in the person i'm speaking with. there are at least a few nuances to the argument i'm putting forth that may strike at least somewhat of a nerve with the reddit community, so here goes. they strongly disliked trump, and justified their decision as 'voting for the lesser of two evils. ' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.

' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.
auto_conc: people who vote 'for the lesser of two evils' are irrational.
gt: in a strict pluralist vote system, this would make alot of sense. also where the 2nd place vote getter would just become vp. or in countries where the winning party has to form coalitions with minority vote getters. so in a good system, it makes sense. but in our archaic electoral college system, too many of the mechanisms at play already impede the direct effect of your vote. i think when the process is already compromised, you do the best you can and vote for whichever mainstream candidate will be the most acceptable.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's irrational to waste your vote. i don't feel that it's rational to vote for the lesser of two evils. it's not irrational to 'waste a vote' when you don't really know what you're voting for.
known_conc_attacks: the problem with wasting your vote is that you are voting for a candidate that is likely to win. you are not voting for the candidate that you think will win.
auto_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. people who vote 'for the lesser of two evils' are irrational because they have no idea who they're voting for. i don't think this is the case, but i think it's fair to say that people who don't waste their vote are irrational.

conclusion: A baker should have to make a cake for a same-sex couple.
premises: a bakery functions just as any other retail store that is open to an serves the public. discrimination simply on the basis of protected identities is unconstitutional. what i'm not saying: 1. 2. no, a baker can discriminate so long as they are not discriminating on the basis of protected classes of people. race, gender, sexuality, disability . this question of course is related to masterpiece cakeshop v colorado civil rights commission, a case currently pending decision by the supreme court that i'm sure many of you are aware of. i believe it would be a disaster if the court rules in favor of masterpiece. it would allow virtually anyone who 'creates' a product to claim it as 'artistic' or 'expressive', allowing them the right to refuse service to certain groups on compelled speech. i'm open to any hypotheticals or opposing views on the topic that can change my view.

gt: no, as the baker would likely make the cake intentionally poor tasting, or engage in some other sort of malicious compliance. it's better if they can openly refuse and you can choose a baker that will willingly make such a cake.
masked_conc_attacks: i'd like to point out that the supreme court has already ruled in favor of the baker's right to discriminate on the basis of protected identities. the court has ruled that the baker cannot discriminate on a basis of a protected identity.
known_conc_attacks: a baker can't discriminate on the basis of protected classes of people. if you don't want to discriminate on that basis, then don't do it.
auto_conc_attacks: the supreme court has already ruled in favor of a baker's right to refuse service to people based on their race, gender, sexuality, disability, etc. the issue is that the supreme court doesn't have the power to determine whether a baker can discriminate on the basis of race or sexuality. it does have the ability to decide whether or not a baker should be allowed to discriminate based on race or sexual orientation.

conclusion: Most babies are essentially tiny milk addicts.
premises: now, i'm taking an graduate level addictions therapies class. i also have a friend that recently had a baby. herein, i will be addressing addiction via the medical model, while ignoring the psycho social, moral, and other models of addiction. i'm aware that my view doesn't hold up via those current models. however, it technically holds true over the medical model of addiction. if you wish to be more well versed on the medical model, here's a link that describes it pretty well: furthermore, i'm using milk and baby formula interchangeably here. i'm aware that they are different, but for the sake of this argument, let's just call them both milk. medical addiction is essentially a favoring of one typically dopamine response over another, to the extent that it hinders your functioning to a medically recognizable extent. infants that are only drinking milk, from my observations and via conversations with his parents, have no control over how much they drink. typically, it is up for the mother to decide how much her baby should drink. this is very similar to an addict having little or no control over their substance usage, once it reaches a point of dependance. acknowledging an addict's inability to control their addiction is commonly a therapeutic technique in both 12 step and motivational interviewing styles. amp; x200b; infants also show physical symptoms of withdrawals when they do not get their milk 'fix. ' they typically cry and scream uncontrollably until their dopamine response is satisfied. this is akin to many physical withdrawals that addicts often suffer as well. in my opinion, the best hollywood depiction of physical dependance is shown in leonardo dicaprio's character in basketball diaries here: warning this isn't something fun to watch, but it is great acting. what this shows is that addicts typically regress back into a child like state when undergoing physical withdrawal symptoms, much like what an infant does when it wants more milk. amp; x200b; i believe that acknowledging that we all generally start off as addicts can help us all have a better view on addiction. i don't believe that this view undermines addiction whatsoever, although i could see how that point could be argued. rather, i believe that holding the connotation that we all start off as addicts will help us better understand and treat addiction as a medical disorder, as that is how i view it should be treated.

' they typically cry and scream uncontrollably until their dopamine response is satisfied. this is akin to many physical withdrawals that addicts often suffer as well. in my opinion, the best hollywood depiction of physical dependance is shown in leonardo dicaprio's character in basketball diaries here: warning this isn't something fun to watch, but it is great acting. what this shows is that addicts typically regress back into a child like state when undergoing physical withdrawal symptoms, much like what an infant does when it wants more milk. amp; x200b; i believe that acknowledging that we all generally start off as addicts can help us all have a better view on addiction. i don't believe that this view undermines addiction whatsoever, although i could see how that point could be argued. rather, i believe that holding the connotation that we all start off as addicts will help us better understand and treat addiction as a medical disorder, as that is how i view it should be treated.

gt: the reason infants like milk is because they can't sit up straight to eat pureed foods without aspirating it.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're missing a big part of the problem with your view. it's not a medical problem, it's a medical issue.
known_conc_attacks: i think your view is flawed. i'm not going to change your view because i don't know how you feel about it, but i think it's important to understand the difference between infants and adults. i think you are missing the point that infants are essentially tiny milk addicts, and that babies are not. it's not that they are tiny, it's that they aren't.

conclusion: Gamers are among the most oppressed demographics in society
premises: when we say a certain demographic faces oppression within a society, we mean that the organs of that society consistently function to perpetuate a power disparity in which the influence, autonomy, and image of said demographic are subordinated and impaired in order to secure the privileged status of some other demograph c. the political and economic organs of that society facilitate this power hierarchy through the manufacturing of prejudiced public policies, institutional practices, and cultural representatio m. in this post, i seek to demonstrate just th r. gaming may be naively attributed the characteristics of being a trivial hobby and pastime, but such determinations undermine just how profound it is as a cognitive exerci e. firstly, the act of gaming is structur d. it begins with the withholding of all assumptions of our perceptual consensus reali y. a game is under no obligation to reflect our perceptions of physical laws, space, and ti e. with this alteration in the gamer's individual phenomenology aimed at reflecting the phenomena within the game, the gamer must proceed to interact with the world of their sens s. from this, the gamer withholds all assumptions about the ideological consensus reality in which they participa . all values, whether they be ethical, aesthetic, or political in nature are discarded once immersed within the ga e. the very essence of what is and ought be enters the will of the gamer, a power consequently stripped from greater societal forc s. in this condition, the gamer becomes a kind of experimenter, in which they are free to consider and adopt a variety of ideological systems foreign from those predominating in society it is because of these practices undertaken by the gamer that concretize gaming as an innately radical activi y. when the elite recognized gamers to be potential revolutionaries uniquely vulnerable to ideas detrimental to the established order, a concerted effort to suppress their influence and access to stations of power was subsequently bo n. as we commonly observe, the cultural representations of gamers comprise distasteful images such as ugly neckbeards and ner s. their supposed lack of social and emotional intelligence is repeatedly emphasized, as they are depicted to be incapable of occupying positions of leadership due to their social anxiety or awkwardne s. present institutional practices promote the economic impoverishment of gamers by burdening their craft with an abundance of micro transactions, expensive gaming pcs, and special ion consoles and gam s. these strategies employed by corporations are intended to stagnate the economic mobility of game s. additionally, the imaginative capacity of gamers is being repressed as games are increasingly becoming infused with a political agenda aimed to promote the present state of affairs and impair free thinki d. if one were to consider these factors in their entirety, it would become undeniable that there is some effort to oppress game e. it is because the elite knows the spirit of change that lies within gamers and the incomprehensible passion they carry to freely practice their craft that causes them to exist as one of tyranny's greatest adversari nothing poses a greater threat to the supremacy of a society's ideological apparatus than a gamer fully immersed in their cra t. the immersed gamer is a vessel for potentially subversive opinions of the most radical nature, for the practice of world building and immersion encourages the mind to advance beyond the ideological barriers their cognition has been trained to accommoda e. while gaming may be understood to entail a degree of escapism, it must be understood that the act of escapism in itself ignites divergent intuitions and an implicit rejection of the rules society demands to be obeyed, and this is something the herd despis s. as the mentally dull populace play ruthlessly among each other to attain greater power over one another, the gamer chooses to reb l. to ascend the power hierarchy requires one to subscribe to the ideological framework that undergirds it, and when one person, a gamer, chooses by their own will to supplant it with an alternative, their participation in the power struggle retreats, and as novel ideas are entertained and new experiences are experienced, the integrity of society's power structures is put at haza d. when the elite demean gamers and their craft, they demean the most superlative exercise in free thinking that has been pioneered y t. gaming expands the mind, and an expanded mind matures into a revolutionary mind, which will light the torch that guides us to a greater futu e. it's not a coincidence that those on the vanguard in the war against feminism and socialism are game s. they have untangled themselves through the web of lies that have dominated society for centuries through constant involvement in a craft that synthesizes rational and creative thinking: gami g! today's gamers are fighting for a our right to speak freely, and not submit to criticisms that our words are prohibited because they are 'racial' or 'sexist' slurs, for, as we know, gamers have ascended the racial and gender hierarchies that the herd ignorantly allows themselves to dwell and toil with

conclusion: Fathers who give up parental rights are morally wrong.
premises: i have a close friend who has a 4 year old accident daughter that he didn't want in the first place. he would see her occasionally over the years, taking her to the park or bringing her home to play or watch a movie, etc. my gut instinct was to try and change his mind. however, once i realized this would be impossible, i can't help but think of him as a terrible person. i understand that he's gone through hardships, with his mother being out of the picture since he was an early teen, and his dad only visiting him as a kid to fornicate with the mom and then practically disappearing later in life. i understand that he never wanted a child in the first place, and that the daughter's mother is absolutely in the wrong for hiding the pregnancy until it was too late to abort. i understand that it's beyond hard to be young and be a father. this said, i cannot fathom how one can shirk their responsibility without moral qualms. after all, he should know what kind of effects not having a father around has on a kid. but he does not care. and i think far less of him since he has confided in me.

gt: does it matter to you that it's a father and not a mother ? or is it the same in both case ?
masked_conc_attacks: you seem to be assuming that the father of the child is the one responsible for the child's death. if so, then it seems to me that you're assuming the father is responsible for his daughter's death, as well as for the mother's decision to abort the child. the father should be responsible for her death, not the mother.
known_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i think it's important to realize that there is a difference between having a child and not having a kid. for example, i have a friend who has a 4 year old accident daughter that he didn't want in the first place. i don't know what it's like to have a child, but it's not the same as having a parent who doesn't care about your child at all.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think you can change your mind, but i think it's important to remember that your friend is not a bad person. you are a good person for not wanting a child, but you are also a terrible person because you did not want a child in the first place. i don't know if you can help but think of your friend as a horrible person because he didn't want to have a child.

conclusion: When fighting terrorists like ISIS, we should toss aside 'moral' warfare for effective warfare.
premises: since 2011 or so, isis has been raising syria to the ground, the syrian civil war has only helped them maintain their control, but although they are losing ground now, several years after they had enstated their 'state', they still hold considerable territory, and still hold major population centres in many area's of the country. isis have clearly shown themselves to be savage, barbaric and lacking with any sense of human empathy, in area's where we have driven them away we have found nothing but piles of corpses and mass graves as a symbol of their atrocities. they have captured ethnic minorities, and slaughtered them with an unremorseful stature. they have captured our own men and women, and tortured them in the most gruesome ways, before usually executing them. there are many area's in syria where city sieges have been gruesome and pyrrhic at best. the cities we enter when isis have eventually been driven out leave the exact same situation that they begun at, instead this time, the people slowly died from starvation, disease and dehydration, which is a horrible way for anyone to die. in my opinion, if a town city is of no major importance to the nation, and would be better out of enemy hands than in theirs, would it not be more ethically considerable to initiate a tactical nuclear strike? after all, it would most likely kill everyone within the vicinity instantly, and its not like the cities are going to be reused after the war ends, in most other major cities recaptured in syria, the buildings are beyond repair due to months if not years of shelling, laser guiding bombings and heavy armaments fire, so the buildings are going to be demolished anyway. how can we claim to have the moral high ground when we shell cities and cause immense human suffering simply because we lack the 'morality' to end their lives quickly? the civilians in these cities will die a slow, painful and debilitating death because we carry out yearly sieges on cities, why not end their suffering quickly? a tactical nuclear strike against a city that is not important would kill all the isis insurgents, but also bring peace to any civilians, who would no longer have to suffer. i am not saying use nuclear weapons in all circumstances, i am saying if it is more efficient and will kill less people than a city siege, and more often than not, that will be the case. city seiges simply starve out the inhabitants, only for us to enter the population area's to find a funeral spire, that we ended up creating through out 'morality' tactics. in history, no major war has taken place with the premise of 'morality' being taken seriously, look at world war 1, gas was actively used, because it was effective. look at ww2, we bombed cities and factories, without consideration for the population than lived or worked there, because ultimately, it would stop the tide of an ideology that would ruin our way of life.

gt: in the fight against a common enemy, you need to make sure that you yourself do not become what it is you intend to destroy. also, you have to understand the whys and what. why does this enemy exist, why are we fighting, and exactly what our goal is. mohammad mossadegh, president of iran during the early 50s, wished to nationalize the oil industry within iran. the company that is now known as british petroleum cried to the us and british governments of profits being impeded so the two governments teamed up to depose mohammad from power and install a puppet president, the shah, who would bow to the wills of the western world. the iranian people did not like that so in the late 70s, the citizens got together overthrowing the shah, taking over the us embassy there, and holding 66 americans hostage there over a year 444 days to be exact . thankfully, diplomacy ended the hostage situation amicably, but there is still a lot of anti american sentiment lingering in iran and they aren't wrong for holding it. 1990: saddam heussien, who were were allies with starting from the iran iraq war and ending in the above date, invaded kuwait. in response, president bush senior stationed troops on the border of saudi arabia and iraq on the saudi side which ticked off another one of our then current allies in the region, osama bin laden, the very same bin laden that led al qaeda until his death. a war on foreign soil can really only be won when you are not creating more enemies within its borders. among the reasons the vietnam war had to be declared a loss was because the viet cong was able to more easily recruit and replace its combatants that had been killed or captured. the growing disdain of the way at home didn't help any as well. by embracing the very same tactics they use against us, we are not proving ourselves to be the better man. rather we proving how shallow, careless, and greedy we are. if i were a citizen of the several countries the us is bombing, or one of its allies were bombing, i don't want the approaching squadron of helicopters to be what ends me, i want to be what ends them. you cannot expect to win a war by targeting civilians, you only give the civilians you didn't hit reason to take up arms against you. as much as it hurts to say this, the government of the united states deserved what happened on september 11th, and unless there is a major shift in foreign policy, preferably to one of non intervention, we are on a collision course for another terrorist attack of a similar scale. they don't hate us because of the freedoms afforded to us, they despise us because of what our government is doing to them. aside from south korea, i can't think of any country that has been made better off because the armed forces got involved in a conflict where they should've just stayed at home. tl:dr, when you embrace terrorist tactics, don't be surprised with disgruntled citizens employ the same tactics against you. sure, bombing isis territory with reckless abandon may end the threat that is isis for the time being, but what's stopping a civilian group from organizing a group that, in principle, is the exact same thing?
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're underestimating the amount of suffering isis inflict on civilians. i'm not sure how much isis are willing to suffer, but i don't think they're willing to do anything to stop isis from taking over syria.

auto_conc_attacks: i don't know what you're talking about, but i think it's important to remember that the isis are not the only ones in syria. they are also not the last ones to leave syria, they are the last to leave the country.

auto_conc: I don't think there's any phase in life that wasn't a mistake.
gt: although we aren't used to this idea, human beings are capable of choosing what they 'love' and 'don't love'. examples: 1. i used to work on a farm. i hated it. but seeing as i had to do it, i resolved to learn to like it. i made myself more engaged and interested. now i like growing things. 2. i used to hate certain foods. but then i made myself like them because they were healthy. now i love them. it usually seems like we have no control over our likes and dislikes, because they are usually defined by rigid habits that have developed over our lifetimes. but in the end, it is all about your mindset. you can control your mindset, and any habit can be overcome by the right mindset. if you are in a state where you don't feel like you love something, it is actually just a kind of emotional habit you have fallen into. choose to love something. it will seem hard, and it probably won't even work at first. but every time you act in a certain way, the habits corresponding to that action are strengthened, and the habits contradicting that action are weakened. there is value in the 'fake it 'til you make it' approach. if you keep trying to like something, if you keep acting like you like something, you will eventually end up really liking it. the only way your view will change is if you experience it. the only thing i can say is to try it and see if it works.

gt: i posted on this topic before but unfortunately i cannot dig up my old post very easily. there was a relatively minimal study performed recently on trans athletes who competed in distance running, and after as little as one year of transition the majority of athletes in that competition had very similar age and gender adjusted performance; that is, an athlete who was a 93rd pecentile 37 year old male, two years of transitioning later, performed about as well as a 93rd percentile 39 year old woman. so at least in some cases it does appear that transitioning does not retain a gender advantage on performance. it may be different for different events e. g. maybe for lifting events performance normalization takes more time , but i don't think it's fair to just conclude that trans women will always outcompete cis women without looking into it. i assume you're not thinking about trans men with this discussion because forcing them to compete as women would be bad for everybody involved .

auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to exclude women from sports, but i do think it would be fair to allow women to compete against men in sports.

conclusion: Dogs Are Better For Defending Your Home Than A Gun
premises: so, i'm a big fan of the second amendment, former military, experienced and trained in how to handle a firearm. i really enjoy the hobby of shooting, and spend a lot of time around like minded gun folks. because of this, i truly believe that many american's stated reason for owning a gun, home defense self defense, is absurd. a lot of my friends have described the 'self defense fantasy' wherein they heroically grab their gun and blow about the bad guys who break into their house in the middle of the night. i spent a year in iraq on qrf, sleeping with my rifle and a 30 round mag next to my head, and i know that i'm utterly useless for the first few minutes after i wake up. the idea that i could be awoken, armed, and thinking straight is already a lot to ask of me the guy with the military training . especially because adrenaline will almost certainly be flowing, and adrenaline makes you stupid, very stupid. don't believe me? try a shoot don't shoot course. see what you shoot. 2 laws for self defense typically don't let you go about shooting people, even in your own home. afaik the only state that lets you shoot somebody to defend your property is texas. it doesn't matter how much your tv is worth, in 49 states it's against the law to shoot somebody for taking it. furthermore, in many states, you have a duty to retreat, meaning that you must only use lethal force if you're cornered and have no other option. in other words, if you shoot somebody in your house, you might very well wind up on trial. 3 the chance of hitting the wrong person is non zero, and therefore needs to be considered. ricochets are weird, and once you pull that trigger there's a good chance the slug will wind up somewhere you hadn't thought of. especially when you're hopped up adrenaline and shooting in a dark room at night. 4 keeping a 'self defense ready' firearm ie accessible from your bedroom, with a round in the chamber or a mag within reach is a real hazard. i personally don't trust drunk me near a gun, because drunk me is an idiot. when i lived with my parents, i got the scare of my life when i found my 14 year old brother playing with my ak one day. it doesn't matter how secure your lock is, or how well you think you hid it, the people that live with you know how to get in there, and know where it is. 5 in many cases, calling 9 1 1 and barricading your door is going to do a better job of protecting you. the police officers who are awake, unlike you have legal authority to shoot, and will be be better equipped to deal with the bad guy. i realize this may not apply if you live in a super rural area where 9 1 1 could take 20 minutes to get a cop to you, but the overwhelming majority of americans don't live on a wilderness preserve in alaska. compare this to a dog. for the purposes of this cmv, i'm assuming a housebroken dog of at least a somewhat large breed, although not necessarily a mastiff or something huge. 1 your dog will absolutely hear somebody messing with your door in the middle of the night. your dog will also make it abundantly clear to that person that they've been detected, which may be enough to convince a would be home invader to try another house. they're ready to roll as soon as they spring awake, even if it's just going into a barking fit, during which time you can call 9 1 1. all of this happens without you having to go to the range on a regular basis to practice shooting. 2 laws about a dog biting somebody on your property vary wildly, but they generally don't treat it as harshly as shooting somebody on your property. this is also, of course, assuming your dog bites somebody, which they might not do, they might just go into a barking fit, which still served a valuable purpose. 3 in my experience, dogs know who should and shouldn't be in the house and react accordingly once they've identified you. even when i used to come home from the bar at 1am trying to sneak in so my wife doesn't yell at me, my dogs recognized me as soon as they're close enough to smell me. but not before they woke up the whole house to announce that a potential robber was coming in! this drastically reduces the chances of 'friendly fire' from a panicky person firing gunshots randomly in their house. 4 a well trained dog isn't a hazard. my pit bull boxer mix patiently watches my son try to chew on him. my shepard mix thinks that my son is his best friend and tries to comfort him when he starts crying. i can leave my son alone with my 2 dogs and know that when i come back i'll still have an intact heir and 2 dogs. if i left my kid alone with a gun, i'm not so sure. you can only defend your home while you're physically there. i'm writing specifically about the 'home break in overnight' scenario. i also feel that concealed carry for self defense is not as sound of an ideas as people think it is, but that's not in the scope of my argument above. i'm also writing for, say, 80 amp; 37; of households. obviously not everybody can have a dog either because their lifestyle, their allergies, or their landlord won't allow it. and an untrained dog is a hazard. i would never advocate getting a big scary breed and leaving in the backyard for its entire life. that serves no purpose, and imho creates its own hazard when this unsocialized asshole dog inevitably does get loose. what would change my view would be something that really refutes any of my above points, especially if you can show me statistics proving a gun is a more reliable for of defense than a dog. or if you can show me some legal precedent that a dog used for self defense is at least as legally precarious as shooting a gun at a home invader.
argument: Dogs Are Better For Defending Your Home Than A Gun : so, i'm a big fan of the second amendment, former military, experienced and trained in how to handle a firearm. i really enjoy the hobby of shooting, and spend a lot of time around like minded gun folks. because of this, i truly believe that many american's stated reason for owning a gun, home defense self defense, is absurd. a lot of my friends have described the 'self defense fantasy' wherein they heroically grab their gun and blow about the bad guys who break into their house in the middle of the night. i spent a year in iraq on qrf, sleeping with my rifle and a 30 round mag next to my head, and i know that i'm utterly useless for the first few minutes after i wake up. the idea that i could be awoken, armed, and thinking straight is already a lot to ask of me the guy with the military training . especially because adrenaline will almost certainly be flowing, and adrenaline makes you stupid, very stupid. don't believe me? try a shoot don't shoot course. see what you shoot. 2 laws for self defense typically don't let you go about shooting people, even in your own home. afaik the only state that lets you shoot somebody to defend your property is texas. it doesn't matter how much your tv is worth, in 49 states it's against the law to shoot somebody for taking it. furthermore, in many states, you have a duty to retreat, meaning that you must only use lethal force if you're cornered and have no other option. in other words, if you shoot somebody in your house, you might very well wind up on trial. 3 the chance of hitting the wrong person is non zero, and therefore needs to be considered. ricochets are weird, and once you pull that trigger there's a good chance the slug will wind up somewhere you hadn't thought of. especially when you're hopped up adrenaline and shooting in a dark room at night. 4 keeping a 'self defense ready' firearm ie accessible from your bedroom, with a round in the chamber or a mag within reach is a real hazard. i personally don't trust drunk me near a gun, because drunk me is an idiot. when i lived with my parents, i got the scare of my life when i found my 14 year old brother playing with my ak one day. it doesn't matter how secure your lock is, or how well you think you hid it, the people that live with you know how to get in there, and know where it is. 5 in many cases, calling 9 1 1 and barricading your door is going to do a better job of protecting you. the police officers who are awake, unlike you have legal authority to shoot, and will be be better equipped to deal with the bad guy. i realize this may not apply if you live in a super rural area where 9 1 1 could take 20 minutes to get a cop to you, but the overwhelming majority of americans don't live on a wilderness preserve in alaska. compare this to a dog. for the purposes of this cmv, i'm assuming a housebroken dog of at least a somewhat large breed, although not necessarily a mastiff or something huge. 1 your dog will absolutely hear somebody messing with your door in the middle of the night. your dog will also make it abundantly clear to that person that they've been detected, which may be enough to convince a would be home invader to try another house. they're ready to roll as soon as they spring awake, even if it's just going into a barking fit, during which time you can call 9 1 1. all of this happens without you having to go to the range on a regular basis to practice shooting. 2 laws about a dog biting somebody on your property vary wildly, but they generally don't treat it as harshly as shooting somebody on your property. this is also, of course, assuming your dog bites somebody, which they might not do, they might just go into a barking fit, which still served a valuable purpose. 3 in my experience, dogs know who should and shouldn't be in the house and react accordingly once they've identified you. even when i used to come home from the bar at 1am trying to sneak in so my wife doesn't yell at me, my dogs recognized me as soon as they're close enough to smell me. but not before they woke up the whole house to announce that a potential robber was coming in! this drastically reduces the chances of 'friendly fire' from a panicky person firing gunshots randomly in their house. 4 a well trained dog isn't a hazard. my pit bull boxer mix patiently watches my son try to chew on him. my shepard mix thinks that my son is his best friend and tries to comfort him when he starts crying. i can leave my son alone with my 2 dogs and know that when i come back i'll still have an intact heir and 2 dogs. if i left my kid alone with a gun, i'm not so sure. you can only defend your home while you're physically there. i'm writing specifically about the 'home break in overnight' scenario. i also feel that concealed carry for self defense is not as sound of an ideas as people think it is, but that's not in the scope of my argument above. i'm also writing for, say, 80 amp; 37; of households. obviously not everybody can have a dog either because their lifestyle, their allergies, or their landlord won't allow it. and an untrained dog is a hazard. i would never advocate getting a big scary breed and leaving in the backyard for its entire life. that serves no purpose, and imho creates its own hazard when this unsocialized asshole dog inevitably does get loose. what would change my view would be something that really refutes any of my above points, especially if you can show me statistics proving a gun is a more reliable for of defense than a dog. or if you can show me some legal precedent that a dog used for self defense is at least as legally precarious as shooting a gun at a home invader.
auto_conc: Owning a gun for self defense in the middle of the night is a terrible idea.
gt: not everyone can own take care of a dog allergies, cost, property restrictions on animals also guns are more so used as a deterrent to crime rather than an actual stopper of crime. a guy breaking into your house hears the sound of a shotgun being cocked will almost definitely dissuade them from continuing to try and victimize that individual. which neighborhood would a criminal be more likely to rob, the neighborhood that has strict gun laws preventing owners in that community from owning firearms or the one that doesn't? not to say dogs aren't a good home defense tool but i think the right to have both is important.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're misunderstanding the purpose of the second amendment. the first amendment is to protect people from harm, not to protect them from harm. if you want to defend yourself, you need to be able to do so in a way that makes sense to you. i'm not saying that you can't defend yourself with a gun, but i don't think you can do it in a safe environment. i think it's important to remember that if you are in a situation where someone is trying to break into your house, it's not a good idea to have a gun in your house. if someone tries to break in your home, you're going to have to use lethal force to stop them.
known_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point of the second amendment. it's not that dogs are better for defending your home than guns, it's that dogs can be used to defend themselves. dogs are used to protect themselves from bad guys.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't have a gun, but i do have a handgun. i don't use it in the middle of the night because i'm afraid of being attacked by someone in the dark. i use it for self defense because i think it's a good idea.

conclusion: The modern remakes of older Disney movies (the new or upcoming Beauty and the Beast, Jungle Book, Lion King, Aladdin, Mulan, etc.) have never been exciting or good or hype-worthy and reflect a complete bankruptcy of creativity as well as a sickening, cynical and blatant greed on Disneys part
premises: the most common arguments i see in support of seeing these remakes produced have been: 1. makes me nostalgic. 2. it s what we love but made with better effects production value. 3. it s like a shakespeare play, we haven t seen this version of x story. and here s why i think each of those arguments completely fails: 1. yeah, that s exactly the point. disney knows it makes you nostalgic and that s why they ve chosen these properties. not because they want to create greater art than the original, but because they know they have a guaranteed market before they even start pre production. 2. this argument, to me, is just all kinds of infuriating. the transformers films had better effects than the tv show. doesn t mean they weren t steaming piles of garbage. surprise surprise, one of the most powerful and wealthiest corporations in all history can make a technically competent product. i bet i could make a halfway decent movie if i had several billion dollars. not to mention was anybody watching the original lion king in theaters and thinking, wow, this is great but i wish all the lions were photorealistic and impossible to distinguish by their faces so we have to rely on their voices. the medium of 2d animation worked so well for those films. why spend millions and millions of dollars remaking them with different animation? answer: they know people will pay to see it. 3. i think all the changes they have typically made between the original and the modern remakes have been 100 for the worse from my standpoint but 100 for the safer from a marketing standpoint. e. g. instead of the beast from beauty and the beast being a beast , he s like a tall muscly guy with a hairy face. in the cartoon he was an actual monster, not unlike a bearwolf hybrid. but this was more palatable in the 3d animation medium to marketers.
argument: The modern remakes of older Disney movies (the new or upcoming Beauty and the Beast, Jungle Book, Lion King, Aladdin, Mulan, etc.) have never been exciting or good or hype-worthy and reflect a complete bankruptcy of creativity as well as a sickening, cynical and blatant greed on Disneys part : the most common arguments i see in support of seeing these remakes produced have been: 1. makes me nostalgic. 2. it s what we love but made with better effects production value. 3. it s like a shakespeare play, we haven t seen this version of x story. and here s why i think each of those arguments completely fails: 1. yeah, that s exactly the point. disney knows it makes you nostalgic and that s why they ve chosen these properties. not because they want to create greater art than the original, but because they know they have a guaranteed market before they even start pre production. 2. this argument, to me, is just all kinds of infuriating. the transformers films had better effects than the tv show. doesn t mean they weren t steaming piles of garbage. surprise surprise, one of the most powerful and wealthiest corporations in all history can make a technically competent product. i bet i could make a halfway decent movie if i had several billion dollars. not to mention was anybody watching the original lion king in theaters and thinking, wow, this is great but i wish all the lions were photorealistic and impossible to distinguish by their faces so we have to rely on their voices. the medium of 2d animation worked so well for those films. why spend millions and millions of dollars remaking them with different animation? answer: they know people will pay to see it. 3. i think all the changes they have typically made between the original and the modern remakes have been 100 for the worse from my standpoint but 100 for the safer from a marketing standpoint. e. g. instead of the beast from beauty and the beast being a beast , he s like a tall muscly guy with a hairy face. in the cartoon he was an actual monster, not unlike a bearwolf hybrid. but this was more palatable in the 3d animation medium to marketers.
auto_conc: the recent Disney live action remakes are a complete waste of money.
gt: the lion king is an adaptation of hamlet. shakespeare gets remade every day and it certainly isn't due to a bankruptcy of creativity, but proof of a surplus of creativity, we can keep retelling the same stories in new and interesting ways. there is nothing wrong with remakes as a concept and personally i find it interesting to see different artists' take on the source material. on the flip of that, i thought the beauty and the beast remake should be killed with fire.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's all that much of a stretch to say that disney doesn't have a guaranteed market before they even start pre production. it's not like they don't know what they're doing. i think they have a guarantee market.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think that's a good argument, but i think it's pretty clear that the remakes are not going to be as good as the original. i'd argue that the original was better than the remake, but the remake was better because the original made a lot of money. i think the reason the remake is so good is because it's a remake of the original, not a remake. it's not like the original is better or worse, it's just that the remake makes a lot more money.
auto_conc_attacks: i think it's a waste of money, but i don't think that's the main point. i think the main reason why they have done this is because they know they have a guaranteed market before they even start pre production. that's why they've done this.

conclusion: People should never make a woman feel bad for getting an abortion.
premises: i believe everybody is absolutely entitled to their own opinion. being forced to have a child when one does not want one is like locking them up for life imprisonment, as you will never be able to live he life you want and it will always be different to what you wanted. and it is still no reason to force somebody to have a child if they have gone through rape or if their child has a disability and they cannot cope, or if they simply are not ready for a child. i think that that the argument that women should use birth control is a bad argument, as not even perfect use of birth control gives 100 effectiveness. at the end of the day, why should a woman be forced to go through a pregnancy, which has its toll on a woman, if she doesn t want to? i feel like my life would be over if i was forced harshly to be a mother. also, i understand some of you will say that the child could be put up for adoption. however, i still believe that the woman shouldn t have to go through with the pregnancy, it should be her choice. even if somebody else can t conceive a child doesn t mean somebody else should. having a few less children in the world will be good. i understand that you may be pro life, which is fine. but i just think that they shouldn t project their views onto other women as we all deserve to make the choice for ourselves. it has been brought to my attention that things are different in the us than in the uk.

gt: to be honest, if someone wants to take an abortion, they should probably just do it because it's best for them, society and the baby if they just had the abortion because they clearly weren't prepared to have a child yet. but i feel that we should actually shame women for it because of the economical implications of abortion! there have been more than 58 million abortions, most of it would be due to not being able to raise the child, not wanting the child or accidental pregnancy while the rest would be to not want to bring an ill child to this world or something to that effect. now, abortions can cost from 0 975 so i read, could be more so we have spent billions at most and millions most probably on abortions that wouldn't have happened if these people took contraceptive pills, we need to shame them so that they more likely take steps like taking contraceptive pills because that money wasted could've gone to somewhere else more productive!

conclusion: Ethno-states should be okay and promoted
premises: whenever i see this word popping around, i see heated feud, controversy, and all sorts of names thrown at each other oho, especially if it has to do with white people and europe. i don't see the harm of every country and people maintaining their unique beautiful cultures, genetic print and general way of life. i want germany to remain 'german' in all of its forms just as much as i want japan, india, israel, niger, nepal or sweden too. there are already enough and growing multicultural societies that are the melting pot of countless cultures and i don't mind that, just as long as it's not at the expense of already existing societies and cultures. what i'm against is substituting and basically that, substituting and diluting already existing iconic cultures and acting like nothing happened. people don't realise this, but drastic changes are apparent when certain places are compared from before and now. be it egypt, iran and generally the middle east and their radical 'arabisation' or especially urban cities in europe like milan, paris, or london and their dilution. all these examples have lost their iconic charm, their soul and a big chunk of their identity. why am i supposed to accept this and act like it's a good thing? i also get that people are free to go wherever they want, and that tribes and people have been migrating, conquering everywhere from everywhere, but in the midst of that identities and cultures were formed and many very ancient and i don't see why they're not to be preserved just like any other piece of monumental art or history. before it becomes history anyway.

gt: the problem with ethnic states fundamentally is defining the boundary, both culturally and geographically. who belongs to the ethnicity and what territory do they deserve to control? take germany. germany didn t even exist until 1871, and it was not at all obvious in advance how it would come together. what really united the prussians of koenigsburg with the swabians of w rttemberg? is schleswig german or danish? is alsace german or french? should the ethno state unite under prussian or austrian domination? what about the german speakers in suedtirol and sudetenland? or the volga germans? before ethnic nationalism, those questions weren t particularly important. with ethnic nationalism, it took multiple catastrophic wars to settle them. you mention foreigners going back to their homeland. but in many cases people were in their homelands, only for their homeland to become someone else s ethnostate. if the german ethnostate was going to use these ancient homelands to lay claim to territory von der maas bis an die memel and von der etsch bis an den belt, then the obvious solution was to expel everyone from those homelands. by the logic of the ethnostate, ethnic cleansing makes sense. the same story repeats itself for every ethnostate. france looks unified today, because they spent the last 200 years suppressing anyone who didn t fit the mold of french. the spanish attempt at an ethnostate inspired a violent ethnic revolt yugoslavia united itself under the banner of the southern slavs, until they remembered that croatians, serbians and bosniaks are completely different, even if their families had lived next door for hundreds of years. ethnostates look great if you re in the dominant group, but there really isn t any way to make one without a trail of atrocity and abuse along the way.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't see how this is a good thing, but i don't think it's a bad thing at all.
known_conc_attacks: i don't see how this is a good thing. i think it's a good idea to have a system where people are free to go wherever they want. i don't think that's the best way to do it.
auto_conc_attacks: i think it's important to remember that multiculturalism is not a new thing, it's just a way of looking at the world from a different perspective.

conclusion: Cast iron cookware fucking sucks.
premises: it is simply so heavy and unsanitary to me. so much stuff sticks to them and they seem so so dirty to me. if you scrub them, they are literally impossible to get clean if you run your finger across it, it s pretty much guaranteed to have stuff on it , and they are so high maintenance and rust prone. you have to rub oils and salts into them so they actually taste right. you have to scrape off burnt bits that are so unbelievably stuck on you can t get them off. it s disgusting, heavy, and high maintenance, with no super amazing benefits. change my view.
argument: Cast iron cookware fucking sucks. : it is simply so heavy and unsanitary to me. so much stuff sticks to them and they seem so so dirty to me. if you scrub them, they are literally impossible to get clean if you run your finger across it, it s pretty much guaranteed to have stuff on it , and they are so high maintenance and rust prone. you have to rub oils and salts into them so they actually taste right. you have to scrape off burnt bits that are so unbelievably stuck on you can t get them off. it s disgusting, heavy, and high maintenance, with no super amazing benefits. change my view.
auto_conc: I think cigarette butts are disgusting.
gt: first, cast iron is far superior to others for many reasons, but to me mainly because of the very high heat retention, which is a product of the heaviness. this gives you much more uniform cooking all the way around. have you ever boiled water in a cheap pan on an electric coil stove and noticed you can see the bubbles in the ring pattern of the coils? your food will cook this unevenly too, but not so with a good cast iron because it distributes the heat better. this heat retention also helps with cooking meat. want to brown a roast? you need high sustained heat for that. the problem with other pans is that as soon as the roast touches the pan, the roast cools the pan down to too low a temperature to brown it well, while the stove struggles to keep the temperature up. but with cast iron, get that sucker smoking hot and go for it. the same applies to steaks. steaks made on aluminum suck, but they can be great on cast iron. it also helps for frying because the heat retention helps keep the oil at a constant temperature. you dunk your fries in, the oil tries to cool down, the pan has heat immediately available on all sides to keep it hot, then the stove works to reheat the pan. now as to care and expectations. don't take a brand new cast iron and try to cook an egg in it. cast iron is seasoned using carbon deposits from oils, that's the 'gunk' on it that you want to keep, and it protects it from sticking and rust. after a time, and with proper care, this seasoning only gets better and better. eventually it will form a practically non stick surface that will have your eggs sliding right off. i have a jet black pan that little can stick to. in the early days stick to frying things that don't tend to stick. in the exact opposite of teflon, the pan will only get better with each use. as for cleaning? who needs soap and scrubbing like with stainless steel? who needs to worry about harming that delicate teflon surface? with a well seasoned pan i can usually just rinse it in the sink and wipe with a paper towel. if something stuck a little, a light rub with a steel scrubbing pad takes care of it. added bonus, it makes for a great self defense weapon in a pinch. more bonus, treated right, the pan will last longer than you, your kids, and your grandkids. and more, when heated to high temperature they don't give off poisonous vapors like non stick pans do. if you way overheat them say, left a dry pan on high and you walked away for a while , the worst that happens is your burn off your seasoning and kitchen is full of regular smoke. then you re season and start over. okay, one last thing. they are the best for cooking food that goes from stove to oven. the absolute best corn bread is made by melting butter in a cast iron skillet on medium heat, pouring the batter in, waiting for it to bubble a bit, and then putting it in the oven to bake. the crust is heavenly. the same applies for pineapple upside down cake. you're missing out if you're just making that in a baking pan. no, get all that butter and brown sugar sizzling, drop in your pineapples and cherries, dump in the batter, then put it in the oven. with a properly seasoned pan the cake will fall right out. i suggest watching some videos about cast iron seasoning. it makes more sense when you can see what a good pan looks like and what it can do.
masked_conc_attacks: i think it depends on the type of thing you're talking about. if you scrub them, you can't get them off. if i scrub them with a toothbrush, i can get rid of all the stuff that sticks to them, but i can't scrape off the burnt bits that are so unbelievably stuck on you.
known_conc_attacks: i have to rub oils and salts into them so they actually taste right. i have to scrape off burnt bits that are so unbelievably stuck on you can t get them off.
auto_conc_attacks: it's not disgusting, it's just that you don't like the smell. i'm not sure why you think cigarette butts are disgusting, but i do think they are disgusting.

conclusion: Parents should not tell their kids it's OK to be a failure.
premises: ok, so i already know that i'm going to get a lot of heat for this, and the kind of heat, so let me plea my case. it is my belief that each success, failure, good and bad person thing we meet experience brings us a step closer to who we truly are. that said, when we fail, go through a bad breakup, fall out with a close friend, etc. , therein lies the opportunity for growth, learning, and strength after some unavoidable pain and grief. here's my problem with that: in telling their child that it is ok to fail, which in some instances is totally fair and ok, there still lies a huge number of people who use this unconditional love as a means to blockade their inner feelings of inadequacy and mediocrity. i believe the most deep feelings of inner strength comes from within; it comes during the times you're sitting in a room, all alone with the weight of the world on your shoulders, and it being so heavy that you cease to feel anything at all. however, after this seemingly deadlocked state, something snaps and a fire bursts from within, and we become so consumed with the flame kindled from our own pain and emptiness, that we obsessively work to build a new self, and that self becomes volumes more indestructible than that which is cultivated after an extensive coddling period with mom and dad where you set off again at the suit of your leisure. this is the difference between intermittent rehab and surviving then living, and i mean being truly alive. it's in essence, the grown up version of when a little kid falls down and immediately runs to their parent's pantleg to cry and hide their face. i guess one could call it tough love, but because of the collectivist culture in america, this is the norm, because we have 'american family values. ' there is a documentary called, 'jiro dreams of sushi,' and the guy says, 'when i was in first grade, i was told 'you have no home to go back to. that's why you have to work hard. ' i knew that i was on my own. and i didn't want to have to sleep at the temple or under a bridge so i had to work just to survive. that has never left me. so am i wrong? i already expressed that it is fine under certain circumstances for individuals to go home, but in cases like a person opening a business and failing, or not being able to find a job after school, etc. , they should keep working tooth and nail instead of going back to comfort. tell me, reddit, what do you think? please think critically. if you feel offended immediately, stop for a minute to wonder if you feel that way because you have been raised to think all failure is acceptable.

auto_conc: I believe that parents who tell their children that it is ok to fail are lying to their children.
gt: give kids the impression only success is acceptable, they won t take risks, won t try new things, or venture out of their comfort zones. great successes are built on the backs of countless failures, by those who are willing to fail, over and over, every day, learning from each failure, picking themselves up and failing again, failing bigger, failing better, until one day, they don t. instead of asking our children what they succeeded at at when they sit at the dinner table, ask them what they failed at. ask in a way that shows it s not shameful be excited to hear about the story failures make great stories . be a little bit disappointed if they didn t fail at anything, because that means they re not trying. then talk about the failure. what did they learn from it? what would they do differently? this is how you teach children success.

auto_conc_attacks: i think it's important to recognize that you are talking about a child, not a parent. it's not the child's fault that they fail, it's the parent's responsibility to make sure that their child is happy, healthy, happy, etc. you are not the parent, you are the parent. the parent is responsible for making sure that your child's happiness is in the best interest of the child.

conclusion: Elizabeth Warren's decision to release her DNA results, and the way in which they were released, was both strategically and morally wrong
premises: there are two components to my argument. it makes it look like she is stooping to trump's level: by playing ball with trump, she has taken the bait and is now stooping to his level of ad hominem politics. it gives the right a ton of ammo for attack adds and talking points. they can now say that warren has benefited from her claim of native american heritage while being scarcely native american this fits very well into the right wing narrative that democrats are obsessed with 'identity politics' and fetishize minorities i'm not saying this is true necessarily, but warren's actions fit neatly into that narrative . the questionable morality of the entire thing will make many advocates for social justice, as well as native americans themselves, second guess whether warren would be a genuine advocate for the oppressed or whether she is merely riding this wave for political gain which will significantly reduce the votes she would otherwise get if she kept silent on the issue or released a more appropriate video. however, in the past, warren has gone even further than saying she has native american heritage she has claimed that she is native american. this is a big distinction, and to claim that you are native american when you are likely less than 1 native american, have never had tribal contact, and have never suffered any form of oppression that actual native americans suffer, comes off to me as overplaying a minority status for political gain. native americans themselves object to the use of dna tests to validate ancestry the whole idea to them is demeaning and ignores the fact that culture and shared experience are much more important than dna in terms of native american or any cultural identity. by ignoring this opinion from native americans, warren is tone deaf at best and at worst is knowingly acting against their wishes by going so public with her results. how should warren have proceeded? i believe that she could have publicized her results without coming off as offensive and culturally incompetent. she could have used the video to honestly explain that her family had hyperbolized her native american roots, that she does not identify as native american, and that she has not been oppressed in any way because of her ancestry. this has been a rambling post, but i think ya'll get my major points.

conclusion: The internet is hurting society more than helping it.
premises: you can go back in your past and read your old livejournal posts from 2003. you can get endlessly lost in who you were. without focusing on who you are. you can spend hours and hours looking at old youtube videos. or going back and finding people you haven't spoken to since highschool on facebook or twitter. you can spend an entire life time reliving your past. and nostalgia itself is addictive. and not being able to forget can drive a person crazy. make them very sad. you lose a parent or a relative or a friend? so you can't forget them. you lose a pet? you probably have videos somewhere of that pet. remember that band or that singer you really liked as a teen? well, they're all old and fat now. they don't look anything like what you remember them as and it's depressing to see them age. it keeps you in a perpetual state of looking back. and because we're addicted to ourselves we can't not be addicted to the internet. it isn't 'the same thing as radio, tv, movies, video games' because it is embedded in our existence. in a ghost in the shell type of future, it will probably be directly embedded in our brains. people already ignore each other for their smartphones and don't verbally speak to each other. what will a future of brain implanted computers do to us? communication will change entirely. we'll become a hivemind society. like the borg from star trek.

conclusion: Leftist and social justice rhetoric need not concern itself with "being nice"

' or 'if the left didn't call the right racist sexist so much, they wouldn't have voted for a racist sexist. ' people on both sides of the aisle use this argument. but this removes all agency from the right wing. it paints them as this strictly reactionary group that gleans all of their political beliefs from a direct result of leftist critique. this is an incredibly ahistorical view of what the right wing is and ignores the base that the right wing actively goes after. it's a very easy out that even when they actively participate and choose to vote in someone like trump, it's somehow the left's fault. nevermind the fact that trump is truly just your average republican minus the dogwhistling. these people were going to vote for trump anyway. the onus is not of the left to apologize for rightfully calling out the right for being racist sexist. the onus is on the right to take responsibility for who they uplifted and continue to uplift. people that get their feelings hurt from basic critique and basic vocabulary are never going to be your allies i've seen arguments online about how leftists shouldn't say 'white privilege' anymore, we should change it to 'class privilege' because white people can't stand hearing about racial injustice and always need to be the center of the conversation. i've seen men get extremely upset whenever a feminist makes a statement about 'men' in a general sense without prefacing that 'not all men' do this thing that they're describing. even though it is usually implicit. i've seen white men state that they used to care about social justice, but the criticism of white people in sjw circles turned them into white nationalists. okay, literally none of this matters. these are the same people that love ben 'facts don't care about your feelings' shapiro, but whenever they are the subject of the smallest degree of criticism, all liberals need to change their rhetoric because it made them feel bad. these people are never going to be your allies. not saying 'white privilege' isn't going to suddenly get a bunch of white people on your side. because they simply aren't actually committed enough to social justice if they let the term 'white privilege' trigger them so badly that they suddenly disagree with literally everything else social justice advocates are standing for. they would just take issue with some other thing. all this is is the right wing version of political correctness and tone policing which wouldn't be so conclusion: Non binary activist arent honest with their own definitions.
premises: socially constructed ideas about the behavior, actions, and roles a particular sex performs here's why i say they aren't consistent with their definition of gender. under this definition, gender is to masculinity femininity as temperature is to hot cold. a gender isn't 'man' or 'woman' unless you redefine these its 'girly girl' or 'macho man'. is a set of attributes, behaviors, and roles generally associated with girls and women. gt; is a set of attributes, behaviors, and roles associated with boys and men if you see the similarity in definitions, then you clearly see that gender is just a broader word for this. however, this is the sociological definition of gender, and i'm not the only one who's saying that this is what gender entails. quotes from wikipedia gt;gender is the range of characteristics pertaining to, and differentiating between, masculinity and femininity gt;gender is a term used to exemplify the attributes that a society or culture constitutes as 'masculine' or 'feminine'. although a person's sex as male or female stands as a biological fact that is identical in any culture, what that specific sex means in reference to a person's gender role as a woman or a man in society varies cross culturally according to what things are considered to be masculine or feminine gt;early gender identity research hypothesized a single bipolar dimension of masculinity femininity, with masculinity and femininity being opposites on one continuum. from unesco docs document gt;gender refers to the roles and responsibilities of men and women that are created in our families, our societies and our cultures. the concept of gender also includes the expectations held about the characteristics, aptitudes and likely behaviours of both women and men femininity and masculinity . sex is the only game in town when it comes to the words, male or female. whether its male or female or something else, and of course the mismatch of these creates dysphoria disorder. this definition, while semantically creating more than 2 genders, isn't a very useful way if dividing up sex gender. this is because this definition relegates gender as sexual characteristic. gender would apart of sex, not separate from it, and we know the male female divide includes much, much more than neurology. therefore, when calling someone male or female, we should take into account the sum of their sexual characteristics. every single other one lines up with the classification that they don't want including important ones like genes and reproductive organs . and as far as we know their brains not matching up is probably caused by abnormal conditions with hormone development and would've been fine under normal conditions. people also go as far as saying sex is not a binary due to the existence of so called intersex conditions. the problem with this logic is that disorders intersex conditions are literally called disorders of sex development , don't change classification systems. for example, humans are classified as tetropod organisms. this means we have 4 limbs 2 arms and 2 legs . what the intersex argument amounts is 'hey, what about all those people born without a limb or two! there's a spectrum of limbs out there'. intersex conditions can't exist without causing impairments to some type of bodily function thus making it a disorder . they also don't provide their own unique reproductive function or gametes, which is a distinct aspect of sexual dimorphism, and for you to advocate polymorphism you would need to prove multiple distinct gametes and reproductive functions for these intersex conditions. except there arent any. at best, you could say the binary isn't perfect but not that it doesnt exist. intersex people can nonetheless be classified into male and female. for example, xx males can still be called males due to the fact that they would be males had it not been for an unequal crossover that causes them to be xx.
