conclusion: "Reverse racism" doesn't exist, it's just called racism. Anyone can be racist.
premises: hi, i am an 18 year old asian american currently living in texas. as a person who has experienced racism many times before, i can attest to the fact that claiming that only white people can be racist is inherently racist in and of itself. i am pretty solid in this belief, because both common sense and logic both back up my claim. i most often hear the argument that 'it is possible to be prejudiced against white people, but not racist. ' this, however, is self contradictory because predjudice for racial reasons is the definition of racism. i don't know what can change my view on this, but i am looking forward to hearing your counter arguments!
argument: "Reverse racism" doesn't exist, it's just called racism. Anyone can be racist. : hi, i am an 18 year old asian american currently living in texas. as a person who has experienced racism many times before, i can attest to the fact that claiming that only white people can be racist is inherently racist in and of itself. i am pretty solid in this belief, because both common sense and logic both back up my claim. i most often hear the argument that 'it is possible to be prejudiced against white people, but not racist. ' this, however, is self contradictory because predjudice for racial reasons is the definition of racism. i don't know what can change my view on this, but i am looking forward to hearing your counter arguments!
auto_conc: I believe that only white people can be racist.
gt: first, let us start with a pretty simple definition of racism: racism: treating a race as inferior to everyone else or believing your race is superior to all other races you can go check the dictionary, but they all basically boil down to this definition ' superiority' now, the whole superiority thing is important. if you think a race is 'different', but you don't think that the difference makes them better worse, then you aren't really racist. it may be a lot of other things, but it isn't automatically racist. example: i think that asians have crustier ear wax than other races this isn't racist reverse racism 'reverse racism' is really not describing traditional racism. when people are being 'reverse racist' against white people, they aren't assuming white people are dumber more violent etc. they are simply directing malice towards them based on their race. 'disliking someone because of their race' is not racism. it is bigotry. however, people don't really like using that word 'bigoted' for some reason. it is the technically correct word, but people won't use it. why do people use the term. people can absolutely be racist against white people. i know some chinese people who are racist as fuck about white people. however, this isn't what anyone is talking about when they discuss 'reverse racism'. 'reverse racism' is a buzzword to describe anti white bigotry and sentiment which exists in minority communities, frequently because of perceived racism from the white people against the minorities. many white people feel that the backlash against white people has become too severe and now this 'reverse racism' bigotry threatens to over correct and cause even more racial animosity than existed when white people were originally being super racist. it is just a word that tries to sum up a lot of political sentiment at once and wrap it in a neat little package. lots of terms like this one homophobe describes anti gay people and attempts to accuse them of secretly fearing gay people fake news a borrowed term, which was originally used to describe actual false journalism, but is now used to insult tainted or biased journalism or the appearance of bias these terms are used to quickly allow people of similar persuasions to connect and recognize one another and share the sentiment without having to share a long winded conversation. they are literally 'memes'. they are almost never as simple as you are trying to make them. if you appreciate the context and historical background of the ideas being expressed by the speakers, you will realize why they are used and why people argue against them.
masked_conc_attacks: you seem to be assuming that 'white people can be racist' is the same thing as 'black people can't be racist'. i'm not sure if this is true or not, but i think it's possible to be prejudiced against a group of people because of their race.
known_conc_attacks: you're confusing 'racism' with 'nazi racism'. i'm not sure what you mean by that, but i'm going to try to change your view. i think you're confusing the two terms. firstly, i think it's important to understand that the term 'racist' is used to refer to people who are prejudiced against certain groups of people based on their race. i don't think that's a good way to define racism, but it's a useful way to look at it. second, i would like to point out that it's not the same thing as 'white people can be racist' or 'black people can't be racist.'it's just a way to use the word to describe someone who is prejudiced towards certain groups based on race. it's also a way of saying that people who have been prejudiced for racial reasons are not racist, because they are not. this is a very different way of defining racism. third,
auto_conc_attacks: you can be racist, but you can't be prejudiced against all white people. you have to be able to be racist against all black people.

conclusion: If workplace sexual harassment is a solvable issue, the market should have gotten rid of it
premises: for the last few years i've worked in small teams of essentially only men and a few women, but the kind women who would fit very well in a group of dudes shooting the shit at bar , so i don't really have a good perspective here, and i think my model could be flawed because of this. the way i think of it right now is as follows. i assume this from personal experience seeing and hearing about many mixed teams where no issues of the sort existed and from an inherent statistical logic most features aren't distributed evenly . men and women are, relatively speaking, equally valuable to their company's or team's success if they occupy a similar role for the sake of my argument, women being usually better than men in the same position is also a valid viewpoint, it actually strengthens it . so essentially, women aren't getting any 'free launches' and they a being evaluated on the same criteria as men, or, possibly using harsher criteria see gender pay gap, which essentially implies this . there isn't something inherently 'wrong' with most men that makes them suddenly become savages, essentially guaranteeing most men will do something very inappropriate to a woman if a long enough span of time passes. in this case, wouldn't even an imperfectly rational world result in: a women move from the companies and teams where they are being harassed, to ones that have a reputation for not perpetuating any sexual harassment b companies and teams that don't contain sexual harassment, have a broader talent pool to chose from then those that do since most people will only work in places where they are not harassed, or at least, will strongly prefer them . as they start dying out for economic reasons, resulting the 'normal' people moving into other 'normal' teams, or, they fire people that perpetuate sexual harassment. obviously, this isn't something that happens over night. so, assuming my premises are correct, why would this happen ? what are the elements that this 'mental model' or mine is ignoring ? again, this is talking on a macro scale, obviously 'edge cases' like the porn industry or the armed forces branch of the military are a bit more complicated. bit i'm thinking about stem, administration and 'standard' service jobs here, since those comprises most jobs in the 'western world'.

conclusion: Therapy should be mandatory in high school
premises: we could solve a lot of problems in this world if people just worked on their baggage. everyone has baggage because no parent is perfect and children with their developing brains, inevitably cannot perceive the world correctly. so many problems in the world like shootings are caused by men being pressured to be 'macho' and being unable to process their anger. they also have broken logic, processing the world in black and white . even if you don't have 'severe' problems, everyone could use with therapy to see their own broken thinking patterns that they developed as a child. every time you see someone using a strawman argument, red herring, or 'whataboutemails', they're using broken logic that inevitably also makes other areas of their life miserable. sweeping generalisations, catastrophic thinking, black and white thinking, these are all patterns that therapy will tell you to work on getting rid of to lead a better life. most of all, everyone should at least try once, the experience of talking with absolutely no filter or judgement. even with your closest friend, your spouse, you have a filter on because you don't want to be judged or hurt others feelings or keep a secret. in a strong community, the role of therapist is fulfilled by a good priest or or counselor or coach or wise person. update most of the comments rebutting this are about logistical and practical implementations: there aren't enough good therapists to ensure everyone has a good experience, ie. they will force drugs , have imperfect diganosis, be bad person to talk to. i would even venture that most people commenting had a terrible experience with therapy. no money to pay for it i agree with all this, and so i guess this thread has made me clarify my stance. i think what i was imagining was a perfect system where everyone would get to process their baggage aside from memorizing pointless history facts but the reality was that 80 of everything is garbage and people would get bad therapists and unnecessary drug prescriptions. our society just isnt' there yet. getting help is currently a personal responsibility and unfortunately the people who need it the most will not go get help or are unable to get it financially, or belief wise they have too much anger to seek help

gt: i'm a big supporter of therapy and mental health awareness. this is an unnecessary change. i recently stopped seeing my therapist, not because i'm cured of my depression, but because my depression has stopped controlling all aspects of my life. i stopped having things to talk about in therapy, because i'm fortunately in a very healthy place right now. forcing me to go to therapy right now would not change much about my life other than the time it takes out my week and the money it costs. if you don't need therapy, then forcing someone into therapy isn't helpful. it would be a massive waste of time and money. therapy is important, but not necessary for everybody.

conclusion: Climate change should be the the focus in upcoming elections.

conclusion: art critics are full of shit
premises: don t get me wrong, i love art. i m an artist myself. yes, obviously art can have deeper meanings, however for most art which is someone trying to copy something they see or abstract , they are reading into something that isn t there. the prime example being abstract art. you can t look at a jackson pollock splatter painting and tell how the artist was feeling, he just threw paint at the paper. and better yet, every expert will have a different opinion on his emotion, but claim theirs is factually correct. likewise, you can t pull deeper meaning from a portrait because it s just a portrait of a person.
argument: art critics are full of shit : don t get me wrong, i love art. i m an artist myself. yes, obviously art can have deeper meanings, however for most art which is someone trying to copy something they see or abstract , they are reading into something that isn t there. the prime example being abstract art. you can t look at a jackson pollock splatter painting and tell how the artist was feeling, he just threw paint at the paper. and better yet, every expert will have a different opinion on his emotion, but claim theirs is factually correct. likewise, you can t pull deeper meaning from a portrait because it s just a portrait of a person.
auto_conc: I believe art can not have meaning because it is just a painting.
gt: i agree with your premise that a critic is unable to tell you what the artist meant or felt while creating a piece, unless they were there while it was produced and were told by the creator how they felt why it was produced. so i will focus on the other half of your argument about evoking emotions. firstly, it s important to note that how a piece speaks to you is unique to you alone and does not make a blanket statement about how it evokes emotion in all viewers, because everyone will view a piece subjectively from their own point of view. art evokes emotions, even if they are simple. if you look at a piece and think i like that and nothing more, the piece has still had an effect on your perception. you don t hate it, you don t feel nothing; you like it. this feeling is unique to you and in no way more or less important than the way it affects anyone else. but it did evoke an emotion. same if you were to see a 2 year old s scribble and think that s not very good . my point is, while i agree that art critics have no right to tell other people how they should feel about a piece of art, they are entitled to voice how the piece has spoken to and affects them, regardless of how deep or shallow or pretentious they sound.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're talking about here, but i think you're missing the point of art. art can have deeper meanings, but it doesn't have to be'meaningful' to me. for example, if you look at a painting of a man, you can't really tell how the artist was feeling, because he just threw paint at the paper. that's not to say that a painting can't have deeper meaning because it's just a portrait of a person.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think art critics are full of shit, but i think you're missing the point of art criticism. i think art criticism is a way to try to make a point, but it's also a way of trying to make sense of things. i'm not saying that art critics aren't full of crap, i'm saying that they're full of bullshit. however, i think they're trying to get their point across, and i think that's a pretty good way to do it. if you don't like art critics, you're probably not going to be able to convince them of their point of view.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't know if you've ever heard of the word'meaning' in the context of art, but i'm going to take a stab at it. it's not just a painting, it's a painting of a person. it can be interpreted as meaning, but it doesn't have to be meaning. it just has to have meaning. you can't just look at a painting and say, 'this is just a portrait of a man.'it can't have meaning because it is not a painting.

conclusion: Most cyclists on the road are incredibly inconsiderate and rude, and we should enforce them not getting in the way far more than we do.
premises: maybe it's just where i live. but every morning evening when i drive to from work, there are packs of cyclists riding around. i think cycling is great. however my issue is often the attitude of these cyclists. they are less visible. it will be dark and many of them do not wear anything to stick out properly. they often travel in packs. packs that, instead of riding single file along the side of the road, clump together blocking huge portions of the road. i see no reason why this is necessary. the result is they cause traffic jams and instill fear in drivers like me.
argument: Most cyclists on the road are incredibly inconsiderate and rude, and we should enforce them not getting in the way far more than we do. : maybe it's just where i live. but every morning evening when i drive to from work, there are packs of cyclists riding around. i think cycling is great. however my issue is often the attitude of these cyclists. they are less visible. it will be dark and many of them do not wear anything to stick out properly. they often travel in packs. packs that, instead of riding single file along the side of the road, clump together blocking huge portions of the road. i see no reason why this is necessary. the result is they cause traffic jams and instill fear in drivers like me.
auto_conc: I believe that cyclists cause more problems than they solve.
gt: cyclists are encouraged to cycle in the middle of the lane rather than against the curb for two main reasons. a the edge of the road contains most debris and drains which can be lethal hazards to cyclistsb you ve already alluded to trying to squeeze past cyclists within your own lane . this is dangerous and irresponsible and is the very reason cyclists block you from doing it. on your point about packs, they re far easier to overtake assuming they are in one lane than a long string of cyclists, simply by waiting for a space on the other side of the road. the only way to overtake a long string of cyclists is by dangerously squeezing past them as per b . treat it as a tractor. it s slow, it s an annoyance, but is has as much right to be there as you. only overtake when it is actually safe to do so. if you know that cyclists are prevalent on your route then leave an extra 2 mins early to account for the minimal delay you experience.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're missing the point. there's a lot of people who ride in packs all the time. i'm not sure if you're familiar with it, but i think it's important to note that it's not just the people riding in packs, it's also the people who are riding in groups. i don't know if you've ever seen a pack of cyclists, but it's definitely a lot more prevalent than it used to be.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's a good idea to have a limit on the number of cyclists you can see.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think there is a reason why cyclists cause more problems than they solve.

conclusion: Artificial intelligence can't become conscious.
premises: i believe that it is not possible for a mere computer program, running on a turing equivalent machine, to ever develop consciousness. alternatively, perhaps our brains are capable of hyper computation but this is not a serious field of research because all known models of hyper computers can't exist in our universe except possibly at the edges of black holes where space time does weird things, but i think it's safe to say that humans aren't walking around with black holes in their heads . i shall consider these possibilities outside of the scope of this cmv, since ai research isn't headed in those directions. my reason for believing this was inspired by a bunch of rocks the way we design computers today is totally arbitrary and nothing like how a human brain operates. our brains are made up of a large network of neurons connected via axons and dendrites which send signals chemically through a variety of different neurotransmitters. modern computers, by contrast, are made up of a large network of transistors connected via tiny wires which send binary electrical signals. if it was possible to write a program which, if run on a computer, develops a consciousness, then this difference would imply that consciousness likely doesn't depend on the medium upon which the computations are performed. computers of the past used to be based on vacuum tubes or relays instead of transistors. it's also possible to design a computer based on fludic logic in which signals are sent as pressure waves through a fluid instead of an electrical pulse. there are even designs for a purely mechanical computer engine . the important point is that you can build a turing equivalent computer using any of these methods. the same ai software could be run on any of them, albeit probably much more slowly. if it can develop a consciousness on any one of them, it ought to be able to develop a consciousness on all of them. but why stop there? ultimately, a computer is little more than a memory store and a processor. programs are stored in memory and their instructions are fed one by one into the processor. the instructions themselves are incredibly simple load and store numbers in memory, add or subtract these numbers, jump to a different instruction based on the result that's actually about all you need. all other instructions implemented by modern processors could be written in terms of these. computer memory doesn't have to be implemented via electrical transistors. you can use dots on a sheet of paper or a bunch of rocks sitting in a vast desert. likewise, the execution of program instructions doesn't have to be automated a mathematician could calculate by hand each instruction individually and write out the result on a piece of paper. it shouldn't make a difference as far as the software is concerned. what if our mathematician, hand computing the code to our ai, wrote out all of his work a complete trace of the program's execution? let's say he never erased anything. for each instruction in the program, he'd simply write out the instruction, its result, the address of the next instruction, and the addresses values of all updates to memory or, alternatively, a copy of all memory allocated by the program that includes these updates . after running the program to completion, what if our mathematician did it all again a second time? the same program, the same initial memory values. would a consciousness be created a second time, albeit having exactly the same experiences? a negative answer to this question would be very bizarre. how could the universe possibly remember that this particular program was already run once before and thereby force all subsequent executions to not develop consciousness? what if a layman came by and copied down the mathematician's written work, but without understanding it. why should it matter whether he understands what he's writing? arguably even the mathematician didn't understand the whole program, only each instruction in isolation. would this mean there exists a sequence of symbols which, when written down, would automatically develop consciousness? what if our mathematician did not actually write out the steps of this second execution. what if he just read off all of his work from the first run and verified mentally that each instruction was processed correctly. would this mean there exists a sequence of symbols which, if even just read , would automatically develop consciousness? why should the universe care whether or not someone is actively reading these symbols? why should the number of times the program develops consciousness depend on the number of people who simply read it? to change my view, you could explain to me how a program running on a modern future turing equivalent computer could develop consciousness, but would not if run on a computationally equivalent but mechanically simpler machine. alternatively, you could make the argument that my absurd consequences don't actually follow from my premises that there's a fundamental difference between what our mathematician does and what happens in an electronic fluidic mechanical computer. you could also argue that the human brain might actually be a hypercomputer and that hyper computation is a realistic direction for ai research, thereby invalidating my argument which depends on turing equivalence. what won't change my view, however, are arguments along the lines of 'since humans are conscious, therefore it must be possible to create a consciousness by simulating a human brain'. such a thing would mean that my absurd conclusions have to be true, and it seems disingenuous to hold an absurd view simply because it's the least absurd of all others that i currently know of.

auto_conc: I believe that it is impossible for a mere computer program, running on a turing equivalent machine, to ever develop consciousness.
gt: u cybyss op has awarded 3 deltas in this post. all comments that earned deltas from op or other users are listed here r deltalog comments 8hwrl8 , in r deltalog. please note that a change of view doesn't necessarily mean a reversal or that the conversation has ended. delta system explained deltaboards
masked_conc_attacks: what do you mean by ai? you're saying that it's not possible for a mere computer program, running on a turing equivalent machine, to ever develop consciousness?
known_conc_attacks: what about a computer that runs on a turing equivalent machine? what about a machine that can't run on a computer?
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's possible for a mere computer program, running on a turing equivalent machine, to ever develop consciousness. it's just a matter of time. there's no way to know whether a computer program can develop consciousness on any one of them.

conclusion: I'm on course to vote no to the upcoming abortion referendum.
premises: while i've been pro choice most of my life that's begun to change. what brought this on was the online discussion surrounding people with down syndrome and the news that most mothers who are made aware of their unborn having ds opting to abort. while i find this very sad ultimately it's very difficult to raise a child with ds and i can't force that responsibility on a family. what i can't justify to myself however is how this screening technology will be developed to apply to gay people in the future. there are physiological differences between straight and gay people and this is a subject of research. in the event a test is developed that detects gayness in foetuses with reasonable accuracy i realise this will lead to gay babies being aborted and that's what i find objectionable. it may sound silly but medical technology is always improving by leaps and bounds and when the technology of tomorrow meets the laws of today i fear it will lead to a portion of the gay community disappearing and i don't want that. i suppose the core view i want changed if a woman's choice to abort is always moral even if the reason is homophobia or some bigotry like that. i think if you're aborting a foetus because of a benign trait it will manifest in the future you are no longer treating it as a foetus but as a person it will become and it's my belief gay rights override the right to choice in this circumstance. in other words i have a gut feeling that voting to repeal will mean condemning future gay men and women to pre emptive deaths. i'd like to be convinced i'm wrong. thanks for taking the time to read and i'll be here a few hours.
argument: I'm on course to vote no to the upcoming abortion referendum. : while i've been pro choice most of my life that's begun to change. what brought this on was the online discussion surrounding people with down syndrome and the news that most mothers who are made aware of their unborn having ds opting to abort. while i find this very sad ultimately it's very difficult to raise a child with ds and i can't force that responsibility on a family. what i can't justify to myself however is how this screening technology will be developed to apply to gay people in the future. there are physiological differences between straight and gay people and this is a subject of research. in the event a test is developed that detects gayness in foetuses with reasonable accuracy i realise this will lead to gay babies being aborted and that's what i find objectionable. it may sound silly but medical technology is always improving by leaps and bounds and when the technology of tomorrow meets the laws of today i fear it will lead to a portion of the gay community disappearing and i don't want that. i suppose the core view i want changed if a woman's choice to abort is always moral even if the reason is homophobia or some bigotry like that. i think if you're aborting a foetus because of a benign trait it will manifest in the future you are no longer treating it as a foetus but as a person it will become and it's my belief gay rights override the right to choice in this circumstance. in other words i have a gut feeling that voting to repeal will mean condemning future gay men and women to pre emptive deaths. i'd like to be convinced i'm wrong. thanks for taking the time to read and i'll be here a few hours.
auto_conc: i'm pro choice but i don't think it's moral to abort a foetus because of a genetic abnormality
gt: you want to force women to bear unwanted children now , force the responsibility of raising children with down syndrome now , risk their health and financial stability now because of something that might happen at some point in the future? i privilege not causing real and present pain and not forcing real and present burdens over hypothetical bigotry. if by the time we can reliably determine that a fetus will be gay, gay rights are such that those babies are being aborted, we can talk then about preventative measures banning those tests, for example.
masked_conc_attacks: i think it's important to remember that this is not a hypothetical situation. it's a hypothetical scenario where a woman is forced to abort her child because she is gay. that's not the case, it's the case that a woman's choice to abort the child doesn't matter at all. you can't force a woman to abort a child because of a benign trait it will manifest in the future. if you force a man to abort, you can force him to abort. if a man decides to abort his child because he is gay, he can force that man to kill his child.
known_conc_attacks: i think it's important to note that you are not saying that gay rights override the right to choice in this circumstance. you are saying that the issue is that gay people are more likely to be aborted than straight people.
auto_conc_attacks: i'm a pro choice person, but i don't think it's moral to abort a foetus because of a genetic abnormality.

conclusion: When someone gets upset about the suffering of dogs but are indifferent to the suffering of animals in factory farms, they are being logically inconsistent.
premises: i love my dogs, whenever i see my little pups in pain it hurts me. here on reddit there are many instances of people justly showing disgust an instance of abuse towards a pet animal while then hating on vegans who say that they should show similar concern for pigs, cows, etc. it is to not have the suffering going on be salient in your mind. imagine a factory farm with golden retrievers instead of pigs. you probably would be rightly upset. why should we not hold the same or even a similar standard towards pigs, cows, etc.
argument: When someone gets upset about the suffering of dogs but are indifferent to the suffering of animals in factory farms, they are being logically inconsistent. : i love my dogs, whenever i see my little pups in pain it hurts me. here on reddit there are many instances of people justly showing disgust an instance of abuse towards a pet animal while then hating on vegans who say that they should show similar concern for pigs, cows, etc. it is to not have the suffering going on be salient in your mind. imagine a factory farm with golden retrievers instead of pigs. you probably would be rightly upset. why should we not hold the same or even a similar standard towards pigs, cows, etc.
auto_conc: I think it's hypocritical for vegans to be upset about dogs that eat their meat.
gt: yes, it is horrific, but there is a fundamental difference between our relationship with livestock and with dogs. we bred and domesticated dogs to be our friends and companions. we bred and domesticated livestock to be killed for food. the fact that people react differently and i'm not certain the extent to which they actually do reflects that the relationship between humans and the two groups are vastly different.
masked_conc_attacks: i agree with you, but i don't see any reason why it shouldn't be the case.
known_conc_attacks: i don't know about you, but i think it's important to note that i don't think you're being inconsistent. i think your argument is based on the assumption that people are being inconsistent in their beliefs about the suffering of animals. for example, if someone is upset about a dog being in pain, they are being consistent in their belief that the dog is in pain. if they are not, then they are inconsistent in the belief that dogs are in pain because they were raised in a factory farm. in other words, if you are upset about dogs, then you are not consistent in your belief that pigs, cows, etc. are suffering because they are raised in factory farms, or because you are indifferent to pigs?
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's hypocritical to be upset about dogs that eat their meat.

conclusion: People should stop assuming that someone in a political party believes EVERYTHING that party believes in.
premises: i m a republican. but i believe that anyone can be married to anyone. as long as it doesn t hinder my rights you can marry whoever you want. you can spend the rest of your life with the any person you desire. i can t believe it was not legal in the first place. things like that make me question the party continuously. my major beliefs belong to the republican party. therefore, i call myself republican. i get slandered all the time by republicans calling me traitor or flat out ignoring me. i get assigned to the long belief list on the republican website. i actually hate many things republicans in power do. i don t like trump. i ve seen enough. this doesn t just apply to republicans though. it applies to all parties. i only know about the republican side because of my experience.

gt: whether you agree with everything a party stands for is irrelevant because, so long as you vote for them, you're giving them the power to carry out their all of their policies not just the ones you agree with personally. after all, america is a representative democracy and not a direct democracy. furthermore, if you disagree with a party on an issue but vote for them in spite of that, it shows that you do not prioritise said issue. people are criticising you for that as much as for the issues which you actually do support. for example, the gop has opposed same sex marriage; all republican voters thus either do not support same sex marriage themselves or, at the very least, are largely apathetic to the issue. both can, and in my opinion should, be criticised. also, op, if you disagree with the gop on trump then look elsewhere. tea party trumpism is the direction the party has been heading in for years now. mark yourself as an independent and vote on a candidate basis instead of partisan one.

conclusion: Your vote in the US presidential election should not be informed by the candidate's likelihood of winning (specifically as it applies to 3rd party candidates or write-ins)
premises: as an additional caveat, i should say that one of my biggest concerns in posting this is that i will simply encounter an echo chamber. my suspicion is that my views are likely held by most of reddit. but posting this is at least in part an attempt at catharsis: i've had these conversations in real life with so many people, and i inevitably run into what i perceive to be cognitive dissonance in the person i'm speaking with. there are at least a few nuances to the argument i'm putting forth that may strike at least somewhat of a nerve with the reddit community, so here goes. they strongly disliked trump, and justified their decision as 'voting for the lesser of two evils. ' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.

auto_conc: people who vote 'for the lesser of two evils' are irrational.
gt: here's the deal. you are right that an individual vote doesn't pick the president. but the election does pick the president. i'm gunna use people who ran in 2016, because i've been drinking, and it'll make it easier for me to keep straight, but assume this point is broadly applicable to elections generally. now, in 2016, you had clinton, trump, johnson and stein. and everyone who isn't retarded knew it was either going to be clinton or trump as president. now, you're correct, if you voted stein or johnson, you didn't change who the president is today. but the way an election works, people who voted third party, as in all of them, arguably did change the results. its been talked about endlessly that more people voted for stein then clinton lost whisconson by. as in, if they'd voted for clinton instead of stein, clinton would have, at least, won that state. so here's the major point. you have to act like your vote is the deciding vote, while keeping in mind only one of two people have a shot of becoming president. let's say every voter had a prefered candidate who polled at one percent a day before the election. each voter thought of this person as the best president we'd ever have. but because that voter knows that person is only polling at one percent, that voter knows for a fact that this person won't become the president. further, this voter understands that the differences between the two people who have a shot are vast. if you put a gun to the average stein voters head the day before the election, and said, unless the next word out of your mouth is either clinton or trump, i'm blowing your brains out all over your fucking tofu, now who do you want to be president, most stein voters would have admitted the answer was clinton, and then they went ahead and voted for stein. so what they were doing was deciding they were above it all. they'd vote for stein, and count on the rest of the suckers to vote for hillary, and then hillary would be president and they could complain about her for four or eight years.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's irrational to waste your vote. it's not irrational to vote for a candidate that you don't like. it isn't irrational to not vote for someone you dislike.
known_conc_attacks: if you are voting for a candidate who is likely to win, you are not wasting your vote. you are wasting a vote. if you don't vote for the candidate you dislike, you have lost the opportunity to identify with the winning team.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think it's irrational to vote for the lesser of two evils, but it's not irrational to not vote for a candidate that you don't like. it's just not irrational.

' when he took away his powers with kryptonite. in practice whatever adjective or quality is put before the noun whether good or bad is reduced when put in front of 'woman' compared to 'man'; it is not just in terms of praise: 'he was the most evil man in history' also sounds a lot worse than 'she was the most evil woman in history' which again implies that a lot of males were more evil.

' when he took away his powers with kryptonite. in practice whatever adjective or quality is put before the noun whether good or bad is reduced when put in front of 'woman' compared to 'man'; it is not just in terms of praise: 'he was the most evil man in history' also sounds a lot worse than 'she was the most evil woman in history' which again implies that a lot of males were more evil.

auto_conc: I believe that the US should be split into 4 separate countries,
gt: i posted the following on a very similar to this about a year ago. they proposed 4 countries as opposed to your 5, but otherwise everything i'm about to say is materially the same: there are many many complexities to this, but i want to go into the weeds with just one: debt. the us government owes a lot of money to a lot of people. those debts are guaranteed by the constitution 14th amendment and are owed in us dollars. if the us splits up, somebody needs to handle all of the debt somehow. there would need to be a 'successor state' to the united states who would inherit the obligations of the erstwhile usa. for an historical example, russia was the successor state of the ussr, and inherited the soviet debt, which it finished paying off in 2006. if the us split into 4 equal ish size countries, the successor state would be left with a debt:gdp ratio of about 3. 5:1, which is way higher than any other developed country has right now and would be totally unsustainable. as such, the non successor states would need to either undertake debt payments to the successor state for decades into the future, or else would need to make enormous lump sum payments at the time of the disunion. the former transfer payment system would be a major detriment to the sovereignty of the new nations. in particular, it would mean decades of payments in a currency they no longer control to a foreign state. ask greece how fun that is. the latter would be an enormous and likely impossible burden, as they would need to all market trillions of dollars of bonds in new currencies at the same time which would be damn near impossible. i'd also add that by dividing up the fiscal power of the united states, you can end up with parts which are less than the whole. the us treasury is the single largest unified economic entity on earth right now. merely due to its massive size, it is inherently a very safe place to park your money as it has the command of more resources than anywhere else. four or 5 smaller states would not have the enormous size advantage that comes from being the usa. their currencies would fluctuate a lot more. a california anchored nation would for instance feel a much bigger burden from a second tech crash than would the current usa. that risk would mean people would demand higher yields from investments, and therefore higher interest rates on debt. markets also might not trust the smaller nation governments as much to be fiscally sound in a crisis, and you could see big debt crises like canada saw in the 1990s. this is obviously only a small slice of the complexities of actually doing something like this, but i think it's a good example of just how hard it is to actually do something like this.
masked_conc_attacks: what if california was split into two states? would it be better to split the north and the midwest into two separate states?
known_conc_attacks: the problem with this is that it's a lot more complicated than what you're describing. it's not like the us is a single country, it's just a bunch of different countries with different political philosophies. for example, in the united states, there is a state called texas. texas is part of texas, and texas has part of california. the midwest has some of the most diverse political philosophies in the world, but they are not part of the us.

conclusion: Crimes involving breach of trust should have more severe legal repercussions than the similar ones without.
premises: to elucidate my view, i'll try to frame an illustration. consider two acts of theft being performed which constitute as a crime under legal purview. case a: a man is walking down a lonely street late at night. suddenly, a mugger appears out of nowhere and robs him at gunpoint. case b: a man is walking down a busy street. a stranger walks to him seeking for help, describing a life and death situation. on humanitarian grounds, the man follows the stranger who leads him to not so happening street only to realize that it's all a setup. he is then robbed after being held at gun point. now, it is reasonable to state that the ultimate outcome in both of the cases was the man ended up being robbed. however when considered on a profound level, the varying experiences have resulted in different psychological impacts on that person. in case a, it is streetwise to avoid a deserted road to prevent from being taken advantage of. hence, the man would have estimated the probability of getting mugged and made a conscious decision. this would then conform to his existing prejudice about travelling isolated roads at night, which he would definitely avoid in the near future. however an experience from case b would have definitely scarred him by affecting his school of thought towards humanity. it would drive him to a conclusion that it is better off to avoid helping a human or anybody for that matter to avoid the risk of a false case. the next time he sees someone asking for help, even though his conscience would provoke him to provide assistance, his previous experience would say otherwise, thus deterring him from bestowing a respectable act of humanity. on an individual level it would not make a big difference, but consider the impact it would have if hundreds of individuals were robbed in a similar manner. it would then go on to be a preconceived notion that helping somebody en route to an isolated location would have disastrous implications. now imagine the plight of a person asking for help if his case was genuine. statistics suggest that majority of rape victims knew their perpetrators at least at a hierarchical level of an acquaintance. if this keeps on increasing individuals would be wary of accomplices, thus developing trust issues. events like this would make humans lean on individualism and would make them think twice before trusting other humans. and this, as far as the functioning of society is considered, would be the worst thing to happen to it. the basic intention of law is to ensure that humans act in a civilized manner in a society. however what use would the law be if society ceased to exist.

conclusion: Paid DLC has ruined the video game industry.
premises: gone are the days where you could buy a game and know that game developers and publishers have put their heart and soul into a finished product. i know i'm being a bit naive if i said that companies like ea, nintendo and bethesda once had a passion to bring joy to their customers, those businesses in the end are still just like any other business: they're ultimate goal is to make money and nothing more. but around the late 2000s when companies started to realize that they can make lots of money just by adding extra skins and patches everything went down the toilet. money is now the driving force of how and why we consume video games. it's the reason why we have seen countless versions of call of duty or assassin's creed. this is also why the indie scene has also exploded as well, the only ones who have a passion for making fun games have realized they they can not develop their goals under the yoke of titans like microsoft or sony. time and time again we see companies take our money and leave after only a few months, we continue to be let down by game developers who make false claims. e3 drives us crazy and literally leaves some of us drooling wanting more, and yet again we are always disappointed by with product that we paid 60 100 dollars for. remember no mans sky, watch dogs 1, star wars battlefront 1? they are by no means old games if we go by their release date, but now that the industry pumps out new games every month with the incentive of only taking our money these games now seem to be dinosaurs.

i m sure you can see my point here. 2. both men and women are capable of being condescending, but a man doing it to a woman needs a specific term for it? i think if you break it down the sexism lies in the assumption that a man who is condescending is just an asshole if it s towards a man and sexist if it is towards a woman. 3. why not just use he is condescending or she is condescending because both sexes are capable of being condescending. i feel like if you make a special word for one of them you are being obvious sexist. my whole point is if we say he yelled at her we should also be saying she yelled at her. just like we should be saying she was condescending and he was condescending instead of she was condescending to her vs he was mansplaining to her 4. you don t know if the man you are speaking to is being condescending simply because he is an asshole. this is in effect creating a double standard where the belief is women can freely explain things to men but men cannot freely explain to women under risk of appearing to be a sexist. i don t care for the societal institutional argument where the claim is that sexism hurt women in the workplace and society because men had more power in those roles. i did not do that. i took no part in that and don t know anyone that has. i m sorry if someone you know was hurt by that happening but i had nothing to do with it and if you can associate me with that kind of sexism because of my gender, then you are the sexist one. i am very open to other perspectives and would love to hear what you have to say :

gt: having read a few comments it seems like mansplaining isn't actually to do with being condescending towards women in general but more the fact that men will explain women's issues to women. could someone correct me if i'm wrong? a few examples would really help as they always help get a point across for me. also, if it is to do with being condescending in general, is it solely defined as a man talking down to a woman or can it include a man talking down to a man? i'm also a man if that helps anyone's replies. thanks :

conclusion: People who denounce the poor for owning "Luxuries", Just want the poor to know their place.
premises: anything that might stand out on a person as being a bit expensive. many people, unfortunately on the conservative and neo conservative and libertarian sides, claim that these people own these things because they are poor spenders and it is a good example of why the poor stay poor in this country. i believe it is just the individual using whatever little resources they can to blend into society. to fool it into thinking that they are of nominal wealth, so they aren't bothered about it. so they can interact and find opportunity like any other normal looking member of society with a smartphone and decent clothing. even worse, the political pundits, who make these claims are often of above average wealth and upbringing, often with two parents supporting them in a stable home. ben shapiro and the roving millenial come to mind. both born into affluent families. that makes me take on this view that the outrage about this is disingenious. i rarely see someone who came out of poverty taking on this view, if ever. the roving millenial, who has a crtv show now, has even gone as far to say that you do not need a refrigerator to survive, that is it a luxury. what is next? your shoes don't have to be made of that expensive rubber, wear wood shoes? they're affordable nowadays, but the accusers of these people always claim they have the 'new' iphone, or that they scramble to buy the newest products. they don't. change my view on this, do you they geniunely care about their spending habits and the long term effects on the country, or do you they pick on them because you feel like they appear stupid complaining about being poor while possessing these items? are the poor in a bad financial situation they're making the best of, or do you believe they have a 'place' to inhabit and should abandon all luxuries until they are out of that situation? amp; x200b; amp; x200b; amp; x200b;

conclusion: Certain private companies like the social media/tech giants should be bound by similar free speech laws as the government.
premises: let me start off by saying i do not think we should tolerate intolerance, but at the same time i am against censorship. these laws exist for very valid reasons, and in some places have a few, also valid, exceptions, such as calling for violence against a person or group. this means that a restaurant for example, can expel guests who are obnoxiously sharing extreme political opinions. now here is where my issue arises. take facebook for example. a social media site with billions of users. whether you agree with it or not, many people get their news from facebook. be it through news outlets posting articles on their pages, or groups sharing them, a very large number of people get their information about a plethora of topics from facebook. due to this fact, facebook has almost unprecedented power over what people can see. what can start off as extreme opinions that call for violence, ie something very clear cut and easy to determine, can slowly erode into something more grey and harder to define like 'no bigotry'. now i know this may seem like a slippery slope argument, but i am not saying it will necessarily turn into this, but simply highlighting that it is possible, and i don't think it should be. if facebook decided to update their policy to exclude things in a more vague way this could have far reaching impacts on the social sphere. there simply aren't any other platforms besides maybe twitter that can compete with facebook in terms of reaching a large audience. if you have an opinion or something you want to share, if you are barred from the widest used social media network, you are cut off from the largest way to share that idea. another perhaps more effective example would be if google skewed search results to favour a certain narrative. if searching something neutral like 'trump' in google brought up almost exclusively negative or positive articles, that would seriously impact how information was shared. google is perhaps the biggest example because they are not only a search engine, but the premier search engine for most people globally. i am aware that this would infringe upon the company's right to do what they want with their own property, but in the circumstances i think it is a reasonable concession.

that idea. another perhaps more effective example would be if google skewed search results to favour a certain narrative. if searching something neutral like 'trump' in google brought up almost exclusively negative or positive articles, that would seriously impact how information was shared. google is perhaps the biggest example because they are not only a search engine, but the premier concession.
auto_conc: i think it is possible for a company to censor what people can see.
gt: i absolutely disagree. no one is entitled to the servers, technical assistance, and high overhead required to deliver these 'platforms'. if someone violates a company's terms of service, then they have a right to kill their channel. these companies often host an individual's business model, such as a youtube channel, but so do television networks, which have always maintained their power to terminate any show at a whim. if i start a social media network with the intent of bringing people together and it begins to be used to undermine every one of my intentions, i shouldn't be forced to allow it to continue just because i'm 'big'.
masked_conc_attacks: i think the problem with your view is that it doesn't apply to any other social media site. it applies to all forms of media. for example, in the us, there is a ban on certain types of media because they are not allowed to use it. the only way to stop this is to make it illegal to use social media. this is not the case in other countries, but in the u. s. where there is no such restriction, it is the government that has the power to enforce it. if you are going to enforce this, you have to make sure that you don't infringe on the freedom of speech of others. if the government has a monopoly on speech, then you have the right to do what you want with your own property.
known_conc_attacks: i don't see how this is going to be any different from the government. the government has no power over what people can and can't do. it has no authority over what they can and cannot do.
auto_conc_attacks: the problem is that it's not possible for a company to censor what people can see. it's possible for companies to censor the content of their websites, but it's also possible for them to censor their own content.

conclusion: Your vote in the US presidential election should not be informed by the candidate's likelihood of winning (specifically as it applies to 3rd party candidates or write-ins)
premises: as an additional caveat, i should say that one of my biggest concerns in posting this is that i will simply encounter an echo chamber. my suspicion is that my views are likely held by most of reddit. but posting this is at least in part an attempt at catharsis: i've had these conversations in real life with so many people, and i inevitably run into what i perceive to be cognitive dissonance in the person i'm speaking with. there are at least a few nuances to the argument i'm putting forth that may strike at least somewhat of a nerve with the reddit community, so here goes. they strongly disliked trump, and justified their decision as 'voting for the lesser of two evils. ' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.

' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.
auto_conc: people who vote 'for the lesser of two evils' are irrational.
gt: this line of thinking is probably why we rarely see centrists win elections. you have to get through the gauntlet of the primaries first, which means being more insert party than the rest of the candidates. the problem is, now the vote is mostly split along party lines in the general election. say your side has two candidates in the primaries. let's say they're gop, it doesn't matter. candidate a falls about 90 on gop issues, while b is maybe 66 . you agree more with a, but b has a much better chance at getting center votes. however, you know the dems are pushing a 5 gop issue candidate, a hard left counterpart to your candidate a. you'd much rather have b than a dem, but you'd also rather have a than b. do you go for a hail mary vote, or a more certain win but compromise a little?
masked_conc_attacks: if you're voting for the lesser of two evils, then you're wasting your vote.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think wasting your vote is going to change the outcome of the election.
auto_conc_attacks: i don't think people who vote 'for the lesser of two evils' are irrational, but i do think that people who don't vote for the better of 2 evils are irrational.

conclusion: the US is sleepwalking into Fascism, and Trump is just the catalyst.
premises: am i the only one who is now fully convinced that the us is rapidly becoming fascist? i think there's considerable evidence that it is heading towards fascism. i literally saw an abc news story in a facebook post, and almost all of the comments are either foreigners decrying it, or american neo nazis blaming everything on george soros. it almost matches the weimar republic at this point the more i learn about either the weimar republic or modern us, the more they line up. i'm convinced that the country is one national crisis away from it being all over i really, really want people to change my view. i don't want to be right.

conclusion: humanity's ultimate goal should be to become a spacefaring civilization and we should invest more in it
premises: that's what we, and pretty much every other species, have evolved to do. there are many scenarios for humanity's extinction, most of them are based on the idea that we'll destroy earth ourselves, such as exploiting all of its resources, destroying its atmosphere or biosphere, global warming, etc. most of these scenarios can theoretically be avoided in the short term, but there's something which we can do absolutely nothing about. in a few billion years the sun will engulf earth and we'll have no other choice but to leave it, and that's assuming we'll survive long enough on earth for that to happen. so, my point is: either we leave earth or we face extinction, and if we want to eventually leave our planet we should start investing in space exploration right now since the future of our species depends on it.

auto_conc: I believe that humanity has no choice but to leave this planet,
gt: there's already billions of dollars allocated on organisations like nasa and spacex. the rest of the resources must go to somewhere else, there are other parts which not only are as important but affects what we do experience right now and of the future.
masked_conc_attacks: i think you're underestimating the potential for extinction. there are many scenarios for humanity's extinction, and most of them are based on the idea that we'll survive long enough on earth to face extinction.

conclusion: You should be able to report disability fraud anonymously
premises: the reason the government wants you to provide your information is because the burden of proof is on the accuser. if the accusation is not true, the accuser can be charged with making a false accusation. the government also claims that the person you accuse will not be notified who reported them. on the reason explanation, the burden of proof should not be on the accuser. under the current system, you are not allowed to report suspicious activity. if an accuser's neighbor receives disability for a bad back, and sees him doing yard work and playing golf, the accuser can not know 100 that he is committed fraud. however, the accuser can make a judgment that something does not seem right, and the accuser would like the government to take a look. this is not unreasonable. from the s. s website gt; typically you would have to know someone quite well in order to determine whether or not he or she is taking advantage of the system. if you know someone as well as s. s wants you to, the accuser would need to practically live with the accused. the burden of proof is too high, and the punishments for false accusations are too strong. on the latter, i cannot see why or how this is true. it may not be the procedure to release the information to the accused, but if it goes to court, it has to be part of the discovery. there will be the information of the accuser in the government files, and if the accused fought hard enough he will get it. however, if the accused really cannot know who accused them, why demand the information at all. the benefits of staying anonymous is obvious. someone sees someone committing fraud, reports it to the proper authorities, and goes about their lives with 0 concern. my current situation is i work with someone who's husband collects disability for disease. he is a drug user, in a motorcycle gang, and works an under the table job that pays him good money. the wife i work with makes over 80k per year. but if i am wrong, what happens to me? i face charges? will his wife find out via our workplace than the s. s office is charging me, than tell her 1 husband about? it is not worth my risks

conclusion: My roommate, who is away for a month, should still pay all flat rate bills for that month
premises: my bills are internet, gas, water, electric, and rent. i have two chief arguments for this. first, him being away does not affect these at all. if i were not living here too, then he would still have to pay all of these fees. by agreeing with these companies to have these services, he locked us into paying at least x per month in service fees. even if we decided that we no longer need water and stopped using it, we would still have to pay these fees for a year. therefore, him not using these services should have no bearing on whether or not he pays the service fees. this is assuming that we mutually agreed to these service, which we did. i would not use this argument if i had purchased cable tv that he did not want to begin with. second, these fees would have to be paid if i also left. for example, if i happened to plan a month long vacation at the same time, we would both be away and both not using these services. however, someone would have to pay the bills. by assuming his argument true, neither of us are responsible for the bills. yet, they must be paid by someone. therefore, using proof by contradiction, i must be correct.

gt: he should pay half of the rent and internet because they have to be paid every month and it doesn't matter if they are used or not. the rest are dependent on usage. they do cost to be shut off and turned back on at least where i am and have a base rate. for that reason he should pay 25 or 33 of the other bills. start with 33 and agree to 25. ultimately it's better than finding a new house mate.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think you are correct in assuming that you are not paying for these services. you are assuming that he is not using these services, which is not the case. i don't see how you can be wrong in assuming he is using the services. if he was not using them, you would have to pay for them. if you were not using those services, you wouldn't be paying for them, because you would still be paying them.

conclusion: Male and female heterosexuality are different
premises: based on the people i've talked to, and research i've read, i think heterosexual men tend to be exclusively attracted to women physically, while heterosexual women usually are physically attracted to people of both sexes despite only having romantic interest in men. as a hetero guy i find someone like younger brad pitt sexy but not to the point that i physically get turned on, more in the sense of admiration and mild envy. i get the idea that straight women often do get turned on thinking about other women, even if they wouldn't necessarily do sexual things with them. most straight men who watch porn find gay porn gross but many straight women prefer lesbian porn over straight porn because it often has less of a 'male gaze'. i think part of the reason why women have an in group bias towards other women that men lack with other men is because they are attracted to other women to some degree, albeit usually not to the extent they would want to have sex or relationships with them. some people would say that 'all women are bisexual' but i disagree; i think it would be better explained that men and women who are heterosexual experience their orientation differently. if you're turned on by someone of the same sex but not to the point that actual contact would be enjoyable i'd still consider that person straight. one thing that might counter my hypothesis is perhaps the male gaze is so prevalent in culture that many women end up viewing other women's bodies from a straight male perspective? i mean after all male bisexuality was prominent in certain circles of greek and roman culture, but is on the fringe of our own culture.

gt: i would argue only one point: it's not that they do or do not matter most of the time they do not it's that you won't know if your vote mattered until after you cast it. most of the time and for most of the american public, for any federal legislator position, your vote is lost in a sea of other votes, and didn't make a discernible difference as the election was heavily skewed to one or the other candidate. you may also live in a state that is heavily leaning in one direction or another, so your agreement or disagreement is basically just background noise. but there are occasions where the election is very close, and your single vote may be among thousands or even hundreds that put someone over the top. and it's not always clear when that will be. two recent examples of such votes were brexit, in which many supporters regretted their vote saying they were 'protest votes' and that they had no expectations it would pass. and the other is hillary vs. trump, where centrists, and liberals assumed hillary had the election locked up and stayed home, whereas the right wing was out in force. states that were blue turned purple, and states that were purple turned red. so yes, votes matter every once in a while, but you'll never know which once in a while until afterwards.

conclusion: The USA should bring back compulsory service
premises: all would be required to serve for some x amount of years. serving in the military should still be available as an option but other accommodations should be made for differing beliefs. if you feel alright about us foreign policy you can do x years in the military, but if you are opposed to it you could do x year serving as a policeman. if you're a pacifist you could do x years serving as an emt for some public hospital or x years in the peace corps. forcing people to serve together in this way would accomplish a couple things: 1 ensures that well trained citizenry is always nearby and ready in case of catastrophe. in a world with this type of service, if a terrorist attack were to occur: 1 4 of all people in the vicinity will be trained soldiers, 1 4 will be trained police, 1 to 2 4 will have some medical training. first responders would already be there because everybody would basically be a first responder. 2 provides young people with something to do. in my mind the service would occur in the 18 22 time frame so that it comes before college. i don't know about any of you but i was someone who went to college because that was just the thing to do. no one had gone before me and that was the route to success, so there i went. it worked for me the debt was real but i got solid job out of it but it doesn't work out for a lot of folks. not only that but asking an 18 year old to decide the institution and career that may define the rest of their lives and saddle them with a mountain of debt seems insane to me. who the fuck knows anything at 18? 3 increases national unity. soldiers peace corp should serve with others from across the country, while police emts should work in parts of the city different form where they live. doing this ensures that all americans are for at least some short time in their lives forced to reckon with their fellow countrymen. besides providing perspective this also helps foster a sense of egalitarianism since it will provide the sense that a citizenship has been 'earned. ' recognition of valid service provides a sort of floor of respectability, which is something that seems sorely lacking these days. 4 it is a project that is unachievable in the free market. while one can imagine how organizations such as the ymca given the proper incentives could establish a role in a society as a pre college and service like pillar, it comes with some tricky issues. a private institution training soldiers and policemen is a break in the government monopoly on violence which i think most people agree is necessary for a functional government . a private institution is accountable to whoever funds it, moral or no, while a public institution would at least by law be held accountable to the voters. and the idea of charging money for things that the peace corps does just seems wrong. so, cmv. tbh i've always been okay with the idea of a draft in it's most raw form but i figure this might make it more palatable for people who don't.

conclusion: The N-word is overly stigmatized and should be used freely in certain settings (such as academics)
premises: i'll preface this by saying: for those of you that don't know, the n word refers to 'nigger'. i'll simply refer to the term by 'nword' from here on out to avoid offending people. and although i may share this view on other euphemisms, i'll strictly be discussing the nword to keep the conversation scope narrow. when discussing the root origins of the word, people fear speaking it out loud. even i cringed when i typed out the nword in my first paragraph. stigmatizing the word gives it more power. that's like saying, 'hey! don't remind black people that they were once oppressed slaves! keep it on the hush hush. ' i believe the attitude should instead be more along the lines of, 'blacks should be proud of how empowered they've become despite societal oppression. so keep using it. we don't care because it only shows the leaps and bounds they've made in recent decades. ' we don't use 'the c word' for chink or 'the c word' for cracker. in fact, especially stigmatizing the nword over other racial slurs seems to send a message that other racial slurs are more ok when they should all be equally frowned upon in colloquial language.

' we don't use 'the c word' for chink or 'the c word' for cracker. in fact, especially stigmatizing the nword over other racial slurs seems to send a message that other racial slurs are more ok when they should all be equally frowned upon in colloquial language.
auto_conc: the n-word should not be stigmatized any more than other racial slurs.
gt: if you feel it 'should' be used freely in some cases, why do you self censor all but one time here? if you think it is the best option to self censor to avoid offending , why accuse everyone else of being wrong when they make the same decision you do?

auto_conc_attacks: the n word is a slur. it's used to refer to a group of people who were oppressed by the government. the word is used to describe black people. the n word also refers to black people who are enslaved by the state. it is used as a way of saying that black people are oppressed by their government, and that they should be proud of how empowered they've become despite societal oppression. the 'n word' is used by black people to say that they were once oppressed slaves, but that they are now oppressed by society. if you are using the word 'nigger' as a slur, then it should be stigmatized as well.

premises: am i an advocate for both of these things? god no. maybe they'd be mocked or slandered, who knows. south park did a very good episode highlighting this topic if anyone has seen it. i've had this opinion for a while now but decided to make this post after hearing about a video regarding it on the front page yesterday.

gt: i'm not really sure why you think you can say that it will never be taken seriously by 'society', unless you just mean in sitcoms or something. an ever increasing number of women are convicted of domestic violence will it be taken as seriously as domestic violence by men? probably not, because men are statistically stronger than women, and serious injuries and death among male victims are far lower than the reverse. but that doesn't mean that it's not taken seriously when it happens. will there be jokes about female perpetrators and or their male victims? sure. but surely you've encountered jokes about male perpetrators and female victims, have you not? what do you call a woman with 2 black eyes? a slow learner. i mean i really don't see a lot of evidence, for example, that lorena bobbit wasn't treated seriously by the legal system for cutting off her husband's penis, do you? the fact that there are jokes about the victim in this case doesn't change how seriously 'society', in the form of our elected government, took it.

conclusion: It is unethical to expose your child to video games.
premises: when parents purchase their children playstations, x box's, gaming pcs, etc, i see this is a serious moral failing. i hold this view because of the following intuitions: it decreases the child's attentiveness to school work. it can increase their propensity for violence. it can lead to the development of addictive personality. it decreases the possibility of the child focussing on other more worthwhile pursuits, such as human reading, going outside, learning, etc.
